
   
<EOS>
There
was
no
possibility
of
taking
a
walk
that
day
.
<EOS>
We
had
been
wandering
,
indeed
,
in
the
leafless
shrubbery
an
hour
in
the
morning
;
but
since
dinner
(
Mrs.
Reed
,
when
there
was
no
company
,
dined
early
)
<EOS>
the
cold
winter
wind
had
brought
with
it
clouds
so
sombre
,
and
a
rain
<EOS>
so
penetrating
,
that
further
out
-
door
exercise
was
now
out
of
the
question
.
  
<EOS>
I
was
glad
of
it
:
I
never
liked
long
walks
,
especially
on
chilly
afternoons
:
<EOS>
dreadful
to
me
was
the
coming
home
in
the
raw
twilight
,
with
nipped
fingers
and
toes
,
and
a
heart
saddened
by
the
chidings
of
Bessie
,
the
nurse
,
and
humbled
by
the
consciousness
of
my
physical
inferiority
to
Eliza
,
John
,
and
Georgiana
Reed
.
  
<EOS>
The
said
Eliza
,
John
,
and
Georgiana
were
now
clustered
<EOS>
round
their
mama
in
the
drawing
-
room
<EOS>
:
she
lay
reclined
on
a
sofa
by
the
fireside
,
and
with
her
darlings
about
her
(
for
the
time
neither
quarrelling
nor
crying
)
looked
perfectly
happy
.
<EOS>
Me
,
she
had
dispensed
from
joining
the
group
;
saying
,
"
She
regretted
to
be
under
the
necessity
of
keeping
me
at
a
distance
;
but
that
until
she
heard
from
Bessie
,
and
could
discover
by
her
own
observation
,
that
I
was
endeavouring
in
good
earnest
to
acquire
a
more
sociable
and
childlike
disposition
,
a
more
attractive
and
sprightly
manner
 
something
lighter
,
franker
,
more
natural
,
as
it
were
 
she
really
must
exclude
me
from
privileges
intended
only
for
contented
,
happy
,
little
children
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
What
does
Bessie
say
I
have
done
?
<EOS>
"
I
asked
.
  
<EOS>
"
Jane
,
I
do
n't
like
cavillers
or
questioners
;
besides
,
there
is
something
truly
forbidding
in
a
child
taking
up
her
elders
in
that
manner
.
<EOS>
Be
seated
somewhere
;
and
until
you
can
speak
pleasantly
,
remain
silent
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
A
breakfast
-
room
adjoined
the
drawing
-
room
,
I
slipped
in
there
.
<EOS>
It
contained
a
bookcase
:
I
soon
possessed
myself
of
a
volume
,
taking
care
that
it
should
be
one
stored
with
pictures
.
<EOS>
I
mounted
into
the
window-
seat
:
gathering
up
my
feet
<EOS>
,
I
sat
cross
-
legged
,
like
a
Turk
;
and
,
having
drawn
the
red
moreen
curtain
nearly
close
,
I
was
shrined
in
double
retirement
.
  
<EOS>
Folds
of
scarlet
drapery
shut
in
my
view
to
the
right
hand
;
to
the
left
were
the
clear
panes
of
glass
,
protecting
,
but
not
separating
me
from
the
drear
November
day
.
<EOS>
At
intervals
,
while
turning
over
the
leaves
of
my
book
,
I
studied
the
aspect
of
that
winter
afternoon
.
<EOS>
Afar
,
it
offered
a
pale
blank
of
mist
and
cloud
;
near
a
scene
of
wet
lawn
and
storm
-
beat
shrub
,
with
ceaseless
rain
sweeping
away
wildly
before
a
long
and
lamentable
blast
.
  
<EOS>
I
returned
to
my
book
 
Bewick
's
History
of
British
Birds
:
the
letterpress
thereof
I
cared
little
for
,
generally
speaking
;
and
yet
there
were
certain
introductory
pages
that
,
child
as
I
was
,
I
could
not
pass
quite
as
a
blank
.
<EOS>
They
were
those
which
treat
of
the
haunts
of
sea
-
fowl
;
of
"
the
solitary
rocks
and
promontories
"
by
them
only
inhabited
;
of
the
coast
of
Norway
,
studded
with
isles
from
its
southern
extremity
,
the
Lindeness
,
or
Naze
,
to
the
North
Cape
    
"
Where
the
Northern
Ocean
,
in
vast
whirls
,
Boils
round
the
naked
,
melancholy
isles
Of
farthest
Thule
;
and
the
Atlantic
surge
Pours
in
among
the
stormy
Hebrides
.
"
  
<EOS>
Nor
could
I
pass
unnoticed
the
suggestion
of
the
bleak
shores
of
Lapland
,
Siberia
,
Spitzbergen
,
Nova
Zembla
,
Iceland
,
Greenland
,
with
"
the
vast
sweep
of
the
Arctic
Zone
,
and
those
forlorn
regions
of
dreary
space
,
 
that
reservoir
of
frost
and
snow
,
where
firm
fields
of
ice
,
the
accumulation
of
centuries
of
winters
,
glazed
in
Alpine
heights
above
heights
,
surround
the
pole
,
and
concentre
the
multiplied
rigours
of
extreme
cold
.
<EOS>
"
Of
these
death
-
white
realms
I
formed
an
idea
of
my
own
:
shadowy
,
like
all
the
half
-
comprehended
notions
that
float
dim
through
children
's
brains
,
but
strangely
impressive
.
<EOS>
The
words
in
these
introductory
pages
connected
themselves
with
the
succeeding
vignettes
,
and
gave
significance
to
the
rock
standing
up
alone
in
a
sea
of
billow
and
spray
;
to
the
broken
boat
stranded
on
a
desolate
coast
;
to
the
cold
and
ghastly
moon
glancing
through
bars
of
cloud
at
a
wreck
just
sinking
.
  
<EOS>
I
can
not
tell
what
sentiment
haunted
the
quite
solitary
churchyard
,
with
its
inscribed
headstone
;
its
gate
,
its
two
trees
,
its
low
horizon
,
girdled
by
a
broken
wall
,
and
its
newly
-
risen
crescent
,
attesting
the
hour
of
eventide
.
  
<EOS>
The
two
ships
becalmed
on
a
torpid
sea
,
I
believed
to
be
marine
phantoms
.
  
<EOS>
The
fiend
pinning
down
the
thief
's
pack
behind
him
<EOS>
,
I
passed
over
quickly
:
it
was
an
object
of
terror
.
  
<EOS>
So
was
the
black
horned
thing
seated
aloof
on
a
rock
,
surveying
a
distant
crowd
surrounding
a
gallows
.
  
<EOS>
Each
picture
told
a
story
;
mysterious
often
to
my
undeveloped
understanding
and
imperfect
feelings
,
yet
ever
profoundly
interesting
:
as
interesting
as
the
tales
<EOS>
Bessie
sometimes
narrated
on
winter
evenings
,
when
she
chanced
to
be
in
good
humour
;
and
when
,
having
brought
her
ironing
-
table
to
the
nursery
hearth
,
she
allowed
us
to
sit
about
it
,
and
while
she
got
up
Mrs.
Reed
's
lace
frills
,
and
crimped
her
nightcap
borders
,
fed
our
eager
attention
with
passages
of
love
and
adventure
taken
from
old
fairy
tales
and
other
ballads
;
or
(
as
at
a
later
period
I
discovered
)
from
the
pages
of
Pamela
,
and
Henry
,
Earl
of
Moreland
.
  
<EOS>
With
Bewick
on
my
knee
,
I
was
then
happy
:
happy
at
least
in
my
way
.
<EOS>
I
feared
nothing
but
interruption
,
and
that
came
too
soon
.
<EOS>
The
breakfast-
room
door
opened
.
  
<EOS>
"
Boh
!
Madam
Mope
!
"
cried
the
voice
of
John
Reed
;
then
he
paused
:
he
found
the
room
apparently
empty
.
  
<EOS>
"
Where
the
dickens
is
she
!
"
<EOS>
he
continued
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Lizzy
!
<EOS>
Georgy
!
<EOS>
(
calling
to
his
sisters
)
<EOS>
Joan
is
not
here
:
tell
mama
she
is
run
out
into
the
rain
 
<EOS>
bad
animal
!
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
It
is
well
<EOS>
I
drew
the
curtain
,
"
thought
I
;
and
I
wished
fervently
he
might
not
discover
my
hiding
-
place
:
nor
would
John
Reed
have
found
it
out
himself
;
he
was
not
quick
either
of
vision
or
conception
;
but
Eliza
just
put
her
head
in
at
the
door
,
and
said
at
once
    
"
<EOS>
She
is
in
the
window
-
seat
,
to
be
sure
,
Jack
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
And
I
came
out
immediately
,
for
I
trembled
at
the
idea
of
being
dragged
forth
by
the
said
Jack
.
  
<EOS>
"
What
do
you
want
?
<EOS>
"
I
asked
,
with
awkward
diffidence
.
  
<EOS>
"
Say
,
"
What
do
you
want
,
Master
Reed
?
"
<EOS>
"
was
the
answer
.
<EOS>
"
I
want
you
to
come
here
;
"
and
seating
himself
in
an
arm

chair
,
he
intimated
by
a

that
I
was
to
approach
and
stand
before
him
.
  
<EOS>
John
Reed
was
a
schoolboy
of
fourteen
years
old
;
four
years
older
than
I
,
for
I
was
but
ten
:
large
and
stout
for
his
age
,
with
a
dingy
and
unwholesome
skin
;
thick
lineaments
in
a
spacious
visage
,
heavy
limbs
and
large
extremities
.
<EOS>
He
gorged
himself
habitually
at
table
,
which
made
him
bilious
,
and
gave
him
a
dim
and
bleared
eye
and
flabby
cheeks
.
<EOS>
He
ought
now
to
have
been
at
school
;
but
his
mama
had
taken
him
home
for
a
month
or
two
,
"
on
account
of
his
delicate
health
.
"
<EOS>
Mr.
Miles
,
the
master
,
affirmed
that
he
would
do
very
well
if
he
had
fewer
cakes
and
sweetmeats
sent
him
from
home
;
but
the
mother
's
heart
turned
from
an
opinion
so
harsh
,
and
inclined
rather
to
the
more
refined
idea
that
John
's
sallowness
was
owing
to
over
-
application
and
,
perhaps
,
to
pining
after
home
.
  
<EOS>
John
had
not
much
affection
for
his
mother
and
sisters
,
and
an
antipathy
to
me
.
<EOS>
He
bullied
and
punished
me
;
not
two
or
three
times
in
the
week
,
nor
once
or
twice
in
the
day
,
but
continually
:
every
nerve
I
had
feared
him
,
and
every
morsel
of
flesh
in
my
bones
shrank
when
he
came
near
.
<EOS>
There
were
moments
when
I
was
bewildered
by
the
terror
he
inspired
,
because
I
had
no
appeal
<EOS>
whatever
against
either
his
menaces
or
his
inflictions
;
the
servants
did
not
like
to
offend
their
young
master
by
taking
my
part
against
him
,
and
Mrs.
Reed
was
blind
and
deaf
on
the
subject
:
she
never
saw
him
strike
or
heard
him
abuse
me
,
though
he
did
both
now
and
then
in
her
very
presence
,
more
frequently
,
however
,
behind
her
back
.
  
<EOS>
Habitually
obedient
to
John
,
I
came
up
to
his
chair
:
he
spent
some
three
minutes
in
thrusting
out
his
tongue
at
me
as
far
as
he
could
without
damaging
the
roots
:
<EOS>
I
knew
he
would
soon
strike
,
and
while
dreading
the
blow
,
I
mused
on
the
disgusting
and
ugly
appearance
of
him
who
would
presently
deal
it
.
<EOS>
I
wonder
if
he
read
that
notion
in
my
face
;
for
,
all
at
once
,
without
speaking
,
he
struck
suddenly
and
strongly
.
<EOS>
I
tottered
,
and
on
regaining
my
equilibrium
retired
back
a
step
or
two
from
his
chair
.
  
<EOS>
"
That
is
for
your
impudence
in
answering
mama
awhile
since
,
"
said
he
,
"
and
for
your
sneaking
way
of
getting
behind
curtains
,
and
for
the
look
you
had
in
your
eyes
two
minutes
since
,
you
rat
!
"
  
<EOS>
Accustomed
to
John
Reed
's
abuse
,
I
never
had
an
idea
of
replying
to
it
;
my
care
was
how
to
endure
the
blow
which
would
certainly
follow
the
insult
.
  
<EOS>
"
What
were
you
doing
behind
the
curtain
?
"
<EOS>
he
asked
.
  
<EOS>
"
I
was
reading
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Show
the
book
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
I
returned
to
the
window
and
fetched
it
thence
.
  
<EOS>
"
You
have
no
business
to
take
our
books
;
you
are
a
dependent
<EOS>
,
mama
says
;
you
have
no
money
;
your
father
left
you
none
;
you
ought
to
beg
,
and
not
to
live
here
with
gentlemen
's
children
like
us
,
and
eat
the
same
meals
we
do
,
and
wear
clothes
at
our
mama
's
expense
.
<EOS>
Now
,
I
'll
teach
you
to
rummage
my
bookshelves
:
for
they
_
are
_
mine
;
all
the
house
belongs
to
me
,
or
will
do
in
a
few
years
.
<EOS>
Go
and
stand
by
the
door
,
out
of
the
way
of
the
mirror
and
the
windows
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
I
did
so
,
not
at
first
aware
what
was
his
intention
;
but
when
I
saw
him
lift
and
poise
the
book
and
stand
in
act
to
hurl
it
,
I
instinctively
started
aside
with
a
cry
of
alarm
:
not
soon
enough
,
however
;
the
volume
was
flung
,
it
hit
me
,
and
I
fell
,
striking
my
head
against
the
door
and
cutting
it
.
<EOS>
The
cut
bled
,
the
pain
was
sharp
:
my
terror
had
passed
its
climax
;
other
feelings
succeeded
.
  
<EOS>
"
Wicked
and
cruel
boy
!
<EOS>
"
I
said
.
<EOS>
"
You
are
like
a
murderer
 
<EOS>
you
are
like
a
slave
-
driver
 
<EOS>
you
are
like
the
Roman
emperors
!
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
I
had
read
Goldsmith
's
History
of
Rome
,
and
had
formed
my
opinion
of
Nero
,
Caligula
,
etc
.
<EOS>
Also
I
had
drawn
parallels
in
silence
,
which
I
never
thought
thus
to
have
declared
aloud
.
  
<EOS>
"
What
!
<EOS>
what
!
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
he
cried
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Did
she
say
that
to
me
?
<EOS>
Did
you
hear
her
,
Eliza
and
Georgiana
?
<EOS>
Wo
n't
I
tell
mama
?
<EOS>
but
first
 
"
  
He
ran
headlong
at
me
:
I
felt
him
grasp
my
hair
and
my
shoulder
:
he
had
closed
with
a
desperate
thing
.
<EOS>
I
really
saw
in
him
a
tyrant
,
a
murderer
.
<EOS>
I
felt
a
drop
or
two
of
blood
from
my
head
trickle
down
my
neck
,
and
was
sensible
of
somewhat

:
these
sensations
for
the
time
predominated
over
fear
,
and
I
received
him
in
frantic
sort
.
<EOS>
I
do
n't
very
well
know
what
I
did
with
my
hands
,
but
he
called
me
"
Rat
!
Rat
!
"
and
bellowed
out
aloud
.
<EOS>
Aid
was
near
him
:
<EOS>
Eliza
and
Georgiana
had
run
for
Mrs.
Reed
,
who
was
gone
upstairs
:
she
now
came
upon
the
scene
,
followed
by
Bessie
and
her
maid
Abbot
.
<EOS>
We
were
parted
:
I
heard
the
words
    
"
Dear
!
<EOS>
dear
!
<EOS>
What
a
fury
to
fly
at
Master
John
!
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Did
ever
anybody
see
such

picture
of
passion
!
"
  
<EOS>
Then
Mrs.
Reed
subjoined
    
<EOS>
"
Take
her
away
to
the
red
-
room
,
and
lock
her
in
there
.
"
<EOS>
Four

were
immediately

,
and
I
was

.
    
<EOS>
I
resisted
all

:
a
new

for

,
and
a

greatly

the
bad
opinion
Bessie

Miss

were

entertain
of

.
<EOS>
The

,
I
was
a

;
or
rather
_
out
<EOS>
_
of

,

:
I

moment

already

,

,

<EOS>
,

.
  
<EOS>
"
Hold

,

<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
For

!
<EOS>
for

!
"

.
<EOS>
"
What

,
Miss
Eyre
,

,

's

!
<EOS>
Your

.
<EOS>
"
  
"
Master
!
<EOS>
How

?
<EOS>
Am

?
"
  
<EOS>
"
No
;

,

.
<EOS>
There

.
"
  
<EOS>
They

Reed
,
and
had

<EOS>
my

.
  
<EOS>
"
If

,

"

.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Miss

;

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
Miss

.
<EOS>
This

,

.
  
<EOS>
"
Do

,
"
I

"

"
  
<EOS>
In

,

.
  
<EOS>
"
Mind

,
"

.
  
<EOS>
"
She

,
"
<EOS>

<EOS>
"
But

"

.
<EOS>
"
I

.
<EOS>
She

thing
<EOS>
:

<EOS>

<EOS>
ere

<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
I

:
<EOS>

<EOS>
This

<EOS>

<EOS>

.
<EOS>

<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
They

,

,

.
  
<EOS>
The
red
-
room
was
a
square
chamber
,
very
seldom
slept
in
<EOS>
,
I
might
say
never
,
indeed
,
unless
when
a
chance
influx
of

at
Gateshead

:
yet

was
one

.
<EOS>
A

supported
on

,

deep

,
stood

like

;
the

,
with

always

,
were
half

in
festoons
and

of
similar

;
the

was
red
;
the

at
the

was

;
the

were
a
soft

with
a
blush

in

;
the
wardrobe
,
the
toilet

table
,
the
chairs
were
of
darkly

old
mahogany
.
<EOS>
Out
of
these
deep
surrounding
shades
rose
high
,
and
glared
white
,
the
piled-
up
mattresses
and

of
the
bed
,
spread
with
a
snowy
Marseilles
counterpane
.
<EOS>
Scarcely
less

was
an
ample

easy
-
chair
near

the
bed
,
also
white
,
with
a
footstool
before

;
and
looking
,
as
I
thought
,
like
a
pale

.
  
<EOS>
This
room
was
chill
,
because
it
seldom
had
a
fire
;
it
was
silent
,
because
remote
from
the
nursery
and
kitchen
<EOS>
;
solemn
,
because
it
was
known
to
be
so
seldom

.
<EOS>
The
house
-
maid
alone
came
here
on
Saturdays
,
to

the

a
week
's
quiet

:
and

herself
,

,

,

,
her

,

of

;
and

lies
the
secret
of
the
red
-
room
 
the
spell
which
kept

so

.
  
<EOS>
Mr.
Reed
had
been
dead
nine
years
<EOS>
:
it
was
in
this

he
breathed

last
;
here

lay
in
state
;
hence
his

was
borne
by
the
undertaker
's

;
and
,

that

,
a
sense
of
dreary

had
guarded

.
  
<EOS>
My

,
to

Bessie

bitter
Miss

had

,
was

low

near
the
marble

;

;

,

;

;

.
<EOS>
I
was
not

whether
they
had
locked
the
door
;
and
when
I
dared

,
I
got

and
went
to
see
.
<EOS>
Alas
!
<EOS>
yes
:
no
jail
was
ever
more
secure
.
<EOS>
Returning
,
I
had
to
cross
before
the
looking-
glass
;
my
fascinated

involuntarily
explored

depth
it
revealed
.
<EOS>
All
looked
colder
and
darker
in
that
visionary

than
in

:
and
the
strange
little
figure
there
gazing

,
with

,

moving
where
all

,
had
the

:
I
thought

like
one

,

,
Bessie
's

represented
as

,
ferny

,
and
appearing
before
the
eyes
of
belated
travellers
.
<EOS>
I
returned
to
my
stool
.
  
<EOS>
Superstition
was
with
me
at
that
moment
;
but
it
was
not
yet
her
hour
for
complete

:
my
blood
was
still
warm
;
the

of
the
revolted
slave
was
still

with

bitter

;
I
had
to
stem
a
rapid

of

before
I
quailed
to
the
dismal
present
.
  
<EOS>
All
John
Reed
's
violent
tyrannies
,
all
his
sisters
'
proud
indifference
,
all
his
mother
's

,
all
the
servants
'

,
turned
up
in
my
disturbed

like
a
dark
deposit
in
a
turbid
well
.
<EOS>
Why
was
I
always
suffering
,
always
browbeaten
,
always
accused
,
for
ever
condemned
?
<EOS>
Why
could
I
never
please
?
<EOS>
Why
was
it
useless
to
try
to
win
any
one
's
favour
?
<EOS>
Eliza
,
who
was
headstrong
and
selfish
,
was
respected
.
<EOS>
Georgiana
,
who
had
a
spoiled
temper
,
a
very
acrid
spite
,
a
captious
and
insolent
carriage
,
was
universally
indulged
.
<EOS>
Her
beauty
,
her
pink
cheeks
and
golden
curls
,
seemed
to
give
delight
to
all
who
looked
at
her
,
and
to
purchase
indemnity
for
every
fault
.
<EOS>
John
no
one
thwarted
,
much
less
punished
;
though
he
twisted
the
necks
of
the
pigeons
,
killed
the
little
pea
-
chicks
,
set
the
dogs
at
the
sheep
,
stripped
the
hothouse
vines
of
their
fruit
,
and
broke
the
buds
off
the
choicest
plants
in
the
conservatory
:
he
called
his
mother
"
old
girl
,
"
too
;
sometimes
reviled
her
for
her
dark
skin
,
similar
to
his
own
;
bluntly
disregarded
her
wishes
;
not
unfrequently
tore
and
spoiled
her
silk
attire
;
and
he
was
still
"
her
own
darling
.
<EOS>
"
I
dared
commit
no
fault
:
I
strove
to
fulfil
every
duty
;
and
I
was
termed
naughty
and
tiresome
,
sullen
and
sneaking
,
from
morning
to
noon
,
and
from
noon
to
night
.
  
<EOS>
My
head
still
ached
and
bled
with
the
blow
and
fall
<EOS>
I
had
received
:
no
one
had
reproved
John
for
wantonly
striking
me
;
and
because
I
had
turned
against
him
to
avert
farther
irrational
violence
,
I
was
loaded
with
general
opprobrium
.
  
<EOS>
"
Unjust
!
 
<EOS>
unjust
!
"
said
my
reason
,
forced
by
the
agonising
stimulus
into
precocious
though
transitory
power
:
and
Resolve
,
equally
wrought
up
,
instigated
some
strange
expedient
to
achieve
escape
from
insupportable
oppression
 
as
running
away
,
or
,
if
that
could
not
be
effected
,
never
eating
or
drinking
more
,
and
letting
myself
die
.
  
<EOS>
What
a
consternation
of
soul
was
mine
that
dreary
afternoon
!
<EOS>
How
all
my
brain
was
in
tumult
,
and
all
my
heart
in
insurrection
!
<EOS>
Yet
in
what
darkness
,
what
dense
ignorance
,
was
the
mental
battle
fought
!
<EOS>
I
could
not
answer
the
ceaseless
inward
question
 
_
<EOS>
why
_
I
thus
suffered
;
now
,
at
the
distance
of
 
I
will
not
say
how
many
years
,
I
see
it
clearly
.
  
<EOS>
I
was
a
discord
in
Gateshead
Hall
<EOS>
:
I
was
like
nobody
there
;
I
had
nothing
in
harmony
with
Mrs.
Reed
or
her
children
,
or
her
chosen
vassalage
.
<EOS>
If
they
did
not
love
me
,
in
fact
,
as
little
did
I
love
them
.
<EOS>
They
were
not
bound
to
regard
with
affection
a
thing
that
could
not
sympathise
with
one
amongst
them
;
a
heterogeneous
thing
,
opposed
to
them
in
temperament
,
in
capacity
,
in
propensities
;
a
useless
thing
,
incapable
of
serving
their
interest
,
or
adding
to
their
pleasure
;
a
noxious
thing
,
cherishing
the
germs
of
indignation
at
their
treatment
,
of
contempt
of
their
judgment
.
<EOS>
I
know
that
had
I
been
a
sanguine
,
brilliant
,
careless
,
exacting
,
handsome
,
romping
child
 
though
equally
dependent
and
friendless
 
<EOS>
Mrs.
Reed
would
have
endured
my
presence
more
complacently
;
her
children
would
have
entertained
for
me
more
of
the
cordiality
of
fellow
-
feeling
;
the
servants
would
have
been
less
prone
to
make
me
the
scapegoat
of
the
nursery
.
  
<EOS>
Daylight
began
to
forsake
the
red
-
room
;
it
was
past
four
o'clock
,
and
the
beclouded
afternoon
was
tending
to
drear
twilight
.
<EOS>
I
heard
the
rain
still
beating
continuously
on
the
staircase
window
,
and
the
wind
howling
in
the
grove
behind
the
hall
;
I
grew
by
degrees
cold
as
a
stone
,
and
then
my
courage
sank
.
<EOS>
My
habitual
mood
of
humiliation
,
self
-
doubt
,
forlorn
depression
,
fell
damp
on
the
embers
of
my
decaying
ire
.
<EOS>
All
said
I
was
wicked
,
and
perhaps
I
might
be
so
;
what
thought
had
I
been
but
just
conceiving
of
starving
myself
to
death
?
<EOS>
That
certainly
was
a
crime
:
and
was
I
fit
to
die
?
<EOS>
Or
was
the
vault
under
the
chancel
of
Gateshead
Church
an
inviting
bourne
?
<EOS>
In
such
vault
I
had
been
told
did
Mr.
Reed
lie
buried
;
and
led
by
this
thought
to
recall
his
idea
,
I
dwelt
on
it
with

dread
.
<EOS>
I
could
not
remember
him
;
but
I
knew
that
he
was
my
own
uncle
 
<EOS>
my
mother
's
brother
 
<EOS>
that
he
had
taken
me
when
a
parentless
infant
to
his

;
and
that

his

had
required
a

of
Mrs.
Reed
that
she
would
rear
and

.
<EOS>
Mrs.
Reed
probably
considered
she
had

;
and
so
she
had
<EOS>
,
I
dare

,

;
but
how

really
like

not
of
her

,
and

with
her
,

her

's

,
by
any

?
<EOS>
It

most

,

.
  
<EOS>
A
singular
notion
dawned
upon

.
<EOS>
I
doubted
not
 
never
doubted
 
that
if
Mr.
Reed
had
been

he
would

treated

;
and
now
,
as

sat

the
white

occasionally

<EOS>
I
began

recall
what

,

in

by
the
violation

,

;
and

Mr.
Reed
's
spirit
,

of
his

's
child
,
might
quit

abode
 
whether

the

the
departed
 
and
rise
before

.
<EOS>
I
wiped

,

of
violent

might

to

,
or

from
the

<EOS>
some

,

.
<EOS>
This

,

,
I
felt
would

:
with

<EOS>
I

to

.
<EOS>
Shaking

,

and

<EOS>
Was

,

?
<EOS>
No
;

,

;

<EOS>
I

:
<EOS>

<EOS>

;

,

.
  
<EOS>
"

,

?
"

.
  
<EOS>
"

!
<EOS>

!
"

.
  
<EOS>
"

!
<EOS>
Let

!
"

.
  
<EOS>
"
What

?
<EOS>
Are

?
<EOS>
Have

something
?
"

.
  
<EOS>
"
<EOS>

!
<EOS>
I

,

.
<EOS>
"
I

,

.
  
<EOS>
"
She

"

<EOS>

<EOS>

I

"

<EOS>
"

"

"
  
"

<EOS>

:
"

<EOS>

"

<EOS>

<EOS>

.
  
<EOS>
No

<EOS>
Yes
,

,

,

,

:

,

.
  
<EOS>
Next

,

,

was

,

.
<EOS>
I

:

:

;

<EOS>
Yet

,

,

.
<EOS>
Abbot
,

,
was
sewing
in
another

,

Bessie
,
as

,

,
<EOS>
addressed

every

<EOS>

.
<EOS>
This

,

;
but
,

,

now

such

that
no

could

,
and
no

excite

agreeably
.
  
<EOS>
Bessie
had

down

,
and

a

on

,
whose

,

,
had
been
wo

to
stir
in

a
most

;
and
<EOS>
which
plate
I
had
often

,
but

of
such
a
privilege
.
<EOS>
This
precious
vessel
was
now
placed
on
my
knee
,
and
I
was
cordially
invited
to
eat
the
circlet
of
delicate
pastry
upon
it
.
<EOS>
Vain
favour
!
<EOS>
coming
,
like
most
other
favours
long
deferred
and
often
wished
for
,
too
late
!
<EOS>
I
could
not
eat
the
tart
;
and
the
plumage
of
the
bird
,
the
tints
of
the
flowers
,
seemed
strangely
faded
:
I
put
both
plate
and
tart
away
.
<EOS>
Bessie
asked
if
I
would
have
a
book
:
<EOS>
the
word
_
book
_
acted
as
a
transient
stimulus
,
and
I
begged
her
to
fetch
Gulliver
's
Travels
from
the
library
.
<EOS>
This
book
I
had
again
and
again
perused
with
delight
.
<EOS>
I
considered
it
a
narrative
of
facts
,
and
discovered
in
it
a
vein
of
interest
deeper
than
what
I
found
in
fairy

:
<EOS>
for
as
to
the
elves
,
having
sought
them
in
vain
among
foxglove

and
bells
,
under
mushrooms
and
beneath
the
ground
-
ivy
mantling
old
wall
-
nooks
,
I
had
at
length
made
up
my
mind
to
the
sad
truth
,
that
they
were
all
gone
out
of
England
to
some
savage
country
where
the
woods
were
wilder
and
thicker
,
and
the
population
more
scant
;
whereas
,
Lilliput
and
Brobdignag
being
,
in
my
creed
,
solid
parts
of
the
earth
's
surface
,
I
doubted
not
that
I
might
one
day
,
by
taking
a
long
voyage
,
see
with
my
own

the
little
fields
,
houses
,
and
trees
,
the
diminutive
people
,
the
tiny
cows
,
sheep
,
and
birds
of
the
one
realm
;
and
the
corn
-
fields
forest
-
high
,
the
mighty
mastiffs
,
the
monster
cats
,
the
tower
-
like
men
and
women
,
of
the
other
.
<EOS>
Yet
,
when
this
cherished
volume
was
now
placed
in
my
hand
 
when
I
turned
over
its
leaves
,
and
sought
in
its
marvellous
pictures
the
charm
I
had
,
till
now
,
never
failed
to
find
 
all
was
eerie
and
dreary
;
the
giants
were
gaunt
goblins
,
the
pigmies
malevolent
and
fearful
imps
,
Gulliver
a
most
desolate
wanderer
in
most
dread
and
dangerous
regions
.
<EOS>
I
closed
the
book
,
which
I
dared
no
longer
peruse
,
and
put
it
on
the
table
,
beside
the
untasted
tart
.
  
<EOS>
Bessie
had
now
finished
dusting
and
tidying
the
room
,
and
having
washed
her
hands
,
she
opened
a
certain
little
drawer
,
full
of
splendid
shreds
of
silk
and

,
and
began
making
a
new
bonnet
for
Georgiana
's
doll
.
<EOS>
Meantime
she
sang
:
<EOS>
her
song
was
    
"
<EOS>
In
the
days
when
we
went
gipsying
,
A
long
time
ago
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
I
had
often
heard
the
song
before
,
and
always
with
lively

;
for
Bessie
had
a
sweet
voice
,
 
at
least
,
I
thought

.
<EOS>
But
now
,
though
her
voice
was
still

,

found

.
<EOS>
Sometimes
,
preoccupied

,
she

the

,

;
"
A
long

ago
"
came
out
like
the

.
<EOS>
She
passed
into
another

,
this
time
a
really
doleful

.
  
<EOS>
"
My
feet
they
are
sore
,
and
my
limbs
they
are
weary
;
Long
is
the
way
,
and
the
mountains
are
wild
;
Soon
will
the
twilight
close
moonless
and
dreary
Over
the
path
of
the
poor
orphan
child
.
  
<EOS>
Why
did
they
send
me
so
far
and
so

,
Up
where
the
moors
spread
and
grey

?
<EOS>
Men
are
hard

,
and
kind
angels
<EOS>
only
Watch
o'er
the
steps
of
a
poor
orphan
child
.
  
<EOS>
Yet
distant

night

is

,
Clouds
there
are
none
,
and
clear

beam

,
<EOS>
God
,
in
His

,
protection
is
showing
,
Comfort

the

child
.
  
<EOS>
Ev'n
<EOS>
should

fall
o'er

,
Or

,
by

<EOS>
,
Still

,

,
Take

the

.
  
<EOS>
There

that
for

avail

,
Though
both
of
shelter
and
kindred
despoiled
;
Heaven
is
a
home
,
and
a
rest
will
not

me
;
God
is
a

to
the
poor
orphan

.
<EOS>
"
  
"
Come
,
Miss
Jane
,
do

,
"
said
Bessie
as

finished
.
<EOS>
She
might

,
"
do

burn
!
"
<EOS>
but
how

divine

morbid

to
which
I
was
a
prey
?
<EOS>
In
the
course

morning
Mr.
Lloyd
came
again
.
  
<EOS>
"
What
,
already
up
!
"
said

,
as
he

the

.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Well
,
nurse
,
how
is
she
?
"
  
<EOS>
Bessie
answered
that
I
was
doing
very

.
  
<EOS>
"
Then
she
ought
to
look

.
<EOS>
Come
here
,
Miss
Jane
:
<EOS>
your
name

Jane
,

?
"
  
<EOS>
"
Yes
,

,
Jane
Eyre
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Well
,
you
have
been
crying
,
Miss
Jane
Eyre
;
can
you
tell
me
what
about
?
<EOS>
Have
you
any
pain
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
No
,
sir
.
"
  
<EOS>
"
Oh
!
<EOS>
I
daresay
she
is
crying
because
she
could
not
go
out
with
Missis
in
the
carriage
,
"
interposed

.
  
<EOS>
"
Surely
not
!
<EOS>
why
,
she
is
too
old
for
such
pettishness
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
I
thought
so

;
and
my
self
-
esteem
being
wounded
by

false

,
I
answered

,
"
I
never
cried
for
such

in

life
:
I
hate

out
in
the

.
<EOS>
I
cry
because
I
am
miserable
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Oh
fie
,
Miss
!
"
said
Bessie
.
  
<EOS>
The
good
apothecary
appeared
a

.
<EOS>
I
was
standing
before

;
he
fixed
his

very

:
his

were
small

;
not

,
but
I
dare

should

shrewd
now
:
he
had
a
hard
-
featured
yet
good

.
<EOS>
Having

at

,

said
    
"
What
made
you
ill
yesterday
?
<EOS>
"
  
"
She
had
a
fall
,
"
said
Bessie
,
again

in

.
  
<EOS>
"
Fall
!
<EOS>
why
,
that
is
like

again
!
<EOS>
Ca
n't

manage
to
walk
at

?
<EOS>
She
must

eight

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
was
knocked
down
,
"
was

,

by

;
"
but
that

not

ill
,
"
I

;
while
Mr.
Lloyd

to

.
  
<EOS>
As

the
box
to

,

for
the
servants
'

;
he
knew

.
<EOS>
"
That
's
for
you
,
nurse
,
"
said

;
"
you
can

down
;
I
'll

Miss
Jane
a

till

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
Bessie
would
rather

,
but
she
was
obliged

,
because
punctuality
at
meals
was
rigidly

at
Gateshead
Hall
.
  
<EOS>
"
The
fall
did
not
make

ill
;
what

,

?
<EOS>
"

Lloyd
when

.
  
<EOS>
"
I
was
shut

in
a
room
where
there
is
a
ghost
till

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
I
saw
Mr.
Lloyd
smile
and

at

.
  
<EOS>
"
Ghost
!
<EOS>
What
,
you
are

!
<EOS>
You
are

?
<EOS>
"
  
"
Of
Mr.
Reed
's

I
am
:
he
died

,
and
was

.
<EOS>
Neither
Bessie

will

,
if

;

,
 
so
cruel
that
I
think
I
shall
never

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Nonsense
!
<EOS>
And

that

so

?
<EOS>
Are
you
afraid
now
in

?
"
  
<EOS>
"
No
:
<EOS>
but
night
will
come
again
before
long
:
and

,
 
I
am
unhappy
,
 
very

,
for
other

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
What
other
things
?
<EOS>
Can

?
"
  
<EOS>
How

I
wished
to
reply
fully
to
this

!
<EOS>
How
difficult

was
to
frame

!
<EOS>
Children
can
feel
,
but
they
can
not
analyse
their

;
and
if
the

is
partially
effected
in

,
they
know
not

result

.
<EOS>
Fearful
,

,

,
I
,

,

,
though
,
as
far

,
true

.
  
<EOS>
"
For
one
thing
,
I
have
no
father
or
mother
,
brothers
or
sisters
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
You
have
a
kind
aunt
and
cousins
.
"
  
<EOS>
Again
I
paused
;
then
bunglingly
enounced
    
"
<EOS>
But
John
Reed
knocked
me
down
,
and
my
aunt
shut
me
up
in
the
red
-
room
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
Mr.
Lloyd
a

produced

.
  
<EOS>
"
Do
n't
you
think
Gateshead
Hall
a

?
"

.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Are

not
very

?
"
  
<EOS>
"
It
is

,

;
and
Abbot

I
have
less

to

here
than

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Pooh
!
<EOS>
you
ca

?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
If

,

;
but
I
can

Gateshead
till

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Perhaps
you
may
 
who

?
<EOS>
Have

Mrs.
Reed
?
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
think

,

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
None

?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
do
n't
know
.
<EOS>
I
asked
Aunt
Reed
once
,
and
<EOS>
she
said
possibly
I
might
have
some
poor
,
low
relations
called
Eyre
,
but
she
knew
nothing
about
them
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
If
you
had
such
,
would
you
like
to
go
to
them
?
"
  
<EOS>
I
reflected
.
<EOS>
Poverty
looks
grim
to
grown
people
;
still
more
so
to
children
:
they
have
not
much
idea
of
industrious
,
working
,
respectable

;
they
think
of
the
word
only
as
connected
with
ragged

,

,
fireless
grates
,
rude

,
and
debasing

:
poverty
for
me
was
synonymous
with
degradation
.
  
<EOS>
"
No
;
I
should
not
like
to
belong
to
poor
people
,
"
was
my
reply
.
  
<EOS>
"
Not
even
if
they
were
kind
to

?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
I
shook
my
head
:
<EOS>
I
could
not
see
how
poor
people
had
the
means
of
being
kind
;
and
then
to
learn
to
speak
like
them
,
to
adopt
their
manners
,
to
be
uneducated
,
to
grow
up
like
one
of
the
poor
women
I
saw
sometimes
nursing
their
children
or
washing
their
clothes
at
the
cottage
doors
of
the
village
of
Gateshead
:
<EOS>
no
,
I
was
not
heroic
enough
to
purchase
liberty
at
the
price
of
caste
.
  
<EOS>
"
But
are
your
relatives
so
very
poor
?
<EOS>
Are
they
working
people
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
can
not
tell
;
Aunt
Reed
says
if
I
have
any
,
they
must
be
a
beggarly
set
:
I
should
not
like
to
go
a
begging
.
<EOS>
"
  
"
Would
you
like
to
go
to
school
?
"
  
<EOS>
Again
I
reflected
:
I
scarcely
knew
what
school
was
:
Bessie
sometimes
spoke
of
it
as
a
place
where
young
ladies
sat
in
the
stocks
,
wore
backboards
,
and
were
expected
to
be
exceedingly
genteel
and
precise
:
John
Reed
hated
his
school
,
and
abused
his
master
;
but
John
Reed
's
tastes
were
no
rule
for
mine
,
and
if
Bessie
's
accounts
of
school
-
discipline
(
gathered
from
the
young
ladies
of
a
family
where
she
had
lived
before
coming
to
Gateshead
)
were
somewhat
appalling
,
her
details
of
certain
accomplishments
attained
by
these
same
young
ladies
were
,
I
thought
,
equally
attractive
.
<EOS>
She
boasted
of
beautiful
paintings
of
landscapes
and
flowers
by
them
executed
;
of
songs
they
could
sing
and
pieces
they
could
play
,
of
purses
they
could
net
,
of
French
books
they
could
translate
;
till
my
spirit
was
moved
to
emulation
as
I
listened
.
<EOS>
Besides
,
school
would
be
a
complete
change
:
it
implied
a
long
journey
,
an
entire
separation
from
Gateshead
,
an
entrance
into
a
new
life
.
  
<EOS>
"
I
should
indeed
like
to
go
to
school
,
"
was
the
audible
conclusion
of
my
musings
.
  
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Well
,
well
!
<EOS>
who
knows
what
may
happen
?
"
said
Mr.
Lloyd
,
as
he
got
up
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
The
child
ought
to
have
change
of
air
and
scene
,
"
he
added
,
speaking
to
himself
;
"
nerves
not
in
a
good
state
.
"
  
<EOS>
Bessie
now
returned
;
at
the
same
moment
the
carriage
was
heard
rolling
up
the
gravel
-
walk
.
  
<EOS>
"
Is
that
your
mistress
,
nurse
?
"
asked
Mr.
Lloyd
.
<EOS>
"
I
should
like
to
speak
to
her
before
I
go
.
"
  
<EOS>
Bessie
invited
him
to
walk
into
the
breakfast
-
room
,
and
led
the
way
out
.
<EOS>
In
the
interview
which
followed
between
him
and
Mrs.
Reed
,
I
presume
,
from
after
-
occurrences
,
that
the
apothecary
ventured
to
recommend
my
being
sent
to
school
;
and
the
recommendation
was
no
doubt
readily
enough
adopted
;
for
as
Abbot
said
,
in
discussing
the
subject
with
Bessie
when
both
sat
sewing
in
the
nursery
one
night
,
after
I
was
in
bed
,
and
,
as
they
thought
,
asleep
,
"
Missis
was
,
she
dared
say
,
glad
enough
to
get
rid
of
such
a
tiresome
,
ill
-
conditioned
child
,
who
always
looked
as
if
she
were
watching
everybody
,
and
scheming
plots
underhand
.
<EOS>
"
Abbot
,
I
think
,
gave
me
credit
for
being
a
sort
of
infantine
Guy
Fawkes
.
  
<EOS>
On
that
same
occasion
I
learned
,
for
the
first
time
,
from
Miss
Abbot
's
communications
to
Bessie
,
that
my
father
had
been
a
poor
clergyman
;
that
my
mother
had
married
him
against
the
wishes
of
her
friends
,
who
considered
the
match
beneath
her
;
that
my
grandfather
Reed
was
so
irritated
at
her
disobedience
,
he
cut
her
off
without
a
shilling
;
that
after
my
mother
and
father
had
been
married
a
year
,
the
latter
caught
the
typhus
fever
while
visiting
among
the
poor
of
a
large
manufacturing
town
where
his
curacy
was
situated
,
and
where
that
disease
was
then
prevalent
:
that
my
mother
took
the
infection
from
him
,
and
both
died
within
a
month
of
each
other
.
  
<EOS>
Bessie
,
when
she
heard
this
narrative
,
sighed
and
said
,
"
Poor
Miss
Jane
is
to
be
pitied
,
too
,
Abbot
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Yes
,
"
responded
Abbot
;
"
if
she
were
a
nice
,
pretty
child
,
one
might
compassionate
her
forlornness
;
but
one
really
can
not
care
for
such
a
little
toad
as
that
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Not
a
great
deal
,
to
be
sure
,
"
agreed
Bessie
:
"
<EOS>
at
any
rate
,
a
beauty
like
Miss
Georgiana
would
be
more
moving
in
the
same
condition
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Yes
,
I
doat
on
Miss
Georgiana
!
"
cried
the
fervent
Abbot
.
"
<EOS>
Little
darling
!
 
<EOS>
with
her
long
curls
and
her
blue
eyes
,
and
such
a
sweet
colour
as
she
has
;
just
as
if
she
were
painted
!
 
<EOS>
Bessie
,
I
could
fancy
a
Welsh
rabbit
for
supper
.
<EOS>
"
  
"
So
could
I
 
with
a
roast
onion
.
<EOS>
Come
,
we
'll
go
down
.
<EOS>
"
They
went
.
    
<EOS>
From
my
discourse
with
Mr.
Lloyd
,
and
from
the
above
reported
conference
between
Bessie
and
Abbot
,
I
gathered
enough
of
hope
to
suffice
as
a
motive
for
wishing
to
get
well
:
<EOS>
a
change
seemed
near
,
 
I
desired
and
waited
it
in
silence
.
<EOS>
It
tarried
,
however
:
<EOS>
days
and
weeks
passed
:
I
had
regained
my
normal
state
of
health
,
but
no
new
allusion
was
made
to
the
subject
over
which
I
brooded
.
<EOS>
Mrs.
Reed
surveyed
me
at
times
with
a
severe
eye
,
but
seldom
addressed
me
:
since
my
illness
,
she
had
drawn
a
more
marked
line
of
separation
than
ever
between
me
and
her
own
children
;
appointing
me
a
small
closet
to
sleep
in
by
myself
,
condemning
me
to
take
my
meals
alone
,
and
pass
all
my
time
in
the
nursery
,
while
my
cousins
were
constantly
in
the
drawing
-
room
.
<EOS>
Not
a
hint
,
however
,
did
she
drop
about
sending
me
to
school
:
still
I
felt
an
instinctive
certainty
that
she
would
not
long
endure
me
under
the
same
roof
with
her
;
for
her
glance
,
now
more
than
ever
,
when
turned
on
me
,
expressed
an
insuperable
and
rooted
aversion
.
  
<EOS>
Eliza
and
Georgiana
,
evidently
acting
according
to
orders
,
spoke
to
me
as
little
as
possible
:
John
thrust
his
tongue
in
his
cheek
whenever
he
saw
me
,
and
once
attempted
chastisement
;
but
as
I
instantly
turned
against
him
,
roused
by
the
same
sentiment
of
deep
ire
and
desperate
revolt
which
had
stirred
my
corruption
before
,
he
thought
it
better
to
desist
,
and
ran
from
me
tittering
execrations
,
and
vowing
I
had
burst
his
nose
.
<EOS>
I
had
indeed
levelled
at
that
prominent
feature
as
hard
a
blow
as
my
knuckles
could
inflict
;
and
when
I
saw
that
either
that
or
my
look
daunted
him
,
I
had
the
greatest
inclination
to
follow
up
my
advantage
to
purpose
;
but
he
was
already
with
his
mama
.
<EOS>
I
heard
him
in
a
blubbering
tone
commence
the
tale
of
how
"
that
nasty
Jane
Eyre
"
had
flown
at
him
like
a
mad
cat
:
he
was
stopped
rather
harshly
    
"
Do
n't
talk
to
me
about
her
,
John
<EOS>
:
I
told
you
not
to
go
near
her
;
she
is
not
worthy
of
notice
;
I
do
not
choose
that
either
you
or
your
sisters
should
associate
with
her
.
"
  
<EOS>
Here
,
leaning
over
the
banister
,
I
cried
out
suddenly
,
and
without
at
all
deliberating
on
my
words
    
<EOS>
"
They
are
not
fit
to
associate
with
me
.
"
  
<EOS>
Mrs.
Reed
was
rather
a
stout
woman
;
but
,
on
hearing
this
strange
and
audacious
declaration
,
she
ran
nimbly
up
the
stair
,
swept
me
like
a
whirlwind
into
the
nursery
,
and
crushing
me
down
on
the
edge
of
my
crib
,
dared
me
in
an
emphatic
voice
to
rise
from
that
place
,
or
utter
one
syllable
during
the
remainder
of
the
day
.
  
<EOS>
"
What
would
Uncle
Reed
say
to
you
,
if
he
were
alive
?
"
was
my
scarcely
voluntary
demand
.
<EOS>
I
say
scarcely
voluntary
,
for
it
seemed
as
if
my
tongue
pronounced
words
without
my
will
consenting
to
their
utterance
<EOS>
:
something
spoke
out
of
me
over
which
I
had
no
control
.
  
<EOS>
"
What
?
"
said
Mrs.
Reed
under
her
breath
:
<EOS>
her
usually
cold
composed
grey
eye
became
troubled
with
a
look
like
fear
;
she
took
her
hand
from
my
arm
,
and
gazed
at
me
as
if
she
really
did
not
know
whether
I
were
child
or
fiend
.
<EOS>
I
was
now
in
for
it
.
  
<EOS>
"
My
Uncle
Reed
is
in
heaven
,
and
can
see
all
you
do
and
think
;
and
so
can
papa
and
mama
:
<EOS>
they
know
how
you
shut
me
up
all
day
long
,
and
how
you
wish
me
dead
.
"
  
<EOS>
Mrs.
Reed
soon
rallied
her
spirits
:
she
shook
me
most
soundly
,
she
boxed
both
my
ears
,
and
then
left
me
without
a
word
.
<EOS>
Bessie
supplied
the
hiatus
by
a
homily
of
an
hour
's
length
,
in
which
she
proved
beyond
a
doubt
that
I
was
the
most
wicked
and
abandoned
child
ever
reared
under
a
roof
.
<EOS>
I
half
believed
her
;
for
I
felt
indeed
only
bad
feelings
surging
in
my
breast
.
  
<EOS>
November
,
December
,
and
half
of
January
passed
away
.
<EOS>
Christmas
and
the
New
Year
had
been
celebrated
at
Gateshead
with
the
usual
festive
cheer
;
presents
had
been
interchanged
,
dinners
and
evening
parties
given
.
<EOS>
From
every
enjoyment
I
was
,
of
course
,
excluded
:
<EOS>
my
share
of
the
gaiety
consisted
in
witnessing
the
daily
apparelling
of
Eliza
and
Georgiana
,
and
seeing
them
descend
to
the
drawing
-
room
,
dressed
out
in
thin
muslin
frocks
and
scarlet
sashes
,
with
hair
elaborately
ringletted
;
and
afterwards
,
in
listening
to
the
sound
of
the
piano
or
the
harp
played
below
,
to
the
passing
to
and
fro
of
the
butler
and
footman
,
to
the
jingling
of
glass
and
china
as
refreshments
were
handed
,
to
the
broken
hum
of
conversation
as
the
drawing
-
room
door
opened
and
closed
.
<EOS>
When
tired
of
this
occupation
,
I
would
retire
from
the
stairhead
to
the
solitary
and
silent
nursery
:
there
,
though
somewhat
sad
,
I
was
not
miserable
.
<EOS>
To
speak
truth
,
I
had
not
the
least
wish
to
go
into
company
,
for
in
company
I
was
very
rarely
noticed
;
and
if
Bessie
had
but
been
kind
and
companionable
,
I
should
have
deemed
it
a
treat
to
spend
the
evenings
quietly
with
her
,
instead
of
passing
them
under
the
formidable
eye
of
Mrs.
Reed
,
in
a
room
full
of
ladies
and
gentlemen
.
<EOS>
But
Bessie
,
as
soon
as
she
had
dressed
her
young
ladies
,
used
to
take
herself
off
to
the
lively
regions
of
the
kitchen
and
housekeeper
's
room
,
generally
bearing
the
candle
along
with
her
.
<EOS>
I
then
sat
with
my
doll
on
my
knee
till
the
fire
got
low
,
glancing
round
occasionally
to
make
sure
that
nothing
worse
than
myself
haunted
the
shadowy
room
;
and
when
the
embers
sank
to
a
dull
red
,
I
undressed
hastily
,
tugging
at
knots
and
strings
as
I
best
might
,
and
sought
shelter
from
cold
and
darkness
in
my
crib
.
<EOS>
To
this
crib
I
always
took
my
doll
;
human
beings
must
love
something
,
and
,
in
the
dearth
of
worthier
objects
of
affection
,
I
contrived
to
find
a
pleasure
in
loving
and
cherishing
a
faded
graven
image
,
shabby
as
a
miniature
scarecrow
.
<EOS>
It
puzzles
me
now
to
remember
with
what
absurd
sincerity
I
doated
on
this
little
toy
,
half
fancying
it
alive
and
capable
of
sensation
.
<EOS>
I
could
not
sleep
unless
it
was
folded
in
my
night
-
gown
;
and
when
it
lay
there
safe
and
warm
,
I
was
comparatively
happy
,
believing
it
to
be
happy
likewise
.
  
<EOS>
Long
did
the
hours
seem
while
I
waited
the
departure
of
the
company
,
and
listened
for
the
sound
of
Bessie
's
step
on
the
stairs
:
sometimes
she
would
come
up
in
the
interval
to
seek
her
thimble
or
her
scissors
,
or
perhaps
to
bring
me
something
by
way
of
supper
 
<EOS>
a
bun
or
a
cheese
-
cake
 
<EOS>
then
she
would
sit
on
the
bed
while
I
ate
it
,
and
when
I
had
finished
,
she
would
tuck
the
clothes
round
me
,
and
twice
she
kissed
me
,
and
said
,
"
Good
night
,
Miss
Jane
.
<EOS>
"
When
thus
gentle
,
Bessie
seemed
to
me
the
best
,
prettiest
,
kindest
being
in
the
world
;
and
I
wished
most
intensely
that
she
would
always
be
so
pleasant
and
amiable
,
and
never
push
me
about
,
or
scold
,
or
task
me
unreasonably
,
as
she
was
too
often
wo
nt
to
do
.
<EOS>
Bessie
Lee
must
,
I
think
,
have
been
a
girl
of
good
natural
capacity
,
for
she
was
smart
in
all
she
did
,
and
had
a
remarkable
knack
of
narrative
;
so
,
at
least
,
I
judge
from
the
impression
made
on
me
by
her
nursery
tales
.
<EOS>
She
was
pretty
too
,
if
my
recollections
of
her
face
and
person
are
correct
.
<EOS>
I
remember
her
as
a
slim
young
woman
,
with
black
hair
,
dark
eyes
,
very
nice
features
,
and
good
,
clear
complexion
;
but
she
had
a
capricious
and
hasty
temper
,
and
indifferent
ideas
of
principle
or
justice
:
still
,
such
as
she
was
,
I
preferred
her
to
any
one
else
at
Gateshead
Hall
.
  
<EOS>
It
was
the
fifteenth
of
January
,
about
nine
o'clock
in
the
morning
:
<EOS>
Bessie
was
gone
down
to
breakfast
;
my
cousins
had
not
yet
been
summoned
to
their
mama
;
Eliza
was
putting
on
her
bonnet
and
warm
garden
-
coat
to
go
and
feed
her
poultry
,
an
occupation
of
which
she
was
fond
:
and
not
less
so
of
selling
the
eggs
to
the
housekeeper
and
hoarding
up
the
money
she
thus
obtained
.
<EOS>
She
had
a
turn
for
traffic
,
and
a
marked
propensity
for
saving
;
shown
not
only
in
the
vending
of
eggs
and
chickens
,
but
also
in
driving
hard
bargains
with
the
gardener
about
flower
-
roots
,
seeds
,
and
slips
of
plants
;
<EOS>
that
functionary
having
orders
from
Mrs.
Reed
to
buy
of
his
young
lady
all
the
products
of
her
parterre
she
wished
to
sell
:
and
Eliza
would
have
sold
the
hair
off
her
head
if
she
could
have
made
a
handsome
profit
thereby
.
<EOS>
As
to
her
money
,
she
first
secreted
it
in
odd
corners
,
wrapped
in
a
rag
or
an
old
curl
-
paper
;
but
some
of
these
hoards
having
been
discovered
by
the
housemaid
,
Eliza
,
fearful
of
one
day
losing
her
valued
treasure
,
consented
to
intrust
it
to
her
mother
,
at
a
usurious
rate
of
interest
 
fifty
or
sixty
per
cent
.
;
which
interest
she
exacted
every
quarter
,
keeping
her
accounts
in
a
little
book
with
anxious
accuracy
.
  
<EOS>
Georgiana
sat
on
a
high
stool
,
dressing
her
hair
at
the
glass
,
and
interweaving
her
curls
with
artificial
flowers
and
faded
feathers
,
of
which
she
had
found
a
store
in
a
drawer
in
the
attic
.
<EOS>
I
was
making
my
bed
,
having
received
strict
orders
from
Bessie
to
get
it
arranged
before
she
returned
(
for
Bessie
now
frequently
employed
me
as
a
sort
of
under-
nurserymaid
,
to
tidy
the
room
,
dust
the
chairs
,
&
c.
)
.
<EOS>
Having
spread
the
quilt
and
folded
my
night
-
dress
,
I
went
to
the
window
-
seat
to
put
in
order
<EOS>
some
picture
-
books
and
doll
's
house
furniture
scattered
there
;
an
abrupt
command
from
Georgiana
to
let
her
playthings
alone
(
for
the
tiny
chairs
and
mirrors
,
the
fairy
plates
and
cups
,
were
her
property
)
stopped
my
proceedings
;
and
then
,
for
lack
of
other
occupation
,
I
fell
to
breathing
on
the
frost
-
flowers
with
which
the
window
was
fretted
,
and
thus
clearing
a
space
in
the
glass
through
which
I
might
look
out
on
the
grounds
,
where
all
was
still
and
petrified
under
the
influence
of
a
hard
frost
.
  
<EOS>
From
this
window
were
visible
the
porter
's
lodge
and
the
carriage
-
road
,
and
just
as
I
had
dissolved
so
much
of
the
silver
-
white
foliage
veiling
the
panes
as
left
room
to
look
out
,
I
saw
the
gates
thrown
open
and
a
carriage
roll
through
.
<EOS>
I
watched
it
ascending
the
drive
with
indifference
;
carriages
often
came
to
Gateshead
,
but
none
ever
brought
visitors
in
whom
I
was
interested
;
it
stopped
in
front
of
the
house
,
the
door
-
bell
rang
loudly
,
the
new
-
comer
was
admitted
.
<EOS>
All
this
being
nothing
to
me
,
my
vacant
attention
soon
found
livelier
attraction
in
the
spectacle
of
a
little
hungry
robin
,
which
came
and
chirruped
on
the
twigs
of
the
leafless
cherry
-
tree
nailed
against
the
wall
near
the
casement
.
<EOS>
The
remains
of
my
breakfast
of
bread
and
milk
stood
on
the
table
,
and
having
crumbled
a
morsel
of
roll
,
I
was
tugging
at
the
sash
to
put
out
the
crumbs
on
the
window
-
sill
,
when
Bessie
came
running
upstairs
into
the
nursery
.
  
<EOS>
"
Miss
Jane
,
take
off
your
pinafore
;
what
are
you
doing
there
?
<EOS>
Have
you
washed
your
hands
and
face
this
morning
?
<EOS>
"
I
gave
another
tug
before
I
answered
,
for
I
wanted
the
bird
to
be
secure
of
its
bread
:
the
sash
yielded
;
I
scattered
the
crumbs
,
some
on
the
stone
sill
,
some
on
the
cherry
-
tree
bough
,
then
,
closing
the
window
,
I
replied
    
"
<EOS>
No
,
Bessie
;
I
have
only
just
finished
dusting
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Troublesome
,
careless
child
!
<EOS>
and
what
are
you
doing
now
?
<EOS>
You
look
quite
red
,
as
if
you
had
been
about
some
mischief
:
what
were
you
opening
the
window
for
?
"
  
<EOS>
I
was
spared
the
trouble
of
answering
,
for
<EOS>
Bessie
seemed
in
too
great
a
hurry
to
listen
to
explanations
;
she
hauled
me
to
the
washstand
,
inflicted
a
merciless
,
but
happily
brief
scrub
on
my
face
and
hands
with
soap
,
water
,
and
a
coarse
towel
;
disciplined
my
head
with
a
bristly
brush
,
denuded
me
of
my
pinafore
,
and
then
hurrying
me
to
the
top
of
the
stairs
,
bid
me
go
down
directly
,
as
I
was
wanted
in
the
breakfast
-
room
.
  
<EOS>
I
would
have
asked
who
wanted
me
:
I
would
have
demanded
if
Mrs.
Reed
was
there
;
but
Bessie
was
already
gone
,
and
had
closed
the
nursery
-
door
upon
me
.
<EOS>
I
slowly
descended
.
<EOS>
For
nearly
three
months
,
I
had
never
been
called
to
Mrs.
Reed
's
presence
;
restricted
so
long
to
the
nursery
,
the
breakfast
,
dining
,
and
drawing
-
rooms
were
become
for
me
awful
regions
,
on
which
it
dismayed
me
to
intrude
.
  
<EOS>
I
now
stood
in
the
empty
hall
;
before
me
was
the
breakfast
-
room
door
,
and
I
stopped
,
intimidated
and
trembling
.
<EOS>
What
a
miserable
little
poltroon
had
fear
,
engendered
of
unjust
punishment
,
made
of
me
in
those
days
!
<EOS>
I
feared
to
return
to
the
nursery
,
and
feared
to
go
forward
to
the
parlour
;
ten
minutes
I
stood
in
agitated
hesitation
;
the
vehement
ringing
of
the
breakfast
-
room
bell
decided
me
;
I
_
must
_
enter
.
  
<EOS>
"
Who
could
want
me
?
<EOS>
"
I
asked
inwardly
,
as
with
both
hands
I
turned
the
stiff
door
-
handle
,
which
,
for
a
second
or
two
,
resisted
my
efforts
.
<EOS>
"
What
should
I
see
besides
Aunt
Reed
in
the
apartment
?
 
<EOS>
a
man
or
a
woman
?
<EOS>
"
The
handle
turned
,
the
door
unclosed
,
and
passing
through
and
curtseying
low
,
I
looked
up
at
 
a
black
pillar
!
 
<EOS>
such
,
at
least
,
appeared
to
me
,
at
first
sight
,
the
straight
,
narrow
,
sable
-
clad
shape
standing
erect
on
the
rug
<EOS>
:
the
grim
face
at
the
top
was
like
a
carved
mask
,
placed
above
the
shaft
by
way
of
capital
.
  
<EOS>
Mrs.
Reed
occupied
her
usual
seat
by
the
fireside
;
she
made
a
signal
to
me
to
approach
;
I
did
so
,
and
she
introduced
me
to
the
stony
stranger
with
the
words
:
"
<EOS>
This
is
the
little
girl
respecting
whom
I
applied
to
you
.
"
  
<EOS>
_
<EOS>
He
_
,
for
it
was
a
man
,
turned
his
head
slowly
towards
where
I
stood
,
and
having
examined
me
with
the
two
inquisitive
-
looking
grey
eyes
which
twinkled
under
a
pair
of
bushy
brows
,
said
solemnly
,
and
in
a
bass
voice
,
"
Her
size
is
small
:
what
is
her
age
?
"
  
<EOS>
"
Ten
years
.
<EOS>
"
  
"
So
much
?
"
was
the
doubtful
answer
;
and
he
prolonged
his
scrutiny
for
some
minutes
.
<EOS>
Presently
he
addressed
me
 
"
Your
name
,
little
girl
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Jane
Eyre
,
sir
.
"
  
<EOS>
In
uttering
these
words
I
looked
up
:
he
seemed
to
me
a
tall
gentleman
;
but
then
I
was
very
little
;
his
features
were
large
,
and
they
and
all
the
lines
of
his
frame
were
equally
harsh
and
prim
.
  
<EOS>
"
Well
,
Jane
Eyre
,
and
are
you
a
good
child
?
"
  
<EOS>
Impossible
to
reply
to
this
in
the
affirmative
:
my
little
world
held
a
contrary
opinion
<EOS>
:
I
was
silent
.
<EOS>
Mrs.
Reed
answered
for
me
by
an
expressive
shake
of
the
head
,
adding
soon
,
"
Perhaps
the
less
said
on
that
subject
the
better
,
Mr.
Brocklehurst
.
"
  
<EOS>
"
Sorry
indeed
to
hear
it
!
<EOS>
she
and
I
must
have
some
talk
;
"
and
bending
from
the
perpendicular
,
he
installed
his
person
in
the
arm
-
chair
opposite
Mrs.
Reed
's
.
<EOS>
"
Come
here
,
"
he
said
.
  
<EOS>
I
stepped
across
the
rug
;
he
placed
me
square
and
straight
before
him
.
<EOS>
What
a
face
he
had
,
now
that
it
was
almost
on
a
level
with
mine
!
<EOS>
what
a
great
nose
!
<EOS>
and
what
a
mouth
!
<EOS>
and
what
large
prominent
teeth
!
  
<EOS>
"
No
sight
so
sad
as
that
of
a
naughty
child
,
"
he
began
,
"
especially
a
naughty
little
girl
.
<EOS>
Do
you
know
where
the
wicked
go
after
death
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
They
go
to
hell
,
"
was
my
ready
and
orthodox
answer
.
  
<EOS>
"
And
what
is
hell
?
<EOS>
Can
you
tell
me
that
?
"
  
<EOS>
"
A
pit
full
of
fire
.
<EOS>
"
  
"
And
should
you
like
to
fall
into
that
pit
,
and
to
be
burning
there
for
ever
?
"
  
<EOS>
"
No
,
sir
.
"
  
<EOS>
"
What
must
you
do
to
avoid
it
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
I
deliberated
a
moment
;
my
answer
,
when
it
did
come
,
was
objectionable
:
"
I
must
keep
in
good
health
,
and
not
die
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
How
can
you
keep
in
good
health
?
<EOS>
Children
younger
than
you
die
daily
.
<EOS>
I
buried
a
little
child
of
five
years
old
only
a
day
or
two
since
,
 
a
good
little
child
,
whose
soul
is
now
in
heaven
.
<EOS>
It
is
to
be
feared
the
same
could
not
be
said
of
you
were
you
to
be
called
hence
.
"
  
<EOS>
Not
being
in
a
condition
to
remove
his
doubt
,
I
only
cast
my
eyes
down
on
the
two
large
feet
planted
on
the
rug
,
and
sighed
,
wishing
myself
far
enough
away
.
  
<EOS>
"
I
hope
that
sigh
is
from
the
heart
,
and
that
you
repent
of
ever
having
been
the
occasion
of
discomfort
to
your
excellent
benefactress
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Benefactress
!
benefactress
!
<EOS>
"
said
I
inwardly
:
"
they
all
call
Mrs.
Reed
my
benefactress
;
if
so
,
a
benefactress
is
a
disagreeable
thing
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Do
you
say
your
prayers
night
and
morning
?
<EOS>
"
continued
my
interrogator
.
  
<EOS>
"
Yes
,
sir
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Do
you
read
your
Bible
?
"
  
"
Sometimes
.
"
  
"
<EOS>
With
pleasure
?
<EOS>
Are
you
fond
of
it
?
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
like
Revelations
,
and
the
book
of
Daniel
,
and
Genesis
and
Samuel
,
and
a
little
bit
of
Exodus
,
and
some
parts
of
Kings
and
Chronicles
,
and
Job
and
Jonah
.
<EOS>
"
  
"
<EOS>
And
the
Psalms
?
<EOS>
I
hope
you
like
them
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
No
,
sir
.
"
  
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
No
?
<EOS>
oh
,
shocking
!
<EOS>
I
have
a
little
boy
,
younger
than
you
,
who
knows
six
Psalms
by
heart
:
and
when
you
ask
him
which
he
would
rather
have
,
a
gingerbread
-
nut
to
eat
or
a
verse
of
a
Psalm
to
learn
,
he
says
:
"
<EOS>
Oh
!
<EOS>
the
verse
of
a
Psalm
!
<EOS>
angels
sing
Psalms
;
"
says
he
,
"
I
wish
to
be
a
little
angel
here
below
;
"
he
then
gets
two
nuts
in
recompense
for
his
infant
piety
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Psalms
are
not
interesting
,
"
I
remarked
.
  
<EOS>
"
That
proves
you
have
a
wicked
heart
;
and
you
must
pray
to
God
to
change
it
:
to
give
you
a
new
and
clean
one
:
to
take
away
your
heart
of
stone
and
give
you
a
heart
of
flesh
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
I
was
about
to
propound
a
question
,
touching
the
manner
in
which
that
operation
of
changing
my
heart
was
to
be
performed
,
when
Mrs.
Reed
interposed
,
telling
me
to
sit
down
;
she
then
proceeded
to
carry
on
the
conversation
herself
.
  
<EOS>
"
Mr.
Brocklehurst
,
I
believe
I
intimated
in
the
letter
which
I
wrote
to
you
three
weeks
ago
,
that
this
little
girl
has
not
quite
the
character
and
disposition
I
could
wish
:
should
you
admit
her
into
Lowood
school
,
I
should
be
glad
if
the
superintendent
and
teachers
were
requested
to
keep
a
strict
eye
on
her
,
and
,
above
all
,
to
guard
against
her
worst
fault
,
a
tendency
to
deceit
.
<EOS>
I
mention
this
in
your
hearing
,
Jane
,
that
you
may
not
attempt
to
impose
on
Mr.
Brocklehurst
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
Well
might
I
dread
,
well
might
I
dislike
Mrs.
Reed
;
for
it
was
her
nature
to
wound
me
cruelly
;
never
was
I
happy
in
her
presence
<EOS>
;
however
carefully
I
obeyed
,
however
strenuously
I
strove
to
please
her
,
my
efforts
were
still
repulsed
and
repaid
by
such
sentences
as
the
above
.
<EOS>
Now
,
uttered
before
a
stranger
,
the
accusation
cut
me
to
the
heart
;
I
dimly
perceived
that
she
was
already
obliterating
hope
from
the
new
phase
of
existence
which
she
destined
me
to
enter
;
I
felt
,
though
I
could
not
have
expressed
the
feeling
,
that
she
was
sowing
aversion
and
unkindness
along
my
future
path
;
I
saw
myself
transformed
under
Mr.
Brocklehurst
's
eye
into
an
artful
,
noxious
child
,
and
what
could
I
do
to
remedy
the
injury
?
  
<EOS>
"
Nothing
,
indeed
,
"
thought
I
,
as
I
struggled
to
repress
a
sob
,
and
hastily
wiped
away
some
tears
,
the
impotent
evidences
of
my
anguish
.
  
<EOS>
"
Deceit
is
,
indeed
,
a
sad
fault
in
a
child
,
"
said
Mr.
Brocklehurst
;
"
it
is
akin
to
falsehood
,
and
all
liars
will
have
their
portion
in
the
lake
burning
with
fire
and
brimstone
;
she
shall
,
however
,
be
watched
,
Mrs.
Reed
.
<EOS>
I
will
speak
to
Miss
Temple
and
the
teachers
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
should
wish
her
to
be
brought
up
in
a
manner
suiting
her
prospects
,
"
continued
my
benefactress
;
"
to
be
made
useful
,
to
be
kept
humble
:
as
for
the
vacations
,
she
will
,
with
your
permission
,
spend
them
always
at
Lowood
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Your
decisions
are
perfectly
judicious
,
madam
,
"
returned
Mr.
Brocklehurst
.
<EOS>
"
Humility
is
a
Christian
grace
,
and
one
peculiarly
appropriate
to
the
pupils
of
Lowood
;
I
,
therefore
,
direct
that
especial
care
shall
be
bestowed
on
its
cultivation
amongst
them
.
<EOS>
I
have
studied
how
best
to
mortify
in
them
the
worldly
sentiment
of
pride
;
and
,
only
the
other
day
,
I
