<EOS>
Come
to
lunch
!
"
  
<EOS>
It
was
Bessie
<EOS>
,
I
knew
well
enough
;
but
I
did
not
stir
;
her
light
step
came
tripping
down
the
path
.
  
<EOS>
"
You
naughty
little
thing
!
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
she
said
.
<EOS>
"
Why
do
n't
you
come
when
you
are
called
?
"
  
<EOS>
Bessie
's
presence
,
compared
with
the
thoughts
over
which
I
had
been
brooding
,
seemed
cheerful
;
even
though
,
as
usual
,
she
was
somewhat
cross
.
<EOS>
The
fact
is
,
after
my
conflict
with
and
victory
over
Mrs.
Reed
,
I
was
not
disposed
to
care
much
for
the
nursemaid
's
transitory
anger
;
and
I
_
was
_
disposed
to
bask
in
her
youthful
lightness
of
heart
.
<EOS>
I
just
put
my
two
arms
round
her
and
said
,
"
Come
,
Bessie
!
<EOS>
do
n't
scold
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
The
action
was
more
frank
and
fearless
than
any
I
was
habituated
to
indulge
in
:
somehow
it
pleased
her
.
  
<EOS>
"
You
are
a
strange
child
,
Miss
Jane
,
"
she
said
,
as
she
looked
down
at
me
;
"
a
little
roving
,
solitary
thing
:
<EOS>
and
you
are
going
to
school
,
I
suppose
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
I
nodded
.
  
<EOS>
"
And
wo
n't
you
be
sorry
to
leave
poor
Bessie
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
What
does
Bessie
care
for
me
?
<EOS>
She
is
always
scolding
me
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Because
you
're
such
a
queer
,
frightened
,
shy
little
thing
.
<EOS>
You
should
be
bolder
.
"
  
<EOS>
"
What
!
<EOS>
to
get
more
knocks
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Nonsense
!
<EOS>
But
you
are
rather
put
upon
<EOS>
,
that
's
certain
.
<EOS>
My
mother
said
,
when
she
came
to
see
me
last
week
,
that
she
would
not
like
a
little
one
of
her
own
to
be
in
your
place
.
 
<EOS>
Now
,
come
in
,
and
I
've
some
good
news
for
you
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
do
n't
think
you
have
,
Bessie
.
<EOS>
"
  
"
Child
!
<EOS>
what
do
you
mean
?
<EOS>
What
sorrowful
eyes
you
fix
on
me
!
<EOS>
Well
,
but
Missis
and
the
young
ladies
and
Master
John
are
going
out
to
tea
this
afternoon
,
and
you
shall
have
tea
with
me
.
<EOS>
I
'll
ask
cook
to
bake
you
a
little
cake
,
and
then
you
shall
help
me
to
look
over
your
drawers
;
for
I
am
soon
to
pack
your
trunk
.
<EOS>
Missis
intends
you
to
leave
Gateshead
in
a
day
or
two
,
and
you
shall
choose
what
toys
you
like
to
take
with
you
.
"
  
<EOS>
"
Bessie
,
you
must
promise
not
to
scold
me
any
more
till
I
go
.
"
  
<EOS>
"
Well
,
I
will
;
but
mind
<EOS>
you
are
a
very
good
girl
,
and
do
n't
be
afraid
of
me
.
<EOS>
Do
n't
start
when
I
chance
to
speak
rather
sharply
;
it
's
so
provoking
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
do
n't
think
I
shall
ever
be
afraid
of
you
again
,
Bessie
,
because
I
have
got
used
to
you
,
and
I
shall
soon
have
another
set
of
people
to
dread
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
If
you
dread
them
they
'll
dislike
you
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
As
you
do
,
Bessie
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
do
n't
dislike
you
,
Miss
;
I
believe
I
am
fonder
of
you
than
of
all
the
others
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
You
do
n't
show
it
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
You
little
sharp
thing
!
<EOS>
you
've
got
quite
a
new
way
of
talking
.
<EOS>
What
makes
you
so
venturesome
and
hardy
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Why
,
I
shall
soon
be
away
from
you
,
and
besides
"
 
I
was
going
to
say
something
about
what
had
passed
between
me
and
Mrs.
Reed
,
but
on
second
thoughts
I
considered
it
better
to
remain
silent
on
that
head
.
  
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
And
so
you
're
glad
to
leave
me
?
<EOS>
"
  
"
Not
at
all
<EOS>
,
Bessie
;
indeed
,
just
now
I
'm
rather
sorry
.
<EOS>
"
  
"
Just
now
!
and
rather
!
<EOS>
How
coolly
my
little
lady
says
it
!
<EOS>
I
dare
say
now
if
I
were
to
ask
you
for
a
kiss
<EOS>
you
would
n't
give
it
me
<EOS>
:
you
'd
say
you
'd
_
rather
_
not
.
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
'll
kiss
you
and
welcome
:
<EOS>
bend
your
head
down
.
"
<EOS>
Bessie
stooped
;
we
mutually
embraced
,
and
I
followed
her
into
the
house
quite
comforted
.
<EOS>
That
afternoon
lapsed
in
peace
and
harmony
;
and
in
the
evening
Bessie
told
me
some
of
her
most
enchanting
stories
,
and
sang
me
some
of
her
sweetest
songs
.
<EOS>
Even
for
me
life
had
its
gleams
of
sunshine
.
    
<EOS>
Five
o'clock
had
hardly
struck
on
the
morning
of
the
19th
of
January
,
when
Bessie
brought
a
candle
into
my
closet
and
found
me
already
up
and
nearly
dressed
.
<EOS>
I
had
risen
half
-
an
-
hour
before
her
entrance
,
and
had
washed
my
face
,
and
put
on
my
clothes
by
the
light
of
a
half
-
moon
just
setting
,
whose
rays
streamed
through
the
narrow
window
near
my
crib
.
<EOS>
I
was
to
leave
Gateshead
that
day
by
a
coach
which
passed
the
lodge
gates
at
six
a.m.
Bessie
<EOS>
was
the
only
person
yet
risen
;
she
had
lit
a
fire
in
the
nursery
,
where
she
now
proceeded
to
make
my
breakfast
.
<EOS>
Few
children
can
eat
when
excited
with
the
thoughts
of
a
journey
;
nor
could
I.
Bessie
,
having
pressed
me
in
vain
to
take
a
few
spoonfuls
of
the
boiled
milk
and
bread
she
had
prepared
for
me
,
wrapped
up
some
biscuits
in
a
paper
and
put
them
into
my
bag
;
then
she
helped
me
on
with
my
pelisse
and
bonnet
,
and
wrapping
herself
in
a
shawl
,
she
and
I
left
the
nursery
.
<EOS>
As
we
passed
Mrs.
Reed
's
bedroom
,
she
said
,
"
Will
you
go
in
and
bid
Missis
good-
<EOS>
bye
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
No
,
Bessie
:
she
came
to
my
crib
last
night
when
you
were
gone
down
to
supper
,
and
said
I
need
not
disturb
her
in
the
morning
,
or
my
cousins
either
;
and
she
told
me
to
remember
that
she
had
always
been
my
best
friend
,
and
to
speak
of
her
and
be
grateful
to
her
accordingly
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
What
did
you
say
,
Miss
?
"
  
<EOS>
"
Nothing
:
<EOS>
I
covered
my
face
with
the
bedclothes
,
and
turned
from
her
to
the
wall
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
That
was
wrong
,
Miss
Jane
.
"
  
<EOS>
"
It
was
quite
right
,
Bessie
.
<EOS>
Your
Missis
has
not
been
my
friend
:
she
has
been
my
foe
.
<EOS>
"
  
"
<EOS>
O
Miss
Jane
!
<EOS>
do
n't
say
so
!
"
  
<EOS>
"
Good
-
bye
to
Gateshead
!
"
<EOS>
cried
I
,
as
we
passed
through
the
hall
and
went
out
at
the
front
door
.
  
<EOS>
The
moon
was
set
,
and
it
was
very
dark
;
Bessie
carried
a
lantern
,
whose
light
glanced
on
wet
steps
and
gravel
road
sodden
by
a
recent
thaw
.
<EOS>
Raw
and
chill
was
the
winter
morning
:
<EOS>
my
teeth
chattered
as
I
hastened
down
the
drive
.
<EOS>
There
was
a
light
in
the
porter
's
lodge
:
when
we
reached
it
,
we
found
the
porter
's
wife
just
kindling
her
fire
:
<EOS>
my
trunk
,
which
had
been
carried
down
the
evening
before
,
stood
corded
at
the
door
.
<EOS>
It
wanted
but
a
few
minutes
of
six
,
and
shortly
after
that
hour
had
struck
,
the
distant
roll
of
wheels
announced
the
coming
coach
;
I
went
to
the
door
and
watched
its
lamps
approach
rapidly
through
the
gloom
.
  
<EOS>
"
Is
she
going
by
herself
?
"
asked
the
porter
's
wife
.
  
<EOS>
"
Yes
.
"
  
<EOS>
"
And
how
far
is
it
?
"
  
"
<EOS>
Fifty
miles
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
What
a
long
way
!
<EOS>
I
wonder
Mrs.
Reed
is
not
afraid
to
trust
her
so
far
alone
.
"
  
<EOS>
The
coach
drew
up
;
there
it
was
at
the
gates
with
its
four
horses
and
its
top
laden
with
passengers
:
the
guard
and
coachman
loudly
urged
haste
;
my
trunk
was
hoisted
up
;
I
was
taken
from
Bessie
's
neck
,
to
which
I
clung
with
kisses
.
  
<EOS>
"
Be
sure
and
take
good
care
of
her
,
"
cried
she
to
the
guard
,
as
he
lifted
me
into
the
inside
.
  
<EOS>
"
Ay
,
ay
!
<EOS>
"
was
the
answer
:
the
door
was
slapped
to
,
a
voice
exclaimed
"
All
right
,
"
and
on
we
drove
.
<EOS>
Thus
was
I
severed
from
Bessie
and
Gateshead
;
thus
whirled
away
to
unknown
,
and
,
as
I
then
deemed
,
remote
and
mysterious
regions
.
  
<EOS>
I
remember
but
little
of
the
journey
;
I
only
know
that
the
day
seemed
to
me
of
a
preternatural
length
,
and
that
we
appeared
to
travel
over
hundreds
of
miles
of
road
.
<EOS>
We
passed
through
several
towns
,
and
in
one
,
a
very
large
one
,
the
coach
stopped
;
the
horses
were
taken
out
,
and
the
passengers
alighted
to
dine
.
<EOS>
I
was
carried
into
an
inn
,
where
the
guard
wanted
me
to
have
some
dinner
;
but
,
as
I
had
no
appetite
,
he
left
me
in
an
immense
room
with
a
fireplace
at
each
end
,
a
chandelier
pendent
from
the
ceiling
,
and
a
little
red
gallery
high
up
against
the
wall
filled
with
musical
instruments
.
<EOS>
Here
I
walked
about
for
a
long
time
,
feeling
very
strange
,
and
mortally
apprehensive
of
some
one
coming
in
and
kidnapping
me
;
for
I
believed
in
kidnappers
,
their
exploits
having
frequently
figured
in
Bessie
's
fireside
chronicles
.
<EOS>
At
last
the
guard
returned
;
once
more
I
was
stowed
away
in
the
coach
,
my
protector
mounted
his
own
seat
,
sounded
his
hollow
horn
,
and
away
we
rattled
over
the
"
stony
street
"
of
L-
.
  
<EOS>
The
afternoon
came
on
wet
and
somewhat
misty
:
as
it
waned
into
dusk
,
I
began
to
feel
that
we
were
getting
very
far
indeed
from
Gateshead
:
we
ceased
to
pass
through
towns
;
the
country
changed
;
great
grey
hills
heaved
up
round
the
horizon
:
as
twilight
deepened
,
we
descended
a
valley
,
dark
with
wood
,
and
long
after
night
had
overclouded
the
prospect
,
I
heard
a
wild
wind
rushing
amongst
trees
.
  
<EOS>
Lulled
by
the
sound
,
I
at
last
dropped
asleep
;
I
had
not
long
slumbered
when
the
sudden
cessation
of
motion
awoke
me
;
the
coach
-
door
was
open
,
and
a
person
like
a
servant
was
standing
at
it
:
<EOS>
I
saw
her
face
and
dress
by
the
light
of
the
lamps
.
  
<EOS>
"
Is
there
a
little
girl
called
Jane
Eyre
here
?
"
<EOS>
she
asked
.
<EOS>
I
answered
"
Yes
,
"
and
was
then
lifted
out
;
my
trunk
was
handed
down
,
and
the
coach
instantly
drove
away
.
  
<EOS>
I
was
stiff
with
long
sitting
,
and
bewildered
with
the
noise
and
motion
of
the
coach
:
<EOS>
Gathering
my
faculties
,
I
looked
about
me
.
<EOS>
Rain
,
wind
,
and
darkness
filled
the
air
;
nevertheless
,
I
dimly
discerned
a
wall
before
me
and
a
door
open
in
it
;
through
this
door
I
passed
with
my
new
guide
:
she
shut
and
locked
it
behind
her
.
<EOS>
There
was
now
visible
a
house
or
houses
 
for
the
building
spread
far
 
with
many
windows
,
and
lights
burning
in
some
;
we
went
up
a
broad
pebbly
path
,
splashing
wet
,
and
were
admitted
at
a
door
;
then
the
servant
led
me
through
a
passage
into
a
room
with
a
fire
,
where
she
left
me
alone
.
  
<EOS>
I
stood
and
warmed
my
numbed
fingers
over
the
blaze
<EOS>
,
then
I
looked
round
;
there
was
no
candle
,
but
the
uncertain
light
from
the
hearth
showed
,
by
intervals
,
papered
walls
,
carpet
,
curtains
,
shining
mahogany
furniture
<EOS>
:
it
was
a
parlour
,
not
so
spacious
or
splendid
as
the
drawing
-
room
at
Gateshead
,
but
comfortable
enough
.
<EOS>
I
was
puzzling
to
make
out
the
subject
of
a
picture
on
the
wall
,
when
the
door
opened
,
and
an
individual
carrying
a
light
entered
;
another
followed
close
behind
.
  
<EOS>
The
first
was
a
tall
lady
with
dark
hair
,
dark
eyes
,
and
a
pale
and
large
forehead
;
her
figure
was
partly
enveloped
in
a
shawl
,
her
countenance
was
grave
,
her
bearing
erect
.
  
<EOS>
"
The
child
is
very
young
to
be
sent
alone
,
"
said
she
,
putting
her
candle
down
on
the
table
.
<EOS>
She
considered
me
attentively
for
a
minute
or
two
,
then
further
added
    
"
<EOS>
She
had
better
be
put
to
bed
soon
;
she
looks
tired
:
are
you
tired
?
<EOS>
"
she
asked
,
placing
her
hand
on
my
shoulder
.
  
<EOS>
"
A
little
,
ma'am
.
<EOS>
"
  
"
And
hungry
too
,
no
doubt
:
let
her
have
some
supper
before
she
goes
to
bed
,
Miss
Miller
.
<EOS>
Is
this
the
first
time
you
have
left
your
parents
to
come
to
school
,
my
little
girl
?
"
  
<EOS>
I
explained
to
her
that
I
had
no
parents
.
<EOS>
She
inquired
how
long
they
had
been
dead
:
then
how
old
I
was
,
what
was
my
name
,
whether
I
could
read
,
write
,
and
sew
a
little
:
then
she
touched
my
cheek
gently
with
her
forefinger
,
and
saying
,
"
She
hoped
I
should
be
a
good
child
,
"
dismissed
me
along
with
Miss
Miller
.
  
<EOS>
The
lady
I
had
left
might
be
about
twenty
-
nine
;
the
one
who
went
with
me
appeared
some
years
younger
:
<EOS>
the
first
impressed
me
by
her
voice
,
look
,
and
air
.
<EOS>
Miss
Miller
was
more
ordinary
;
ruddy
in
complexion
,
though
of
a
careworn
countenance
;
hurried
in
gait
and
action
,
like
one
who
had
always
a
multiplicity
of
tasks
on
hand
<EOS>
:
she
looked
,
indeed
,
what
I
afterwards
found
she
really
was
,
an
under
-
teacher
.
<EOS>
Led
by
her
,
I
passed
from
compartment
to
compartment
,
from
passage
to
passage
,
of
a
large
and
irregular
building
;
till
,
emerging
from
the
total
and
somewhat
dreary
silence
pervading
that
portion
of
the
house
we
had
traversed
,
we
came
upon
the
hum
of
many
voices
,
and
presently
entered
a
wide
,
long
room
,
with
great
deal
tables
,
two
at
each
end
,
on
each
of
which
burnt
a
pair
of
candles
,
and
seated
all
round
on
benches
,
a
congregation
of
girls
of
every
age
,
from
nine
or
ten
to
twenty
.
<EOS>
Seen
by
the
dim
light
of
the
dips
,
their
number
to
me
appeared
countless
,
though
not
in
reality
exceeding
eighty
;
they
were
uniformly
dressed
in
brown
stuff
frocks
of
quaint
fashion
,
and
long
holland
pinafores
.
<EOS>
It
was
the
hour
of
study
;
they
were
engaged
in
conning
over
their
to
-
morrow
's
task
,
and
the
hum
I
had
heard
was
the
combined
result
of
their
whispered
repetitions
.
  
<EOS>
Miss
Miller
signed
to
me
to
sit
on
a
bench
near
the
door
,
then
walking
up
to
the
top
of
the
long
room
she
cried
out
    
"
Monitors
,
collect
the
lesson
-
books
and
put
them
away
!
"
  
<EOS>
Four
tall
girls
arose
from
different
tables
,
and
going
round
,
gathered
the
books
and
removed
them
.
<EOS>
Miss
Miller
again
gave
the
word
of
command
    
"
Monitors
,
fetch
the
supper
-
trays
!
"
  
<EOS>
The
tall
girls
went
out
and
returned
presently
,
each
bearing
a
tray
,
with
portions
of
something
,
I
knew
not
<EOS>
what
,
arranged
thereon
,
and
a
pitcher
of
water
and
mug
in
the
middle
of
each
tray
.
<EOS>
The
portions
were
handed
round
;
those
who
liked
took
a
draught
of
the
water
,
the
mug
being
common
to
all
.
<EOS>
When
it
came
to
my
turn
,
I
drank
,
for
I
was
thirsty
,
but
did
not
touch
the
food
,
excitement
and
fatigue
rendering
me
incapable
of
eating
:
<EOS>
I
now
saw
,
however
,
that
it
was
a
thin
oaten
cake
shared
into
fragments
.
  
<EOS>
The
meal
over
,
prayers
were
read
by
Miss
Miller
,
and
the
classes
filed
off
,
two
and
two
,
upstairs
.
<EOS>
Overpowered
by
this
time
with
weariness
,
I
scarcely
noticed
what
sort
of
a
place
the
bedroom
was
,
except
that
,
like
the
schoolroom
,
I
saw
it
was
very
long
.
<EOS>
To
-
night
I
was
to
be
Miss
Miller
's
bed
-
fellow
;
she
helped
me
to
undress
:
when
laid
down
I
glanced
at
the
long
rows
of
beds
,
each
of
which
was
quickly
filled
with
two
occupants
;
in
ten
minutes
the
single
light
was
extinguished
,
and
amidst
silence
and
complete
darkness
I
fell
asleep
.
  
<EOS>
The
night
passed
rapidly
.
<EOS>
I
was
too
tired
even
to
dream
;
I
only
once
awoke
to
hear
the
wind
rave
in
furious
gusts
,
and
the
rain
fall
in
torrents
,
and
to
be
sensible
that
Miss
Miller
had
taken
her
place
by
my
side
.
<EOS>
When
I
again
unclosed
my
eyes
,
a
loud
bell
was
ringing
;
the
girls
were
up
and
dressing
;
day
had
not
yet
begun
to
dawn
,
and
a
rushlight
or
two
burned
in
the
room
.
<EOS>
I
too
rose
reluctantly
;
it
was
bitter
cold
,
and
I
dressed
as
well
as
I
could
for
shivering
,
and
washed
when
there
was
a
basin
at
liberty
,
which
did
not
occur
soon
,
as
there
was
but
one
basin
to
six
girls
,
on
the
stands
down
the
middle
of
the
room
.
<EOS>
Again
the
bell
rang
:
all
formed
in
file
,
two
and
two
,
and
in
that
order
descended
the
stairs
and
entered
the
cold
and
dimly
lit
schoolroom
:
here
prayers
were
read
by
Miss
Miller
;
afterwards
she
called
out
    
"
Form
classes
!
"
  
<EOS>
A
great
tumult
succeeded
for
some
minutes
,
during
which
Miss
Miller
repeatedly
exclaimed
,
"
Silence
!
"
<EOS>
and
"
Order
!
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
When
it
subsided
,
I
saw
them
all
drawn
up
in
four
semicircles
,
before
four
chairs
,
placed
at
the
four
tables
;
all
held
books
in
their
hands
,
and
a
great
book
,
like
a
Bible
,
lay
on
each
table
,
before
the
vacant
seat
.
<EOS>
A
pause
of
some
seconds
succeeded
,
filled
up
by
the
low
,
vague
hum
of
numbers
;
Miss
Miller
walked
from
class
to
class
,
hushing
this
indefinite
sound
.
  
<EOS>
A
distant
bell
tinkled
:
immediately
three
ladies
entered
the
room
<EOS>
,
each
walked
to
a
table
and
took
her
seat
.
<EOS>
Miss
Miller
assumed
the
fourth
vacant
chair
,
which
was
that
nearest
the
door
,
and
around
which
the
smallest
of
the
children
were
assembled
:
to
this
inferior
class
I
was
called
,
and
placed
at
the
bottom
of
it
.
  
<EOS>
Business
now
began
,
the
day
's
Collect
was
repeated
,
then
certain
texts
of
Scripture
were
said
,
and
to
these
succeeded
a
protracted
reading
of
chapters
in
the
Bible
,
which
lasted
an
hour
.
<EOS>
By
the
time
that
exercise
was
terminated
,
day
had
fully
dawned
.
<EOS>
The
indefatigable
bell
now
sounded
for
the
fourth
time
:
the
classes
were
marshalled
and
marched
into
another
room
to
breakfast
:
<EOS>
how
glad
I
was
to
behold
a
prospect
of
getting
something
to
eat
!
<EOS>
I
was
now
nearly
sick
from
inanition
,
having
taken
so
little
the
day
before
.
  
<EOS>
The
refectory
was
a
great
,
low
-
ceiled
,
gloomy
room
;
on
two
long
tables
smoked
basins
of
something
hot
,
which
,
however
,
to
my
dismay
,
sent
forth
an
odour
far
from
inviting
.
<EOS>
I
saw
a
universal
manifestation
of
discontent
when
the
fumes
of
the
repast
met
the
nostrils
of
those
destined
to
swallow
it
;
from
the
van
of
the
procession
,
the
tall
girls
of
the
first
class
,
rose
the
whispered
words
    
"
Disgusting
!
<EOS>
The
porridge
is
burnt
again
!
"
  
<EOS>
"
Silence
!
"
<EOS>
ejaculated
a
voice
;
not
that
of
Miss
Miller
,
but
one
of
the
upper
teachers
,
a
little
and
dark
personage
,
smartly
dressed
,
but
of
somewhat
morose
aspect
,
who
installed
herself
at
the
top
of
one
table
,
while
a
more
buxom
lady
presided
at
the
other
.
<EOS>
I
looked
in
vain
for
her
<EOS>
I
had
first
seen
the
night
before
;
she
was
not
visible
:
Miss
Miller
occupied
the
foot
of
the
table
where
I
sat
,
and
a
strange
,
foreign
-
looking
,
elderly
lady
,
the
French
teacher
,
as
I
afterwards
found
,
took
the
corresponding
seat
at
the
other
board
.
<EOS>
A
long
grace
was
said
and
a
hymn
sung
;
then
a
servant
brought
in
some
tea
for
the
teachers
,
and
the
meal
began
.
  
<EOS>
Ravenous
,
and
now
very
faint
<EOS>
,
I
devoured
a
spoonful
or
two
of
my
portion
without
thinking
of
its
taste
;
but
the
first
edge
of
hunger
blunted
,
I
perceived
I
had
got
in
hand
a
nauseous
mess
;
burnt
porridge
is
almost
as
bad
as
rotten
potatoes
;
famine
itself
soon
sickens
over
it
.
<EOS>
The
spoons
were
moved
slowly
:
I
saw
each
girl
taste
her
food
and
try
to
swallow
it
;
but
in
most
cases
the
effort
was
soon
relinquished
.
<EOS>
Breakfast
was
over
,
and
none
had
breakfasted
.
<EOS>
Thanks
being
returned
for
what
we
had
not
got
,
and
a
second
hymn
chanted
,
the
refectory
was
evacuated
for
the
schoolroom
.
<EOS>
I
was
one
of
the
last
to
go
out
,
and
in
passing
the
tables
,
I
saw
one
teacher
take
a
basin
of
the
porridge
and
taste
it
;
she
looked
at
the
others
;
all
their
countenances
expressed
displeasure
,
and
one
of
them
,
the
stout
one
,
whispered
    
"
Abominable
stuff
!
<EOS>
How
shameful
!
"
  
<EOS>
A
quarter
of
an
hour
passed
before
lessons
again
began
,
during
which
the
schoolroom
was
in
a
glorious
tumult
;
for
that
space
of
time
it
seemed
to
be
permitted
to
talk
loud
and
more
freely
,
and
they
used
their
privilege
.
<EOS>
The
whole
conversation
ran
on
the
breakfast
,
which
one
and
all
abused
roundly
.
<EOS>
Poor
things
!
<EOS>
it
was
the
sole
consolation
they
had
.
<EOS>
Miss
Miller
was
now
the
only
teacher
in
the
room
:
a
group
of
great
girls
standing
about
her
spoke
with
serious
and
sullen
gestures
.
<EOS>
I
heard
the
name
of
Mr.
Brocklehurst
pronounced
by
some
lips
;
at
which
Miss
Miller
shook
her
head
disapprovingly
;
but
she
made
no
great
effort
to
check
the
general
wrath
;
doubtless
she
shared
in
it
.
  
<EOS>
A
clock
in
the
schoolroom
struck
nine
;
Miss
Miller
left
her
circle
,
and
standing
in
the
middle
of
the
room
,
cried
    
"
Silence
!
<EOS>
To
your
seats
!
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
Discipline
prevailed
:
in
five
minutes
the
confused
throng
was
resolved
into
order
,
and
comparative
silence
quelled
the
Babel
clamour
of
tongues
.
<EOS>
The
upper
teachers
now
punctually
resumed
their
posts
:
but
still
,
all
seemed
to
wait
.
<EOS>
Ranged
on
benches
down
the
sides
of
the
room
,
the
eighty
girls
sat
motionless
and
erect
;
a
quaint
assemblage
they
appeared
,
all
with
plain
locks
combed
from
their
faces
,
not
a
curl
visible
;
in
brown
dresses
,
made
high
and
surrounded
by
a
narrow
tucker
about
the
throat
,
with
little
pockets
of
holland
(
shaped
something
like
a
Highlander
's
purse
)
tied
in
front
of
their
frocks
,
and
destined
to
serve
the
purpose
of
a
work
-
bag
:
all
,
too
,
wearing
woollen
stockings
and
country
-
made
shoes
,
fastened
with
brass
buckles
.
<EOS>
Above
twenty
of
those
clad
in
this
costume
were
full
-
grown
girls
,
or
rather
young
women
;
it
suited
them
ill
,
and
gave
an
air
of
oddity
even
to
the
prettiest
.
  
<EOS>
I
was
still
looking
at
them
,
and
also
at
intervals
examining
the
teachers
 
<EOS>
none
of
whom
precisely
pleased
me
;
for
the
stout
one
was
a
little
coarse
,
the
dark
one
not
a
little
fierce
,
the
foreigner
harsh
and
grotesque
,
and
Miss
Miller
,
poor
thing
!
<EOS>
looked
purple
,
weather
-
beaten
,
and
over
-
worked
 
<EOS>
when
,
as
my
eye
wandered
from
face
to
face
,
the
whole
school
rose
simultaneously
,
as
if
moved
by
a
common
spring
.
  
<EOS>
What
was
the
matter
?
<EOS>
I
had
heard
no
order
given
:
I
was
puzzled
.
<EOS>
Ere
I
had
gathered
my
wits
,
the
classes
were
again
seated
:
but
as
all
eyes
were
now
turned
to
one
point
,
mine
followed
the
general
direction
,
and
encountered
the
personage
who
had
received
me
last
night
.
<EOS>
She
stood
at
the
bottom
of
the
long
room
,
on
the
hearth
;
for
there
was
a
fire
at
each
end
;
she
surveyed
the
two
rows
of
girls
silently
and
gravely
.
<EOS>
Miss
Miller
approaching
,
seemed
to
ask
her
a
question
,
and
having
received
her
answer
,
went
back
to
her
place
,
and
said
aloud
    
"
Monitor
of
the
first
class
,
fetch
the
globes
!
"
  
<EOS>
While
the
direction
was
being
executed
,
the
lady
consulted
moved
slowly
up
the
room
.
<EOS>
I
suppose
I
have
a
considerable
organ
of
veneration
,
for
I
retain
yet
the
sense
of
admiring
awe
with
which
my
eyes
traced
her
steps
.
<EOS>
Seen
now
,
in
broad
daylight
,
she
looked
tall
,
fair
,
and
shapely
;
brown
eyes
with
a
benignant
light
in
their
irids
,
and
a
fine
pencilling
of
long
lashes
round
,
relieved
the
whiteness
of
her
large
front
;
on
each
of
her
temples
<EOS>
her
hair
,
of
a
very
dark
brown
,
was
clustered
in
round
curls
,
according
to
the
fashion
of
those
times
,
when
neither
smooth
bands
nor
long
ringlets
were
in
vogue
;
her
dress
,
also
in
the
mode
of
the
day
,
was
of
purple
cloth
,
relieved
by
a
sort
of
Spanish
trimming
of
black
velvet
;
a
gold
watch
(
watches
were
not
so
common
then
as
now
)
shone
at
her
girdle
.
<EOS>
Let
the
reader
add
,
to
complete
the
picture
,
refined
features
;
a
complexion
,
if
pale
,
clear
;
and
a
stately
air
and
carriage
,
and
he
will
have
,
at
least
,
as
clearly
as
words
can
give
it
,
a
correct
idea
of
the
exterior
of
Miss
Temple
 
Maria
Temple
,
as
I
afterwards
saw
the
name
written
in
a
prayer
-
book
intrusted
to
me
to
carry
to
church
.
  
<EOS>
The
superintendent
of
Lowood
(
for
such
was
this
lady
)
having
taken
her
seat
before
a
pair
of
globes
placed
on
one
of
the
tables
,
summoned
the
first
class
round
her
,
and
commenced
giving
a
lesson
on
geography
;
the
lower
classes
were
called
by
the
teachers
:
repetitions
in
history
,
grammar
,
&
c.
,
went
on
for
an
hour
;
writing
and
arithmetic
succeeded
,
and
music
lessons
were
given
by
Miss
Temple
to
some
of
the
elder
girls
.
<EOS>
The
duration
of
each
lesson
was
measured
by
the
clock
,
which
at
last
struck
twelve
.
<EOS>
The
superintendent
rose
    
"
I
have
a
word
to
address
to
the
pupils
,
"
said
she
.
  
<EOS>
The
tumult
of
cessation
from
lessons
was
already
breaking
forth
,
but
it
sank
at
her
voice
.
<EOS>
She
went
on
    
<EOS>
"
You
had
this
morning
a
breakfast
which
you
could
not
eat
;
you
must
be
hungry
:
 
<EOS>
I
have
ordered
that
a
lunch
of
bread
and
cheese
shall
be
served
to
all
.
"
  
<EOS>
The
teachers
looked
at
her
with
a
sort
of
surprise
.
  
<EOS>
"
It
is
to
be
done
on
my
responsibility
,
"
she
added
,
in
an
explanatory
tone
to
them
,
and
immediately
afterwards
left
the
room
.
  
<EOS>
The
bread
and
cheese
was
presently
brought
in
and
distributed
,
to
the
high
delight
and
refreshment
of
the
whole
school
.
<EOS>
The
order
was
now
given
"
To
the
garden
!
"
<EOS>
Each
put
on
a
coarse
straw
bonnet
,
with
strings
of
coloured
calico
,
and
a
cloak
of
grey
frieze
.
<EOS>
I
was
similarly
equipped
,
and
,
following
the
stream
,
I
made
my
way
into
the
open
air
.
  
<EOS>
The
garden
was
a
wide
inclosure
,
surrounded
with
walls
so
high
as
to
exclude
every
glimpse
of
prospect
;
a
covered
verandah
ran
down
one
side
,
and
broad
walks
bordered
a
middle
space
divided
into
scores
of
little
beds
:
these
beds
were
assigned
as
gardens
for
the
pupils
to
cultivate
,
and
each
bed
had
an
owner
.
<EOS>
When
full
of
flowers
they
would
doubtless
look
pretty
;
but
now
,
at
the
latter
end
of
January
,
all
was
wintry
blight
and
brown
decay
.
<EOS>
I
shuddered
as
I
stood
and
looked
round
me
:
it
was
an
inclement
day
for
outdoor
exercise
;
not
positively
rainy
,
but
darkened
by
a
drizzling
yellow
fog
;
all
under
foot
was
still
soaking
wet
with
the
floods
of
yesterday
.
<EOS>
The
stronger
among
the
girls
ran
about
and
engaged
in
active
games
,
but
sundry
pale
and
thin
ones
herded
together
for
shelter
and
warmth
in
the
verandah
;
and
amongst
these
,
as
the
dense
mist
penetrated
to
their
shivering
frames
<EOS>
,
I
heard
frequently
the
sound
of
a
hollow
cough
.
  
<EOS>
As
yet
I
had
spoken
to
no
one
,
nor
did
anybody
seem
to
take
notice
of
me
<EOS>
;
I
stood
lonely
enough
:
but
to
that
feeling
of
isolation
<EOS>
I
was
accustomed
;
it
did
not
oppress
me
much
.
<EOS>
I
leant
against
a
pillar
of
the
verandah
,
drew
my
grey
mantle
close
about
me
,
and
,
trying
to
forget
the
cold
which
nipped
me
without
,
and
the
unsatisfied
hunger
which
gnawed
me
within
,
delivered
myself
up
to
the
employment
of
watching
and
thinking
.
<EOS>
My
reflections
were
too
undefined
and
fragmentary
to
merit
record
:
I
hardly
yet
knew
where
I
was
;
Gateshead
and
my
past
life
seemed
floated
away
to
an
immeasurable
distance
;
the
present
was
vague
and
strange
,
and
of
the
future
I
could
form
no
conjecture
.
<EOS>
I
looked
round
the
convent
-
like
garden
,
and
then
up
at
the
house
 
<EOS>
a
large
building
,
half
of
which
seemed
grey
and
old
,
the
other
half
quite
new
.
<EOS>
The
new
part
,
containing
the
schoolroom
and
dormitory
,
was
lit
by
mullioned
and
latticed
windows
,
which
gave
it
a
church
-
like
aspect
;
a
stone
tablet
over
the
door
bore
this
inscription
:
    
"
Lowood
Institution
.
 
<EOS>
This
portion
was
rebuilt
A.D.
,
by
Naomi
Brocklehurst
,
of
Brocklehurst
Hall
,
in
this
county
.
"
<EOS>
"
Let
your
light
so
shine
before
men
,
that
they
may
see
your
good
works
,
and
glorify
your
Father
which
is
in
heaven
.
"
 
<EOS>
St.
Matt
.
<EOS>
v.
16
.
  
<EOS>
I
read
these
words
over
and
over
again
:
I
felt
that
an
explanation
belonged
to
them
,
and
was
unable
fully
to
penetrate
their
import
.
<EOS>
I
was
still
pondering
the
signification
of
"
Institution
,
"
and
endeavouring
to
make
out
a
connection
between
the
first
words
and
the
verse
of
Scripture
,
when
the
sound
of
a
cough
close
behind
me
made
me
turn
my
head
.
<EOS>
I
saw
a
girl
sitting
on
a
stone
bench
near
;
she
was
bent
over
a
book
,
on
the
perusal
of
which
<EOS>
she
seemed
intent
:
from
where
I
stood
I
could
see
the
title
 
<EOS>
it
was
"
Rasselas
;
"
a
name
that
struck
me
as
strange
,
and
consequently
attractive
.
<EOS>
In
turning
a
leaf
she
happened
to
look
up
,
and
I
said
to
her
directly
    
"
Is
your
book
interesting
?
<EOS>
"
I
had
already
formed
the
intention
of
asking
her
to
lend
it
to
me
some
day
.
  
<EOS>
"
I
like
it
,
"
she
answered
,
after
a
pause
of
a
second
or
two
,
during
which
she
examined
me
.
  
<EOS>
"
What
is
it
about
?
<EOS>
"
I
continued
.
<EOS>
I
hardly
know
where
I
found
the
hardihood
thus
to
open
a
conversation
with
a
stranger
;
the
step
was
contrary
to
my
nature
and
habits
:
<EOS>
but
I
think
her
occupation
touched
a
chord
of
sympathy
somewhere
;
for
I
too
liked
reading
,
though
of
a
frivolous
and
childish
kind
;
I
could
not
digest
or
comprehend
the
serious
or
substantial
.
  
<EOS>
"
You
may
look
at
it
,
"
replied
the
girl
,
offering
me
the
book
.
  
<EOS>
I
did
so
;
a
brief
examination
convinced
me
that
the
contents
were
less
taking
than
the
title
:
"
Rasselas
"
looked
dull
to
my
trifling
taste
;
I
saw
nothing
about
fairies
,
nothing
about
genii
;
no
bright
variety
seemed
spread
over
the
closely
-
printed
pages
.
<EOS>
I
returned
it
to
her
;
she
received
it
quietly
,
and
without
saying
anything
she
was
about
to
relapse
into
her
former
studious
mood
:
again
I
ventured
to
disturb
her
    
"
Can
you
tell
me
what
the
writing
on
that
stone
over
the
door
means
?
<EOS>
What
is
Lowood
Institution
?
<EOS>
"
  
"
This
house
where
you
are
come
to
live
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
And
why
do
they
call
it
Institution
?
<EOS>
Is
it
in
any
way
different
from
other
schools
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
It
is
partly
a
charity
-
school
:
<EOS>
you
and
I
,
and
all
the
rest
of
us
,
are
charity
-
children
.
<EOS>
I
suppose
you
are
an
orphan
:
are
not
either
your
father
or
your
mother
dead
?
"
  
<EOS>
"
Both
died
before
I
can
remember
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Well
,
all
the
girls
here
have
lost
either
one
or
both
parents
,
and
this
is
called
an
institution
for
educating
orphans
.
<EOS>
"
  
"
Do
we
pay
no
money
?
<EOS>
Do
they
keep
us
for
nothing
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
We
pay
,
or
our
friends
pay
,
fifteen
pounds
a
year
for
each
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Then
why
do
they
call
us
charity
-
children
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Because
fifteen
pounds
is
not
enough
for
board
and
teaching
,
and
the
deficiency
is
supplied
by
subscription
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Who
subscribes
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Different
benevolent
-
minded
ladies
and
gentlemen
in
this
neighbourhood
and
in
London
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Who
was
Naomi
Brocklehurst
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
The
lady
who
built
the
new
part
of
this
house
as
that
tablet
records
,
and
whose
son
overlooks
and
directs
everything
here
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Why
?
"
  
<EOS>
"
Because
he
is
treasurer
and
manager
of
the
establishment
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Then
this
house
does
not
belong
to
that
tall
lady
who
wears
a
watch
,
and
who
said
we
were
to
have
some
bread
and
cheese
?
<EOS>
"
  
"
<EOS>
To
Miss
Temple
?
<EOS>
Oh
,
no
!
<EOS>
I
wish
it
did
:
she
has
to
answer
to
Mr.
Brocklehurst
for
all
she
does
.
<EOS>
Mr.
Brocklehurst
buys
all
our
food
and
all
our
clothes
.
<EOS>
"
  
"
Does
he
live
here
?
<EOS>
"
  
"
<EOS>
No
 
two
miles
off
,
at
a
large
hall
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Is
he
a
good
man
?
"
  
<EOS>
"
He
is
a
clergyman
,
and
is
said
to
do
a
great
deal
of
good
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Did
you
say
that
tall
lady
was
called
Miss
Temple
?
<EOS>
"
  
"
<EOS>
Yes
.
"
  
<EOS>
"
And
what
are
the
other
teachers
called
?
"
  
<EOS>
"
The
one
with
red
cheeks
is
called
Miss
Smith
;
she
attends
to
the
work
,
and
cuts
out
 
for
we
make
our
own
clothes
,
our
frocks
,
and
pelisses
,
and
everything
;
the
little
one
with
black
hair
is
Miss
Scatcherd
;
she
teaches
history
and
grammar
,
and
hears
the
second
class
repetitions
;
and
the
one
who
wears
a
shawl
,
and
has
a
pocket
-
handkerchief
tied
to
her
side
with
a
yellow
ribband
,
is
Madame
Pierrot
:
<EOS>
she
comes
from
Lisle
,
in
France
,
and
teaches
French
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Do
you
like
the
teachers
?
<EOS>
"
  
"
Well
enough
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Do
you
like
the
little
black
one
,
and
the
Madame
?
 
<EOS>
I
can
not
pronounce
her
name
as
you
do
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Miss
Scatcherd
is
hasty
 
<EOS>
you
must
take
care
not
to
offend
her
;
Madame
Pierrot
is
not
a
bad
sort
of
person
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
But
Miss
Temple
is
the
best
 
is
n't
she
?
"
  
<EOS>
"
Miss
Temple
is
very
good
and
very
clever
;
she
is
above
the
rest
,
because
she
knows
far
more
than
they
do
.
<EOS>
"
  
"
Have
you
been
long
here
?
"
  
"
Two
years
.
<EOS>
"
  
"
Are
you
an
orphan
?
"
  
<EOS>
"
My
mother
is
dead
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Are
you
happy
here
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
You
ask
rather
too
many
questions
.
<EOS>
I
have
given
you
answers
enough
for
the
present
:
now
I
want
to
read
.
"
  
<EOS>
But
at
that
moment
the
summons
sounded
for
dinner
;
all
re
-
entered
the
house
.
<EOS>
The
odour
which
now
filled
the
refectory
was
scarcely
more
appetising
than
that
which
had
regaled
our
nostrils
at
breakfast
:
the
dinner
was
served
in
two
huge
tin
-
plated
vessels
,
whence
rose
a
strong
steam
redolent
of
rancid
fat
.
<EOS>
I
found
the
mess
to
consist
of
indifferent
potatoes
and
strange
shreds
of
rusty
meat
,
mixed
and
cooked
together
.
<EOS>
Of
this
preparation
a
tolerably
abundant
plateful
was
apportioned
to
each
pupil
.
<EOS>
I
ate
what
I
could
,
and
wondered
within
myself
whether
every
day
's
fare
would
be
like
this
.
  
<EOS>
After
dinner
,
we
immediately
adjourned
to
the
schoolroom
:
lessons
recommenced
,
and
were
continued
till
five
o'clock
.
  
<EOS>
The
only
marked
event
of
the
afternoon
was
,
that
I
saw
the
girl
with
whom
I
had
conversed
in
the
verandah
dismissed
in
disgrace
by
Miss
Scatcherd
from
a
history
class
,
and
sent
to
stand
in
the
middle
of
the
large
schoolroom
.
<EOS>
The
punishment
seemed
to
me
in
a
high
degree
ignominious
,
especially
for
so
great
a
girl
 
<EOS>
she
looked
thirteen
or
upwards
.
<EOS>
I
expected
she
would
show
signs
of
great
distress
and
shame
;
but
to
my
surprise
she
neither
wept
nor
blushed
:
composed
,
though
grave
,
she
stood
,
the
central
mark
of
all
eyes
.
<EOS>
"
How
can
she
bear
it
so
quietly
 
so
firmly
?
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
I
asked
of
myself
.
<EOS>
"
Were
I
in
her
place
,
it
seems
to
me
I
should
wish
the
earth
to
open
and
swallow
me
up
.
<EOS>
She
looks
as
if
she
were
thinking
of
something
beyond
her
punishment
 
beyond
her
situation
:
of
something
not
round
her
nor
before
her
.
<EOS>
I
have
heard
of
day
-
dreams
 
<EOS>
is
she
in
a
day
-
dream
now
?
<EOS>
Her
eyes
are
fixed
on
the
floor
,
but
I
am
sure
they
do
not
see
it
 
<EOS>
her
sight
seems
turned
in
,
gone
down
into
her
heart
:
she
is
looking
at
what
she
can
remember
,
I
believe
;
not
at
what
is
really
present
.
<EOS>
I
wonder
what
sort
of
a
girl
she
is
 
whether
good
or
naughty
.
"
  
<EOS>
Soon
after
five
p.m.
we
had
another
meal
,
consisting
of
a
small
mug
of
coffee
,
and
half
-
a
-
slice
of
brown
bread
.
<EOS>
I
devoured
my
bread
and
drank
my
coffee
with
relish
;
but
I
should
have
been
glad
of
as
much
more
 
<EOS>
I
was
still
hungry
.
<EOS>
Half
-
an
-
hour
's
recreation
succeeded
,
then
study
;
then
the
glass
of
water
and
the
piece
of
oat
-
cake
,
prayers
,
and
bed
.
<EOS>
Such
was
my
first
day
at
Lowood
.
    
<EOS>
The
next
day
commenced
as
before
,
getting
up
and
dressing
by
rushlight
;
but
this
morning
we
were
obliged
to
dispense
with
the
ceremony
of
washing
;
the
water
in
the
pitchers
was
frozen
.
<EOS>
A
change
had
taken
place
in
the
weather
the
preceding
evening
,
and
a
keen
north
-
east
wind
,
whistling
through
the
crevices
of
our
bedroom
windows
all
night
long
,
had
made
us
shiver
in
our
beds
,
and
turned
the
contents
of
the
ewers
to
ice
.
  
<EOS>
Before
the
long
hour
and
a
half
of
prayers
and
Bible
-
reading
was
over
,
I
felt
ready
to
perish
with
cold
.
<EOS>
Breakfast
-
time
came
at
last
,
and
this
morning
the
porridge
was
not
burnt
;
the
quality
was
eatable
,
the
quantity
small
.
<EOS>
How
small
my
portion
seemed
!
<EOS>
I
wished
it
had
been
doubled
.
  
<EOS>
In
the
course
of
the
day
I
was
enrolled
a
member
of
the
fourth
class
,
and
regular
tasks
and
occupations
were
assigned
me
:
<EOS>
hitherto
,
I
had
only
been
a
spectator
of
the
proceedings
at
Lowood
;
I
was
now
to
become
an
actor
therein
.
<EOS>
At
first
,
being
little
accustomed
to
learn
by
heart
,
the
lessons
appeared
to
me
both
long
and
difficult
;
the
frequent
change
from
task
to
task
,
too
,
bewildered
me
;
and
I
was
glad
when
,
about
three
o'clock
in
the
afternoon
,
Miss
Smith
put
into
my
hands
a
border
of
muslin
two
yards
long
,
together
with
needle
,
thimble
,
&
c.
,
and
sent
me
to
sit
in
a
quiet
corner
of
the
schoolroom
,
with
directions
to
hem
the
same
.
<EOS>
At
that
hour
most
of
the
others
were
sewing
likewise
;
but
one
class
still
stood
round
Miss
Scatcherd
's
chair
reading
,
and
as
all
was
quiet
,
the
subject
of
their
lessons
could
be
heard
,
together
with
the
manner
in
which
each
girl
acquitted
herself
,
and
the
animadversions
or
commendations
of
Miss
Scatcherd
on
the
performance
.
<EOS>
It
was
English
history
:
among
the
readers
I
observed
my
acquaintance
of
the
verandah
:
at
the
commencement
of
the
lesson
,
her
place
had
been
at
the
top
of
the
class
,
but
for
some
error
of
pronunciation
,
or
some
inattention
to
stops
,
she
was
suddenly
sent
to
the
very
bottom
.
<EOS>
Even
in
that
obscure
position
,
Miss
Scatcherd
continued
to
make
her
an
object
of
constant
notice
:
she
was
continually
addressing
to
her
such
phrases
as
the
following
:
    
"
Burns
"
(
<EOS>
such
it
seems
was
her
name
:
the
girls
here
were
all
called
by
their
surnames
,
as
boys
are
elsewhere
)
,
"
Burns
,
you
are
standing
on
the
side
of
your
shoe
;
turn
your
toes
out
immediately
.
"
<EOS>
"
Burns
,
you
poke
your
chin
most
unpleasantly
;
draw
it
in
.
"
<EOS>
"
Burns
,
I
insist
on
your
holding
your
head
up
;
I
will
not
have
you
before
me
in
that
attitude
,
"
&
c.
&
c.
  
<EOS>
A
chapter
having
been
read
through
twice
,
the
books
were
closed
and
the
girls
examined
.
<EOS>
The
lesson
had
comprised
part
of
the
reign
of
Charles
I.
,
and
there
were
sundry
questions
about
tonnage
and
poundage
and
ship-
money
,
which
most
of
them
appeared
unable
to
answer
;
still
,
every
little
difficulty
was
solved
instantly
when
it
reached
Burns
:
her
memory
seemed
to
have
retained
the
substance
of
the
whole
lesson
,
and
she
was
ready
with
answers
on
every
point
.
<EOS>
I
kept
expecting
that
Miss
Scatcherd
would
praise
her
attention
;
but
,
instead
of
that
,
she
suddenly
cried
out
    
"
You
dirty
,
disagreeable
girl
!
<EOS>
you
have
never
cleaned
your
nails
this
morning
!
"
  
<EOS>
Burns
made
no
answer
:
I
wondered
at
her
silence
.
<EOS>
"
Why
,
"
thought
I
,
"
does
she
not
explain
that
she
could
neither
clean
her
nails
nor
wash
her
face
,
as
the
water
was
frozen
?
"
  
<EOS>
My
attention
was
now
called
off
by
Miss
Smith
desiring
me
to
hold
a
skein
of
thread
:
while
she
was
winding
it
,
she
talked
to
me
from
time
to
time
,
asking
whether
I
had
ever
been
at
school
before
,
whether
I
could
mark
,
stitch
,
knit
,
&
c.
;
till
she
dismissed
me
,
I
could
not
pursue
my
observations
on
Miss
Scatcherd
's
movements
.
<EOS>
When
I
returned
to
my
seat
,
that
lady
was
just
delivering
an
order
of
which
I
did
not
catch
the
import
;
but
Burns
immediately
left
the
class
,
and
going
into
the
small
inner
room
where
the
books
were
kept
,
returned
in
half
a
minute
,
carrying
in
her
hand
a
bundle
of
twigs
tied
together
at
one
end
.
<EOS>
This
ominous
tool
she
presented
to
Miss
Scatcherd
with
a
respectful
curtesy
;
then
she
quietly
,
and
without
being
told
,
unloosed
her
pinafore
,
and
the
teacher
instantly
and
sharply
inflicted
on
her
neck
a
dozen
strokes
with
the
bunch
of
twigs
.
<EOS>
Not
a
tear
rose
to
Burns
'
eye
;
and
,
while
I
paused
from
my
sewing
,
because
my
fingers
quivered
at
this
spectacle
with
a
sentiment
of
unavailing
and
impotent
anger
,
not
a
feature
of
her
pensive
face
altered
its
ordinary
expression
.
  
<EOS>
"
Hardened
girl
!
"
exclaimed
Miss
Scatcherd
;
"
nothing
can
correct
you
of
your
slatternly
habits
:
carry
the
rod
away
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
Burns
obeyed
:
I
looked
at
her
narrowly
as
she
emerged
from
the
book
-
closet
;
she
was
just
putting
back
her
handkerchief
into
her
pocket
,
and
the
trace
of
a
tear
glistened
on
her
thin
cheek
.
  
<EOS>
The
play
-
hour
in
the
evening
I
thought
the
pleasantest
fraction
of
the
day
at
Lowood
:
the
bit
of
bread
,
the
draught
of
coffee
swallowed
at
five
o'clock
had
revived
vitality
,
if
it
had
not
satisfied
hunger
:
the
long
restraint
of
the
day
was
slackened
;
the
schoolroom
felt
warmer
than
in
the
morning
 
its
fires
being
allowed
to
burn
a
little
more
brightly
,
to
supply
,
in
some
measure
,
the
place
of
candles
,
not
yet
introduced
:
the
ruddy
gloaming
,
the
licensed
uproar
,
the
confusion
of
many
voices
gave
one
a
welcome
sense
of
liberty
.
  
<EOS>
On
the
evening
of
the
day
on
which
I
had
seen
Miss
Scatcherd
flog
her
pupil
,
Burns
,
I
wandered
as
usual
among
the
forms
and
tables
and
laughing
groups
without
a
companion
,
yet
not
feeling
lonely
:
when
I
passed
the
windows
,
<EOS>
I
now
and
then
lifted
a
blind
,
and
looked
out
;
it
snowed
fast
,
a
drift
was
already
forming
against
the
lower
panes
;
putting
my
ear
close
to
the
window
,
I
could
distinguish
from
the
gleeful
tumult
within
,
the
disconsolate
moan
of
the
wind
outside
.
  
<EOS>
Probably
,
if
I
had
lately
left
a
good
home
and
kind
parents
,
this
would
have
been
the
hour
when
I
should
most
keenly
have
regretted
the
separation
;
that
wind
would
then
have
saddened
my
heart
;
this
obscure
chaos
would
have
disturbed
my
peace
!
<EOS>
as
it
was
,
I
derived
from
both
a
strange
excitement
,
and
reckless
and
feverish
,
I
wished
the
wind
to
howl
more
wildly
,
the
gloom
to
deepen
to
darkness
,
and
the
confusion
to
rise
to
clamour
.
  
<EOS>
Jumping
over
forms
,
and
creeping
under
tables
,
I
made
my
way
to
one
of
the
fire
-
places
;
there
,
kneeling
by
the
high
wire
fender
,
I
found
Burns
,
absorbed
,
silent
,
<EOS>
abstracted
from
all
round
her
by
the
companionship
of
a
book
,
which
she
read
by
the
dim
glare
of
the
embers
.
  
<EOS>
"
Is
it
still
"
Rasselas
'
?
<EOS>
"
I
asked
,
coming
behind
her
.
  
<EOS>
"
Yes
,
"
she
said
,
"
and
<EOS>
I
have
just
finished
it
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
And
in
five
minutes
more
she
shut
it
up
.
<EOS>
I
was
glad
of
this
.
"
<EOS>
Now
,
"
thought
I
,
"
I
can
perhaps
get
her
to
talk
.
<EOS>
"
I
sat
down
by
her
on
the
floor
.
  
<EOS>
"
What
is
your
name
besides
Burns
?
"
  
<EOS>
"
Helen
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Do
you
come
a
long
way
from
here
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
come
from
a
place
farther
north
,
quite
on
the
borders
of
Scotland
.
<EOS>
"
  
"
Will
you
ever
go
back
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
hope
so
;
but
nobody
can
be
sure
of
the
future
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
You
must
wish
to
leave
Lowood
?
"
  
<EOS>
"
No
!
why
should
I
?
<EOS>
I
was
sent
to
Lowood
to
get
an
education
;
and
it
would
be
of
no
use
going
away
until
I
have
attained
that
object
.
<EOS>
"
  
"
But
that
teacher
,
Miss
Scatcherd
,
is
so
cruel
to
you
?
"
  
"
<EOS>
Cruel
?
<EOS>
Not
at
all
!
<EOS>
She
is
severe
:
she
dislikes
my
faults
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
And
if
I
were
in
your
place
I
should
dislike
her
;
I
should
resist
her
.
<EOS>
If
she
struck
me
with
that
rod
,
I
should
get
it
from
her
hand
;
I
should
break
it
under
her
nose
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Probably
you
would
do
nothing
of
the
sort
:
but
if
you
did
,
Mr.
Brocklehurst
would
expel
you
from
the
school
;
that
would
be
a
great
grief
to
your
relations
.
<EOS>
It
is
far
better
to
endure
patiently
a
smart
which
nobody
feels
<EOS>
but
yourself
,
than
to
commit
a
hasty
action
whose
evil
consequences
will
extend
to
all
connected
with
you
;
and
besides
,
the
Bible
bids
us
return
good
for
evil
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
But
then
it
seems
disgraceful
to
be
flogged
,
and
to
be
sent
to
stand
in
the
middle
of
a
room
full
of
people
;
and
you
are
such
a
great
girl
:
<EOS>
I
am
far
younger
than
you
,
and
I
could
not
bear
it
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Yet
it
would
be
your
duty
to
bear
it
,
if
you
could
not
avoid
it
:
it
is
weak
and
silly
to
say
you
_
can
not
bear
_
<EOS>
what
it
is
your
fate
to
be
required
to
bear
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
I
heard
her
with
wonder
:
I
could
not
comprehend
this
doctrine
of
endurance
;
and
still
less
could
I
understand
or
sympathise
with
the
forbearance
she
expressed
for
her
chastiser
.
<EOS>
Still
I
felt
that
Helen
Burns
considered
things
by
a
light
invisible
to
my
eyes
.
<EOS>
I
suspected
she
might
be
right
<EOS>
and
I
wrong
;
<EOS>
but
I
would
not
ponder
the
matter
deeply
;
like
Felix
,
I
put
it
off
to
a
more
convenient
season
.
  
<EOS>
"
You
say
you
have
faults
,
Helen
:
what
are
they
?
<EOS>
To
me
you
seem
very
good
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Then
learn
from
me
,
not
to
judge
by
appearances
:
I
am
,
as
Miss
Scatcherd
said
,
slatternly
;
I
seldom
put
,
and
never
keep
,
things
,
in
order
;
I
am
careless
<EOS>
;
I
forget
rules
;
I
read
when
I
should
learn
my
lessons
;
I
have
no
method
;
and
sometimes
I
say
,
like
you
,
I
can
not
_
bear
_
to
be
subjected
to
systematic
arrangements
.
<EOS>
This
is
all
very
provoking
to
Miss
Scatcherd
,
who
is
naturally
neat
,
punctual
,
and
particular
.
"
  
"
<EOS>
And
cross
and
cruel
,
"
I
added
;
but
Helen
Burns
would
not
admit
my
addition
:
she
kept
silence
.
  
<EOS>
"
Is
Miss
Temple
as
severe
to
you
as
Miss
Scatcherd
?
"
  
<EOS>
At
the
utterance
of
Miss
Temple
's
name
,
a
soft
smile
flitted
over
her
grave
face
.
  
<EOS>
"
Miss
Temple
is
full
of
goodness
;
it
pains
her
to
be
severe
to
any
one
,
even
the
worst
in
the
school
:
she
sees
my
errors
,
and
tells
me
of
them
gently
;
and
,
if
I
do
anything
worthy
of
praise
,
she
gives
me
my
meed
liberally
.
<EOS>
One
strong
proof
of
my
wretchedly
defective
nature
is
,
that
even
her
expostulations
,
so
mild
,
so
rational
,
have
not
influence
to
cure
me
of
my
faults
;
and
even
her
praise
,
though
I
value
it
most
highly
,
can
not
stimulate
me
to
continued
care
and
foresight
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
That
is
curious
,
"
said
I
,
"
it
is
so
easy
to
be
careful
.
<EOS>
"
  
"
<EOS>
For
_
you
<EOS>
_
<EOS>
I
have
no
doubt
it
is
.
<EOS>
I
observed
you
in
your
class
this
morning
,
and
saw
you
were
closely
attentive
:
your
thoughts
never
seemed
to
wander
while
Miss
Miller
explained
the
lesson
and
questioned
you
.
<EOS>
Now
,
mine
continually
rove
away
;
when
I
should
be
listening
to
Miss
Scatcherd
,
and
collecting
all
she
says
with
assiduity
,
often
I
lose
the
very
sound
of
her
voice
;
I
fall
into
a
sort
of
dream
.
<EOS>
Sometimes
I
think
I
am
in
Northumberland
,
and
that
the
noises
I
hear
round
me
are
the
bubbling
of
a
little
brook
which
runs
through
Deepden
,
near
our
house
;
 
then
,
<EOS>
when
it
comes
to
my
turn
to
reply
,
I
have
to
be
awakened
;
and
having
heard
nothing
of
what
was
read
for
listening
to
the
visionary
brook
,
I
have
no
answer
ready
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Yet
how
well
you
replied
this
afternoon
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
It
was
mere
chance
;
the
subject
on
which
we
had
been
reading
had
interested
me
.
<EOS>
This
afternoon
,
instead
of
dreaming
of
Deepden
,
I
was
wondering
how
a
man
who
wished
to
do
right
could
act
so
unjustly
and
unwisely
as
Charles
the
First
sometimes
did
;
and
I
thought
what
a
pity
it
was
that
,
with
his
integrity
and
conscientiousness
,
he
could
see
no
farther
than
the
prerogatives
of
the
crown
.
<EOS>
If
he
had
but
been
able
to
look
to
a
distance
,
and
see
how
what
they
call
the
spirit
of
the
age
was
tending
!
<EOS>
Still
,
I
like
Charles
 
<EOS>
I
respect
him
 
<EOS>
I
pity
him
,
poor
murdered
king
!
<EOS>
Yes
,
his
enemies
were
the
worst
:
they
shed
blood
they
had
no
right
to
shed
.
<EOS>
How
dared
they
kill
him
!
"
  
<EOS>
Helen
was
talking
to
herself
now
<EOS>
:
she
had
forgotten
<EOS>
I
could
not
very
well
understand
her
 
that
I
was
ignorant
,
or
nearly
so
,
of
the
subject
she
discussed
.
<EOS>
I
recalled
her
to
my
level
.
  
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
And
when
Miss
Temple
teaches
you
,
do
your
thoughts
wander
then
?
<EOS>
"
  
"
No
,
certainly
,
not
often
;
because
Miss
Temple
has
generally
something
to
say
which
is
newer
than
my
own
reflections
;
her
language
is
singularly
agreeable
to
me
,
and
the
information
she
communicates
is
often
just
what
I
wished
to
gain
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Well
,
then
,
with
Miss
Temple
you
are
good
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Yes
,
in
a
passive
way
:
I
make
no
effort
;
I
follow
as
inclination
guides
me
.
<EOS>
There
is
no
merit
in
such
goodness
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
A
great
deal
:
you
are
good
to
those
who
are
good
to
you
.
<EOS>
It
is
all
I
ever
desire
to
be
.
<EOS>
If
people
were
always
kind
and
obedient
to
those
who
are
cruel
and
unjust
,
the
wicked
people
would
have
it
all
their
own
way
:
they
would
never
feel
afraid
,
and
so
they
would
never
alter
,
but
would
grow
worse
and
worse
.
<EOS>
When
we
are
struck
at
without
a
reason
,
we
should
strike
back
again
very
hard
;
I
am
sure
we
should
 
so
hard
as
to
teach
the
person
who
struck
us
never
to
do
it
again
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
You
will
change
your
mind
,
I
hope
,
when
you
grow
older
:
<EOS>
as
yet
you
are
but
a
little
untaught
girl
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
But
I
feel
this
,
Helen
;
I
must
dislike
those
who
,
whatever
I
do
to
please
them
,
persist
in
disliking
me
;
I
must
resist
those
who
punish
me
unjustly
.
<EOS>
It
is
as
natural
as
that
I
should
love
those
who
show
me
affection
,
or
submit
to
punishment
when
I
feel
it
is
deserved
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Heathens
and
savage
tribes
hold
that
doctrine
,
but
Christians
and
civilised
nations
disown
it
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
How
?
I
do
n't
understand
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
It
is
not
violence
that
best
overcomes
hate
 
nor
vengeance
that
most
certainly
heals
injury
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
What
then
?
"
  
"
Read
the
New
Testament
,
and
observe
what
Christ
says
,
and
how
He
acts
;
make
His
word
your
rule
,
and
His
conduct
your
example
.
"
  
<EOS>
"
What
does
He
say
?
<EOS>
"
  
"
Love
your
enemies
;
bless
them
that
curse
you
;
do
good
to
them
that
hate
you
and
despitefully
use
you
.
"
  
<EOS>
"
Then
I
should
love
Mrs.
Reed
,
which
I
can
not
do
;
I
should
bless
her
son
John
,
which
is
impossible
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
In
her
turn
,
Helen
Burns
asked
me
to
explain
,
and
I
proceeded
forthwith
to
pour
out
,
in
my
own
way
,
the
tale
of
my
sufferings
and
resentments
.
<EOS>
Bitter
and
truculent
when
excited
<EOS>
,
I
spoke
as
I
felt
,
without
reserve
or
softening
.
  
<EOS>
Helen
heard
me
patiently
to
the
end
:
I
expected
she
would
then
make
a
remark
,
but
she
said
nothing
.
  
<EOS>
"
Well
,
"
I
asked
impatiently
,
"
is
not
Mrs.
Reed
a
hard
-
hearted
,
bad
woman
?
"
  
<EOS>
"
She
has
been
unkind
to
you
,
no
doubt
;
because
you
see
,
she
dislikes
your
cast
of
character
,
as
Miss
Scatcherd
does
mine
;
but
how
minutely
you
remember
all
she
has
done
and
said
to
you
!
<EOS>
What
a
singularly
deep
impression
her
injustice
seems
to
have
made
on
your
heart
!
<EOS>
No
ill
-
usage
so
brands
its
record
on
my
feelings
.
<EOS>
Would
you
not
be
happier
if
you
tried
to
forget
her
severity
,
together
with
the
passionate
emotions
it
excited
?
<EOS>
Life
appears
to
me
too
short
to
be
spent
in
nursing
animosity
or
registering
wrongs
.
<EOS>
We
are
,
and
must
be
,
one
and
all
,
burdened
with
faults
in
this
world
:
but
the
time
will
soon
come
when
,
I
trust
,
we
shall
put
them
off
in
putting
off
our
corruptible
bodies
;
when
debasement
and
sin
will
fall
from
us
with
this
cumbrous
frame
of
flesh
,
and
only
the
spark
of
the
spirit
will
remain
,
 
the
impalpable
principle
of
light
and
thought
,
pure
as
when
it
left
the
Creator
to
inspire
the
creature
:
whence
it
came
it
will
return
;
perhaps
again
to
be
communicated
to
some
being
higher
than
man
 
perhaps
to
pass
through
gradations
of
glory
,
from
the
pale
human
soul
to
brighten
to
the
seraph
!
<EOS>
Surely
it
will
never
,
on
the
contrary
,
be
suffered
to
degenerate
from
man
to
fiend
?
<EOS>
No
;
I
can
not
believe
that
:
I
hold
another
creed
:
which
no
one
ever
taught
me
,
and
which
I
seldom
mention
;
but
in
which
I
delight
,
and
to
which
I
cling
:
<EOS>
for
it
extends
hope
to
all
:
it
makes
Eternity
a
rest
 
<EOS>
a
mighty
home
,
not
a
terror
and
an
abyss
.
<EOS>
Besides
,
with
this
creed
,
I
can
so
clearly
distinguish
between
the
criminal
and
his
crime
;
I
can
so
sincerely
forgive
the
first
while
I
abhor
the
last
:
with
this
creed
revenge
never
worries
my
heart
,
degradation
never
too
deeply
disgusts
me
,
injustice
never
crushes
me
too
low
:
I
live
in
calm
,
looking
to
the
end
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
Helen
's
head
,
always
drooping
,
sank
a
little
lower
as
she
finished
this
sentence
.
<EOS>
I
saw
by
her
look
<EOS>
she
wished
no
longer
to
talk
to
me
,
but
rather
to
converse
with
her
own
thoughts
.
<EOS>
She
was
not
allowed
much
time
for
meditation
:
a
monitor
,
a
great
rough
girl
,
presently
came
up
,
exclaiming
in
a
strong
Cumberland
accent
    
"
Helen
Burns
,
if
you
do
n't
go
and
put
your
drawer
in
order
,
and
fold
up
your
work
this
minute
,
I
'll
tell
Miss
Scatcherd
to
come
and
look
at
it
!
"
  
<EOS>
Helen
sighed
as
her
reverie
fled
,
and
getting
up
,
obeyed
the
monitor
without
reply
as
without
delay
.
    
<EOS>
My
first
quarter
at
Lowood
seemed
an
age
;
and
not
the
golden
age
either
;
it
comprised
an
irksome
struggle
with
difficulties
in
habituating
myself
to
new
rules
and
unwonted
tasks
.
<EOS>
The
fear
of
failure
in
these
points
harassed
me
worse
than
the
physical
hardships
of
my
lot
;
though
these
were
no
trifles
.
  
<EOS>
During
January
,
February
,
and
part
of
March
,
the
deep
snows
,
and
,
after
their
melting
,
the
almost
impassable
roads
,
prevented
our
stirring
beyond
the
garden
walls
,
except
to
go
to
church
;
but
within
these
limits
we
had
to
pass
an
hour
every
day
in
the
open
air
.
<EOS>
Our
clothing
was
insufficient
to
protect
us
from
the
severe
cold
:
we
had
no
boots
,
the
snow
got
into
our
shoes
and
melted
there
:
<EOS>
our
ungloved
hands
became
numbed
and
covered
with
chilblains
,
as
were
our
feet
:
I
remember
well
the
distracting
irritation
I
endured
from
this
cause
<EOS>
every
evening
,
when
my
feet
inflamed
;
and
the
torture
of
thrusting
the
swelled
,
raw
,
and
stiff
toes
into
my
shoes
in
the
morning
.
<EOS>
Then
the
scanty
supply
of
food
was
distressing
:
with
the
keen
appetites
of
growing
children
,
we
had
scarcely
sufficient
to
keep
alive
a
delicate
invalid
.
<EOS>
From
this
deficiency
of
nourishment
resulted
an
abuse
,
which
pressed
hardly
on
the
younger
pupils
:
whenever
the
famished
great
girls
had
an
opportunity
,
they
would
coax
or
menace
the
little
ones
out
of
their
portion
.
<EOS>
Many
a
time
I
have
shared
between
two
claimants
the
precious
morsel
of
brown
bread
distributed
at
tea
-
time
;
and
after
relinquishing
to
a
third
half
the
contents
of
my
mug
of
coffee
,
I
have
swallowed
the
remainder
with
an
accompaniment
of
secret
tears
,
forced
from
me
by
the
exigency
of
hunger
.
  
<EOS>
Sundays
were
dreary
days
in
that
wintry
season
.
<EOS>
We
had
to
walk
two
miles
to
Brocklebridge
Church
,
where
our
patron
officiated
.
<EOS>
We
set
out
cold
,
we
arrived
at
church
colder
:
during
the
morning
service
we
became
almost
paralysed
.
<EOS>
It
was
too
far
to
return
to
dinner
,
and
an
allowance
of
cold
meat
and
bread
,
in
the
same
penurious
proportion
observed
in
our
ordinary
meals
,
was
served
round
between
the
services
.
  
<EOS>
At
the
close
of
the
afternoon
service
we
returned
by
an
exposed
and
hilly
road
,
where
the
bitter
winter
wind
,
blowing
over
a
range
of
snowy
summits
to
the
north
,
almost
flayed
the
skin
from
our
faces
.
  
<EOS>
I
can
remember
Miss
Temple
walking
lightly
and
rapidly
along
our
drooping
line
,
her
plaid
cloak
,
which
the
frosty
wind
fluttered
,
gathered
close
about
her
,
and
encouraging
us
,
by
precept
and
example
,
to
keep
up
our
spirits
,
and
march
forward
,
as
she
said
,
"
like
stalwart
soldiers
.
<EOS>
"
The
other
teachers
,
poor
things
,
were
generally
themselves
too
much
dejected
to
attempt
the
task
of
cheering
others
.
  
<EOS>
How
we
longed
for
the
light
and
heat
of
a
blazing
fire
when
we
got
back
!
<EOS>
But
,
to
the
little
ones
at
least
,
this
was
denied
:
each
hearth
in
the
schoolroom
was
immediately
surrounded
by
a
double
row
of
great
girls
,
and
behind
them
the
younger
children
crouched
in
groups
,
wrapping
their
starved
arms
in
their
pinafores
.
  
<EOS>
A
little
solace
came
at
tea
-
time
,
in
the
shape
of
a
double
ration
of
bread
 
<EOS>
a
whole
,
instead
of
a
half
,
slice
 
with
the
delicious
addition
of
a
thin
scrape
of
butter
<EOS>
:
it
was
the
hebdomadal
treat
to
which
we
all
looked
forward
from
Sabbath
to
Sabbath
.
<EOS>
I
generally
contrived
to
reserve
a
moiety
of
this
bounteous
repast
for
myself
;
but
the
remainder
I
was
invariably
obliged
to
part
with
.
  
<EOS>
The
Sunday
evening
was
spent
in
repeating
,
by
heart
,
the
Church
Catechism
,
and
the
fifth
,
sixth
,
and
seventh
chapters
of
St.
Matthew
;
and
in
listening
to
a
long
sermon
,
read
by
Miss
Miller
,
whose
irrepressible
yawns
attested
her
weariness
.
<EOS>
A
frequent
interlude
of
these
performances
was
the
enactment
of
the
part
of
Eutychus
by
some
half
-
dozen
of
little
girls
,
who
,
overpowered
with
sleep
,
would
fall
down
,
if
not
out
of
the
third
loft
,
yet
off
the
fourth
form
,
and
be
taken
up
half
dead
.
<EOS>
The
remedy
was
,
to
thrust
them
forward
into
the
centre
of
the
schoolroom
,
and
oblige
them
to
stand
there
till
the
sermon
was
finished
.
<EOS>
Sometimes
their
feet
failed
them
,
and
they
sank
together
in
a
heap
;
they
were
then
propped
up
with
the
monitors
'
high
stools
.
  
<EOS>
I
have
not
yet
alluded
to
the
visits
of
Mr.
Brocklehurst
;
and
indeed
that
gentleman
was
from
home
during
the
greater
part
of
the
first
month
after
my
arrival
;
perhaps
prolonging
his
stay
with
his
friend
the
archdeacon
:
his
absence
was
a
relief
to
me
.
<EOS>
I
need
not
say
that
I
had
my
own
reasons
for
dreading
his
coming
:
but
come
he
did
at
last
.
  
<EOS>
One
afternoon
(
I
had
then
been
three
weeks
at
Lowood
)
,
as
I
was
sitting
with
a
slate
in
my
hand
,
puzzling
over
a
sum
in
long
division
,
my
eyes
,
raised
in
abstraction
to
the
window
,
caught
sight
of
a
figure
just
passing
:
<EOS>
I
recognised
almost
instinctively
that
gaunt
outline
;
and
when
,
two
minutes
after
,
all
the
school
,
teachers
included
,
rose
_
en
<EOS>
masse
_
<EOS>
,
it
was
not
necessary
for
me
to
look
up
in
order
to
ascertain
whose
entrance
they
thus
greeted
.
<EOS>
A
long
stride
measured
the
schoolroom
,
and
presently
beside
Miss
Temple
,
who
herself
had
risen
,
stood
the
same
black
column
which
had
frowned
on
me
so
ominously
from
the
hearthrug
of
Gateshead
.
<EOS>
I
now
glanced
sideways
at
this
piece
of
architecture
.
<EOS>
Yes
,
I
was
right
:
it
was
Mr.
Brocklehurst
,
buttoned
up
in
a
surtout
,
and
looking
longer
,
narrower
,
and
more
rigid
than
ever
.
  
<EOS>
I
had
my
own
reasons
for
being
dismayed
at
this
apparition
;
too
well
I
remembered
the
perfidious
hints
given
by
Mrs.
Reed
about
my
disposition
,
&
c.
;
the
promise
pledged
by
Mr.
Brocklehurst
to
apprise
Miss
Temple
and
the
teachers
of
my
vicious
nature
.
<EOS>
All
along
I
had
been
dreading
the
fulfilment
of
this
promise
,
 
I
had
been
looking
out
daily
for
the
"
Coming
Man
,
"
whose
information
respecting
my
past
life
and
conversation
was
to
brand
me
as
a
bad
child
for
ever
:
now
there
he
was
.
  
<EOS>
He
stood
at
Miss
Temple
's
side
;
he
was
speaking
low
in
her
ear
:
<EOS>
I
did
not
doubt
he
was
making
disclosures
of
my
villainy
;
and
I
watched
her
eye
with
painful
anxiety
,
expecting
every
moment
to
see
its
dark
orb
turn
on
me
a
glance
of
repugnance
and
contempt
.
<EOS>
I
listened
too
;
and
as
I
happened
to
be
seated
quite
at
the
top
of
the
room
,
I
caught
most
of
what
he
said
:
its
import
relieved
me
from
immediate
apprehension
.
  
<EOS>
"
I
suppose
,
Miss
Temple
,
the
thread
I
bought
at
Lowton
will
do
;
it
struck
me
that
it
would
be
just
of
the
quality
for
the
calico
chemises
,
and
I
sorted
the
needles
to
match
.
<EOS>
You
may
tell
Miss
Smith
that
I
forgot
to
make
a
memorandum
of
the
darning
needles
,
but
she
shall
have
some
papers
sent
in
next
week
;
and
she
is
not
,
on
any
account
,
to
give
out
more
than
one
at
a
time
to
each
pupil
:
if
they
have
more
,
they
are
apt
to
be
careless
and
lose
them
.
<EOS>
And
,
O
ma'am
!
<EOS>
I
wish
the
woollen
stockings
were
better
looked
to
!
 
<EOS>
when
I
was
here
last
,
I
went
into
the
kitchen
-
garden
and
examined
the
clothes
drying
on
the
line
;
there
was
a
quantity
of
black
hose
in
a
very
bad
state
of
repair
:
from
the
size
of
the
holes
in
them
<EOS>
I
was
sure
they
had
not
been
well
mended
from
time
to
time
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
He
paused
.
  
<EOS>
"
Your
directions
shall
be
attended
to
,
sir
,
"
said
Miss
Temple
.
  
<EOS>
"
And
,
ma'am
,
"
he
continued
,
"
the
laundress
tells
me
some
of
the
girls
have
two
clean
tuckers
in
the
week
:
it
is
too
much
;
the
rules
limit
them
to
one
.
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
think
I
can
explain
that
circumstance
,
sir
.
<EOS>
Agnes
and
Catherine
Johnstone
were
invited
to
take
tea
with
some
friends
at
Lowton
last
Thursday
,
and
I
gave

leave
to
put
on
clean
tuckers
for
the
occasion
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
Mr.
Brocklehurst
nodded
.
  
<EOS>
"
Well
,
for
once
it
may
pass
;
but
please
not
to
let
the
circumstance
occur
too
often
.
<EOS>
And
there
is
another
thing
which
surprised
me
;
I
find
,
in
settling
accounts
with
the
housekeeper
,
that
a
lunch
,
consisting
of
bread
and
cheese
,
has
twice
been
served
out
to
the
girls
during
the
past
fortnight
.
<EOS>
How
is
this
?
<EOS>
I
looked
over
the
regulations
,
and
I
find
no
such
meal
as
lunch
mentioned
.
<EOS>
Who
introduced
this
innovation
?
<EOS>
and
by
what
authority
?
"
  
"
I
must
be
responsible
for
the
circumstance
,
sir
,
"
replied
Miss
Temple
:
<EOS>
"
the
breakfast
was
so
ill
prepared
that
the
pupils
could
not
possibly
eat
it
;
and
I
dared
not
allow
them
to
remain

till
dinner

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Madam
,
allow
me
an
instant
.
<EOS>
You
are
aware
that
my
plan
in
bringing
up
these
girls
is
,
not
to
accustom
them
to
habits
of
luxury
and
indulgence
,
but
to
render
them
hardy
,
patient
,
self
-
denying
.
<EOS>
Should
any
little
accidental
disappointment
of
the
appetite
occur
,
such
as
the
spoiling
of
a
meal
,
the
under
or
the
over

of
a

,
the
incident
ought
not
to
be
neutralised
by
replacing
with
something
more
delicate
the
comfort
lost
,
thus
pampering
the
body
and
obviating
the
aim
of
this
institution
;
it
ought
to
be
improved
to
the
spiritual
edification
of
the
pupils
,
by
encouraging
them
to
evince
fortitude
under
temporary

.
<EOS>
A
brief
address
on
those
occasions
would
not
be
mistimed
,
wherein
a
judicious
instructor
would
take
the

of
referring
to
the
sufferings
of
the
primitive

;
to
the

;
to

of
our

Lord
Himself
,
calling

to
take

and

;
to
His
warnings
that
man
shall
not

by

alone
,
but
by
every
word
that
proceedeth
out
of

;
to

divine
consolations
,
"
If
ye
suffer
hunger
or
thirst
for
My
sake
,
happy

.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Oh
,
madam
,
when
you
put
bread
and
cheese
,
instead
of
burnt

,
into
these
children
's
mouths
,
you
may
indeed
feed
their
vile
bodies
,
but
you
little
think
how
you
starve
their
immortal
souls
!
"
  
<EOS>
Mr.
Brocklehurst
again
paused
 
perhaps
overcome
by
his
feelings
.
<EOS>
Miss
Temple
had
looked
down
when
he
first
began
to
speak
to
her
;
but
she
now
gazed
straight
before
her
,
and
her
face
,
naturally
pale
as
marble
,
appeared
to
be
assuming
also
the
coldness
and
fixity
of
that

;
especially
her

,
closed
as
if

have
required
a

's

to

,
and
her

into

.
  
<EOS>
Meantime
,
Mr.
Brocklehurst
,
standing
on

hearth
with

hands
behind

,
majestically
surveyed
the
whole
school
.
<EOS>
Suddenly

gave
a

,
as
if
it
had
met
something
that
either
dazzled
or
shocked
its
pupil
;
turning
<EOS>
,
he
said
in
more

than

"
Miss
Temple
,
Miss
Temple
,
what
 
<EOS>
_
<EOS>
what
_
is
that
girl

?
<EOS>
Red
hair
,

,
curled
 
curled
all

?
"
<EOS>
And

,

.
  
<EOS>
"
It
is
Julia
Severn
,
"

Miss
Temple
,
very

.
  
<EOS>
"
Julia
Severn
,
ma'am
!
<EOS>
And
why

she
,
or
any

,

?
<EOS>
Why
,

,

here

as
to
wear

one

?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Julia
's
hair
curls
naturally
,
"
returned
Miss
Temple
,
still
more

.
  
<EOS>
"
Naturally
!
<EOS>
Yes
,
but
we
are
not
to
conform

nature
;
I
wish
these
girls
to
be
the
children
of
Grace
:
and
why

?
<EOS>
I
have
again

again

that
I
desire
the
hair
to

arranged

,
modestly
,

.
<EOS>
Miss
Temple
,
that
girl
's

must

;
I
will
send

to
-
morrow
:
and
I
see
others
who
have
far
too
much
of
the
excrescence
 
<EOS>
that
tall

,

.
<EOS>
Tell

the

.
"
  
<EOS>
Miss
Temple
passed
her

,
as

smooth

the
involuntary

that

;
she

,
however
,
and
when
the
first
class
could
take
in
what
was
required

,
they

.
<EOS>
Leaning
a
little

,
I
could

the

with

:
it
was
a
pity
Mr.
Brocklehurst
could
not

them
too
;
he
would
perhaps
have
felt
that
,

with

,
the

further

than

.
  
<EOS>
He
scrutinised

reverse
of
these
living
medals
some
five
minutes
,
then
pronounced
sentence
.
<EOS>
These
words
fell
like
the
knell
of
doom
    
"
All
those
top
-
knots
must
be
cut
off
.
"
  
<EOS>
Miss
Temple
seemed
to
remonstrate
.
  
<EOS>
"
Madam
,
"
he

,
"
I
have
a
Master
to
serve
whose

is
not
of
this

:
my
mission
is
to
mortify
in
these
girls
the
lusts
of
the
flesh
;
to
teach

to
clothe
themselves
with
shame

facedness
and
sobriety
,
not
with
braided

and
costly

;
and
each
of
the
young

before
us
has
a
string
of
hair
twisted
in
plaits
which
vanity
itself
might
have
woven
;
these
,
I
repeat
,
must
be
cut
off
;
think
of
the
time
wasted
,
of
 
"
  
<EOS>
Mr.
Brocklehurst
was
here
interrupted
:
three
other
visitors
,
ladies
,
now
entered
the
room
.
<EOS>
They
ought
to
have
come
a
little
sooner
to
have
heard
his
lecture
on
dress
,
for
they
were
splendidly
attired
in
velvet
,
silk
,
and

.
<EOS>
The
two
younger
of
the
trio
(
fine
girls
of
sixteen
and
seventeen
)
had
grey
beaver
hats
,
then
in
fashion
,
shaded
with
ostrich
plumes
,
and
from
under
the
brim
of
this
graceful
head
-
dress
fell
a
profusion
of
light
tresses
,
elaborately
curled
;
the
elder
lady
was
enveloped
in
a
costly
velvet
shawl
,
trimmed
with
ermine
,
and
she
wore
a
false

of
French
