tone
 
<EOS>
"
But
you
are
young
,
Miss
;
and
I
should
say
a
light
sleeper
<EOS>
:
perhaps
you
may
have
heard
a
noise
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
did
,
"
said
I
,
dropping

voice
,
so
that
Leah
,

was
still

,
could
not

,
"
and
at

Pilot
:
<EOS>
but
Pilot
can
not
laugh
;
and
I
am
certain
I
heard

laugh
,
and
a

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
She
took
a
new

of

,
waxed
it
carefully
,
threaded
her
needle
with
a

,
and
then
observed
,
with
perfect
composure
    
<EOS>
"
It
is
hardly
likely
master
would
laugh
,
I
should
think
,
Miss
,
when
he
was
in
such
danger
:
You
must
have
been
dreaming
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
was
not
dreaming
,
"
I
said
,
with
some

,
for
her
brazen
coolness
provoked

.
<EOS>
Again

looked
at
me
;
and
with
the
same
scrutinising
and
conscious

.
  
<EOS>
"
Have
you
told
master
that
you
heard
a
laugh
?
"
<EOS>
she

.
  
<EOS>
"
I
have
not

of
speaking
to

this

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
You
did
not
think
of
opening
your
door
and
looking

the
gallery
?
<EOS>
"
she
further

.
  
<EOS>
She
appeared
to
be
cross
-
questioning
me
,
attempting
to
draw
from
me
<EOS>
information
unawares
.
<EOS>
The
idea
struck
me
that
if
she
discovered
I
knew
or
suspected
her
guilt
,
she
would
be
playing
of
some
of
her
malignant
pranks
on
me
;
I
thought
it
advisable
to
be
on
my
guard
.
  
<EOS>
"
On
the
contrary
,
"
said
I
,
"
I
bolted
my
door
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Then
you
are
not
in
the
habit
of
bolting
your
door
every
night
before
you
get
into
bed
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Fiend
!
<EOS>
she
wants
to
know
my
habits
,
that
she
may
lay
her
plans
accordingly
!
"
<EOS>
Indignation
again
prevailed
over
prudence
:
I
replied
sharply
,
"
Hitherto
I
have
often
omitted
to
fasten
the
bolt
:
<EOS>
I
did
not
think
it
necessary
.
<EOS>
I
was
not
aware
any
danger
or

was
to
be
dreaded
at
Thornfield
Hall
:
but
in
future
"
(
and
I
laid
marked

on

words
)
"
I
shall
take
good
care
to
make
all
secure
before
I
venture
to
lie
down
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
It
will
be
wise
so
to
do
,
"
was
her
answer
:
"
this
neighbourhood
is
as
quiet
as
any
I
know
,
and
I
never
heard
of
the
hall
being
attempted
by
robbers
since
it
was
a
house
;
though
there
are
hundreds
of
pounds
'
worth
of
plate
in
the
plate
-
closet
,
as
is
well
known
.
<EOS>
And
you
see
,
for
such
a
large
house
,
there
are
very
few
servants
,
because
master
has
never
lived
here
much
;
and
when
he
does
come
,
being
a
bachelor
,
he
needs
little
waiting
on
:
<EOS>
but
I
always
think
it
best
to
err
on
the
safe
side
;
a
door
is
soon
fastened
,
and
it
is
as
well
to
have
a
drawn
bolt
between
one
and
any
mischief
that
may
be
about
.
<EOS>
A
deal
of
people
,
Miss
,
are
for
trusting
all
to
Providence
;
but
I
say
Providence
will
not
dispense
with
the
means
,
though
He
often
blesses
them
when
they
are
used
discreetly
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
And
here
she
closed
her
harangue
:
a
long
one
for
her
,
and
uttered
with
the
demureness
of
a
Quakeress
.
  
<EOS>
I
still
stood
absolutely
dumfoundered
at
what
appeared
to
me
her
miraculous
self
-
possession
and
most
inscrutable
hypocrisy
,
when
the
cook
entered
.
  
<EOS>
"
Mrs.
Poole
,
"
said
she
,
addressing
Grace
,
"
the
servants
'
dinner
will
soon
be
ready
:
will
you
come
down
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
No
;
just
put
my
pint
of
porter
and
bit

on
a

,
and
I
'll
carry

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
You
'll
have
some

?
<EOS>
"
  
"
<EOS>
Just
a
morsel
,
and
a
taste
of
cheese
,
that
's
all
.
<EOS>
"
  
"
<EOS>
And
the
sago
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Never
mind
it
at
present
:
I
shall
be
coming
down
before
teatime
:
I
'll
make
it
myself
.
"
  
<EOS>
The
cook
here
turned
to
me
,
saying
that
Mrs.
Fairfax
was
waiting
for
me
:
so
I
departed
.
  
<EOS>
I
hardly
heard
Mrs.
Fairfax
's
account
of
the
curtain
conflagration
during
dinner
,
so
much
was
I
occupied
in
puzzling
my
brains
over
the
enigmatical
character
of
Grace
Poole
,
and
still
more
in
pondering
the
problem
of
her
position
at
Thornfield
and
questioning
why
she
had
not
been
given
into
custody
that
morning
,
or
,
at
the
very
least
,
dismissed
from
her
master
's
service
.
<EOS>
He
had
almost
as
much
as
declared
his
conviction
of
her
criminality
last
night
:
what
mysterious
cause
withheld
him
from
accusing
her
?
<EOS>
Why
had
he
enjoined
me
,
too
,
to
secrecy
?
<EOS>
It
was
strange
:
a
bold
,
vindictive
,
and
haughty
gentleman
seemed
somehow
in
the
power
of
one
of
the
meanest
of
his
dependants
;
so
much
in
her
power
,
that
even
when
she
lifted
her
hand
against
his
life
,
he
dared
not
openly
charge
her
with
the
attempt
,
much
less
punish
her
for
it
.
  
<EOS>
Had
Grace
been
young
and
handsome
,
I
should
have
been
tempted
to
think
that
tenderer
feelings
than
prudence
or
fear
influenced
Mr.
Rochester
in
her
behalf
;
but
,
hard
-
favoured
and
matronly
as
she
was
,
the
idea
could
not
be
admitted
.
"
<EOS>
Yet
,
"
I
reflected
,
"
she
has
been
young
once
;
her
youth
would
be
contemporary
with
her
master
's
:
Mrs.
Fairfax
told
me
once
,
she
had
lived
here
many
years
.
<EOS>
I
do
n't
think
she
can
ever
have
been
pretty
;
but
,
for
aught
I
know
,
she
may
possess
originality
and
strength
of
character
to
compensate
for
the
want
of
personal
advantages
.
<EOS>
Mr.
Rochester
is
an
amateur
of
the
decided
and
eccentric
:
Grace
is
eccentric
at
least
.
<EOS>
What
if
a
former
caprice
(
a
freak
very
possible
to
a
nature
so
sudden
and
headstrong
as
his
)
has
delivered
him
into
her
power
,
and
she
now
exercises
over
his
actions
a
secret
influence
,
the
result
of
his
own
indiscretion
,
which
he
can
not
shake
off
,
and
dare
not
disregard
?
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
But
,
having
reached
this
point
of
conjecture
,
Mrs.
Poole
's
square
,
flat
figure
,
and
uncomely
,
dry
,
even
coarse
face
,
recurred
so
distinctly
to
my
mind
's
eye
,
that
I
thought
,
"
No
;
impossible
!
<EOS>
my
supposition
can
not
be
correct
.
<EOS>
Yet
,
"
suggested
the
secret
voice
which
talks
to
us
in
our
own
hearts
,
"
you
are
not
beautiful
either
,
and
perhaps
Mr.
Rochester
approves
you
:
at
any
rate
,
you
have
often
felt
as
if
he
did
;
and
last
night
 
remember
his
words
;
remember
his
look
;
remember
his
voice
!
"
  
<EOS>
I
well
remembered
all
;
language
,
glance
,
and
tone
seemed
at
the
moment
vividly
renewed
.
<EOS>
I
was
now
in
the
schoolroom
;
Adele
was
drawing
;
I
bent
over
her
and
directed
her
pencil
.
<EOS>
She
looked
up
with
a
sort
of
start
.
  
<EOS>
"
Qu
'
avez
-
vous
,
mademoiselle
?
"
said
she
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Vos
doigts
tremblent
comme
la
feuille
,
et
vos
joues
sont
rouges
:
mais
,
rouges
comme
des
cerises
!
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
am
hot
,
Adele
,
with
stooping
!
"
<EOS>
She
went
on
sketching
;
I
went
on
thinking
.
  
<EOS>
I
hastened
to
drive
from
my
mind
the
hateful
notion
I
had
been
conceiving
respecting
Grace
Poole
;
it
disgusted
me
.
<EOS>
I
compared
myself
with
her
,
and
found
we
were
different
.
<EOS>
Bessie
Leaven
had
said
I
was
quite
a
lady
;
and
she
spoke
truth
 
<EOS>
I
was
a
lady
.
<EOS>
And
now
I
looked
much
better
than
I
did
when
Bessie
saw
me
;
I
had
more
colour
and
more
flesh
,
more
life
,
more
vivacity
,
because
I
had
brighter
hopes
and
keener
enjoyments
.
  
<EOS>
"
Evening
approaches
,
"
said
I
,
as
I
looked
towards
the
window
.
<EOS>
"
I
have
never
heard
Mr.
Rochester
's
voice
or
step
in
the
house
to
-
day
;
but
surely
I
shall
see
him
before
night
:
I
feared
the
meeting
in
the
morning
;
now
I
desire
it
,
because
expectation
has
been
so
long
baffled
that
it
is
grown
impatient
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
When
dusk
actually
closed
,
and
when
Adele
left
me
to
go
and
play
in
the
nursery
with
Sophie
,
I
did
most
keenly
desire
it
.
<EOS>
I
listened
for
the
bell
to
ring
below
;
I
listened
for
Leah
coming
up
with
a
message
;
I
fancied
<EOS>
sometimes
I
heard
Mr.
Rochester
's
own
tread
,
and
I
turned
to
the
door
,
expecting
it
to
open
and
admit
him
.
<EOS>
The
door
remained
shut
;
darkness
only
came
in
through

window
.
<EOS>
Still
it
was
not
late
;
he
often
sent
for
me
at
seven
and
eight
o'clock
,
and
it
was
yet
but
six
.
<EOS>
Surely
I
should
not
be
wholly

to
-
night
,
when
I
had
so
many

to

!
<EOS>
I
wanted
again
to
introduce
the
subject
of
Grace
Poole
,
and
to
hear

he

;
I
wanted
to

plainly
if

really
believed
it
was
she
who
had
made
last
night
's
hideous
attempt
;
and
if
so
,
why
he
kept
her

a
secret
.
<EOS>
It
little
mattered
whether
my
curiosity
irritated
him
;
I
knew
the
pleasure
of
vexing
and
soothing
him
by
turns
;
it
was
one
I
chiefly
delighted
in
,
and
<EOS>
a
sure
instinct
always
prevented
me
from
going
too
far
;
beyond
the
verge
of
provocation
I
never
ventured
;
on
the
extreme
brink
I
liked
well
to
try
my
skill
.
<EOS>
Retaining
every
minute
form
of
respect
,
every

of
my
station
,
I
could
still
meet
him
in

or

;
this
suited
both

.
  
<EOS>
A
tread
creaked
on
the
stairs
at
last
.
<EOS>
Leah
made
her
appearance
;
but
it
was
only
to
intimate
that
tea
was
ready
in
Mrs.
Fairfax
's

.
<EOS>
Thither

repaired
,
glad

;
for
that

,
I

,
nearer
to
Mr.
Rochester
's

.
  
<EOS>
"
You
must
want
your
tea
,
"
said
the
good

,
as
I
joined

;
"
you
ate
so

.
<EOS>
I
am
afraid
<EOS>
,
"
she

,
"
you
are
not
well
<EOS>
to-

:
you
look

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Oh
,
quite
well
!
<EOS>
I
never
felt
better
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Then
you
must

;

?
"
<EOS>

,

,
by

I

,
of
making
the
most

,

.
  
<EOS>
"
It
is
fair
to
-

,
"

,

,
"
though

;
Mr.
Rochester
has
,
on

,

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Journey
!
 
<EOS>
Is

Rochester
gone

?
<EOS>
I
did
not

was

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Oh
,
he
set

!
<EOS>
He

to
the
Leas
,
Mr.
Eshton
's

,
ten

Millcote
.
<EOS>
I

;

<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Do

to

?
<EOS>
"
  
"
<EOS>
No
 
nor
to

morrow
either
<EOS>
;
I
should

is

a

:
<EOS>
when
these
fine
,

people
get

,
they
are
so

by

and

,
so
well

that
can

and

,

to

.
<EOS>
Gentlemen
especially
are
often
in
request
on
such

;
and
Mr.
Rochester
is
so

and
so

in

,
that
I
believe
he
is
a
general

:
the
ladies
are
very
fond
of
him
;
though
you
would
not

particularly
in

:
<EOS>
but
I

his
acquirements
and
abilities
,
perhaps
his

good
blood
,
make

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Are

at

?
"
  
<EOS>
"
There
are
Mrs.
Eshton
and

very

;
and

the
Honourable

Mary
Ingram
,
most

women
,
I

:
indeed
I
have
seen

,
six

,

.
<EOS>
She
came
here

a

party
Mr.

.
<EOS>
You
should
have
seen

that
day
 
<EOS>
how

decorated
,
how

!
<EOS>
I
should
think

were

and

all
of
the
first

;
and
Miss
Ingram

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
You

,
you

,
Mrs.
Fairfax
<EOS>
:
what

like
?
"
  
<EOS>
"
Yes
,
I

.
<EOS>
The

were

;
and
,

,

,

.
<EOS>
Mr.
Rochester
would
have
me
to
come
in
,
and
I

.
<EOS>
I
never
saw
a
more

:
the

were

;
most

at

looked

;
but
Miss
Ingram
was

the

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
And
what

?
"
  
<EOS>
"
Tall
,
fine

,

;
long
,

:
olive

,

;

;

rather

Rochester
's
:
large

,
<EOS>
and
as

as
her

.
<EOS>
And
then
she
had
such
a
fine
head
of

;
raven

black
and
so

:
a

,

,

.
<EOS>
She
was

in
pure

;
an
amber

was
passed
over

and

,
tied

,
and

,

below

.
<EOS>
She
wore
an
amber

flower
,

,
in
her

:
it
contrasted

the

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
She
was
greatly

,

?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Yes
,

:
and

.
<EOS>
She
was
one

the

:
a

.
<EOS>
She

Rochester
sang

.
<EOS>
"
  
"
<EOS>
Mr.
Rochester
?
<EOS>
I

.
<EOS>
"
  
"
Oh
!
<EOS>
he

,

.
<EOS>
"
  
"
And

Ingram
:
<EOS>

?
"
  
<EOS>
"
A
very
rich

one
<EOS>
:
she
sang

;
it
was

treat
to

;
 
and
she
played
afterwards
.
<EOS>
I
am
no

of
music
,
but
Mr.
Rochester
is
;
and
I
heard

say
her
execution
was
remarkably
good
.
"
  
"
<EOS>
And
this
beautiful
and
accomplished
lady
,
she
is
not
yet

?
"
  
<EOS>
"
It
appears

:
I
fancy
<EOS>
neither
she
nor
her
sister
have
very
large

.
<EOS>
Old
Lord
Ingram
's
estates
were
chiefly

,
and
the

son
came
in
for

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
But
I
wonder
no
wealthy
nobleman
or

has
taken

to
her
:
<EOS>
Mr.
Rochester
,
for

.
<EOS>
He

,

?
"
  
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Oh
!
<EOS>
yes
.
<EOS>
But

there

difference

age
:
<EOS>
Mr.
Rochester
is
nearly

;
she
is
but

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
What
of
that
?
<EOS>
More

matches
are
made
every

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
True
:
yet
<EOS>
I
should

fancy
Mr.
Rochester
would
entertain
an
idea
of
the
sort
.
<EOS>
But
you
eat
nothing
:
you
have
scarcely
tasted
since
you
began
tea
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
No
:
I
am
too
thirsty
to
eat
.
<EOS>
Will
you
let
me
have
another
cup
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
I
was
about
again
to
revert
to
the
probability
of
a
union
between
Mr.
Rochester
and
the
beautiful
Blanche
;
but
Adele
came
in
,
and
the
conversation
was
turned
into
another

.
  
<EOS>
When
once
more
alone
,
I
reviewed
the
information
I
had
got
;
looked
into
my
heart
,
examined
its
thoughts
and
feelings
,
and
endeavoured
to
bring
back
with
a
strict
hand
such
as
had
been
straying
through
imagination
's
boundless
and
trackless
waste
,
into
the
safe
fold
of
common
sense
.
  
<EOS>
Arraigned
at
my
own
bar
,
Memory
having
given
her
evidence
of
the
hopes
,
wishes
,
sentiments
I
had
been
cherishing
since
last
night
 
of
the
general
state
of
mind
in
which
I
had
indulged
for
nearly
a
fortnight
past
;
Reason
having
come
forward
and
told
,
in
her
own
quiet
way
a
plain
,
unvarnished
tale
,
showing
how
I
had
rejected
the
real
,
and
rabidly
devoured
the
ideal
;
 
I
pronounced
judgment
to
this
effect
:
    
That
a
greater
fool
than
Jane
Eyre
had
never
breathed
the
breath
of
life
;
that
a
more
fantastic
idiot
had
never
surfeited
herself
on
sweet
lies
,
and
swallowed
poison
as
if
it
were
nectar
.
  
<EOS>
"
_
You
_
,
"
I
said
,
"
a
favourite
with
Mr.
Rochester
?
<EOS>
_
<EOS>
You
_
gifted
with
the
power
of
pleasing
him
?
<EOS>
_
<EOS>
You
_
of
importance
to
him
in
any
way
?
<EOS>
Go
!
<EOS>
your
folly
sickens
me
.
<EOS>
And
you
have
derived
pleasure
from
occasional
tokens
of
preference
 
equivocal
tokens
shown
by
a
gentleman
of
family
and
a
man
of
the
world
to
a
dependent
and
a
novice
.
<EOS>
How
dared
you
?
<EOS>
Poor
stupid
dupe
!
 
<EOS>
Could
not
even
self
-
interest
make
you
wiser
?
<EOS>
You
repeated
to
yourself
this
morning
the
brief
scene
of
last
night
?
 
<EOS>
Cover
your
face
and
be
ashamed
!
<EOS>
He
said
something
in
praise
of
your
eyes
,
did
he
?
<EOS>
Blind
puppy
!
<EOS>
Open
their
bleared
lids
and
look
on
your
own
accursed
senselessness
!
<EOS>
It
does
good
to
no
woman
to
be
flattered
by
her
superior
,
who
can
not
possibly
intend
to
marry
her
;
and
it
is
madness
in
all
women
to
let
a
secret
love
kindle
within
them
,
which
,
if
unreturned
and
unknown
,
must
devour
the
life
that
feeds
it
;
and
,
if
discovered
and
responded
to
,
must
lead
,
_
ignis
-
fatus_-like
,
into
miry
wilds
<EOS>
whence
there
is
no
extrication
.
  
<EOS>
"
Listen
,
then
,
Jane
Eyre
,
to
your
sentence
:
to
-
morrow
,
place
the
glass
before
you
,
and
draw
in
chalk
your
own
picture
,
faithfully
,
without
softening
one
defect
;
omit
no
harsh
line
,
smooth
away
no
displeasing
irregularity
;
write
under
it
,
"
Portrait
of
a
Governess
,
disconnected
,
poor
,
and
plain
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Afterwards
,
take
a
piece
of
smooth
ivory
 
<EOS>
you
have
one
prepared
in
your
drawing
-
box
:
take
your
palette
,
mix
your
freshest
,
finest
,
clearest
tints
;
choose
your
most
delicate
camel
-
hair
pencils
;
delineate
carefully
the
loveliest
face
you
can
imagine
;
paint
it
in
your
softest
shades
and
sweetest
lines
,
according
to
the
description
given
by
Mrs.
Fairfax
of
Blanche
Ingram
;
remember
the
raven
ringlets
,
the
oriental
eye
;
 
<EOS>
What
!
<EOS>
you
revert
to
Mr.
Rochester
as
a
model
!
<EOS>
Order
!
<EOS>
No
snivel
!
 
<EOS>
no
sentiment
!
 
<EOS>
no
regret
!
<EOS>
I
will
endure
only
sense
and
resolution
.
<EOS>
Recall
the
august
yet
harmonious
lineaments
,
the
Grecian
neck
and
bust
;
let
the
round
and
dazzling
arm
be
visible
,
and
the
delicate
hand
;
omit
neither
diamond
ring
nor
gold
bracelet
;
portray
faithfully
the
attire
,
aerial
lace
and
glistening
satin
,
graceful
scarf
and
golden
rose
;
call
it
"
Blanche
,
an
accomplished
lady
of
rank
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Whenever
,
in
future
,
you
should
chance
to
fancy
Mr.
Rochester
thinks
well
of
you
,
take
out
these
two
pictures
and
compare
them
:
say
,
"
Mr.
Rochester
might
probably
win
that
noble
lady
's
love
,
if
he
chose
to
strive
for
it
;
is
it
likely
he
would
waste
a
serious
thought
on
this
indigent
and
insignificant
plebeian
?
"
<EOS>
"
  
"
I
'll
do
it
,
"
I
resolved
:
and
having
framed
this
determination
,
I
grew
calm
,
and
fell
asleep
.
  
<EOS>
I
kept
my
word
.
<EOS>
An
hour
or
two
sufficed
to
sketch
my
own
portrait
in
crayons
;
and
in
less
than
a
fortnight
I
had
completed
an
ivory
miniature
of
an
imaginary
Blanche
Ingram
.
<EOS>
It
looked
a
lovely
face
enough
,
and
when
compared
with
the
real
head
in
chalk
,
the
contrast
was
as
great
as
self-
control
could
desire
.
<EOS>
I
derived
benefit
from
the
task
:
it
had
kept
my
head
and
hands
employed
,
and
had
given
force
and
fixedness
to
the
new
impressions
I
wished
to
stamp
indelibly
on
my
heart
.
  
<EOS>
Ere
long
,
I
had
reason
to
congratulate
myself
on
the
course
of
wholesome
discipline
to
which
I
had
thus
forced
my
feelings
to
submit
.
<EOS>
Thanks
to
it
,
I
was
able
to
meet
subsequent
occurrences
with
a
decent
calm
,
which
,
had
they
found
me
unprepared
,
I
should
probably
have
been
unequal
to
maintain
,
even
externally
.
    
<EOS>
A
week
passed
,
and
no
news
arrived
of
Mr.
Rochester
:
ten
days
,
and
still
he
did
not
come
.
<EOS>
Mrs.
Fairfax
said
she
should
not
be
surprised
if
he
were
to
go
straight
from
the
Leas
to
London
,
and
thence
to
the
Continent
,
and
not
show
his
face
again
at
Thornfield
for
a
year
to
come
;
he
had
not
unfrequently
quitted
it
in
a
manner
quite
as
abrupt
and
unexpected
.
<EOS>
When
I
heard
this
,
I
was
beginning
to
feel
a
strange
chill
and
failing
at
the
heart
.
<EOS>
I
was
actually
permitting
myself
to
experience
a
sickening
sense
of
disappointment
;
but
rallying
my
wits
,
and
recollecting
my
principles
,
I
at
once
called
my
sensations
to
order
;
and
it
was
wonderful
how
I
got
over
the
temporary
blunder
 
<EOS>
how
I
cleared
up
the
mistake
of
supposing
Mr.
Rochester
's
movements
a
matter
in
which
I
had
any
cause
to
take
a
vital
interest
.
<EOS>
Not
that
I
humbled
myself
by
a
slavish
notion
of
inferiority
:
on
the
contrary
,
I
just
said
    
"
You
have
nothing
to
do
with
the
master
of
Thornfield
,
further
than
to
receive
the
salary
he
gives
you
for
teaching
his
protegee
,
and
to
be
grateful
for
such
respectful
and
kind
treatment
as
,
if
you
do
your
duty
,
you
have
a
right
to
expect
at
his
hands
.
<EOS>
Be
sure
that
is
the
only
tie
he
seriously
acknowledges
between
you
and
him
;
so
do
n't
make
him
the
object
of
your
fine
feelings
,
your
raptures
,
agonies
,
and
so
forth
.
<EOS>
He
is
not
of
your
order
:
keep
to
your
caste
,
and
be
too
self
-
respecting
to
lavish
the
love
of
the
whole
heart
,
soul
,
and
strength
,
where
such
a
gift
is
not
wanted
and
would
be
despised
.
"
  
<EOS>
I
went
on
with
my
day
's
business
tranquilly
;
but
ever
and
anon
vague
suggestions
kept
wandering
across
my
brain
of
reasons
why
I
should
quit
Thornfield
;
and
I
kept
involuntarily
framing
advertisements
and
pondering
conjectures
about
new
situations
:
these
thoughts
I
did
not
think
to
check
;
they
might
germinate
and
bear
fruit
if
they
could
.
  
<EOS>
Mr.
Rochester
had
been
absent
upwards
of
a
fortnight
,
when
the
post
brought
Mrs.
Fairfax
a
letter
.
  
<EOS>
"
It
is
from
the
master
,
"
said
she
,
as
she
looked
at
the
direction
.
<EOS>
"
Now
I
suppose
we
shall
know
whether
we
are
to
expect
his
return
or
not
.
"
  
<EOS>
And
while
she
broke
the
seal
and
perused
the
document
,
I
went
on
taking
my
coffee
(
we
were
at
breakfast
)
:
<EOS>
it
was
hot
,
and
I
attributed
to
that
circumstance
a
fiery
glow
which
suddenly
rose
to
my
face
.
<EOS>
Why
my
hand
shook
,
and
why
I
involuntarily
spilt
half
the
contents
of
my
cup
into
my
saucer
,
I
did
not
choose
to
consider
.
  
<EOS>
"
Well
,
I
sometimes
think
we
are
too
quiet
;
but
we
run
a
chance
of
being
busy
enough
now
:
for
a
little
while
at
least
,
"
said
Mrs.
Fairfax
,
still
holding
the
note
before
her
spectacles
.
  
<EOS>
Ere
I
permitted
myself
to
request
an
explanation
,
I
tied
the
string
of
Adele
's
pinafore
,
which
happened
to
be
loose
:
having
helped
her
also
to
another
bun
and
refilled
her
mug
with
milk
,
I
said
,
nonchalantly
    
"
Mr.
Rochester
is
not
likely
to
return
soon
,
I
suppose
?
<EOS>
"
  
"
Indeed
he
is
 
in
three
days
,
he
says
:
that
will
be
next
Thursday
;
and
not
alone
either
.
<EOS>
I
do
n't
know
how
many
of
the
fine
people
at
the
Leas
are
coming
with
him
:
he
sends
directions
for
all
the
best
bedrooms
to
be
prepared
;
and
the
library
and
drawing
-
rooms
are
to
be
cleaned
out
;
I
am
to
get
more
kitchen
hands
from
the
George
Inn
,
at
Millcote
,
and
from
wherever
else
I
can
;
and
the
ladies
will
bring
their
maids
and
the
gentlemen
their
valets
:
so
we
shall
have
a
full
house
of
it
.
"
<EOS>
And
Mrs.
Fairfax
swallowed
her
breakfast
and
hastened
away
to
commence
operations
.
  
<EOS>
The
three
days
were
,
as
she
had
foretold
,
busy
enough
.
<EOS>
I
had
thought
all
the
rooms
at
Thornfield
beautifully
clean
and
well
arranged
;
but
it
appears
I
was
mistaken
.
<EOS>
Three
women
were
got
to
help
;
and
such
scrubbing
,
such
brushing
,
such
washing
of
paint
and
beating
of
carpets
,
such
taking
down
and
putting
up
of
pictures
,
such
polishing
of
mirrors
and
lustres
,
such
lighting
of
fires
in
bedrooms
,
such
airing
of
sheets
and
feather
-
beds
on
hearths
,
I
never
beheld
,
either
before
or
since
.
<EOS>
Adele
ran
quite
wild
in
the
midst
of
it
:
the
preparations
for
company
and
the
prospect
of
their
arrival
,
seemed
to
throw
her
into
ecstasies
.
<EOS>
She
would
have
Sophie
to
look
over
all
her
"
toilettes
,
"
as
she
called
frocks
;
to
furbish
up
any
that
were
"
_
passees
_
,
"
and
to
air
and
arrange
the
new
.
<EOS>
For
herself
,
she
did
nothing
but
caper
about
in
the
front
chambers
,
jump
on
and
off
the
bedsteads
,
and
lie
on
the
mattresses
and
piled
-
up
bolsters
and
pillows
before
the
enormous
fires
roaring
in
the
chimneys
.
<EOS>
From
school
duties
she
was
exonerated
:
Mrs.
Fairfax
had
pressed
me
into
her
service
,
and
I
was
all
day
in
the
storeroom
,
helping
(
or
hindering
)
<EOS>
her
and
the
cook
<EOS>
;
learning
to
make
custards
and
cheese
-
cakes
and
French
pastry
,
to
truss
game
and
garnish
desert
-
dishes
.
  
<EOS>
The
party
were
expected
to
arrive
on
Thursday
afternoon
,
in
time
for
dinner
at
six
.
<EOS>
During
the
intervening
period
I
had
no
time
to
nurse
chimeras
;
and
I
believe
I
was
as
active
and
gay
as
anybody
 
Adele
excepted
.
<EOS>
Still
,
now
and
then
,
I
received
a
damping
check
to
my
cheerfulness
;
and
was
,
in
spite
of
myself
,
thrown
back
on
the
region
of
doubts
and
portents
,
and
dark
conjectures
.
<EOS>
This
was
when
I
chanced
to
see
the
third
-
storey
staircase
door
(
which
of
late
had
always
been
kept
locked
)
open
slowly
,
and
give
passage
to
the
form
of
Grace
Poole
,
in
prim
cap
,
white
apron
,
and
handkerchief
;
when
I
watched
her
glide
along
the
gallery
,
her
quiet
tread
muffled
in
a
list
slipper
;
when
I
saw
her
look
into
the
bustling
,
topsy
-
turvy
bedrooms
,
 
just
say
a
word
,
perhaps
,
to
the
charwoman
about
the
proper
way
to
polish
a
grate
,
or
clean
a
marble
mantelpiece
,
or
take
stains
from
papered
walls
,
and
then
pass
on
.
<EOS>
She
would
thus
descend
to
the
kitchen
once
a
day
,
eat
her
dinner
,
smoke
a
moderate
pipe
on
the
hearth
,
and
go
back
,
carrying
her
pot
of
porter
with
her
,
for
her
private
solace
,
in
her
own
gloomy
,
upper
haunt
.
<EOS>
Only
one
hour
in
the
twenty
-
four
did
she
pass
with
her
fellow
-
servants
below
;
all
the
rest
of
her
time
was
spent
in
some
low
-
ceiled
,
oaken
chamber
of
the
second
storey
:
there
she
sat
and
sewed
 
and
probably
laughed
drearily
to
herself
,
 
as
companionless
as
a
prisoner
in
his
dungeon
.
  
<EOS>
The
strangest
thing
of
all
was
,
that
not
a
soul
in
the
house
,
except
me
,
noticed
her
habits
,
or
seemed
to
marvel
at
them
:
no
one
discussed
her
position
or
employment
;
no
one
pitied
her
solitude
or
isolation
.
<EOS>
I
once
,
indeed
,
overheard
part
of
a
dialogue
between
Leah
and
one
of
the
charwomen
,
of
which
Grace
formed
the
subject
.
<EOS>
Leah
had
been
saying
something
I
had
not
caught
,
and
the
charwoman
remarked
    
"
She
gets
good
wages
,
I
guess
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Yes
,
"
said
Leah
;
<EOS>
"
I
wish
I
had
as
good
;
not
that
mine
are
to
complain
of
,
 
<EOS>
there
's
no
stinginess
at
Thornfield
;
but
they
're
not
one
fifth
of
the
sum
Mrs.
Poole
receives
.
<EOS>
And
she
is
laying
by
<EOS>
:
she
goes
every
quarter
to
the
bank
at
Millcote
.
<EOS>
I
should
not
wonder
but
she
has
saved
enough
to
keep
her
independent
if
she
liked
to
leave
;
but
I
suppose
she
's
got
used
to
the
place
;
and
then
she
's
not
forty
yet
,
and
strong
and
able
for
anything
.
<EOS>
It
is
too
soon
for
her
to
give
up
business
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
She
is
a
good
hand
,
I
daresay
,
"
said
the
charwoman
.
  
<EOS>
"
Ah
!
 
<EOS>
she
understands
what
she
has
to
do
,
 
<EOS>
nobody
better
,
"
rejoined
Leah
significantly
;
"
and
it
is
not
every
one
could
fill
her
shoes
 
not
for
all
the
money
she
gets
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
That
it
is
not
!
"
was
the
reply
.
<EOS>
"
I
wonder
whether
the
master
 
"
  
The
charwoman
was
going
on
;
but
here
Leah
turned
and
perceived
me
,
and
she
instantly
gave
her
companion
a
nudge
.
  
<EOS>
"
Does
n't
she
know
?
<EOS>
"
I
heard
the
woman
whisper
.
  
<EOS>
Leah
shook
her
head
,
and
the
conversation
was
of
course
dropped
.
<EOS>
All
I
had
gathered
from
it
amounted
to
this
,
 
that
there
was
a
mystery
at
Thornfield
;
and
that
from
participation
in
that
mystery
I
was
purposely
excluded
.
  
<EOS>
Thursday
came
:
all
work
had
been
completed
the
previous
evening
;
carpets
were
laid
down
,
bed
-
hangings
festooned
,
radiant
white
counterpanes
spread
,
toilet
tables
arranged
,
furniture
rubbed
,
flowers
piled
in
vases
:
both
chambers
and
saloons
looked
as
fresh
and
bright
as
hands
could
make
them
.
<EOS>
The
hall
,
too
,
was
scoured
;
and
the
great
carved
clock
,
as
well
as
the
steps
and
banisters
of
the
staircase
,
were
polished
to
the
brightness
of
glass
;
in
the
dining
-
room
,
the
sideboard
flashed
resplendent
with
plate
;
in
the
drawing
-
room
and
boudoir
,
vases
of
exotics
bloomed
on
all
sides
.
  
<EOS>
Afternoon
arrived
:
Mrs.
Fairfax
assumed
her
best
black
satin
gown
,
her
gloves
,
and
her
gold
watch
;
for
it
was
her
part
to
receive
the
company
,
 
to
conduct
the
ladies
to
their
rooms
,
&
c.
Adele
<EOS>
,
too
,
would
be
dressed
:
though
I
thought
she
had
little
chance
of
being
introduced
to
the
party
that
day
at
least
.
<EOS>
However
,
to
please
her
,
I
allowed
Sophie
to
apparel
her
in
one
of
her
short
,
full
muslin
frocks
.
<EOS>
For
myself
,
I
had
no
need
to
make
any
change
;
I
should
not
be
called
upon
to
quit
my
sanctum
of
the
schoolroom
;
for
a
sanctum
it
was
now
become
to
me
,
 
"
a
very
pleasant
refuge
in
time
of
trouble
.
"
  
<EOS>
It
had
been
a
mild
,
serene
spring
day
 
one
of
those
days
which
,
towards
the
end
of
March
or
the
beginning
of
April
,
rise
shining
over
the
earth
as
heralds
of
summer
.
<EOS>
It
was
drawing
to
an
end
now
;
but
the
evening
was
even
warm
,
and
I
sat
at
work
in
the
schoolroom
with
the
window
open
.
  
<EOS>
"
It
gets
late
,
"
said
Mrs.
Fairfax
,
entering
in
rustling
state
.
<EOS>
"
I
am
glad
I
ordered
dinner
an
hour
after
the
time
Mr.
Rochester
mentioned
;
for
it
is
past
six
now
.
<EOS>
I
have
sent
John
down
to
the
gates
to
see
if
there
is
anything
on
the
road
:
one
can
see
a
long
way
from
thence
in
the
direction
of
Millcote
.
<EOS>
"
She
went
to
the
window
.
<EOS>
"
Here
he
is
!
"
said
she
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Well
,
John
"
(
leaning
out
)
,
"
any
news
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
They
're
coming
,
ma'am
,
"
was
the
answer
.
<EOS>
"
They
'll
be
here
in
ten
minutes
.
"
  
<EOS>
Adele
flew
to
the
window
.
<EOS>
I
followed
,
taking
care
to
stand
on
one
side
,
so
that
,
screened
by
the
curtain
,
I
could
see
without
being
seen
.
  
<EOS>
The
ten
minutes
John
had
given
seemed
very
long
,
but
at
last
wheels
were
heard
;
four
equestrians
galloped
up
the
drive
,
and
after
them
came
two
open
carriages
.
<EOS>
Fluttering
veils
and
waving
plumes
filled
the
vehicles
<EOS>
;
two
of
the
cavaliers
were
young
,
dashing
-
looking

;
the
third
was
Mr.
Rochester
,
on
his
black
horse
,
Mesrour
,
Pilot
bounding
before
him
;
at
his
side
rode
a
lady
,
and
he
and
she
were
the
first
of
the
party
.
<EOS>
Her
purple
riding
-
habit
almost
swept
the
ground
,
her
veil
streamed
long
on
the
breeze
;
mingling
with
its
transparent
folds
,
and
gleaming
through
them
,
shone
rich

.
  
<EOS>
"
Miss
Ingram
!
"
exclaimed
Mrs.
Fairfax
,
and
away
she
hurried
to
her
post
below
.
  
<EOS>
The
cavalcade
,
following
the
sweep
of
the
drive
,
quickly
turned
the
angle
of
the
house
,
and
I
lost
sight
of
it
.
<EOS>
Adele
now
petitioned
to
go
down
;
but
I
took
her
on
my
knee
,
and
gave
her
to
understand
that
she
must
not

venturing

,

unless

:
that

Rochester
would

,
&

"
<EOS>
Some

she

"
on

;
<EOS>
but

she
consented

to

.
  
<EOS>
A

was

:
gentlemen

'

blent

above

,
though

the
master

Hall
,

.
<EOS>
Then

;
and

a

,
and
soft

,
and

,
and
,

.
  
<EOS>
"
Elles

,
"

;
who
,

,

;

.
  
<EOS>
"
Chez

,
"
said

,
"
quand
il
y
avait
<EOS>
du

,
je

,

;

:
<EOS>
comme

.
<EOS>
"
  
"
Do

,

?
"
  
"

,

:
voila

.
"
  
"
<EOS>
Well

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
And

sought

back

stairs
which

directly
to

.
<EOS>
All

that
region
was
fire
and

;
the

were
in
the
last
stage
of

,
and

cook

.
<EOS>
In

servants
'

two

and
three

's
gentlemen
stood

;
the

,
I

,
were
upstairs
with

;
the
new

,
that
had
been
hired

,
were

.
<EOS>
Threading
this
chaos
,
I
at
last
reached
the
larder
;
there
I
took
possession
of
a
cold
chicken
,
a
roll

bread
,
some

,
a
plate
or
two
and
a

:
with
this
booty
<EOS>
I
made
a

.
<EOS>
I
had

the
gallery
,
and
was
just

the
back

door
behind
me
,
when
an

me
that
the
ladies
were

.
<EOS>
I
could
not

to
the

without
passing
some

,
and
running

risk
of
being
surprised
with
my
cargo
of

;
so

at
this
end
,
which
,
being

,
was
dark
:
quite

now
,
for
the
sun
was

and

.
  
<EOS>
Presently

chambers
gave

fair

one

:
each
came

and
airily
,
with
dress
that

through

.
<EOS>
For

stood
grouped

the
other

gallery
,

in
a

sweet

:
they
then
descended
the

almost
as

a

down

.
<EOS>
Their

had
left

high-

,
such
as
I
had
never
before
received
.
  
<EOS>
I
found
Adele
peeping
through
the
schoolroom
door
,
which
she
held
ajar
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
What
beautiful
ladies
!
"
cried
she
in
English
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Oh
,
I
wish
I
might
go
to

!
<EOS>
Do
you
think
Mr.
Rochester
will
send

by

,

?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
No
,

,

do

;
Mr.
Rochester

.
<EOS>
Never

the
ladies
to
-

;
perhaps

to

:
here

.
"
  
<EOS>
She
was
really
hungry
,
so
the
chicken
and
tarts
served
to
divert

attention
for
a

.
<EOS>
It
was
well
<EOS>
I
secured

,

,

,

:
every

.
<EOS>
The

was
not
carried

till

nine
and
at
ten
footmen
were
still

to

.
<EOS>
I

to

;
for

could

,

.
<EOS>
Besides

;
"
et

!
"
  
<EOS>
I

;
and

.
<EOS>
The

,
and

amused

<EOS>
When

,
whither

<EOS>
Presently

;

,

.
<EOS>
The
solo
over

,

:

.
<EOS>
I

:

on

,

those
of
Mr.
Rochester
;

,

,

,

.
  
<EOS>
The
clock

.
<EOS>
I
looked
at
Adele
,
whose

;
her

were

,

.
<EOS>
It

near

before

.
  
<EOS>
The
next

was
as
fine

:
it
was
devoted

to
an

to
some
site

.
<EOS>
They
set

early
in

,
some

,
the
rest
in

;
I
witnessed

and

.
<EOS>
Miss
Ingram
,
as

,

only

;
and
,

,
Mr.
Rochester
galloped
at
her

;
the

rode
a
little
apart

.
<EOS>
I
pointed

this

Mrs.
Fairfax
,
who
was

me
    
<EOS>
"
You
said

,
"

,
"
<EOS>
but

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Yes
,

:

.
"
  
<EOS>
"
And

him
,
"

"

;
I

;

.
"
  
"
You

,
"

.
<EOS>
"
I

Rochester

<EOS>
"
  
"

;

,

"

<EOS>
"

<EOS>

;

"

!
<EOS>

;

.
"
<EOS>
"
  
"
I

,
"
I

.
<EOS>
"
I
will

,

;
but
I

.
<EOS>
Shall

,

?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
No
;
I
pleaded

,
and
he

my

.
<EOS>
I
'll
tell
you
how
to
manage
so

,

.
<EOS>
You

drawing-

ladies

;

;

,
unless

:

nobody
will
notice

.
"
  
<EOS>
"
Will

,

?
<EOS>
"
  
"
Perhaps

,

.
<EOS>
After

,
Sir
George
Lynn
,
who

Millcote
,
will

:

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
It
was

I

when
I
was
to
repair

.
<EOS>
Adele
had
been
in
a
state

all

,
after
hearing
she
was
to

presented
to
the
ladies
in
the

;
and
it

that

.
<EOS>
Then
the

of
the
process
quickly
steadied
her
,
and
by

she
had
her
curls

in

,

,
her

,

,
she

as

any

.
<EOS>
No
need
to
warn

not

disarrange
her
attire
<EOS>
:
when

,

,
taking
care
previously
to
lift

for
fear
she
should
crease

,
and
assured
me
she
would
not

thence
till
I
was
ready
.
<EOS>
This
I
quickly
was
:
my
best
dress
(
the
silver

grey
one
,
purchased
for
Miss
Temple
's
wedding
,
and
never
worn
since
)
was
soon

;
my
hair
was
soon

;
my
sole
ornament
,
the
pearl
brooch
,
soon
assumed
.
<EOS>
We
descended
.
  
<EOS>
Fortunately

another
entrance
to
the
drawing

room
than
that
through
the
saloon
where
they
were

.
<EOS>
We

;

<EOS>
The

hung
before

:
slight
as
was
the
separation
<EOS>
this

formed
from
the
party
in

,

<EOS>
Adele

,
sat

on

I

.
<EOS>

,

<EOS>
Adele

;
ere

.
  
<EOS>
"
What

,

?
"
  
<EOS>
"
Est
-
ce
que
je
<EOS>
ne

<EOS>
Seulement

<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"

"

<EOS>
"
<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>
There

;

<EOS>
Some

;

<EOS>
I

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>
I

<EOS>
First

was
Mrs.
Eshton

.
<EOS>
She

evidently

,

.
<EOS>
Of

<EOS>
The

minois

_

.
  
<EOS>
Lady

<EOS>
Mrs.

<EOS>
She

.
<EOS>
Her

<EOS>
But

<EOS>
They

.
<EOS>
The

might

her

;

<EOS>
Most

<EOS>
She

.
<EOS>
She

:

,

,

<EOS>
A

<EOS>
Blanche

.
<EOS>
Mary

,

.
<EOS>
I

<EOS>

<EOS>
Genius

.
<EOS>

.

She

<EOS>
It

:

"

<EOS>

And

"

<EOS>

At

<EOS>
I

<EOS>

;

Again

<EOS>

;

<EOS>
Henry

.
<EOS>
Mr.

,

,

"
<EOS>
Lord

,

;

<EOS>
And

Rochester
?
  
<EOS>
He
comes
in
last
<EOS>
:
I
am

,

.
<EOS>
I

,

the
purse
<EOS>
I

forming
 
<EOS>
I

<EOS>
How

<EOS>

,
calculated

<EOS>

,

<EOS>

.
<EOS>
I

,

,
 
a

;

,

:
a

.
  
<EOS>
Most
true

that
"

.
<EOS>
"
My
master
's

,
square
,
massive
brow
,
broad
and
jetty
eyebrows
,
deep
eyes
,
strong
features
,
firm
,
grim
mouth
,
 
all
energy
,
decision
,
will
,
 
were
not
beautiful
,
according
to
rule
;
but
they
were
more
than
beautiful
to
me
;
they
were
full
of
an
interest
,
an
influence
that
quite
mastered
me
,
 
that
took
my
feelings
from
my
own
power
and
fettered
them
in
his
.
<EOS>
I
had
not
intended
to
love
him
;
the
reader
knows
I
had
wrought
hard
to
extirpate
from
my
soul
the
germs
of
love
there
detected
;
and
now
,
at
the
first
renewed
view
of
him
,
they
spontaneously
arrived
,
green
and
strong
!
<EOS>
He
made
me
love
him
without
looking
at
me
.
  
<EOS>
I
compared
him
with
his
guests
.
<EOS>
What
was
the
gallant
grace
of
the
Lynns
,
the
languid
elegance
of
Lord
Ingram
,
 
even
the
military
distinction
of
Colonel
Dent
,
contrasted
with
his
look
of
native
pith
and
genuine
power
?
<EOS>
I
had
no
sympathy
in
their
appearance
,
their
expression
:
yet
I
could
imagine
that
most
observers
would
call
them
attractive
,
handsome
,
imposing
;
while
they
would
pronounce
Mr.
Rochester
at
once
harsh
-
featured
and
melancholy
-
looking
.
<EOS>
I
saw
them
smile
,
laugh
 
<EOS>
it
was
nothing
;
the
light
of
the
candles
had
as
much
soul
in
it
as
their
smile
;
the
tinkle
of
the
bell
as
much
significance
as
their
laugh
.
<EOS>
I
saw
Mr.
Rochester
smile
:
 
his
stern
features
softened
;
his
eye
grew
both
brilliant
and
gentle
,
its
ray
both
searching
and
sweet
.
<EOS>
He
was
talking
,
at
the
moment
,
to
Louisa
and
Amy
Eshton
.
<EOS>
I
wondered
to
see
them
receive
with
calm
that
look
which
seemed
to
me
so
penetrating
:
<EOS>
I
expected
their
eyes
to
fall
,
their
colour
to
rise
under
it
;
yet
I
was
glad
when
I
found
they
were
in
no
sense
moved
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
He
is
not
to
them
what
he
is
to
me
,
"
I
thought
:
"
he
is
not
of
their
kind
.
<EOS>
I
believe
he
is
of
mine
;
 
I
am
sure
he
is
 
<EOS>
I
feel
akin
to
him
 
<EOS>
I
understand
the
language
of
his
countenance
and
movements
:
though
rank
and
wealth
sever
us
widely
,
I
have
something
in
my
brain
and
heart
,
in
my
blood
and
nerves
,
that
assimilates
me
mentally
to
him
.
<EOS>
Did
I
say
,
a
few
days
since
,
that
I
had
nothing
to
do
with
him
but
to
receive
my
salary
at
his
hands
?
<EOS>
Did
I
forbid
myself
to
think
of
him
in
any
other
light
than
as
a
paymaster
?
<EOS>
Blasphemy
against
nature
!
<EOS>
Every
good
,
true
,
vigorous
feeling
I
have
gathers
impulsively
round
him
.
<EOS>
I
know
I
must
conceal
my
sentiments
:
I
must
smother
hope
;
I
must
remember
that
he
can
not
care
much
for
me
.
<EOS>
For
when
I
say
that
I
am
of
his
kind
,
I
do
not
mean
that
I
have
his
force
to
influence
,
and
his
spell
to
attract
<EOS>
;
I
mean
only
that
I
have
certain
tastes
and
feelings
in
common
with
him
.
<EOS>
I
must
,
then
,
repeat
continually
that
we
are
for
ever
sundered
:
 
and
yet
,
while
I
breathe
and
think
,
I
must
love
him
.
"
  
<EOS>
Coffee
is
handed
.
<EOS>
The
ladies
,
since
the
gentlemen
entered
,
have
become
lively

;
conversation
waxes
brisk

.
<EOS>
Colonel
Dent
and

Eshton
argue
on
politics
;
their
wives
listen
.
<EOS>
The
two
proud

,

and

,

.
<EOS>
Sir
George
 
<EOS>
whom
,
by

the

,
I
have

describe
,
 
a
very

country

,
<EOS>
stands
before

sofa
,
coffee-
cup
in

,
and
occasionally
puts
in
a
word
.
<EOS>
Mr.
Frederick
Lynn
has
taken

Mary
Ingram
,
and
is
showing

the

of
a

:

,

now

.
<EOS>

leans

the
little
and

Amy

;

,

:
she
likes

better
than

.
<EOS>
Henry
Lynn
has
taken

an
ottoman
at
the
feet
of
Louisa
:
<EOS>
Adele
shares

with

:
he
is
trying
to
talk
French
with
her
,
and
Louisa
laughs
at

.
<EOS>
With

will

Ingram
pair
?
<EOS>
She
is

,

over

album
.
<EOS>
She
seems
waiting
to
be
sought
;
but
she
will
not
wait
too
long
:
she
herself
selects
a
mate
.
  
<EOS>
Mr.
Rochester
,
having
quitted
the
Eshtons
,
stands

hearth
as

:

,

.
  
<EOS>
"
Mr.
Rochester
,
I

?
<EOS>
"
  
"
Nor

"
  
"

,

"

<EOS>
"

<EOS>
is

?

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>
What

<EOS>

I

<EOS>

_

_
<EOS>
,

<EOS>

"

sort

wild
,
fierce
,
bandit
hero
whom
I
could
have
consented
to
gift
with
my

.
"
  
<EOS>
"
Gentlemen
,
you
hear
!
<EOS>
Now

of
you
most
resembles
Bothwell
?
"

Mr.
Rochester
.
  
<EOS>
"
I
should
say
the
preference
lies
with
you
,
"
responded
Colonel
Dent
.
  
<EOS>
"
On
my
honour
,
I
am
much
obliged
to
you
,
"
was
the
reply
.
  
<EOS>
Miss
Ingram
,
who
had
now
seated
herself
with
proud

at
the

,
spreading
out

snowy

in
queenly

,
commenced
a
brilliant

;
talking
meantime
.
<EOS>
She
appeared
to
be
on
her

horse
to
-

;
both

and

to

:
she
was
evidently
bent
on
striking
them
as
something
very
dashing

.
  
<EOS>
"
Oh
,
I
am
so
sick
of
the
young
men
of
the
present
day
!
"
<EOS>
exclaimed

,
rattling
away
at
the
instrument
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Poor
,
puny
things
,
not
fit
to
stir
a
step
beyond
papa
's
park

:
nor
to

even

without
mama
's

and

!
<EOS>
Creatures
so
absorbed
in
care
about
their
pretty

,
and
their
white

,
and
their

;
as

anything

!
<EOS>
As

not

of
woman
 
<EOS>
her
legitimate
appanage
and

!
<EOS>
I
grant
an
ugly
_
woman
<EOS>
_
is
a
blot
on
the
fair
face
of
creation
;
but
as

_
gentlemen
_
,

to

:
let

be
:
 
Hunt
,
shoot
,

fight
:
the
rest
is
not
worth
a
fillip
.
<EOS>
Such
should
be
my
device
,
were
I
a
man
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Whenever
I

,
"
she

"
I
am
resolved

not

rival
,
but

.
<EOS>
I

:
his

.
<EOS>
Mr.
Rochester
,
now

,

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
am
all

,
"

.
  
<EOS>
"
Here

is
a
Corsair

.
<EOS>
Know

doat

con

<EOS>
_
.
<EOS>
"
  
"
Commands

Miss
Ingram

<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Take

<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
That

:

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Gardez
-
vous

!
<EOS>
If

,

.
<EOS>
"
  
"
Miss
Ingram
ought

,

.
<EOS>
"
  
"
Ha

"

.
  
<EOS>
"

,

<EOS>

;

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"

!
"

.
  
<EOS>
"
Now

,
"

:

.
<EOS>
Mrs.
Fairfax
had
said

Rochester
possessed
a
fine

:
he
did

,

;

.
<EOS>
I

<EOS>

;

the

,

.
<EOS>
Thence

:

,

;

.
<EOS>
I

;

;

,

.
  
<EOS>
"
How

?
<EOS>
"

.
  
<EOS>
"
I
am

,

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Why

?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
I

:
but

.
<EOS>
I

"

,

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>

<EOS>
"
  
"

;

<EOS>
"
  
"
<EOS>
And

as

.
<EOS>
What

"
  
<EOS>
"

<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"

<EOS>

?
"
  
"
<EOS>

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Return

:
<EOS>

<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>

.
  
<EOS>
"

,
"

.
<EOS>
"

"
  
<EOS>
"
Nothing
 
nothing
,

.
<EOS>
I

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
But

:

indeed
,

,

;
and

has

.
<EOS>
If

,

.
<EOS>
Well
,

<EOS>

;

.
<EOS>
Now

.
<EOS>
Good

,
my
 
"
He

,

.
    
<EOS>
Merry
days
were
these
at
Thornfield
Hall
;
and
busy
days
too
<EOS>
:
how
different
from
the
first
three
months
of
stillness
,

,
and
solitude
I
had
passed
beneath
its
roof
!
<EOS>
All
sad
feelings
seemed
now
driven
from
the
house
,
all
gloomy
associations
forgotten
:
there
was
life
everywhere
,
movement
all
day
long
.
<EOS>
You
could
not
now
traverse
the
gallery
,
once
so
hushed
,
nor
enter
the
front
chambers
,
once
so
tenantless
,
without
encountering
a
smart
lady's
-
maid
or
a

.
  
<EOS>
The
kitchen
,
the

's

,
the

'

,

,
were
equally

;
and
the

were
only

void

still
when
the
blue
sky
and
halcyon

of
the
genial

called
their
occupants
out
into

.
<EOS>
Even

weather
was
broken
,
and

in

,
no

:

,

.
  
<EOS>
I

the

a

:
they

"

,
"

.
<EOS>
The

were
called

,

,
the

otherwise

,
the

.
<EOS>
While

Rochester
and

other

,
the

and
<EOS>
down

.
<EOS>
Mrs.
Fairfax
was
summoned
to

information

the
resources
of
the
house
in
shawls
,
dresses
,
draperies
of
any
kind
;
and
certain

were

,

,

,

,

;
then

made
,
and
such
things
as
were
chosen
were

to
the

within

-
room
.
  
<EOS>
Meantime
,
Mr.
Rochester
had
again

the
ladies

,
and
was
selecting
certain
of

number
to
be
of

.
"
<EOS>
Miss
Ingram
is
mine
,

course
,
"
said
he
:
<EOS>
afterwards
he
named
the
two
Misses
Eshton
,
and
Mrs.
Dent
.
<EOS>
He
looked
at
me
:
<EOS>
I
happened
to
be
near

,
as
I
had

Dent
's

,

.
  
<EOS>
"
Will

?
"
<EOS>
he

.
<EOS>
I

.
<EOS>
He

,

;

.
  
<EOS>
He

:
the

,

.
<EOS>
One

,
Mr.

,

;

Lady

.
  
<EOS>
"
No
,
"
I

:
"
<EOS>
she
looks

any

.
"
  
<EOS>
Ere

a
bell

,
and
the

.
<EOS>
Within

,

Sir

,

,

.
<EOS>
Somebody
,

,

;
then
Adele
(
who
had
insisted
on
being

,

,

the

.
<EOS>
Then

the

of
Miss
Ingram
,

,

,

;

Mr.
Rochester
,
and
together

.
<EOS>
They

;
while
Mrs.
Dent
and
Louisa
Eshton
,
dressed
also

white
,
took
up

.
<EOS>
A
ceremony
followed
,
in
dumb
show
,
in
which
it
was
easy
to
recognise
the
pantomime
of
a

.
<EOS>
At
its
termination
,
Colonel
Dent
and
his
party
consulted
in

for
two
minutes
,
then
the
Colonel
called
out
    
"
Bride
!
"
<EOS>
Mr.
Rochester
bowed
,
and
the
curtain
fell
.
  
<EOS>
A
considerable
interval
elapsed
before
it
again
rose
.
<EOS>
Its
second
rising
displayed
a
more
elaborately
prepared
scene
than
the
last
.
<EOS>
The
drawing-
room
,
as
I
have
before
observed
,
was
raised
two
steps
above
the
dining-
room
,
and
on
the
top
of
the
upper
step
,
placed
a
yard
or
two
back
within
the
room
,
appeared
a
large
marble
basin
 
which
I
recognised
as
an
ornament
of
the
conservatory
 
where
it
usually
stood
,
surrounded
by
exotics
,
and
tenanted
by
gold
fish
 
and
whence
it
must
have
been
transported
with
some
trouble
,
on
account
of
its
size
and
weight
.
  
<EOS>
Seated
on
the
carpet
,
by
the
side
of
this
basin
,
was
seen
Mr.
Rochester
,
costumed
in
shawls
,
with
a
turban
on
his
head
.
<EOS>
His
dark
eyes
and
swarthy
skin
and
Paynim
features
suited
the
costume
exactly
:
he
looked
the
very
model
of
an
Eastern
emir
,
an
agent
or
a
victim
of
the
bowstring
.
<EOS>
Presently
advanced
into
view
Miss
Ingram
.
<EOS>
She
,
too
,
was
attired
in
oriental
fashion
:
a
crimson
scarf
tied
sash
-
like
round
the
waist
:
an
embroidered
handkerchief
knotted
about
her
temples
;
her
beautifully
-
moulded
arms
bare
,
one
of
them
upraised
in
the
act
of
supporting
a
pitcher
,
poised
gracefully
on
her
head
.
<EOS>
Both
her
cast
of
form
and
feature
,
her
complexion
and
her
general
air
,
suggested
the
idea
of
some
Israelitish
princess
of
the
patriarchal
days
;
and
such
was
doubtless
the
character
she
intended
to
represent
.
  
<EOS>
She
approached
the
basin
,
and
bent
over
it
as
if
to
fill
her
pitcher
;
she
again
lifted
it
to
her
head
.
<EOS>
The

<EOS>
"
She

<EOS>
It

<EOS>
Pardon

;

<EOS>
She

.

something

,
because
one
day
she
might
look
into
the
abyss
at
her
leisure
,
explore
its
secrets
and
analyse
their
nature
.
  
<EOS>
Meantime
,
while
I
thought
only
of
my
master
and
his
future
bride
 
saw
only
them
,
heard
only
their
discourse
,
and
considered
only
their
movements
of
importance
 
the
rest
of
the
party
were
occupied
with
their
own
separate
interests
and
pleasures
.
<EOS>
The
Ladies
Lynn
and
Ingram
continued
to
consort
in
solemn
conferences
,
where
they
nodded
their
two
turbans
at
each
other
,
and
held
up
their
four
hands
in
confronting
gestures
of
surprise
,
or
mystery
,
or
horror
,
according
to
the
theme
on
which
their
gossip
ran
,
like
a
pair
of
magnified
puppets
.
<EOS>
Mild
Mrs.
Dent
talked
with
good
-
natured
Mrs.
Eshton
;
and
the
two
sometimes
bestowed
a
courteous
word
or
smile
on
me
.
<EOS>
Sir
George
Lynn
,
Colonel
Dent
,
and
Mr.
Eshton
discussed
politics
,
or
county
affairs
,
or
justice
business
.
<EOS>
Lord
Ingram
flirted
with
Amy
Eshton
;
Louisa
played
and
sang
to
and
with
one
of
the
Messrs.
Lynn
;
and
Mary
Ingram
listened
languidly
to
the
gallant
speeches
of
the
other
.
<EOS>
Sometimes
all
,
as
with
one
consent
,
suspended
their
by
-
play
to
observe
and
listen
to
the
principal
actors
:
for
,
after
all
,
Mr.
Rochester
and
 
because
closely
connected
with
him
 
<EOS>
Miss
Ingram
were
the
life
and
soul
of
the
party
.
<EOS>
If
he
was
absent
from
the
room
an
hour
,
a
perceptible
dulness
seemed
to
steal
over
the
spirits
of
his
guests
;
and
his
re
-
entrance
was
sure
to
give
a
fresh
impulse
to
the
vivacity
of
conversation
.
  
<EOS>
The
want
of
his
animating
influence
appeared
to
be
peculiarly
felt
one
day
that
he
had
been
summoned
to
Millcote
on
business
,
and
was
not
likely
to
return
till
late
.
<EOS>
The
afternoon
was
wet
:
a
walk
the
party
had
proposed
to
take
to
see
a
gipsy
camp
,
lately
pitched
on
a
common
beyond
Hay
,
was
consequently
deferred
.
<EOS>
Some
of
the
gentlemen
were
gone
to
the
stables
:
<EOS>
the
younger
ones
,
together
with
the
younger
ladies
,
were
playing
billiards
in
the
billiard
-
room
.
<EOS>
The
dowagers
Ingram
and
Lynn
sought
solace
in
a
quiet
game
at
cards
.
<EOS>
Blanche
Ingram
,
after
having
repelled
,
by
supercilious
taciturnity
,
some
efforts
of
Mrs.
Dent
and
Mrs.
Eshton
to
draw
her
into
conversation
,
had
first
murmured
over
some
sentimental
tunes
and
airs
on
the
piano
,
and
then
,
having
fetched
a
novel
from
the
library
,
had
flung
herself
in
haughty
listlessness
on
a
sofa
,
and
prepared
to
beguile
,
by
the
spell
of
fiction
,
the
tedious
hours
of
absence
.
<EOS>
The
room
and
the
house
were
silent
:
only
now
and
then
the
merriment
of
the
billiard
-
players
was
heard
from
above
.
  
<EOS>
It
was
verging
on
dusk
,
and
the
clock
had
already
given
warning
of
the
hour
to
dress
for
dinner
,
when
little
Adele
,
who
knelt
by
me
in
the
drawing
-
room
window
-
seat
,
suddenly
exclaimed
    
"
Voila
,
Monsieur
Rochester
,
qui
revient
!
"
  
<EOS>
I
turned
,
and
Miss
Ingram
darted
forwards
from
her
sofa
:
<EOS>
the
others
,
too
,
looked
up
from
their
several
occupations
;
for
at
the
same
time
a
crunching
of
wheels
and
a
splashing
tramp
of
horse
-
hoofs
became
audible
on
the
wet
gravel
.
<EOS>
A
post
-
chaise
was
approaching
.
  
<EOS>
"
What
can
possess
him
to
come
home
in
that
style
?
"
said
Miss
Ingram
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
He
rode
Mesrour
(
the
black
horse
)
,
did
he
not
,
when
he
went
out
?
<EOS>
and
Pilot
was
with
him
:
 
<EOS>
what
has
he
done
with
the
animals
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
As
she
said
this
,
she
approached
her
tall
person
and
ample
garments
so
near
the
window
,
that
I
was
obliged
to
bend
back
almost
to
the
breaking
of
my
spine
:
in
her
eagerness
she
did
not
observe
me
at
first
,
but
when
she
did
,
she
curled
her
lip
and
moved
to
another
casement
.
<EOS>
The
post
-
chaise
stopped
;
the
driver
rang
the
door
-
bell
,
and
a
gentleman
alighted
attired
in
travelling
garb
;
but
it
was
not
Mr.
Rochester
;
it
was
a
tall
,
fashionable
-
looking
man
,
a
stranger
.
  
<EOS>
"
How
provoking
!
<EOS>
"
exclaimed
Miss
Ingram
:
"
you
tiresome
monkey
!
"
<EOS>
(
apostrophising
Adele
)
,
"
who
perched
you
up
in
the
window
to
give
false
intelligence
?
"
<EOS>
and
she
cast
on
me
an
angry
glance
,
as
if
I
were
in
fault
.
  
<EOS>
Some
parleying
was
audible
in
the
hall
,
and
soon
the
new
-
comer
entered
.
<EOS>
He
bowed
to
Lady
Ingram
,
as
deeming
her
the
eldest
lady
present
.
  
<EOS>
"
It
appears
I
come
at
an
inopportune
time
,
madam
,
"
said
he
,
"
when
my
friend
,
Mr.
Rochester
,
is
from
home
;
but
I
arrive
from
a
very
long
journey
,
and
I
think
I
may
presume
so
far
on
old
and
intimate
acquaintance
as
to
instal
myself
here
till
he
returns
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
His
manner
was
polite
;
his
accent
,
in
speaking
,
struck
me
as
being
somewhat
unusual
,
 
not
precisely
foreign
,
but
still
not
altogether
English
:
his
age
might
be
about
Mr.
Rochester
's
,
 
between
thirty
and
forty
;
his
complexion
was
singularly
sallow
:
otherwise
he
was
a
fine
-
looking
man
,
at
first
sight
especially
.
<EOS>
On
closer
examination
,
you
detected
something
in
his
face
that
displeased
,
or
rather
that
failed
to
please
.
<EOS>
His
features
were
regular
,
but
too
relaxed
:
his
eye
was
large
and
well
cut
,
but
the
life
looking
out
of
it
was
a
tame
,
vacant
life
 
<EOS>
at
least
so
I
thought
.
  
<EOS>
The
sound
of
the
dressing
-
bell
dispersed
the
party
.
<EOS>
It
was
not
till
after
dinner
that
I
saw
him
again
:
he
then
seemed
quite
at
his
ease
.
<EOS>
But
I
liked
his
physiognomy
even
less
than
before
:
it
struck
me
as
being
at
the
same
time
unsettled
and
inanimate
.
<EOS>
His
eye
wandered
,
and
had
no
meaning
in
its
wandering
:
this
gave
him
an
odd
look
,
such
as
I
never
remembered
to
have
seen
.
<EOS>
For
a
handsome
and
not
an
unamiable
-
looking
man
,
he
repelled
me
exceedingly
:
there
was
no
power
in
that
smooth
-
skinned
face
of
a
full
oval
shape
:
no
firmness
in
that
aquiline
nose
and
small
cherry
mouth
;
there
was
no
thought
on
the
low
,
even
forehead
;
no
command
in
that
blank
,
brown
eye
.
  
<EOS>
As
I
sat
in
my
usual
nook
,
and
looked
at
him
with
the
light
of
the
girandoles
on
the
mantelpiece
beaming
full
over
him
 
for
he
occupied
an
arm
-
chair
drawn
close
to
the
fire
,
and
kept
shrinking
still
nearer
,
as
if
he
were
cold
,
I
compared
him
with
Mr.
Rochester
.
<EOS>
I
think
(
with
deference
be
it
spoken
)
<EOS>
the
contrast
could
not
be
much
greater
between
a
sleek
gander
and
a
fierce
falcon
:
between
a
meek
sheep
and
the
rough
-
coated
keen
-
eyed
dog
,
its
guardian
.
  
<EOS>
He
had
spoken
of
Mr.
Rochester
as
an
old
friend
.
<EOS>
A
curious
friendship
theirs
must
have
been
:
a
pointed
illustration
,
indeed
,
of
the
old
adage
that
"
extremes
meet
.
"
  
<EOS>
Two
or
three
of
the
gentlemen
sat
near
him
,
and
I
caught
at
times
scraps
of
their
conversation
across
the
room
.
<EOS>
At
first
I
could
not
make
much
sense
of
what
I
heard
;
for
the
discourse
of
Louisa
Eshton
and
Mary
Ingram
,
who
sat
nearer
to
me
,
confused
the
fragmentary
sentences
that
reached
me
at
intervals
.
<EOS>
These
last
were
discussing
the
stranger
;
they
both
called
him
"
a
beautiful
man
.
"
<EOS>
Louisa
said
he
was
"
a
love
of
a
creature
,
"
and
she
"
adored
him
;
"
and
Mary
instanced
his
"
pretty
little
mouth
,
and
nice
nose
,
"
as
her
ideal
of
the
charming
.
  
<EOS>
"
And
what
a
sweet
-
tempered
forehead
he
has
!
"
<EOS>
cried
Louisa
,
 
"
so
smooth
 
none
of
those
frowning
irregularities
I
dislike
so
much
;
and
such
a
placid
eye
and
smile
!
"
  
<EOS>
And
then
,
to
my
great
relief
,
Mr.
Henry
Lynn
summoned
them
to
the
other
side
of
the
room
,
to
settle
some
point
about
the
deferred
excursion
to
Hay
Common
.
  
<EOS>
I
was
now
able
to
concentrate
my
attention
on
the
group
by
the
fire
,
and
I
presently
gathered
that
the
new
-
comer
was
called
Mr.
Mason
<EOS>
;
then
I
learned
that
he
was
but
just
arrived
in
England
,
and
that
he
came
from
some
hot
country
:
which
was
the
reason
,
doubtless
,
<EOS>
his
face
was
so
sallow
,
and
that
he
sat
so
near
the
hearth
,
and
wore
a
surtout
in
the
house
.
<EOS>
Presently
the
words
Jamaica
,
Kingston
,
Spanish
Town
,
indicated
the
West
Indies
as
his
residence
;
and
it
was
with
no
little
surprise
I
gathered
,
ere
long
,
that
he
had
there
first
seen
and
become
acquainted
with
Mr.
Rochester
.
<EOS>
He
spoke
of
his
friend
's
dislike
of
the
burning
heats
,
the
hurricanes
,
and
rainy
seasons
of
that
region
.
<EOS>
I
knew
Mr.
Rochester
had
been
a
traveller
:
<EOS>
Mrs.
Fairfax
had
said
so
;
but
I
thought
the
continent
of
Europe
had
bounded
his
wanderings
;
till
now
I
had
never
heard
a
hint
given
of
visits
to
more
distant
shores
.
  
<EOS>
I
was
pondering
these
things
,
when
an
incident
,
and
a
somewhat
unexpected
one
,
broke
the
thread
of
my
musings
.
<EOS>
Mr.
Mason
,
shivering
as
some
one
chanced
to
open
the
door
,
asked
for
more
coal
to
be
put
on
the
fire
,
which
had
burnt
out
its
flame
,
though
its
mass
of
cinder
still
shone
hot
and
red
.
<EOS>
The
footman
who
brought
the
coal
,
in
going
out
,
stopped
near
Mr.
Eshton
's
chair
,
and
said
something
to
him
in
a
low
voice
,
of
which
I
heard
only
the
words
,
"
old
woman
,
"
 
"
quite
troublesome
.
"
  
<EOS>
"
Tell
her
she
shall
be
put
in
the
stocks
if
she
does
not
take
herself
off
,
"
replied
the
magistrate
.
  
<EOS>
"
No
 
stop
!
"
<EOS>
interrupted
Colonel
Dent
.
<EOS>
"
Do
n't
send
her
away
,
Eshton
;
we
might
turn
the
thing
to
account
;
better
consult
the
ladies
.
"
<EOS>
And
speaking
aloud
,
he
continued
 
<EOS>
"
Ladies
,
you
talked
of
going
to
Hay
Common
to
visit
the
gipsy
camp
;
Sam
here
says
that
one
of
the
old
Mother
Bunches
is
in
the
servants
'
hall
at
this
moment
,
and
insists
upon
being
brought
in
before
"
the
quality
,
"
to
tell
them
their
fortunes
.
<EOS>
Would
you
like
to
see
her
?
"
  
<EOS>
"
Surely
,
colonel
,
"
cried
Lady
Ingram
,
"
you
would
not
encourage
such
a
low
impostor
?
<EOS>
Dismiss
her
,
by
all
means
,
at
once
!
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
But
I
can
not
persuade
her
to
go
away
,
my
lady
,
"
said
the
footman
;
"
nor
can
any
of
the
servants
:
Mrs.
Fairfax
is
with
her
just
now
,
entreating
her
to
be
gone
;
but
she
has
taken
a
chair
in
the

-
corner
,
and
says
nothing
shall
stir
her
from
it
till
she
gets
leave
to
come
in
here
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
What
does
she
want
?
"
asked

Eshton
.
  
<EOS>
"
"
To
tell
the
gentry
their
fortunes
,
"
she
says
,
ma'am
;
and
she
swears
she
must
and
will
do
it
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
What
is
she
like
?
"
inquired

Misses
Eshton
,
in
a

.
  
<EOS>
"
A
shockingly
ugly
old
creature
,
miss
;
almost
as
black
as
a
crock
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Why
,
she
's
a
real
sorceress
!
"
<EOS>
cried
Frederick
Lynn
.
<EOS>
"
Let
us
have
her
in
,
of
course
.
"
  
<EOS>
"
To
be
sure
,
"
rejoined
his
brother
;
"
it
would
be
a
thousand
pities
to
throw

such
a
chance
of
fun
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
My
dear
boys
,
what
are
you
thinking
about
?
"
exclaimed
Mrs.
Lynn
.
  
<EOS>
"
I
can
not
possibly
countenance
any
such
inconsistent
proceeding
,
"
chimed
in
the
Dowager
Ingram
.
  
<EOS>
"
Indeed
,
mama
,
but
you
can
 
and
will
,
"
pronounced
the
haughty
voice
of
Blanche
,
as

turned
round
on
the
piano
-
stool
;
where
till
now
she
had
sat
silent
,
apparently
examining
sundry
sheets
of
music
.
<EOS>
"
I
have
a
curiosity
to
hear
my
fortune
told
:
therefore
,
Sam
,
order
the
beldame
forward
.
<EOS>
"
  
"
<EOS>
My
darling
Blanche
!
<EOS>
recollect
 
<EOS>
"
  
"
I
do
 
<EOS>
I
recollect
all
you
can
suggest
;
and
I
must
have
my
will
 
quick
,
Sam
!
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Yes
 
yes
 
yes
!
"
cried
all
the
juveniles
,
both
ladies
and
gentlemen
.
<EOS>
"
Let
her
come
 
it
will
be
excellent
sport
!
"
  
<EOS>
The
footman
still
lingered
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
She
looks
such
a
rough
one
,
"
said

.

"

<EOS>
I
wish
to
foster
,
not
to
blight
 
to
earn
gratitude
,
not
to
wring
tears
of
blood
 
no
,
nor
of
brine
:
my
harvest
must
be
in
smiles
,
in
endearments
,
in
sweet
 
That
will
do
.
<EOS>
I
think
I
rave
in
a
kind
of
exquisite
delirium
.
<EOS>
I
should
wish
now
to
protract
this
moment
_
ad
infinitum
_
;
but
I
dare
not
.
<EOS>
So
far
I
have
governed
myself
thoroughly
.
<EOS>
I
have
acted
as
I
inwardly
swore
I
would
act
;
but
further
might
try
me
beyond
my
strength
.
<EOS>
Rise
,
Miss
Eyre
:
leave
me
;
the
play
is
played
out
'
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
Where
was
I
?
<EOS>
Did
I
wake
or
sleep
?
<EOS>
Had
I
been
dreaming
?
<EOS>
Did
I
dream
still
?
<EOS>
The
old
woman
's
voice
had
changed
:
her
accent
,
her
gesture
,
and
all
were
familiar
to
me
as
my
own
face
in
a
glass
 
as
the
speech
of
my
own
tongue
.
<EOS>
I
got
up
,
but
did
not
go
.
<EOS>
I
looked
;
I
stirred
the
fire
,
and
I
looked
again
:
but
she
drew
her
bonnet
and
her
bandage
closer
about
her
face
,
and
again
beckoned
me
to
depart
.
<EOS>
The
flame
illuminated
her
hand
stretched
out
:
roused
now
,
and
on
the
alert
for
discoveries
,
I
at
once
noticed
that
hand
.
<EOS>
It
was
no
more
the
withered
limb
of
eld
than
my
own
;
it
was
a
rounded
supple
member
,
with
smooth
fingers
,
symmetrically
turned
;
a
broad
ring
flashed
on
the
little
finger
,
and
stooping
forward
,
I
looked
at
it
,
and
saw
a
gem
I
had
seen
a
hundred
times
before
.
<EOS>
Again
I
looked
at
the
face
;
which
was
no
longer
turned
from
me
 
on
the
contrary
,
the
bonnet
was
doffed
,
the
bandage
displaced
,
the
head
advanced
.
  
<EOS>
"
Well
,
Jane
,
do
you
know
me
?
"
asked
the
familiar
voice
.
  
<EOS>
"
Only
take
off
the
red
cloak
,
sir
,
and
then
 
"
  
"
<EOS>
But
the
string
is
in
a
knot
 
<EOS>
help
me
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Break
it
,
sir
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
There
,
then
 
"
Off
,
ye
lendings
!
"
<EOS>
"
And
Mr.
Rochester
stepped
out
of
his
disguise
.
  
<EOS>
"
Now
,
sir
,
what
a
strange
idea
!
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
But
well
carried
out
,
eh
?
<EOS>
Do

you
think
so
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
With
the
ladies
you
must
have
managed
well
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
But
not
with
you
?
"
  
<EOS>
"
You
did
not
act
the
character
of
a
gipsy
with
me
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
What
character
did
I
act
?
<EOS>
My
own
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
No
;
some
unaccountable
one
.
<EOS>
In
short
,
I
believe
you
have
been
trying
to
draw
me
out
 
or
in
;
you
have
been
talking
nonsense
to
make
me
talk
nonsense
.
<EOS>
It
is
scarcely
fair
,
sir
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Do
you
forgive
me
,
Jane
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
can
not
tell
till
I
have
thought
it
all
over
.
<EOS>
If
,
on
reflection
,
I
find
I
have
fallen
into
no

,
I
shall
try
to
forgive
you
;
but
it
was
not
right
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Oh
,
you
have
been
very
correct
 
very
careful
,
very
sensible
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
I
reflected
,
and
thought
,
on
the
whole
,
I
had
.
<EOS>
It
was
a
comfort
;
but
,
indeed
,
I
had
been
on
my
guard
almost
from
the
beginning
of
the
interview
.
<EOS>
Something
of
masquerade
I
suspected
.
<EOS>
I
knew
gipsies
and
fortune
-
tellers
did
not
express
themselves
as
this
seeming
old
woman
had
expressed
herself
;
besides
I
had
noted
her
feigned
voice
,
her
anxiety
to

.
<EOS>
But
my
mind
had
been
running
on
Grace
Poole
 
<EOS>
that
living
enigma
,
that
mystery
of
mysteries
,
as
I
considered
her
.
<EOS>
I
had
never
thought
of
Mr.
Rochester
.
  
<EOS>
"
Well
,
"
said
he
,
"
what
are
you
musing
about
?
<EOS>
What
does
that
grave

signify
?
<EOS>
"
  
"
Wonder
and
self

,
sir
.
<EOS>
I
have
your

to

now
,
I

?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
No
;
stay
a

;
and
tell

the

yonder
are

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Discussing
the
gipsy
,
I
daresay
.
<EOS>
"
  
"
Sit
down
!
 
<EOS>
Let
me
hear
what
they
said
about
me
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
had
better
not
stay
long
,
sir
;
it
must
be
near
eleven

.
<EOS>
Oh
,
are
you
aware
,
Mr.
Rochester
,
that
a
stranger
has
arrived
here
since
you
left
this

?
"
  
<EOS>
"
A
stranger
!
 
<EOS>
no
;
who
can
it
be
?
<EOS>
I
expected
no
one
;
is
he
gone
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
No
;
he
said
he
had
known
you
long
,
and
that
he
could
take
the
liberty
of
installing
himself
here
till
you
returned
.
<EOS>
"
  
"
The
devil
he
did
!
<EOS>
Did
he
give
his
name
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
His
name
is
Mason
,
sir
;
and
he
comes
from
the
West
Indies
;
from
Spanish
Town
,
in
Jamaica
,
I

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
Mr.
Rochester
was
standing
near
me
;
he
had
taken
my
hand
,
as
if
to
lead
me
to
a

.
<EOS>
As
I
spoke
he
gave
my
wrist
a
convulsive
grip
;
the
smile
on
his
lips
froze
:
<EOS>
apparently
a
spasm
caught
his
breath
.
  
<EOS>
"
Mason
!
 
<EOS>
the
West
Indies
!
"
<EOS>
he
said
,
in
the
tone
one
might
fancy
a
speaking
automaton
to
enounce
its
single

;
"
Mason
!
 
<EOS>
the
West
Indies
!
"
<EOS>
he
reiterated
;
and
he
went
over
the
syllables
three
times
,
growing
,
in
the
intervals
of
speaking
,
whiter
than
ashes
:
<EOS>
he
hardly
seemed
to
know
what
he
was
doing
.
  
<EOS>
"
Do
you
feel
ill
,
sir
?
<EOS>
"
I
inquired
.
  
<EOS>
"
Jane
,
I
've
got
a
blow
;
I
've
got
a
blow
,
Jane
!
"
<EOS>
He
staggered
.
  
<EOS>
"
Oh
,
lean
on
me
,

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Jane
,
you
offered
me
your
shoulder
once
before
;
let
me
have
it
now
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Yes
,
sir
,
yes
;
and
my
arm
.
"
  
<EOS>
He
sat
down
,
and
made

beside

.
<EOS>
Holding
my
hand
in

his
own
,
he
chafed

;
gazing
on

,
at
the

,

.
  
<EOS>
"
My
little
friend
!
<EOS>
"
said

,
"
I
wish
I
were
in
a
quiet
island
with
only
you
;
and
trouble
,
and
danger
,
and
hideous
recollections
removed
from

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Can
I
help
you
,
sir
?
 
<EOS>
I
'd
give
my
life
to
serve
you
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Jane
,
if
aid
is
wanted
,
I
'll

;
I

.
"
  
<EOS>
"
Thank

,

.
<EOS>
Tell

what
to
do
,
 
I
'll

,
at

,

do

.
"
  
<EOS>
"
Fetch
me
now
,
Jane
,
a
glass
of
wine
from

-
room
:
they
will
be
at
supper
there
;
and

if
Mason
is

,

is

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
I
went
.
<EOS>
I
found
all
the
party
in
the
dining
-
room
at
supper
,
as
Mr.
Rochester
had
said
;
they
were
not
seated
at
table
,
 
the
supper
was
arranged
on
the

;
each
had
taken
what
he
chose
,
and
they
stood
about
here
and

,
their
plates
and

in

.
<EOS>
Every
one
seemed
in
high
glee
;
laughter
and
conversation
were
general
and
animated
.
<EOS>
Mr.
Mason
stood
near
the
fire
,
talking
to
Colonel
and
Mrs.
Dent
,
and
appeared
as
merry
as
any
of
them
.
<EOS>
I
filled
a
wine
-
glass
<EOS>
(
I
saw
Miss
Ingram
watch
me
frowningly
as
I
did
so
<EOS>
:
she
thought
I
was
taking
a
liberty
,
I
daresay
)
,
and
I
returned
to
the
library
.
  
<EOS>
Mr.
Rochester
's
extreme
pallor
had
disappeared
,
and
he
looked
once
more
firm
and
stern
.
<EOS>
He
took
the
glass
from
my
hand
.
  
<EOS>
"
Here
is
to
your
health
,
ministrant
spirit
!
"
<EOS>
he
said
.
<EOS>
He
swallowed
the
contents
and
returned
it
to
me
.
<EOS>
"
What
are
they
doing
,
Jane
?
"
  
"
Laughing
and
talking
,
sir
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
They
do
n't
look
grave
and
mysterious
,
as

had

strange
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Not
at
all
:
they
are
full
of

and

.
<EOS>
"
  
"
<EOS>
And
Mason
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
He
was
laughing
too
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
If
all
these
people
came
in
a
body
and
spat
at
me
,
what
would
you
do
,
Jane
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Turn
them
out
of
the
room
,
sir
,
if
I
could
.
"
  
<EOS>
He
half
smiled
.
<EOS>
"
But
if
I
were
to
go
to
them
,
and
they
only
looked
at
me

,
and

amongst

,

one

,
<EOS>
what

?
<EOS>
Would

go
with

?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
rather
think
not
,
sir
:
<EOS>
I
should
have
more
pleasure
in
staying
with
you
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
To
comfort

?
"
  
<EOS>
"
Yes
,
sir
,
to
comfort
you
,
as
well
as
I
could
.
"
  
"
And
if
they
laid
you
under
a
ban
for
adhering
to
me
?
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
,
probably
,
should
know
nothing
about
their
ban
;
and
if
I
did
,
I
should
care
nothing
about

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Then
,
you
could
dare
censure
for
my

?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
could
dare
it
for
the
sake
of
any
friend
who
deserved
my
adherence
;
as
you
,
I
am
sure
,
do
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Go
back
now
into

;
step

up

Mason
,
and

in

Mr.
Rochester
is
come
and
wishes

see
him
:
show
him
in
here
and
then
leave

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Yes
,
sir
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
I
did
his
behest
.
<EOS>
The
company
all
stared
at
me
as
I
passed
straight
among
them
.
<EOS>
I
sought
Mr.
Mason
,
delivered
the
message
,
and
preceded
him
from
the
room
:
I
ushered
him
into
the
library
,
and
then
I
went
upstairs
.
  
<EOS>
At
a
late
hour
,
after
I
had
been
in
bed
some
time
,
I
heard
the
visitors
repair
to
their
chambers
:
I
distinguished
Mr.
Rochester
's
voice
,
and
heard
him
say
,
"
This
way
,
Mason
;
this
is
your
room
.
"
  
<EOS>
He
spoke
cheerfully
:
<EOS>
the
gay
tones
set
my
heart
at
ease
.
<EOS>
I
was
soon
asleep
.
    
<EOS>
I
had
forgotten
to
draw
my
curtain
,
which
I
usually
did
,
and
also
to
let
down
my
window
-
blind
.
<EOS>
The
consequence
was
,
that
when
the
moon
,
which
was
full
and
bright
(
for
the
night
was
fine
)
,
came
in
her
course
to
that
space
in
the
sky
opposite
my
casement
,
and
looked
in
at
me
through
the
unveiled
panes
,
her
glorious
gaze
roused
me
.
<EOS>
Awaking
in
the
dead
of
night
,
I
opened
my
eyes
on
her
disk
 
silver
-
white
and
crystal
clear
.
<EOS>
It
was
beautiful
,
but
too
solemn
;
I
half
rose
,
and
stretched
my
arm
to
draw
the
curtain
.
  
<EOS>
Good
God
!
<EOS>
What
a
cry
!
  
<EOS>
The
night
 
its
silence
 
its
rest
,
was
rent
in
twain
by
a
savage
,
a
sharp
,
a
shrilly
sound
that
ran
from
end
to
end
of
Thornfield
Hall
.
  
<EOS>
My
pulse
stopped
:
my
heart
stood
still
;
my
stretched
arm
was
paralysed
.
<EOS>
The
cry
died
,
and
was
not
renewed
.
<EOS>
Indeed
,
whatever
being
uttered
that
fearful
shriek
could
not
soon
repeat
it
:
not
the
widest
-
winged
condor
on
the
Andes
could
,
twice
in
succession
,
send
out
such
a
yell
from
the
cloud
shrouding
his
eyrie
.
<EOS>
The
thing
delivering
such
utterance
must
rest
ere
it
could
repeat
the
effort
.
  
<EOS>
It
came
out
of
the
third
storey
;
for
it
passed
overhead
.
<EOS>
And
overhead
 
yes
,
in
the
room
just
above
my
chamber
-
ceiling
 
<EOS>
I
now
heard
a
struggle
:
<EOS>
a
deadly
one
it
seemed
from
the
noise
;
and
a
half
-
smothered
voice
shouted
    
"
Help
!
<EOS>
help
!
<EOS>
help
!
"
<EOS>
three
times
rapidly
.
  
<EOS>
"
Will
no
one
come
?
"
<EOS>
it
cried
;
and
then
,

,
<EOS>
I
distinguished

"
Rochester
!
<EOS>
Rochester
!
<EOS>
for

"
  
<EOS>
A

:

.
<EOS>
Another

and

.
  
<EOS>
I
had

on
some

,
though
horror

;
I

.
<EOS>
The

.
<EOS>
Gentlemen

and
"

<EOS>
what

"
 
<EOS>
"

<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
What

"
 
<EOS>
"

"
 
<EOS>
"

"
 
<EOS>
"

?
"

<EOS>
But

"

<EOS>
"
I

<EOS>
"

<EOS>
Here

<EOS>
here

"

<EOS>

<EOS>

No

<EOS>

Again

He

Remember
!

"

<EOS>
I

<EOS>
Here

the

.
  
<EOS>
I

,

.
<EOS>
I

these

,

.
  
<EOS>
According

,

,

,

<EOS>
But

:

,

step
creak
,
a
momentary
renewal
of
the
snarling
,
canine
noise
,
and
a
deep
human
groan
.
  
<EOS>
Then
my
own
thoughts
worried
me
.
<EOS>
What
crime
was
this
that
lived
incarnate
in
this
sequestered
mansion
,
and
could
neither
be
expelled
nor
subdued
by
the
owner
?
 
<EOS>
what
mystery
,
that
broke
out
now
in
fire
and
now
in
blood
,
at
the
deadest
hours
of
night
?
<EOS>
What
creature
was
it
,
that
,
masked
in
an
ordinary
woman
's
face
and
shape
,
uttered
the
voice
,
now
of
a
mocking
demon
,
and
anon
of
a
carrion
-
seeking
bird
of
prey
?
  
<EOS>
And
this
man
I
bent
over
 
this
commonplace
,
quiet
stranger
 
<EOS>
how
had
he
become
involved
in
the
web
of
horror
?
<EOS>
and
why
had
the
Fury
flown
at
him
?
<EOS>
What
made
him
seek
this
quarter
of
the
house
at
an
untimely
season
,
when
he
should
have
been
asleep
in
bed
?
<EOS>
I
had
heard
Mr.
Rochester
assign
him
an
apartment
below
 
<EOS>
what
brought
him
here
!
<EOS>
And
why
,
now
,
was
he
so
tame
under
the
violence
or
treachery
<EOS>
done
him
?
<EOS>
Why
did
he
so
quietly
submit
to
the
concealment
Mr.
Rochester
enforced
?
<EOS>
Why
_
did
_
Mr.
Rochester
enforce
this
concealment
?
<EOS>
His
guest
had
been
outraged
,
his
own
life
on
a
former
occasion
had
been
hideously
plotted
against
;
and
both
attempts
he
smothered
in
secrecy
and
sank
in
oblivion
!
<EOS>
Lastly
,
I
saw
Mr.
Mason
was
submissive
to
Mr.
Rochester
;
that
the
impetuous
will
of
the
latter
held
complete
sway
over
the
inertness
of
the
former
:
the
few
words
which
had
passed
between
them
assured
me
of
this
.
<EOS>
It
was
evident
that
in
their
former
intercourse
,
the
passive
disposition
of
the
one
had
been
habitually
influenced
by
the
active
energy
of
the
other
:
whence
then
had
arisen
Mr.
Rochester
's
dismay
when
he
heard
of
Mr.
Mason
's
arrival
?
<EOS>
Why
had
the
mere
name
of
this
unresisting
individual
 
<EOS>
whom
his
word
now
sufficed
to
control
like
a
child
 
<EOS>
fallen
on
him
,
a
few
hours
since
,
as
a
thunderbolt
might
fall
on
an
oak
?
  
<EOS>
Oh
!
<EOS>
I
could
not
forget
his
look
and
his
paleness
when
he
whispered
:
"
Jane
,
I
have
got
a
blow
 
<EOS>
I
have
got
a
blow
,
Jane
.
<EOS>
"
I
could
not
forget
how
the
arm
had
trembled
which
he
rested
on
my
shoulder
:
and
it
was
no
light
matter
which
could
thus
bow
the
resolute
spirit
and
thrill
the
vigorous
frame
of
Fairfax
Rochester
.
  
<EOS>
"
When
will
he
come
?
<EOS>
When
will
he
come
?
<EOS>
"
I
cried
inwardly
,
as
the
night
lingered
and
lingered
 
as
my
bleeding
patient
drooped
,
moaned
,
sickened
:
and
neither
day
nor
aid
arrived
.
<EOS>
I
had
,
again
and
again
,
held
the
water
to
Mason
's
white
lips
;
again
and
again
offered
him
the
stimulating
salts
:
my
efforts
seemed
ineffectual
:
either
bodily
or
mental
suffering
,
or
loss
of
blood
,
or
all
three
combined
,
were
fast
prostrating
his
strength
.
<EOS>
He
moaned
so
,
and
looked
so
weak
,
wild
,
and
lost
,
I
feared
he
was
dying
;
and
I
might
not
even
speak
to
him
.
  
<EOS>
The
candle
,
wasted
at
last
,
went
out
;
as
it
expired
,
I
perceived
streaks
of
grey
light
edging
the
window
curtains
:
dawn
was
then
approaching
.
<EOS>
Presently
I
heard
Pilot
bark
far
below
,
out
of
his
distant
kennel
in
the
courtyard
:
hope
revived
.
<EOS>
Nor
was
it
unwarranted
:
in
five
minutes
more
the
grating
key
,
the
yielding
lock
,
warned
me
my
watch
was
relieved
.
<EOS>
It
could
not
have
lasted
more
than
two
hours
:
many
a
week
has
seemed
shorter
.
  
<EOS>
Mr.
Rochester
entered
,
and
with
him
the
surgeon
he
had
been
to
fetch
.
  
<EOS>
"
Now
,
Carter
,
be
on
the
alert
,
"
he
said
to
this
last
:
"
I
give
you
but
half
-
an
-
hour
for
dressing
the
wound
,
fastening
the
bandages
,
getting
the
patient
downstairs
and
all
.
"
  
<EOS>
"
But
is
he
fit
to
move
,
sir
?
"
  
<EOS>
"
No
doubt
of
it
;
it
is
nothing
serious
;
he
is
nervous
,
his
spirits
must
be
kept
up
.
<EOS>
Come
,
set
to
work
.
"
  
<EOS>
Mr.
Rochester
drew
back
the
thick
curtain
,
drew
up
the
holland
blind
,
let
in
all
the
daylight
he
could
;
and
I
was
surprised
and
cheered
to
see
how
far
dawn
was
advanced
:
what
rosy
streaks
were
beginning
to
brighten
the
east
.
<EOS>
Then
he
approached
Mason
,
whom
the
surgeon
was
already
handling
.
  
<EOS>
"
Now
,
my
good
fellow
,
how
are
you
?
"
<EOS>
he
asked
.
  
<EOS>
"
She
's
done
for
me
,
I
fear
,
"
was
the
faint
reply
.
  
<EOS>
"
Not
a
whit
!
 
<EOS>
courage
!
<EOS>
This
day
fortnight
you
'll
hardly
be
a
pin
the
worse
of
it
:
you
've
lost
a
little
blood
;
that
's
all
.
<EOS>
Carter
,
assure
him
there
's
no
danger
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
can
do
that
conscientiously
,
"
said
Carter
,
who
had
now
undone
the
bandages
;
"
only
I
wish
I
could
have
got
here
sooner
<EOS>
:
he
would
not
have
bled
so
much
 
<EOS>
but
how
is
this
?
<EOS>
The
flesh
on
the
shoulder
is
torn
as
well
as
cut
.
<EOS>
This
wound
was
not
done
with
a
knife
:
there
have
been
teeth
here
!
"
  
<EOS>
"
She
bit
me
,
"
he
murmured
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
She
worried
me
like
a
tigress
,
when
Rochester
got
the
knife
from
her
.
"
  
<EOS>
"
You
should
not
have
yielded
:
you
should
have
grappled
with
her
at
once
,
"
said
Mr.
Rochester
.
  
<EOS>
"
But
under
such
circumstances
,
what
could
one
do
?
"
returned
Mason
.
<EOS>
"
Oh
,
it
was
frightful
!
"
<EOS>
he
added
,
shuddering
.
"
<EOS>
And
I
did
not
expect
it
:
she
looked
so
quiet
at
first
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
warned
you
,
"
was
his
friend
's
answer
;
"
I
said
 
be
on
your
guard
when
you
go
near
her
.
<EOS>
Besides
,
you
might
have
waited
till
to
-
morrow
,
and
had
me
with
you
:
it
was
mere
folly
to
attempt
the
interview
to
-
night
,
and
alone
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
thought
I
could
have
done
some
good
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
You
thought
!
<EOS>
you
thought
!
<EOS>
Yes
,
it
makes
me
impatient
to
hear
you
:
<EOS>
but
,
however
,
you
have
suffered
,
and
are
likely
to
suffer
enough
for
not
taking
my
advice
;
so
I
'll
say
no

.
<EOS>
Carter
 
hurry
!
 
<EOS>
hurry
!
<EOS>
The
sun
will
soon
rise
,
and
I
must
have
him
off
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Directly
,

;
the
shoulder
is
just

.
<EOS>
I
must
look
to
this
other
wound
in
the

:
she
has
had
her
teeth
here
too
,
I

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
She
sucked
the
blood
:
she
said
she
'd
drain
my
heart
,
"
said
Mason
.
  
<EOS>
I
saw
Mr.
Rochester
shudder
:
a
singularly
marked
expression
of
disgust
,
horror
,
hatred
,
warped
his

almost
to

;
but
he
only

"
Come
,

silent
,
Richard
,
and
never

her

:
do

repeat

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
wish
I
could
forget
it
,
"
was
the

.
  
<EOS>
"
You
will
when
you
are
out
of
the
country
:
when
you
get
back
to
Spanish
Town
,
you
may
think
of
her
as
dead

or

,

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Impossible
to

night
!
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
It
is
not
impossible
:
have
some
energy
,
man
.
<EOS>
You
thought
you
were
as
dead
as
a
herring
two
hours
since
,

you
are
all

and

.
<EOS>
There
!
 
<EOS>
Carter
has
done
with
you
or

;
I
'll

you
decent

.
<EOS>
Jane
"
<EOS>
(

for

re

)
,
"
take
this
key
:

,

:

:

;
and

.
"
  
<EOS>
I
went
;
sought
the
repository
he
had
mentioned
,
found
the
articles

,
and

.
  
<EOS>
"
Now
,
"
said

,
"
go
to

I
order

;
but
do

room
:
you
may
be
wanted
again
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
I

as

.
  
<EOS>
"
Was
anybody
stirring
below
when
you
went
down
,
Jane
?
"
inquired

Rochester
presently
.
  
<EOS>
"
No
,
sir
;
all
was
very

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
We
shall
get
you
off
cannily
,
Dick
:
and
it
will
be
better
,
both
for
your
sake
,
and
for
that
of
the
poor

in

.
<EOS>
I
have
striven
long
to
avoid
exposure
,
and
I
should
not

it
to
come
at
last
.
<EOS>
Here
,
Carter
,
help
him
on
with

.
<EOS>
Where
did
you
leave
your
furred

?
<EOS>
You
ca
n't
travel
a
mile
without
that
,
I
know
,
in
this
damned

climate
.
<EOS>
In
your
room
?
 
<EOS>
Jane
,
run
down
to
Mr.
Mason
's
room
,
 
the
one
next
mine
,
 
and
fetch
a
cloak
you
will
see
there
.
"
  
<EOS>
Again
I
ran
,
and
again
returned
,
bearing
an
immense
mantle
lined
and
edged
with
fur
.
  
<EOS>
"
Now
,
I
've
another
errand
for
you
,
"
said
my
untiring

;
<EOS>
"
you
must
away
to
my
room
again
.
<EOS>
What
a
mercy
you
are
shod
with
velvet
,
Jane
!
 
<EOS>
a
clod
-
hopping
messenger
would
never
do
at
this

.
<EOS>
You
must
open
the
middle

of
my
toilet
-

and
take

a
little
phial
and

little

you

,
 
quick
!
"
  
<EOS>
I
flew
thither
and
back
,
bringing
the
desired
vessels
.
  
<EOS>
"
That
's
well
!
<EOS>
Now
,
doctor
,
I
shall
take
the

of
administering
a
dose
myself
,
on

.
<EOS>
I
got
this
cordial
at
Rome
,
of
an
Italian
charlatan
 
<EOS>
a
fellow
you
would
have
kicked
,
Carter
.
<EOS>
It
is
not
a
thing
to
be
used

,
but
it
is
good
upon

:
as

,

.
<EOS>
Jane
,
a
little
water
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
He
held
out
the
tiny

,

I
half

from

-

.
  
<EOS>
"
That
will
do
;
 
now
wet
the
lip
of
the
phial
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
I
did
so
;
he
measured
twelve
drops
of
a
crimson
liquid
,
and
presented
it
to
Mason
.
  
<EOS>
"
Drink
,
Richard
:
it
will
give
you
the

you
lack
,
for
an

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
But
will
it
hurt
me
?
 
<EOS>
is
it
inflammatory
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Drink
!
drink
!
<EOS>
drink
!
"
  
<EOS>
Mr.
Mason
obeyed
,
because
it
was
evidently
useless
to
resist
.
<EOS>
He
was
dressed
now
:
he
still
looked
pale
,
but
he
was
no
longer
gory
and
sullied
.
<EOS>
Mr.
Rochester
let
him
sit
three
minutes
after
he
had
swallowed
the
liquid
;
he
then
took
his
arm
    
"
<EOS>
Now
I
am
sure
you
can
get
on
your
feet
,
"
he
said
 
"
try
.
"
  
<EOS>
The
patient
rose
.
  
<EOS>
"
Carter
,
take
him
under
the
other
shoulder
.
<EOS>
Be
of
good
cheer
,
Richard
;
step
out
 
that
's
it
!
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
do
feel
better
,
"
remarked
Mr.
Mason
.
  
<EOS>
"
I
am
sure
you
do
.
<EOS>
Now
,
Jane
,
trip
on
before
us
away
to
the
backstairs
;
unbolt
the
side
-

,
and

the
driver
of
the
post
-
chaise
you
will
see
in
the
yard
 
or
just
outside
,
for
I
told

not
to

over
the

to
be
ready
;
we
are
coming
:
and
,
Jane
,
if
any

is

,
come
to

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
It
was
by
this
time
half
-
past
five
,
and
the
sun
was
on
the
point
of
rising
;
but
I
found
the
kitchen
still
dark
and

.
<EOS>
The
side
-
passage
door
was
fastened
;
I
opened
it
with
as
little

as
possible
:
all
the
yard
was
quiet
;
but
the
gates
stood
wide
open
,
and
there
was
a
post
-
chaise
,
with
horses
ready

,
and
driver
seated
on
the
box
,
stationed
outside
.
<EOS>
I
approached
him
,
and
said
the
gentlemen
were
coming
;
he
nodded
:
then
I
looked
carefully
round
and
listened
.
<EOS>
The
stillness
of
early
morning
slumbered
everywhere
;
the
curtains
were
yet
drawn
over
the
servants
'
chamber
windows
;
little
birds
were
just
twittering
in
the
blossom
-
blanched
orchard
trees
,
whose
boughs
drooped
like
white
garlands
over
the
wall
enclosing
one
side
of
the
yard
;
the
carriage
horses
stamped
from
time
to
time
in
their
closed
stables
:
all
else
was
still
.
  
<EOS>
The
gentlemen
now
appeared
.
<EOS>
Mason
,
supported
by
Mr.
Rochester
and
the
surgeon
,
seemed
to
walk
with
tolerable
ease
:
they
assisted
him
into
the
chaise
;
Carter
followed
.
  
<EOS>
"
Take
care
of
him
,
"
said
Mr.
Rochester
to

,
"
and
keep
him
at
your

till
he
is
quite
well
:
I
shall
ride
over
in
a
day

two
to
see
how
he
gets
on
.
<EOS>
Richard
,
how
is
it
with
you
?
"
  
<EOS>
"
The
fresh
air
revives
me
,
Fairfax
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Leave
the
window
open
on
his
side
,
Carter
;
there
is
no
wind
 
good
-
bye
,
Dick
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Fairfax
 
"
  
"
Well
what
is
it
?
"
  
<EOS>
"
Let
her
be
taken
care
of
;
let
her
be
treated
as

as
may
be
:
let
her
 
"
he
stopped
and
burst
into

.
  
<EOS>
"
I
do
my
best
;
and
have
done
it
,
and
will
do
it
,
"
was
the
answer
:
he
shut

,

.
  
<EOS>
"
Yet
would
to
God
<EOS>
there
was
an
end
of
all
this
!
"
<EOS>
added

Rochester
,
as

and

heavy

.
  
<EOS>
This

,
he
moved
with
slow

and
abstracted

towards
a
door
in
the
wall
bordering
the
orchard
.
<EOS>
I
,
supposing
he
had
done

me
,
prepared
to

;
again
,

I

"
Jane
!
"
<EOS>
He
had
opened

and

,

.
  
<EOS>
"
Come
where
there
is
some

,

,
"
he

;
"
that

:

?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
It

,

.
"
  
<EOS>
"
The

"

"

you
can
not

,

mere

.
<EOS>
Now
_
here
<EOS>
_
<EOS>
"
(

had

)
"
<EOS>
all

,

,

.
"
  
<EOS>
He

down
a
walk
edged
with
box
,
with

,

,
and

,

.
<EOS>
They

of
April

,

by
a
lovely
spring

,
could

:
the

just

,
and
his

illumined
the
wreathed

.
  
<EOS>
"
Jane
,
will
you
have
a

?
"
  
<EOS>
He
gathered
a
half
-
blown
rose
,
the
first
on
the

,
and

to
me
.
  
<EOS>
"
Thank
you
,
sir
.
<EOS>
"
  
"
Do
you
like
this
sunrise
,
Jane
?
<EOS>
That

with

and

which

warm
 
this

?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"

,

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
You
have
passed

,
Jane
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Yes
,

.
"
  
<EOS>
"
And

has

look
pale
 
were

?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"

I

<EOS>
I

in

pocket
<EOS>
:
I

my

so
near

,

:
<EOS>
you

.
<EOS>
"
  
"
Will

,

?
"
  
"
<EOS>
Oh

!
<EOS>
do

about
her
 
<EOS>
put

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Yet

your

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Never
fear
 
I
will
take

.
"
  
<EOS>
"
Is
the

you
apprehended
last

gone
by

,

?
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
can
not
vouch
for

till

:
nor

.
<EOS>
To

,

,
Jane
,
is
to
stand
on

-

which
may

and

fire
any

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
But
Mr.
Mason
seems
a
man

led
.
<EOS>
Your
influence
,
sir
,
is
evidently
potent
with
him
:
he
will
never
set
you
at

or
wilfully

you
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Oh
,
no
!
<EOS>
Mason
will
not
defy
me
;
nor
,
knowing
it
,
will
he
hurt
me
 
<EOS>
but
,
unintentionally
,
he
might
in

,
by

,
deprive
me
,
if

,
yet

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Tell

,

:
let

fear
,
and
show

to

.
"
  
<EOS>
He
laughed

,
hastily
took
my

,
and
as

it
from

.
  
<EOS>
"
If
I
could
do
that
,
simpleton
,
where
would
the
danger
be
?
<EOS>
Annihilated
in

.
<EOS>
Ever
since
I
have
known
Mason
,
I
have
only

"
Do

,
"
and

.
<EOS>
But

:
I

"

,
Richard
;
"
for

that

.
<EOS>
Now
you
look

;
and
I
will

you
further
.
<EOS>
You
are
my
little
friend
,

?
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
like
to
serve
you
,
sir
,
and
to

you
in
all
that
is
right
.
"
  
<EOS>
"
Precisely
:
I
see
you
do
.
<EOS>
I
see
genuine
contentment
in
your

and

,
your

and

,
when

are

me
 
working

,
and
with

,
in
,

,
"
_
all
that
is
right
_
:
<EOS>
"
for
if
I
bid

you
thought
wrong
,
there
would
be
no
light
-

,
no

,

.
<EOS>
My
friend
would
then

,
quiet

,

"
No
,

;

:
I

,
because
it
is

;
"
and
would
become

as

.
<EOS>
Well
,
you
too
have
power
over
me
,
and
may

:
yet
I
dare
not

,
lest
,

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"

,

,
you
are

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
God

!
<EOS>
Here
,

,

;

.
"
  
<EOS>
The

was
an

,

;

.
<EOS>
Mr.
Rochester
took

,

,

:
but

.
  
<EOS>
"
Sit
,
"

"
the

.
<EOS>
You
do

,

?
<EOS>
Is

Jane
?
"
  
<EOS>
I
answered

by
assuming

:
to

would
,

.
  
<EOS>
"
Now
,
my
little
friend
,
while
the

and

fetch

<EOS>
I

you
,
which
you

:
<EOS>
but

,

,

,
and
not

,

<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
No
,

;
I
am

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Well
