,
Jane
,
call
to
aid
your
fancy
:
 
suppose
you
were
no

a
girl

and

,
but
<EOS>
a
wild
boy
indulged
from

upwards
;
imagine
yourself
in
a

;
conceive
that
you
there
commit
a

error
,
<EOS>
no

what

or
from
what

,
but
one
whose

must
follow

through

.
<EOS>
Mind
,
I
do

_

_
;
I

,

might

amenable
to
the

:
my
word
is
_
error
_
.
<EOS>
The
results
of
what
you
have
done
become
in

to

utterly

;
you
take
measures
to

:
unusual

,
but
neither

nor

.
<EOS>
Still
you
are
miserable
;
for
hope
has
quitted
you
on
the
very
confines
of
life
:
your
sun
at
noon
darkens
in
an
eclipse
,
which
you
feel
will
not
leave
it
till
the
time
of
setting
.
<EOS>
Bitter
and
base

have
become
the
sole

of
your

:
you
wander
here
and
there
,
seeking
rest
in
exile
:
happiness
in
pleasure
 
<EOS>
I
mean
in
heartless
,
sensual
pleasure
 
such
as
dulls
intellect
and
blights
feeling
.
<EOS>
Heart
-
weary
and
soul
-
withered
<EOS>
,
you
come
home
after
years
of
voluntary

:
you
make
a
new
acquaintance
 
<EOS>
how
or
where
no
matter
:
you
find
in
this
stranger
much
of
the
good
and
bright
qualities
which
you
have
sought
for
twenty

,
and
never
before
encountered
;
and
they
are
all
fresh
,
healthy
,
without
soil
and
without
taint
.
<EOS>
Such
society
revives
,
regenerates
:
you
feel
better
days
come
back
 
higher
wishes
,
purer
feelings
;
you
desire
to
recommence
your
life
,
and
to
spend
what
remains

of

in

worthy

an

.
<EOS>
To

this

,
are
you
justified
in
overleaping
an

of
custom
 
a
mere
conventional
impediment
which
neither
your

sanctifies
nor
your
judgment
approves
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
He
paused
for
an
answer
:
and
what
was
I
to
say
?
<EOS>
Oh
,
for
some
good
spirit
to
suggest
a
judicious
and
satisfactory
response
!
<EOS>
Vain
aspiration
!
<EOS>
The
west
wind
whispered
in
the
ivy
round
me
;
but
no
gentle
Ariel
borrowed
its
breath
as
a
medium
of
speech
:
the
birds
sang
in
the
tree
-
tops
;
but
their
song
,
however
sweet
,
was
inarticulate
.
  
<EOS>
Again
Mr.
Rochester
propounded
his
query
:
  
"
<EOS>
Is
the
wandering
and
sinful
,
but
now
rest
-
seeking
and
repentant
,
man
justified
in
daring
the
world
's
opinion
,
in
order
to
attach
to
him
for
ever
this
gentle
,
gracious
,
genial
stranger
,
thereby
securing
his
own
peace
of
mind
and
regeneration
of
life
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Sir
,
"
I
answered
,
"
a
wanderer
's
repose
or
a
sinner
's
reformation
should
never
depend
on
a
fellow
-
creature
.
<EOS>
Men
and
women
die
;
philosophers
falter
in
wisdom
,
and
Christians
in
goodness
:
if
any
one
you
know
has
suffered
and
erred
,
let
him
look
higher
than
his
equals
for
strength
to
amend
and
solace
to
heal
.
<EOS>
"
  
"
But
the
instrument
 
the
instrument
!
<EOS>
God
,
who
does
the
work
,
ordains
the
instrument
.
<EOS>
I
have
myself
 
<EOS>
I
tell
it
you
without
parable
 
been
a
worldly
,
dissipated
,
restless
man
;
and
I
believe
I
have
found
the
instrument
for
my
cure
in
 
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
He
paused
:
the
birds
went
on
carolling
,
the
leaves
lightly
rustling
.
<EOS>
I
almost
wondered
they
did
not
check
their
songs
and
whispers
to
catch
the
suspended
revelation
;
but
they
would
have
had
to
wait
many
minutes
 
<EOS>
so
long
was
the
silence
protracted
.
<EOS>
At
last
I
looked
up
at
the
tardy
speaker
:
he
was
looking
eagerly
at
me
.
  
<EOS>
"
Little
friend
,
"
said
he
,
in
quite
a
changed
tone
 
while
his
face
changed
too
,
losing
all
its
softness
and
gravity
,
and
becoming
harsh
and
sarcastic
 
<EOS>
"
you

noticed

<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
He

,

,

.
  
<EOS>

Jane

,
"

"

<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Curse

?
<EOS>
No
,

<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"

.
<EOS>
What

!
<EOS>
They

<EOS>
Jane

"
  
<EOS>
"

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"

<EOS>

"

<EOS>
"
A

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

"

<EOS>
;

"
    
<EOS>
Presentiments
are
strange
things
!
<EOS>
and
so
are
sympathies
;
and
so
are
signs
;
and
<EOS>
the
three
combined
make
one
mystery
to
which
humanity
has
not
yet
found
the
key
.
<EOS>
I
never
laughed
at
presentiments
in
my
life
,
because
I
have
had
strange
ones
of
my
own
.
<EOS>
Sympathies
,
I
believe
,
exist
(
for
instance
,
between
far
-
distant
,
long

,
wholly
estranged
relatives
asserting
,
notwithstanding
their
alienation
,
the
unity
of
the
source
to
which
each
traces
his
origin
)
whose
workings
baffle

.
<EOS>
And
signs
,
for
aught
we
know
,
may
be
<EOS>
but
the
sympathies
of
Nature
with
man
.
  
<EOS>
When
I
was
a

girl
,

,
I
one

Leaven

;
and
that
to

children

a

,

.
<EOS>
The

,

.
<EOS>
The

was
sent

.
  
<EOS>
Of

;

past

<EOS>

<EOS>

,

not
for

the

.
  
<EOS>

It

from

<EOS>

<EOS>
His

:

.
<EOS>
He
came

.
<EOS>

"

Robert

.

"

<EOS>

an
old
lady
who
will
,
perhaps
,
be
dead
before
you
reach
her
:
<EOS>
besides
,
you
say
she
cast
you
off
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Yes
,
sir
,
but
that
is
long
ago
;
and
when
her
circumstances
were
very
different
:
I
could
not
be
easy
to
neglect
her
wishes
now
.
"
  
"
How
long
will
you
stay
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
As
short
a
time
as
possible
,
sir
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Promise
me
only
to
stay
a
week
 
<EOS>
"
  
"
I
had
better
not
pass
my
word
:
I
might
be
obliged
to
break
it
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
At
all
events
you
_
will
_
come
back
:
you
will
not
be
induced
under
any
pretext
to
take
up
a
permanent
residence
with
her
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Oh
,
no
!
<EOS>
I
shall
certainly
return
if
all
be
well
.
<EOS>
"
  
"
And
who
goes
with
you
?
<EOS>
You
do
n't
travel
a
hundred
miles
alone
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
No
,
sir
,
she
has
sent
her
coachman
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
A
person
to
be
trusted
?
"
  
<EOS>
"
Yes
,
sir
,
he
has
lived
ten
years
in
the
family
.
"
  
<EOS>
Mr.
Rochester
meditated
.
<EOS>
"
When
do
you
wish
to
go
?
"
  
"
Early
to
-
morrow
morning
,
sir
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Well
,
you
must
have
some
money
;
you
ca
n't
travel
without
money
,
and
I
daresay
you
have
not
much
<EOS>
:
I
have
given
you
no
salary
yet
.
<EOS>
How
much
have
you
in
the
world
,
Jane
?
"
<EOS>
he
asked
,
smiling
.
  
<EOS>
I
drew
out
my
purse
;
a
meagre
thing
it
was
.
"
<EOS>
Five
shillings
,
sir
.
"
<EOS>
He
took
the
purse
,
poured
the
hoard
into
his
palm
,
and
chuckled
over
it
as
if
its
scantiness
amused
him
.
<EOS>
Soon
he
produced
his
pocket
-
book
:
"
<EOS>
Here
,
"
said
he
,
offering
me
a
note
;
it
was
fifty
pounds
,
and
he
owed
me
but
fifteen
.
<EOS>
I
told
him
I
had
no
change
.
  
<EOS>
"
I
do
n't
want
change
;
you
know
that
.
<EOS>
Take
your
wages
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
I
declined
accepting
more
than
was
my
due
.
<EOS>
He
scowled
at
first
;
then
,
as
if
recollecting
something
,
he
said
    
"
Right
,
right
!
<EOS>
Better
not
give
you
all
now
:
you
would
,
perhaps
,
stay
away
three
months
if
you
had
fifty
pounds
.
<EOS>
There
are
ten
;
is
it
not
plenty
?
"
  
<EOS>
"
Yes
,
sir
,
but
now
you
owe
me
five
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Come
back
for
it
,
then
;
I
am
your
banker
for
forty
pounds
.
<EOS>
"
  
"
Mr.
Rochester
,
I
may
as
well
mention
another
matter
of
business
to
you
while
I
have
the
opportunity
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Matter
of
business
?
<EOS>
I
am
curious
to
hear
it
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
You
have
as
good
as
informed
me
,
sir
,
that
you
are
going
shortly
to
be
married
?
<EOS>
"
  
"
Yes
;
what
then
?
"
  
<EOS>
"
In
that
case
,
sir
,
Adele
ought
to
go
to
school
:
I
am
sure
you
will
perceive
the
necessity
of
it
.
"
  
"
<EOS>
To
get
her
out
of
my
bride
's
way
,
who
might
otherwise
walk
over
her
rather
too
emphatically
?
<EOS>
There
's
sense
in
the
suggestion
;
not
a
doubt
of
it
.
<EOS>
Adele
,
as
you
say
,
must
go
to
school
;
and
you
,
of
course
,
must
march
straight
to
 
the
devil
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
hope
not
,
sir
;
but
I
must
seek
another
situation
somewhere
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
In
course
!
"
he
exclaimed
,
with
a
twang
of
voice
and
a
distortion
of
features
equally
fantastic
and
ludicrous
.
<EOS>
He
looked
at
me
some
minutes
.
  
<EOS>
"
And
old
Madam
Reed
,
or
the
Misses
,
her
daughters
,
will
be
solicited
by
you
to
seek
a
place
,
I
suppose
?
<EOS>
"
  
"
No
,
sir
;
I
am
not
on
such
terms
with
my
relatives
as
would
justify
me
in
asking
favours
of
them
 
<EOS>
but
I
shall
advertise
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
You
shall
walk
up
the
pyramids
of
Egypt
!
"
<EOS>
he
growled
.
<EOS>
"
At
your
peril
you
advertise
!
<EOS>
I
wish
I
had
only
offered
you
a
sovereign
instead
of
ten
pounds
.
<EOS>
Give
me
back
nine
pounds
,
Jane
;
I
've
a
use
for
it
.
<EOS>
"
  
"
And
so
have
I
,
sir
,
"
I
returned
,
putting
my
hands
and
my
purse
behind
me
.
<EOS>
"
I
could
not
spare
the
money
on
any
account
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Little
niggard
!
"
said
he
,
"
refusing
me
a
pecuniary
request
!
<EOS>
Give
me
five
pounds
,
Jane
.
"
  
"
<EOS>
Not
five
shillings
,
sir
;
nor
five
pence
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Just
let
me
look
at
the
cash
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
No
,
sir
;
you
are
not
to
be
trusted
.
<EOS>
"
  
"
Jane
!
"
  
<EOS>
"
Sir
?
"
  
<EOS>
"
Promise
me
one
thing
.
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
'll
promise
you
anything
,
sir
,
that
I
think
I
am
likely
to
perform
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Not
to
advertise
:
and
to
trust
this
quest
of
a
situation
to
me
.
<EOS>
I
'll
find
you
one
in
time
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
shall
be
glad
so
to
do
,
sir
,
if
you
,
in
your

,
will
promise
that
I
and
Adele
shall
be
both
safe
out
of
the
house
before
your
bride
enters
it
.
<EOS>
"
  
"
<EOS>
Very
well
!
<EOS>
very
well
!
<EOS>
I
'll
pledge
my
word
on
it
.
<EOS>
You
go
to
-
morrow
,
then
?
<EOS>
"
  
"
<EOS>
Yes
,
sir
;
early
.
"
  
<EOS>
"
Shall
you
come
down
to
the
drawing
-
room
after
dinner
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
No
,
sir
,
I
must
prepare
for
the
journey
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Then
you
and
I
must
bid
good
-
bye
for
a
little
while
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
suppose
so
,
sir
.
"
  
<EOS>
"
And
how
do
people
perform
that
ceremony
of
parting
,
Jane
?
<EOS>
Teach
me
;
I
'm
not
quite
up
to
it
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
They
say
,
Farewell
,
or
any
other
form
they
prefer
.
"
  
<EOS>
"
Then
say
it
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Farewell
,
Mr.
Rochester
,
for
the
present
.
"
  
<EOS>
"
What
must
I
say
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
The
same
,
if
you
like
,
sir
.
"
  
"
Farewell
,
Miss
Eyre
,
for
the
present
;
is
that
all
?
"
  
"
<EOS>
Yes
?
"
  
<EOS>
"
It
seems
stingy
,
to
my
notions
,
and
dry
,
and
unfriendly
.
<EOS>
I
should
like
something
else
:
a
little
addition
to
the
rite
.
<EOS>
If
one
shook
hands
,
for
instance
;
but
no
 
that
would
not
content
me
either
.
<EOS>
So
you
'll
do
no
more
than
say
Farewell
,
Jane
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
It
is
enough
,
sir
:
as
much
good
-
will
may
be
conveyed
in
one
hearty
word
as
in
many
.
"
  
"
<EOS>
Very
likely
;
but
it
is
blank
and
cool
 
"
Farewell
.
"
<EOS>
"
  
"
How
long
is
he
going
to
stand
with
his
back
against
that
door
?
<EOS>
"
I
asked
myself
;
"
I
want
to
commence
my
packing
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
The
dinner
-
bell
rang
,
and
suddenly
away
he
bolted
,
without
another
syllable
<EOS>
:
I
saw
him
no
more
during
the
day
,
and
was
off
before
he
had
risen
in
the
morning
.
  
<EOS>
I
reached
the
lodge
at
Gateshead
about
five
o'clock
in
the
afternoon
of
the
first
of
May
:
I
stepped
in
there
before
going
up
to
the
hall
.
<EOS>
It
was
very
clean
and
neat
:
the
ornamental
windows
were
hung
with
little
white
curtains
;
the
floor
was
spotless
;
the
grate
and
fire
-
irons
were
burnished
bright
,
and
the
fire
burnt
clear
.
<EOS>
Bessie
sat
on
the
hearth
,
nursing
her
last
-
born
,
and
Robert
and
his
sister
played
quietly
in
a
corner
.
  
<EOS>
"
Bless
you
!
 
<EOS>
I
knew
you
would
come
!
"
<EOS>
exclaimed
Mrs.
Leaven
,
as
I
entered
.
  
<EOS>
"
Yes
,
Bessie
,
"
said
I
,
after
I
had
kissed
her
;
"
and
I
trust
I
am
not
too
late
.
<EOS>
How
is
Mrs.
Reed
?
 
<EOS>
Alive
<EOS>
still
,
I
hope
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Yes
,
she
is
alive
;
and
more
sensible
and
collected
than
she
was
.
<EOS>
The
doctor
says
she
may
linger
a
week
or
two
yet
;
but
he
hardly
thinks
she
will
finally
recover
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Has
she
mentioned
me
lately
?
"
  
<EOS>
"
She
was
talking
of
you
only
this
morning
,
and
wishing
you
would
come
,
but
she
is
sleeping
now
,
or
was
ten
minutes
ago
,
when
I
was
up
at
the
house
.
<EOS>
She
generally
lies
in
a
kind
of
lethargy
all
the
afternoon
,
and
wakes
up
about
six
or
seven
.
<EOS>
Will
you
rest
yourself
here
an
hour
,
Miss
,
and
then
I
will
go
up
with
you
?
"
  
<EOS>
Robert
here
entered
,
and
Bessie
laid
her
sleeping
child
in
the
cradle
and
went
to
welcome
him
:
<EOS>
afterwards
she
insisted
on
my
taking
off
my
bonnet
and
having
some
tea
;
for
she
said
I
looked
pale
and
tired
.
<EOS>
I
was
glad
to
accept
her
hospitality
;
and
I
submitted
to
be
relieved
of
my
travelling
garb
just
as
passively
as
I
used
to
let
her
undress
me
when
a
child
.
  
<EOS>
Old
times
crowded
fast
back
on
me
as
I
watched
her
bustling
about
 
setting
out
the
tea
-
tray
with
her
best
china
,
cutting
bread
and
butter
,
toasting
a
tea
-
cake
,
and
,
between
whiles
,
giving
little
Robert
or
Jane
an
occasional
tap
or
push
,
just
as
she
used
to
give
me
in
former
days
.
<EOS>
Bessie
had
retained
her
quick
temper
as
well
as
her
light
foot
and
good
looks
.
  
<EOS>
Tea
ready
,
I
was
going
to
approach
the
table
;
but
she
desired
me
to
sit
still
,
quite
in
her
old
peremptory
tones
.
<EOS>
I
must
be
served
at
the
fireside
,
she
said
;
and
she
placed
before
me
a
little
round
stand
with
my
cup
and
a
plate
of
toast
,
absolutely
as
she
used
to
accommodate
me
with
some
privately
purloined
dainty
on
a
nursery
chair
:
and
I
smiled
and
obeyed
her
as
in
bygone
days
.
  
<EOS>
She
wanted
to
know
if
I
was
happy
at
Thornfield
Hall
,
and
what
sort
of
a
person
the
mistress
was
;
and
when
I
told
her
there
was
only
a
master
,
whether
he
was
a
nice
gentleman
,
and
if
I
liked
him
.
<EOS>
I
told
her
he
was
rather
an
ugly
man
,
but
quite
a
gentleman
;
and
that
he
treated
me
kindly
,
and
I
was
content
.
<EOS>
Then
I
went
on
to
describe
to
her
the
gay
company
that
had
lately
been
staying
at
the
house
;
and
to
these
details
Bessie
listened
with
interest
:
they
were
precisely
of
the
kind
she
relished
.
  
<EOS>
In
such
conversation
an
hour
was
soon
gone
:
Bessie
restored
to
me
my
bonnet
,
&
c.
,
and
,
accompanied
by
her
,
<EOS>
I
quitted
the
lodge
for
the
hall
.
<EOS>
It
was
also
accompanied
by
her
that
I
had
,
nearly
nine
years
ago
,
walked
down
the
path
I
was
now
ascending
.
<EOS>
On
a
dark
,
misty
,
raw
morning
in
January
,
I
had
left
a
hostile
roof
with
a
desperate
and
embittered
heart
 
a
sense
of
outlawry
and
almost
of
reprobation
 
to
seek
the
chilly
harbourage
of
Lowood
:
that
bourne
so
far
away
and
unexplored
.
<EOS>
The
same
hostile
roof
now
again
rose
before
me
:
<EOS>
my
prospects
were
doubtful
yet
;
and
I
had
yet
an
aching
heart
.
<EOS>
I
still
felt
as
a
wanderer
on
the
face
of
the
earth
;
but
I
experienced
firmer
trust
in
myself
and
my
own
powers
,
and
less
withering
dread
of
oppression
.
<EOS>
The
gaping
wound
of
my
wrongs
,
too
,
was
now
quite
healed
;
and
the
flame
of
resentment
extinguished
.
  
<EOS>
"
You
shall
go
into
the
breakfast
-
room
first
,
"
said
Bessie
,
as
she
preceded
me
through
the
hall
;
"
the
young
ladies
will
be
there
.
"
  
<EOS>
In
another
moment
I
was
within
that
apartment
.
<EOS>
There
was
every
article
of
furniture
looking
just
as
it
did
on
the
morning
I
was
first
introduced
to
Mr.
Brocklehurst
:
the
very
rug
he
had
stood
upon
still
covered
the
hearth
.
<EOS>
Glancing
at
the
bookcases
,
I
thought
I
could
distinguish
the
two
volumes
of
Bewick
's
British
Birds
occupying
their
old
place
on
the
third
shelf
,
and
Gulliver
's
Travels
and
the
Arabian
Nights
ranged
just
above
.
<EOS>
The
inanimate
objects
were
not
changed
;
but
the
living
things
had
altered
past
recognition
.
  
<EOS>
Two

;

Ingram
 
very

.
<EOS>

<EOS>
This

,

Georgiana
<EOS>

"

"

several

<EOS>

.
<EOS>
It

"
  
<EOS>
"
A

<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"

<EOS>

<EOS>

a

<EOS>
It

.
<EOS>
Reed

;

<EOS>

<EOS>

,

<EOS>

<EOS>
John

,

:

he

.
<EOS>

?
<EOS>
I

:

.
<EOS>
I

<EOS>
I

yet
<EOS>

?
<EOS>
Two

.
<EOS>
John

,

poor

!
<EOS>
He

:

his

for

.
"
  
<EOS>
She

.

<EOS>
"

<EOS>

"

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

True
,
generous
feeling
is
made
small
account
of
by
some
,
but
here
were
two
natures
rendered
,
the
one
intolerably
acrid
,
the
other
despicably
savourless
for
the
want
of
it
.
<EOS>
Feeling
without
judgment
is
a
washy
draught
indeed
;
but
judgment
untempered
by
feeling
is
too
bitter
and
husky
a
morsel
for
human
deglutition
.
  
<EOS>
It
was
a
wet
and
windy
afternoon
<EOS>
:
Georgiana
had
fallen
asleep
on
the
sofa
over
the
perusal
of
a
novel
;
Eliza
was
gone
to
attend
a
saint's
-
day
service
at
the
new
church
 
for
in
matters
of
religion
<EOS>
she
was
a
rigid
formalist
:
no
weather
ever
prevented
the
punctual
discharge
of
what
she
considered
her
devotional
duties
;
fair
or
foul
,
she
went
to
church
thrice
every
Sunday
,
and
as
often
on
week
-
days
as
there
were
prayers
.
  
<EOS>
I
bethought
myself
to
go
upstairs
and
see
how
the
dying
woman
sped
,
who
lay
there
almost
unheeded
:
the
very
servants
paid
her
but
a
remittent
attention
:
the
hired
nurse
,
being
little
looked
after
,
would
slip
out
of
the
room
whenever
she
could
.
<EOS>
Bessie
was
faithful
;
but
she
had
her
own
family
to
mind
,
and
could
only
come
occasionally
to
the
hall
.
<EOS>
I
found
the
sick
-
room
unwatched
,
as
I
had
expected
:
no
nurse
was
there
;
the
patient
lay
still
,
and
seemingly

;
her
livid
face
sunk
in
the
pillows
:
the
fire
was
dying
in
the
grate
.
<EOS>
I
renewed
the
fuel
,
re
-
arranged
the
bedclothes
,
gazed
awhile
on
her
who
could
not
now
gaze
on
me
,
and
then
I
moved
away
to
the
window
.
  
<EOS>
The
rain
beat
strongly
against
the
panes
,
the
wind
blew
tempestuously
:
"
One
lies
there
,
"
I
thought
,
"
who
will
soon
be
beyond
the
war
of
earthly
elements
.
<EOS>
Whither
will
that
spirit
 
now
struggling
to
quit
its
material
tenement
 
<EOS>
flit
when
at
length
released
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
In
pondering
the
great
mystery
,
I
thought
of
Helen
Burns
,
recalled
her
dying
words
 
her
faith
 
her
doctrine
of
the
equality
of
disembodied

.
<EOS>
I
was
still

in

her
well

still

her
pale

,
her

her
divine
Father

"
Who

?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
I
knew
Mrs.
Reed
had
not

for
days
:

?
<EOS>
I

.
  
<EOS>
"
It

,
Aunt

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Who
 
I
?
"

.
<EOS>
"
Who

?
"
<EOS>
looking

<EOS>
"

<EOS>
where

?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
She

.
<EOS>
"
  
"

,
"

.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Who

?
<EOS>
You

;

<EOS>
that

<EOS>
why

!
"
  
<EOS>
I
said
nothing
:
<EOS>
I

.
  
<EOS>
"
Yet
,
"

,
"

:

.
<EOS>
I

,

:

,

.
<EOS>
"

now

,

.
  
<EOS>
"
I
am
very
ill
,
I

,
"
she

ere

.
<EOS>
"
I
was

,
and

I
can

.
<EOS>
It

should

:
<EOS>
what

little
of

.
<EOS>
Is

?
<EOS>

<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
I

.
  
<EOS>
"

,

.
<EOS>

"

<EOS>

"

;

<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
She

;

some

,

.
  
<EOS>
"
Well
,
I

.
<EOS>
Eternity

:

.
 
<EOS>

<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
I

.
<EOS>
"
Read

,
"

.
  
<EOS>
It

,
and
thus

:
    
<EOS>
"
Madam
,
 
Will

,

?
<EOS>
It

.
<EOS>
Providence

<EOS>
I

,
&

,

JOHN

,

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
It
was
dated
three

back
.
  
<EOS>
"
Why
did

never

?
<EOS>
"
I

.
  
<EOS>
"

I

too

and

ever
to

.
<EOS>
I

conduct

,
Jane
 
the

;

<EOS>
I

:
<EOS>
I

.
 
<EOS>
Bring

some

!
<EOS>
Oh

!
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Dear

"

<EOS>

"

<EOS>
"
I

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

"

"

"

"

"

.
<EOS>
She

.

As

for

"

.
"
  
<EOS>
Poor

!
<EOS>

<EOS>
,

.
  
<EOS>
The

,

.
<EOS>
I

-

:

.
<EOS>
She

;

:

.
<EOS>
I

,

.
<EOS>
They

.
<EOS>
She
was
by

.
<EOS>
Eliza

:
<EOS>
Georgiana
,

,

.
<EOS>
There

's

,

.
<EOS>
A

.
<EOS>

_

_
woes

_

_

.
  
<EOS>
Eliza
surveyed

.
<EOS>
After

she
observed
    
<EOS>
"
With

should

:

was

by

.
"
<EOS>
And

for

:
<EOS>
as

passed
away
she
turned
and
left

,
and
so

I.
Neither
of
us
had

.
    
<EOS>
Mr.
Rochester
had
given
me
but
one
week
's
leave
of
absence
:
yet
a
month
elapsed
before
I
quitted
Gateshead
.
<EOS>
I
wished
to

immediately
after

,
but
Georgiana
entreated

to
stay
till
she
could

off
to
London
,
whither
<EOS>
she
was
now
at

,

,

to

and

.
<EOS>
Georgiana
said
she
dreaded

Eliza
;
from

got

in

,

,

;

with

as
well

I
could
,
and
did

best
in

and

.
<EOS>
It
is
true
,
that
while
I
worked
,
she
would
idle
;
and
I
thought
to
myself
,
"

you

to

always

,
cousin
,

.
<EOS>
I
should
not

forbearing

;
I
should
assign

your
share
of

,
and

to

,
or
else
<EOS>
it

:
I

,

some

,

.
<EOS>
It

only
because
our
connection

,
and

,
that
I
consent
thus
to
render
it
so
patient
and
compliant
on
my
part
.
"
  
<EOS>
At
last
I
saw
Georgiana
off
;
but
now
it
was
Eliza
's
turn
to
request
me
to
stay
another
week
.
<EOS>
Her
plans
required
all
her
time
and
attention
<EOS>
,
she
said
;
she
was
about

depart
for
some
unknown
bourne
;
and
all

she
stayed
in
her
own

,
her

bolted
within
,
filling

,

,

,
and
holding
no

.
<EOS>
She
wished
me
to
look
after
the
house
,
to
see
callers
,
and
answer
notes
of

.
  
<EOS>
One
morning
she
told

I
was
at
liberty
.
"
<EOS>
And
,
"
she
added
,
"
I
am

to
you
for
your
valuable
services
and
discreet

!
<EOS>
There
is
some
difference
between

such
an

as
you
and

Georgiana
:
you
perform
your
own
part
in

.
<EOS>
To

,
"
she

,
"
I
set

for
the
Continent
.
<EOS>
I
shall
take

my
abode
in
a

near
Lisle
 
a
nunnery
you
would

;
there
I
shall
be

and

.
<EOS>
I
shall

,

I

probably

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
I
neither

.
<EOS>
"
The

will
fit
you
to

hair
,
"
I

:
"
much

!
"
  
<EOS>
When

:
"
Good

,
cousin
Jane
Eyre
<EOS>
;
I

:
you

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
I
then

:
"
You

,

;
but

have
,
I

,

.
<EOS>
However

,
and
so
it
suits
you
<EOS>
,
I
do

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
You

the
right
,
"

.
<EOS>
As

not

again
,
I
may

mention
here
,
that

,
and
that

actually
took

,
and

where
she
passed

,

.
  
<EOS>
How
people
feel
when
they
are
returning
home
from
an
absence
,
long

,
I
did
not

:
<EOS>
I
had
never

.
<EOS>
I
had
known
what
it
was
to
come
back
to
Gateshead
when
a
child
after
a
long
walk
,

for
looking

;
and

to

,
to
long
for

a

,
and
to
be

.
<EOS>
Neither

was
very

:
no

to

,
increasing
in

of

the
nearer
I

.
<EOS>
The

to

was
yet

.
  
<EOS>
My

seemed
tedious
 
very

:
fifty

one

,
a

at

;
fifty

.
<EOS>
During

Reed

<EOS>

<EOS>
few

the

.
<EOS>

<EOS>
The

great

of
 
scattered

;

:

.
  
<EOS>
I
was
going

to
Thornfield
:
<EOS>
but
how
long
was
I
to
stay
there
?
<EOS>
Not
long
;
of
that
I
was
sure
.
<EOS>
I
had
heard
from
Mrs.
Fairfax
in
the

:
the

;

Rochester

London
three

,
but

.
<EOS>
Mrs.
Fairfax
surmised
that

,

Ingram

;

,

.
<EOS>
"
You

,
"

.
<EOS>
"
I
do
n't

.
"
  
<EOS>
The

followed
,
"
Where
was

to

?
<EOS>
"
I

Ingram

Thornfield
against

;

,

.
  
<EOS>

.
<EOS>
I

.
  
<EOS>
It

,

:

:
<EOS>
its

,

strata

.
<EOS>
The

,

,

:
no

<EOS>
it

of

,

.
  
<EOS>
I

<EOS>

<EOS>

"

<EOS>
hasten

<EOS>
How

!
<EOS>
But

<EOS>

;

Rochester

,

.
  
<EOS>
Well

:

.
<EOS>
What

?
<EOS>
I

,

.
<EOS>
I

<EOS>
I

.
<EOS>
I

.
<EOS>
It

;

.
  
<EOS>
"
Hillo
!
"
<EOS>
he

;
and

.
<EOS>
"
There

!
<EOS>
Come

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
I

;

;

;

<EOS>
But

<EOS>
it

down
:
I
may

.
  
<EOS>
"
And

Eyre
?
<EOS>

,

<EOS>
Yes
 
just

:

<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I

<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
A

!
<EOS>
Good

!
<EOS>
She

<EOS>

!
 
<EOS>
but

_

.
<EOS>
Truant
!
truant
!
"
<EOS>

,

.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Absent

,

"

)

,

.
<EOS>
His

that

.
<EOS>
And

Thornfield

my
home
 
would
that

!
  
<EOS>

,

.
<EOS>
I

.
  
<EOS>
"
Yes

<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"

Fairfax

.

And

?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Oh
,

,

!
<EOS>
Everybody

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"

,

,

<EOS>
I

,

"

"

to

"

<EOS>
He
rose
,
and
with
a
stride
reached
me
.
  
<EOS>
"
My
bride
is
here
,
"
he
said
,
again
drawing
me
to
him
,
"
because
my
equal
is
here
,
and
my
likeness
.
<EOS>
Jane
,
will
you
marry
me
?
"
  
<EOS>
Still
I
did
not
answer
,
and
still
I
writhed
myself
from
his
grasp
:
for
I
was
still
incredulous
.
  
<EOS>
"
Do
you
doubt
me
,
Jane
?
"
  
"
<EOS>
Entirely
.
"
  
<EOS>
"
You
have
no
faith
in
me
?
<EOS>
"
  
"
Not
a
whit
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Am
I
a
liar
in
your
eyes
?
"
<EOS>
he
asked
passionately
.
"
<EOS>
Little
sceptic
,
you
_
shall
_
be
convinced
.
<EOS>
What
love
have
I
for
Miss
Ingram
?
<EOS>
None
:
and
that
you
know
.
<EOS>
What
love
has
she
for
me
?
<EOS>
None
:
as
I
have
taken
pains
to
prove
<EOS>
:
I
caused
a
rumour
to
reach
her
that
my
fortune
was
not
a
third
of
what
was

,
and
after
that
I
presented
myself
to
see
the
result
;
it
was
coldness
both
from
her
and
her
mother
.
<EOS>
I
would
not
 
I
could
not
 
marry
Miss
Ingram
.
<EOS>
You
 
<EOS>
you
strange
<EOS>
,
you
almost

thing
!
 
<EOS>
I
love
as

own

.
<EOS>
You
 
poor

,
and
small
and
plain
as
you
are
 
<EOS>
I

to

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
What
,
me
!
<EOS>
"
I
ejaculated
,
beginning
in
his

and
especially
in

to

:
"
me
who

not
a
friend

the
world
<EOS>
but
you
 
if

:
not

but
what

?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
You
,
Jane
,
I
must

you
for

own
 
entirely
my

.
<EOS>
Will

?
<EOS>
Say

,

.
<EOS>
"
  
"
<EOS>
Mr.
Rochester
,

:

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Why
?
"
  
<EOS>
"
Because

turn
!
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
There
!
you
will

more

a

.
<EOS>
Read

:
only

,

.
"
  
<EOS>
His

was
very

,
and

.
  
<EOS>
"
Oh
,
Jane
,
you

me
!
"
<EOS>

.
<EOS>
"
With

,

!
"
  
<EOS>
"
How

I
do

?
<EOS>
If

,

they
can
not

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Gratitude
!
"
<EOS>
he

;
and
added

"
Jane
accept

.
<EOS>
Say
,
Edward
 
give

<EOS>
Edward
 
<EOS>
I
will

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Are

?
<EOS>

?
<EOS>

<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>

<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Then

.
"
  
<EOS>
"
Edward
 
my

!
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Dear

!
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Come

come

,
"

;

,

,
"
Make

will

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
God

!
"
<EOS>

;
"
and
man

not

:
I

,

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
There

no

,

.
<EOS>
I

.
<EOS>
"
  
"
<EOS>
No
 
that
is

,
"
he

.
<EOS>
And

;
but
,

,

from

of
parting
 
called
to

union
 
<EOS>
I
thought
only
of
the
bliss
given

to

in
so

.
<EOS>
Again

said
,
"
Are
you

,
Jane
?
"
<EOS>
And
again
and
again
I
answered
,
"
Yes
.
"
<EOS>
After

he

,
"
It
will
atone
 
<EOS>
it
will
atone
.
<EOS>
Have
I
not
found
her
friendless
,
and
cold
,
and

?
<EOS>
Will
I
not
guard
,
and

,
and

?
<EOS>
Is
there
not
love
in
my
heart
,
and
constancy
in
my

?
<EOS>
It
will
expiate
at
God
's

.
<EOS>
I
know
my
Maker
sanctions
what
I
do
.
<EOS>
For
the
world
's
judgment
 
I
wash
my
hands
thereof
.
<EOS>
For
man
's
opinion
 
I
defy
it
.
"
  
<EOS>
But
what
had
befallen
the
night
?
<EOS>
The
moon
was
not
yet
set
,
and
we
were
all
in
shadow
:
<EOS>
I
could
scarcely
see
my
master
's
face
,
near
as
I
was
.
<EOS>
And
what
ailed
the
chestnut
tree
?
<EOS>
it
writhed
and
groaned
;
while
wind
roared
in
the
laurel
walk
,
and
came
sweeping
over
us
.
  
<EOS>
"
We
must
go
in
,
"
said
Mr.
Rochester
:
"
the
weather
changes
.
<EOS>
I
could
have
sat
with
thee
till
morning
,
Jane
.
<EOS>
"
  
"
<EOS>
And
so
,
"
thought
I
,
"
could
I
with
you
.
<EOS>
"
I
should
have
said
so
,
perhaps
,
but
a
livid
,
vivid
spark
leapt
out
of
a
cloud
at
which
I
was
looking
,
and
there
was
a

,

,
and
a
close

;
and
I
thought
only
of
hiding
my

eyes
against
Mr.
Rochester
's

.
  
<EOS>
The
rain
rushed
down
.
<EOS>
He
hurried
me
up
the
walk
,
through
the
grounds
,
and
into
the
house
;
but
we
were
quite
wet
before
we
could
pass
the
threshold
.
<EOS>
He
was
taking
off
my
shawl
in
the
hall
,
and
shaking
the
water
out
of
my
loosened
hair
,
when
Mrs.
Fairfax
emerged
from
her
room
.
<EOS>
I
did
not
observe
her
at
first
,
nor
did
Mr.
Rochester
.
<EOS>
The
lamp
was
lit
.
<EOS>
The
clock
was
on
the
stroke
of
twelve
.
  
<EOS>
"
Hasten
to
take
off
your
wet
things
,
"
said
he
;
"
and
before
you
go
,
good-
night
 
<EOS>
good
-
night
,
my

!
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
He
kissed
me
repeatedly
.
<EOS>
When
I
looked
up
,
on
leaving
his
arms
,
there
stood
the
widow
,
pale
,
grave
,
and

.
<EOS>
I
only

,
and
ran

.
<EOS>
"
Explanation
will
do
for
another
time
,
"
thought
I.
<EOS>
Still
,
when
I
reached
my

,
I
felt
a
pang
at
the
idea
she
should
even
temporarily
misconstrue
what
she
had
seen
.
<EOS>
But
joy
soon
effaced
every
other
feeling
;
and
loud
as
the
wind
blew
,
near
and
deep
as
the

,

as
the

,

fell

a

of
two
hours
'

,
I
experienced
no
fear
and
little

.
<EOS>
Mr.
Rochester
came
thrice
to
my
door
in
the

it
,
to
ask
if
I
was
safe
and
tranquil
:
and
that
was
comfort
<EOS>
,
that
was
strength
for
anything
.
  
<EOS>
Before
I
left
my
bed
in
the
morning
,
little
Adele
came
running
in
to

me
that
the
great
horse
-
chestnut
at
the
bottom
of
the
orchard
had
been
struck
by
lightning
in

night
,
and
half

split

.
    
<EOS>
As
I
rose
and

,
I
thought
over
what
had
happened
,
and
wondered
if

were

.
<EOS>
I

of

till
I
had
seen
Mr.
Rochester
again
,
and
heard

.
  
<EOS>
While
arranging
my
hair
,
I
looked
at
my
face
in
the
glass
,
and
felt
it
was
no
longer
plain
:
there
was
hope
in
its
aspect
and
life
in

;
and
my
eyes
seemed
as
if
they
had
beheld
the
fount
of
fruition
,
and
borrowed
beams
from
the

.
<EOS>
I
had
often
been
unwilling
to
look
at
my
master
,
because
I
feared
he
could
not
be
pleased
at
my
look
;
but
I
was
sure
I
might
lift
my
face
to
his
now
,
and
not
cool
his
affection
by
its
expression
.
<EOS>
I
took
a
plain
but
clean
and
light
summer
dress
from
my

and
put
it
on
:
it
seemed
no
attire
had
ever
so
well
become
me
,
because
none
had
I
ever
worn
in
so
blissful
a
mood
.
  
<EOS>
I
was
not
surprised
,
when
I
ran
down
into

hall
,
to
see
that
a
brilliant
June
morning
had
succeeded
to

of

;
and
to
feel
,
through
the
open

,
the

of
a
fresh
and

.
<EOS>
Nature
must
be
gladsome
when
I
was
so
happy
.
<EOS>
A
beggar
-
woman
and
her
little
boy
 
pale
,
ragged
objects
<EOS>
both
 
were
coming
up
the
walk
,
and
I
ran
down
and
gave
them
all
the
money
I
happened
to
have
in
my

<EOS>
some
three
or
four
shillings
:
good
or
bad
,
they
must
partake
of
my

.
<EOS>
The
rooks
cawed
,
and
blither
birds
sang
;
but
nothing
was
so
merry
or
so
musical
as
my
own
rejoicing
heart
.
  
<EOS>
Mrs.
Fairfax
surprised
me
by
looking
out
of

window
with
a
sad

,
and
saying
gravely
 
"
Miss
Eyre
,
will

come

?
"
<EOS>
During
the
meal
she
was
quiet
and
cool
:
<EOS>
but
I
could
not
undeceive
her
then
.
<EOS>
I
must
wait
for
my
master
to
give

;
and
so
must

.
<EOS>
I
ate
what
I
could
,
and
then
I

.
<EOS>
I
met
Adele
leaving

.
  
<EOS>
"
Where
are
you
going
?
<EOS>
It
is
time
for

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Mr.
Rochester
has
sent

away
to

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Where
is

?
"
  
<EOS>
"
In
there
,
"
pointing

she

;
and
I

in
,
and
there
he
stood
.
  
<EOS>
"
Come
and
bid
me

morning
,
"
said

.
<EOS>
I
gladly

;
and
it
was
not

now
,
or

hand

,
but
an

.
<EOS>
It
seemed
natural
:
it
seemed
genial
to
be
so
well

,
so
caressed
by
him
.
  
<EOS>
"
Jane
,
you
look
blooming
,
and

,
and
pretty
,
"
said
he
:
"
truly
pretty
this
morning
.
<EOS>
Is
this
my
pale
,
little
elf
?
<EOS>
Is
this
my
mustard-
seed
?
<EOS>
This
little

-

girl

the
dimpled

and
rosy

;
<EOS>
the
satin
-

,

the

?
<EOS>
"
(
I
had
green

,
reader
;
but
you
must
excuse

mistake
:
for
him

were
new
-
dyed
,

.
)
  
<EOS>
"
It
is
Jane
Eyre
,

.
<EOS>
"
  
"
Soon
to
be
Jane
Rochester
,
"
he
added
:
"
in
four
weeks
,
Janet
;
not
a
day
more
.
<EOS>
Do
you
hear
that
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
I
did
,
and
I
could
not
quite
comprehend
it
<EOS>
:
it
made
me
giddy
.
<EOS>
The
feeling
,
the
announcement
sent
through
me
,
was
something
stronger
than
was
consistent
with
joy
 
<EOS>
something
that
smote
and
stunned
.
<EOS>
It
was
,
I
think
almost
fear
.
  
<EOS>
"
You
blushed
,
and
now
you
are
white
,
Jane
<EOS>
:
what
is
that
for
?
"
  
<EOS>
"
Because
you
gave
me
a
new
name
 
Jane
Rochester
;
and
it
seems
so
strange
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Yes
,
Mrs.
Rochester
,
"
said
he
;
"
young
Mrs.
Rochester
 
Fairfax
Rochester
's
girl
-
bride
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
It
can
never
be
,
sir
;
it
does
not
sound
likely
.
<EOS>
Human
beings
never
enjoy
complete
happiness
in
this
world
.
<EOS>
I
was
not
born
for
a
different
destiny
to
the
rest
of
my
species
:
to
imagine
such
a
lot
befalling
me
is
a
fairy
tale
 
<EOS>
a
day
-
dream
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Which
I
can
and
will
realise
.
<EOS>
I
shall
begin
to
-
day
.
<EOS>
This
morning
I
wrote
to
my
banker
in
London
to
send
me
certain
jewels
he
has
in
his
keeping
,
 
heirlooms
for
the
ladies
of
Thornfield
.
<EOS>
In
a
day
or
two
I
hope
to
pour
them
into
your
lap
:
for
every
privilege
,
every
attention
shall
be
yours
that
I
would
accord
a
peer
's
daughter
,
if
about
to
marry
her

,

rather
extinguished
,
her
flame
in
a
moment
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
You
have
a
curious
,
designing
mind
,
Mr.
Rochester
.
<EOS>
I
am
afraid
your
principles
on
some
points
are
eccentric
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
My
principles
were
never
trained
,
Jane
:
they
may
have
grown
a
little
awry
for
want
of
attention
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Once
again
,
seriously
;
may
I
enjoy
the
great
good
that
has
been
vouchsafed
to
me
,
without
fearing
that
any
one
else
is
suffering
the
bitter
pain
I
myself
felt
a
while
ago
?
"
  
"
<EOS>
That
you
may
,
<EOS>
my
good
little
girl
:
there
is
not
another
being
in
the
world
<EOS>
has
the
same
pure
love
for
me
as
yourself
 
for
I
lay
that
pleasant
unction
to
my
soul
,
Jane
,
a
belief
in
your
affection
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
I
turned
my
lips
to
the
hand
that
lay
on
my
shoulder
.
<EOS>
I
loved
him
very
much
 
more
than
I
could
trust
myself
to
say
 
more
than
words
had
power
to
express
.
  
<EOS>
"
Ask
something
more
,
"
he
said
presently
;
"
it
is
my
delight
to
be
entreated
,
and
to
yield
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
I
was
again
ready
with
my
request
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Communicate
your
intentions
to
Mrs.
Fairfax
,
sir
:
she
saw
me
with
you
last
night
in
the
hall
,
and
she
was
shocked
.
<EOS>
Give
her
some
explanation
before
I
see
her
again
.
<EOS>
It
pains
me
to
be
misjudged
by
so
good
a
woman
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Go
to
your
room
,
and
put
on
your
bonnet
,
"
he
replied
.
<EOS>
"
I
mean
you
to
accompany
me
to
Millcote
this
morning
;
and
while
you
prepare
for
the
drive
,
I
will
enlighten
the
old
lady
's
understanding
.
<EOS>
Did
she
think
,
Janet
,
you
had
given
the
world
for
love
,
and
considered
it
well
lost
?
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
believe
she
thought
I
had
forgotten
my
station
,
and
yours
,
sir
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Station
!
station
!
 
<EOS>
your
station
is
in
my
heart
,
and
on
the
necks
of
those
who
would
insult
you
,
now
or
hereafter
.
 
<EOS>
Go
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
I
was
soon
dressed
;
and
when
I
heard
Mr.
Rochester
quit
Mrs.
Fairfax
's
parlour
,
I
hurried
down
to
it
.
<EOS>
The
old
lady
,
had
been
reading
her
morning
portion
of
Scripture
 
the
Lesson
for
the
day
;
her
Bible
lay
open
before
her
,
and
her
spectacles
were
upon
it
.
<EOS>
Her
occupation
,
suspended
by
Mr.
Rochester
's
announcement
,
seemed
now
forgotten
:
<EOS>
her
eyes
,
fixed
on
the
blank
wall
opposite
,
expressed
the
surprise
of
a
quiet
mind
stirred
by
unwonted
tidings
.
<EOS>
Seeing
me
,
she
roused
herself
:
she
made
a
sort
of
effort
to
smile
,
and
framed
a
few
words
of
congratulation
;
but
the
smile
expired
,
and
the
sentence
was
abandoned
unfinished
.
<EOS>
She
put
up
her
spectacles
,
shut
the
Bible
,
and
pushed
her
chair
back
from
the
table
.
  
<EOS>
"
I
feel
so
astonished
,
"
she
began
,
"
I
hardly
know
what
to
say
to
you
,
Miss
Eyre
.
<EOS>
I
have
surely
not
been
dreaming
,
have
I
?
<EOS>
Sometimes
I
half
fall
asleep
when
I
am
sitting
alone
and
fancy
things
that
have
never
happened
.
<EOS>
It
has
seemed
to
me
more
than
once
when
I
have
been
in
a

,
that
my
dear
husband
,
who
died
fifteen
years

,
has
come

sat

;
and
that
I
have
even

call

by

name
,
Alice
,
as

.
<EOS>
Now
,
can

tell

whether

Mr.
Rochester
has

to

him
?
<EOS>
Do

.
<EOS>
But
I
really
thought
he
came
in
here
five
minutes
ago
,
and
said
that
in
a
month
you
would
be
his
wife
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
He
has
said

,
"
I

.
  
<EOS>
"
He
has
!
<EOS>
Do
you
believe
him
?
<EOS>
Have
you
accepted
him
?
<EOS>
"
  
"
<EOS>
Yes
.
"
  
<EOS>
She
looked
at
me

.
<EOS>
"
I
could
never
have
thought
it
.
<EOS>
He
is
a
proud

:
all
the
Rochesters
were
proud
:
and
his
father
,
at

,

.
<EOS>
He

,
has
always
been

careful
.
<EOS>
He
means
to

you
?
"
  
<EOS>
"
He

so
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
She

:
in

I
read
<EOS>
that
they
had
there
found
no

powerful

to

.
  
<EOS>
"
It
passes
me
!
"
<EOS>
she

;
"
but
no

,
it
is
true
since
you
say
so
.
<EOS>
How
it
will
answer
,
I
can
not

:
I
really
do
n't

.
<EOS>
Equality

is
often
advisable
in
such

;
and
there
are
twenty
years
of
difference
in
your
ages
.
<EOS>
He
might
almost

your
father
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
No
,

,
Mrs.
Fairfax
!
"
<EOS>

,

;
"
he

nothing

my

!
<EOS>
No

,

,
would

it
for
an

.
<EOS>
Mr.
Rochester
looks
as
young
,
and
is
as
young
,
as

at

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Is
it
really
for
love
he
is
going
to
marry
you
?
"
<EOS>
she

.
  
<EOS>
I
was
so
hurt
by
her
coldness
and

,
that
the

rose
to

.
  
<EOS>
"
I
am
sorry

,
"
pursued

;
"
but
you
are
so
young
,
and
so
little

with

,
I
wished
to
put
you
on
your

.
<EOS>
It
is
an
old
saying
that
"
all
is
not
gold
that

;
"
and
<EOS>
in
this
case
I
do
fear
there
will
be
something
found
to
be
different
to
what
either
you
or

expect
.
"
  
<EOS>
"
Why
?
 
<EOS>
am
I
a
monster
?
<EOS>
"
I
said
:
"
is
it
impossible
that
Mr.
Rochester
should
have
a
sincere
affection
for
me
?
"
  
<EOS>
"
No
:
you
are
very
well
;
and
much
improved
of
late
;
and
Mr.
Rochester
,
I
daresay
,
is
fond
of
you
.
<EOS>
I
have
always
noticed
that
you
were
a
sort

pet
of
his
.
<EOS>
There
are
times
when
,
for
your
sake
,
I
have
been
a
little
uneasy
at
his
marked
preference
,
and
have
wished
to
put
you
on
your
guard
:
but
I
did
not
like
to
suggest
even
the
possibility
of
wrong
.
<EOS>
I
knew
such
an
idea
would
shock
,
perhaps
offend
you
;
and
you
were
so
discreet
,
and
so
thoroughly
modest
and
sensible
,
I
hoped
you
might
be

to

.
<EOS>
Last
night
I
can
not

you
what
I

when
I

all
over
the

,
and
could

you
nowhere
,
nor
the

either
;
and

,

,

.
"
  
<EOS>
"
Well
,

now
,
"
I

;
"
it
is
enough
that

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
hope
all
will
be
right
in
the
end
,
"
she
said
:
"
but
believe

,
you
can
not

.
<EOS>
Try

Rochester
at

:
distrust

.
<EOS>
Gentlemen
in

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
I
was

:
happily
,
Adele
ran
in
.
  
<EOS>
"
Let
me
go
,
 
let

to
Millcote

!
"
<EOS>

.
"
<EOS>
Mr.
Rochester
wo
n't
:
though
there

so
much
room
in
the

.
<EOS>
Beg

.
<EOS>
"
  
"
That
I

,
Adele
;
"

I

,
glad

.
<EOS>
The

was

:
they

round
to

,
and
my

<EOS>
,
Pilot

.
  
<EOS>
"
Adele
may

,
<EOS>
may

,

?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
told

.
<EOS>
I
'll
have
no

!
 
<EOS>
I
'll
have
only
you
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Do
let
her
go
,
Mr.
Rochester
,
if

:
it

.
"
  
<EOS>
"
Not
it
<EOS>
:
she
will
be
a
restraint
.
"
  
<EOS>
He
was
quite

,
both

.
<EOS>
The

Mrs.
Fairfax
's

,
and

upon

:
<EOS>
something

and

had

.
<EOS>
I
half
lost

sense
of
power
over

.
<EOS>
I
was
about

,
without
further

;
but

,

.
  
<EOS>
"
What
is
the

?
"
<EOS>
he

;
"
all

is

.
<EOS>
Do

really

to
go
?
<EOS>
Will

if

?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
would
far

she

,

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Then
off
for
your
bonnet
,

!
"

.
  
<EOS>
She
obeyed
him
with
what
speed
she
might
.
  
<EOS>
"
After
all
,
a
single
morning
's

will

,
"
said

,
"
when
I
mean
shortly
to
claim
you
 
your
thoughts
,

,
and
company
 
for
life
.
"
  
<EOS>
Adele
,
when
lifted
in
,

,
by

for

:

.
<EOS>
She

;

in

present

,
she
dared

,

.
  
<EOS>
"
Let

to

,
"
I

:
"
she
will
,
perhaps
,
trouble
you
,
sir
<EOS>
:
there
is

room
on
this

.
"
  
<EOS>
He

.
<EOS>
"
I
'll
send
her
to
school
yet
,
"
he
said
,
but
now

was

.
  
<EOS>
Adele
heard

,
and
asked
if
she
was
to
go
to
school
<EOS>
"
sans
mademoiselle
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Yes
,
"
he

,
"
absolutely
sans
mademoiselle
;
for
I
am
to
take
mademoiselle
to
the
moon
,
and
there
I
shall
seek
a
cave
in
one

among
the
volcano
-
tops
,
and
mademoiselle
shall
live
with

,
and

me
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
She
will
have
nothing
to
eat
:
you
will
starve
her
,
"
observed
Adele
.
  
<EOS>
"
I
shall
gather
manna
for
her
morning
and
night
:
the
plains
and
hillsides
in
the
moon
are
bleached
with
manna
,
Adele
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
She
will
want
to
warm
herself
:
what
will
she
do
for
a
fire
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Fire
rises
out

the

:
when
she

cold
,
I
'll
carry
her
up
to
a
peak
,
and
lay
her

the

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Oh
,
qu
'
elle
y
sera
mal
 
peu
comfortable
!
<EOS>
And
her
clothes
,
they
will
wear
out
:
how
can
she
get

?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
Mr.
Rochester
professed
to
be

.
"
<EOS>
Hem
!
<EOS>
"
said
he
.
<EOS>
"
What
would
you
do
,
Adele
?
<EOS>
Cudgel
your
brains
for
an

.
<EOS>
How
would
a
white
or
a
pink
cloud
answer
for
a
gown
,
do
you
think
?
<EOS>
And
one
could
cut
a
pretty
enough

out
of
a

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
She
is

,
"
concluded

,
after

:
"
besides
,
she

in

.
<EOS>
If
I

mademoiselle
,
I
would
never

.
"
  
<EOS>
"
She
has

:
she

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
But
you
ca
n't

;
there

moon
<EOS>
:
it
is

;
and

.
"
  
<EOS>
"
Adele
,

that
field
.
<EOS>
"
We
were
now
outside

,
and

,

well

<EOS>
"
In
that

,
Adele
,
I
was
walking
late
one

about
a
fortnight
since
 
the
evening
of
the
day
<EOS>
you
helped
me
to
make
hay
in
the
orchard
meadows
;
and
,
as
I
was
tired
with
raking
swaths
,
I
sat
down
to
rest
me
on
a
stile
;
and
there
I
took
out
a
little
book
and
a
pencil
,
and
began
to
write
about
a
misfortune
that
befell
me
long
ago
,
and
a
wish
I
had
for
happy
days
to
come
:
I
was
writing
away
very
fast
,
though
daylight
was
fading
from
the
leaf
,
when
something
came
up
the
path
and
stopped
two
yards
off
me
.
<EOS>
I
looked
at
it
.
<EOS>
It
was
a
little
thing
with
a
veil
of
gossamer
on
its
head
.
<EOS>
I
beckoned
it
to
come
near
me
;
it
stood
soon
at
my
knee
.
<EOS>
I
never
spoke
to
it
,
and
it
never
spoke
to
me
,
in
words
;
but
I
read
its
eyes
,
and
it
read
mine
;
and
our
speechless
colloquy
was
to
this
effect
    
<EOS>
"
It
was
a
fairy
,
and
come
from
Elf
-
land
,
it
said
;
and
its
errand
was
to
make
me
happy
:
I
must
go
with
it
out
of
the
common
world
to
a

place
 
such
as
the
moon
,
for
instance
 
<EOS>
and
it

its

her
horn
,
rising

Hay

hill
<EOS>
:
it

where
we
might
live
.
<EOS>
I
said

should
like

;
but
reminded
it
,
as
you
did

,
that
I
had
no

.
  
<EOS>
"
"
Oh
,
"

,
"
that

not

!
<EOS>
Here

a
talisman
will

;
"
and

.
<EOS>
"

,
"

,
"

,

.
"
<EOS>
She

.
<EOS>
The

,

"

<EOS>

<EOS>

?
"
  
<EOS>
"
Mademoiselle

"

.
<EOS>
Mr.
Rochester

.
<EOS>
I

,

:
no

.
<EOS>

:

,

.
<EOS>
With

eye

gay

:
he

a

.
<EOS>
I

<EOS>
:

.
<EOS>

,

.
<EOS>
"

,
"

;
"

<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>

<EOS>
He

<EOS>
I

<EOS>

;

good

.
<EOS>
I

,

,

,

.
<EOS>

,
that

<EOS>

;
but

.

"
Did

"

"

:
    
"
<EOS>

Felt

,
Did

The

,

;

<EOS>

,

:

;

<EOS>
the

,

,

.
<EOS>

,
for

kept

;
though
community
of

was
destroyed
 
<EOS>
the

:

,

"

pleasure

love
is
over
with
you
:
but
you
are
not
desolate
:
<EOS>
each
of
you
has
a
comrade
to
sympathise
with
him
in
his
decay
.
<EOS>
"
As
I
looked
up
at
them
,
the
moon
appeared
momentarily
in
that
part
of
the
sky
which
filled
their
fissure
;
her
disk
was
blood
-
red
and
half
overcast
;
she
seemed
to
throw
on
me
one
bewildered
,
dreary

,
and
buried
herself
again
instantly
in
the
deep

of
cloud
.
<EOS>
The
wind
fell
,
for
a
second
,
round
Thornfield
;
but
far
away
over
wood
and
water
,
poured
a
wild
,
melancholy
wail
<EOS>
:
it
was
sad
to
listen
to
,
and
I
ran
off
again
.
  
<EOS>
Here
<EOS>
and
there
I
strayed
through
the
orchard
,
gathered
up
the
apples
with
which
the
grass
round
the
tree
roots
was
thickly

;
then
I
employed
myself
in
dividing
the
ripe
from
the
unripe
;
I
carried
them
into
the
house
and
put
them
away
in
the
store

room
.
<EOS>
Then
I
repaired
to
the
library
to
ascertain
whether
the
fire
was
lit
,
for
,
though
summer
,
I
knew

such
a
gloomy

Mr.
Rochester
would
like
to
see
a
cheerful
hearth
when
he
came
in
:
<EOS>
yes
,
the
fire
had
been
kindled
some
time
,
and
burnt
well
.
<EOS>
I
placed
his
arm

chair
by
the

corner
:
<EOS>
I
wheeled

table
near
it
:
I
let
down
the
curtain
,
and
had
the
candles
brought

for

.
<EOS>
More

than
ever
,
when
I
had
completed
these
arrangements
I
could
not
sit
still
,
nor
even

in
the
house
:
a
little
time
-
piece
in
the
room
and
the
old
clock

ten
.
  
<EOS>
"
How
late
it
grows
!
<EOS>
"
I
said
.
<EOS>
"
I
will
run
down
to
the
gates
:
it
is
moonlight
at
intervals
;
I
can
see
a
good
way
on
the
road
.
<EOS>
He
may
be
coming
now
,
and
to
meet
him
will
save
some

.
"
  
<EOS>
The
wind
roared
high
in
the
great
trees
which
embowered

gates
;
but
the
road
as
far

I
could

,
to
the

:

out
,
it

but
a
long

,
unvaried
by
one

.
  
<EOS>
A
puerile
tear
dimmed
my
eye
while
I
looked
 
a
tear
of
disappointment
and
impatience
;
ashamed
of

,
I

away
.
<EOS>
I

;
the
moon
shut
herself
wholly
within
her

,
and
drew
close
her
curtain
of
dense

:
the
night
grew

;
rain

driving

on

.
  
<EOS>
"
I
wish
he
would
come
!
<EOS>
I
wish
he
would
come
!
"
<EOS>
I
exclaimed
,
seized
with
hypochondriac

.
<EOS>
I
had
expected
his
arrival
before
tea
;
now
it
was
dark
:
what
could
keep
him
?
<EOS>
Had
an
accident
happened
?
<EOS>
The
event
of
last
night
again
recurred
to
me
.
<EOS>
I
interpreted
it
as
a
warning
of

.
<EOS>
I
feared
my
hopes
were
too
bright
to

;
and
I
had

so
much
bliss
lately
<EOS>
that
I

my

had
passed

,
and

.
  
<EOS>
"
Well
,
I
can
not

to

,
"
I

;
"
I

,
while
he
is
abroad
in
inclement

:
better
tire
my

than
strain

;
I
will
go

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
I

;
I

,
but

:
ere

<EOS>
,

;

came

,

;

.
<EOS>
Away
with
evil
presentiment
!
<EOS>
It

he
:
here

was
,

,

Pilot
.
<EOS>
He

;

<EOS>
I

.
  
<EOS>
"
There
!
"

,

"
You
ca

,

.
<EOS>

"
  
<EOS>
I

:
joy

<EOS>
:

.
<EOS>

"

<EOS>
Is

?
"
  
<EOS>
"
No
,
<EOS>
but
I

would
never

.
<EOS>
I

.
<EOS>
"
  
"
Rain

,

!
<EOS>
Yes

<EOS>
but

<EOS>
I

?
"
  
"
<EOS>
Nothing

;
I

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Then

?
"
  
"
<EOS>
Rather
:

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I

-

;
till

dare

:

.
<EOS>
This

,

,

<EOS>
I

<EOS>

.
<EOS>
You

<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"

<EOS>
Here

:

<EOS>
He

<EOS>
As

<EOS>

<EOS>
"
<EOS>

<EOS>

"

touch

.

:

<EOS>
"

"
Is

?
"

"

<EOS>

<EOS>

"

"

<EOS>

,

<EOS>
I

<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"

.

no

<EOS>
"

"

.
<EOS>
No

.
<EOS>
Yesterday

<EOS>

<EOS>

your

,

an

.
<EOS>

:

.
<EOS>
Just

I

morning
,
and
when
I
looked
round
the
room
to
gather
courage
and
comfort
from
the
cheerful
aspect
of
each
familiar
object
in
full
daylight
,
there
 
on
the
carpet
 
<EOS>
I
saw
what
gave
the
distinct
lie
to
my
hypothesis
,
 
the
veil
,
torn
from
top
to
bottom
in
two
halves
!
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
I
felt
Mr.
Rochester
start
and
shudder
;
he
hastily
flung
his
arms
round
me
.
"
<EOS>
Thank
God
!
"
<EOS>
he
exclaimed
,
"
that
if
anything
malignant
did
come
near
you
last
night
,
it
was
only
the
veil
that
was
harmed
.
<EOS>
Oh
,
to
think
what
might
have
happened
!
"
  
<EOS>
He
drew
his
breath
short
,
and
strained
me
so
close
to
him
,
I
could
scarcely
pant
.
<EOS>
After
some
minutes
'
silence
,
he
continued
,
cheerily
    
"
Now
,
Janet
,
I
'll
explain
to
you
all
about
it
.
<EOS>
It
was
half
dream
,
half
reality
.
<EOS>
A
woman
did
,
I
doubt
not
,
enter
your
room
:
and
that
woman
was
 
must
have
been
 
Grace
Poole
.
<EOS>
You
call
her
a
strange
being
yourself
:
from
all
you
know
,
you
have
reason
so
to
call
her
 
<EOS>
what
did
she
do
to
me
?
<EOS>
what
to
Mason
?
<EOS>
In
a
state
between
sleeping
and
waking
,
you
noticed
her
entrance
and
her
actions
;
but
feverish
,
almost
delirious
as
you
were
,
you
ascribed
to
her
a
goblin
appearance
different
from
her
own
:
the
long
dishevelled
hair
,
the
swelled
black
face
,
the
exaggerated
stature
,
were
figments
of
imagination
;
results
of
nightmare
:
the
spiteful
tearing
of
the
veil
was
real
:
and
it
is
like
her
.
<EOS>
I
see
you
would
ask
why
I
keep
such
a
woman
in
my
house
:
when
we
have
been
married
a
year
and
a
day
,
I
will
tell
you
;
but
not
now
.
<EOS>
Are
you
satisfied
,
Jane
?
<EOS>
Do
you
accept
my
solution
of
the
mystery
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
I
reflected
,
and
in
truth
it
appeared
to
me
the
only
possible
one
:
<EOS>
satisfied
<EOS>
I
was
not
,
but
to
please
him
I
endeavoured
to
appear
so
 
relieved
,
I
certainly
did
feel
;
so
I
answered
him
with
a
contented
smile
.
<EOS>
And
now
,
as
it
was
long
past
one
,
I
prepared
to
leave
him
.
  
<EOS>
"
Does
not
Sophie
sleep
with
Adele
in
the
nursery
?
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
he
asked
,
as
I
lit
my
candle
.
  
<EOS>
"
Yes
,
sir
.
"
  
<EOS>
"
And
there
is
room
enough
in
Adele
's
little
bed
for
you
.
<EOS>
You
must
share
it
with
her
to
-
night
,
Jane
:
it
is
no
wonder
that
the

you
have
related
should
make
you
nervous
,
and
I
would
rather
you
did
not
sleep
alone
:
promise
me
to
go
to
the
nursery
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
shall
be
very
glad
to
do
so
,
sir
.
<EOS>
"
  
"
And
fasten
the
door
securely
on
the
inside
.
<EOS>
Wake
Sophie
when
you
go
upstairs
,
under
pretence
of
requesting
her
to
rouse
you
in
good
time
<EOS>
to-
morrow
;
for
you
must
be
dressed
and
have
finished
breakfast
before
eight
.
<EOS>
And
now
,
no
more
sombre
thoughts
:
chase
dull
care
away
,
Janet
.
<EOS>
Do
n't
you
hear
to
what
soft
whispers
the
wind
has
fallen
?
<EOS>
and
there
is
no
more
beating
of
rain
against
the
window
-
panes
:
<EOS>
look
here
"
(
he
lifted
up
the
curtain
)
 
<EOS>
"
it
is
a
lovely
night
!
"
  
<EOS>
It
was
.
<EOS>
Half
heaven
was
pure
and
stainless
:
<EOS>
the
clouds
,
now
trooping
before
the
wind
,
which
had
shifted
to
the
west
,
were
filing
off
eastward
in
long
,
silvered
columns
.
<EOS>
The
moon
shone
peacefully
.
  
<EOS>
"
Well
,
"
said
Mr.
Rochester
,
gazing
inquiringly
into
my
eyes
,
"
how
is
my
Janet
now
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
The
night
is
serene
,
sir
;
and
so
am
I.
"
  
"
<EOS>
And
you
will
not
dream
of
separation
and
sorrow
to
-
night
;
but
of
happy
love
and
blissful
union
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
This
prediction
was
but
half
fulfilled
:
I
did
not
indeed
dream
of
sorrow
,
but
as
little
did
I
dream
of
joy
;
for
I
never
slept
at
all
.
<EOS>
With
little
Adele
in
my
arms
,
I
watched
the
slumber
of
childhood
 
so
tranquil
,
so
passionless
,
so
innocent
 
and
waited
for
the
coming
day
:
all
my
life
was
awake
and
astir
in
my
frame
:
<EOS>
and
as
soon
as
the
sun
rose
I
rose
too
.
<EOS>
I
remember
Adele
clung
to
me
as
I
left
her
<EOS>
:
I
remember
I
kissed
her
as
I
loosened
her
little

from
my

;
and
I
cried
over
her
with
strange

,
and
quitted
her
because
I
feared
my
sobs
would
break
her
still
sound

.
<EOS>
She
seemed
the
emblem
of
my
past
life
;
and
here
I
was
now
to
array
myself
to
meet
,
the
dread
,
but
adored
,
type
of
my
unknown
future

.
    
<EOS>
Sophie
came
at
seven
to
dress
me
:
she
was
very
long
indeed
in
accomplishing
her
task
;
so
long
that
Mr.
Rochester
,
grown
,
I
suppose
,
impatient
of
my
delay
,
sent
up
to
ask
why
I
did
not
come
.
<EOS>
She
was
just

my
veil
(
the
plain
square
of
blond
after
all
)
to
my
hair
with
a
brooch
;
I
hurried
from
under
her
hands
as
soon
as
I
could
.
  
<EOS>
"
Stop
!
"
<EOS>
she
cried
in
French
.
<EOS>
"
Look
at
yourself
in
the
mirror
:
you
have
not
taken
one
peep
.
"
  
<EOS>
So
I
turned
at
the
door
:
I
saw
a
robed
and
veiled
figure
,
so
unlike
my
usual
self
that
it
seemed
almost
the
image
of
a
stranger
.
<EOS>
"
Jane
!
"
called
a
voice
,
and
I
hastened
down
.
<EOS>
I
was
received
at
the
foot
of
the
stairs
by
Mr.
Rochester
.
  
<EOS>
"
Lingerer
!
"
<EOS>
he
said
,
"
my
brain
is
on
fire
with
impatience
,
and
you
tarry
so
long
!
"
  
<EOS>
He
took
me
into
the
dining
-
room
,
surveyed
me
keenly
all
over
,
pronounced
me
"
fair
as
a
lily
,
and
not
only
the
pride
of
his
life
,
but
the
desire
of
his
eyes
,
"
and
then
telling
me
he
would
give
me
but
ten
minutes
to
eat
some
breakfast
,
he
rang
the
bell
.
<EOS>
One
of
his
lately
hired
servants
,
a
footman
,
answered

.
  
<EOS>
"
Is
John
getting
the
carriage
ready
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Yes
,
sir
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Is
the
luggage
brought
down
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
They
are
bringing
it
down
,
sir
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Go
you
to
the

:
see

Mr.
Wood
(
the

)
and
the
clerk
are

:
return

.
"
  
<EOS>
The
church
,
as
the
reader
knows
,
was
but
just
beyond
the

;
the

soon

.
  
<EOS>
"
Mr.
Wood
is
in
the

,

,

.
<EOS>
"
  
"
<EOS>
And
the

?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
The

are

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
We
shall
not
want
it
to
go
to

;
but
it
must
be
ready
<EOS>
the

:
all

,

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Yes
,

.
"
  
<EOS>
"
Jane
,

?
"
  
<EOS>
I
rose
.
<EOS>
There
were
no

,
no

,
no

to

:
none
but
Mr.
Rochester
and
I.
Mrs.
Fairfax
stood
in
the
hall
as
we
passed
.
<EOS>
I
would
fain
have
spoken
to
her
,
but
my
hand
was
held
by
a
grasp
of
iron
:
I
was
hurried
along
by
a
stride
I
could
hardly
follow
;
and
to
look
at
Mr.
Rochester
's
face
was
to
feel
that
not
a
second
of
delay
would
be
tolerated
for
any
purpose
.
<EOS>
I
wonder
what
other
bridegroom
ever
looked
as
he
did
 
so
bent
up
to
a
purpose
,
so
grimly
resolute
:
or
who
,
under
such
steadfast
brows
,
ever
revealed
such
flaming
and
flashing

.
  
<EOS>
I
know
not
whether
the
day
was
fair
or
foul
;
in
descending
the
drive
,
I
gazed
neither
on
sky
nor
earth
:
my
heart
was
with
my
eyes
;
and
both
seemed
migrated
into
Mr.
Rochester
's
frame
.
<EOS>
I
wanted
to
see
the
invisible
thing
on
which
,
as
we
went
along
,
he
appeared
to
fasten
a
glance
fierce
and
fell
.
<EOS>
I
wanted
to
feel
the
thoughts
whose
force
he
seemed
breasting
and
resisting
.
  
<EOS>
At
the
churchyard
wicket
he
stopped
:
he
discovered
I
was
quite
out
of
breath
.
"
<EOS>
Am
I
cruel
in
my
love
?
"
<EOS>
he
said
.
<EOS>
"
Delay
an
instant
:
<EOS>
lean
on
me
,
Jane
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
And
now
I
can
recall
the
picture
of
the
grey
old
house
of
God
rising
calm
before
me
,
of
a
rook
wheeling
round
the
steeple
,
of
a
ruddy
morning
sky
beyond
.
<EOS>
I
remember
something
,
too
,
of
the
green
grave
-
mounds
;
and
I
have
not
forgotten
,
either
,
two
figures
of
strangers
straying
amongst
the
low
hillocks
and
reading
the
mementoes
graven
on
the
few
mossy
head
-
stones
.
<EOS>
I
noticed
them
,
because
,
as
they
saw
us
,
they
passed
round
to
the
back
of
the
church
;
and
I
doubted
not
they
were
going
to
enter
by
the
side
-
aisle
door
and
witness
the
ceremony
.
<EOS>
By
Mr.
Rochester
they
were
not
observed
;
he
was
earnestly
looking
at
my
face
from
which
the
blood
had
<EOS>
,
I
daresay
,
momentarily
fled
:
for
I
felt
my
forehead
dewy
,
and
my
cheeks
and
lips
cold
.
<EOS>
When
I
rallied
,
which
I
soon
did
,
he
walked
gently
with
me
up
the
path
to
the
porch
.
  
<EOS>
We
entered
the
quiet
and
humble
temple
;
the
priest
waited
in
his
white
surplice
at
the
lowly
altar
,
the
clerk
beside
him
.
<EOS>
All
was
still
:
two
shadows
only
moved
in
a
remote
corner
.
<EOS>
My
conjecture
had
been
correct
:
the
strangers
had
slipped
in
before
us
,
and
they
now
stood
by
the
vault
of
the
Rochesters
,
their
backs
towards
us
,
viewing
through
the
rails
the
old
time
-
stained
marble
tomb
,
where
a
kneeling
angel
guarded
the
remains
of
Damer
de
Rochester
,
slain
at
Marston
Moor
in
the
time
of
the
civil
wars
,
and
of
Elizabeth
,
his
wife
.
  
<EOS>
Our
place
was
taken
at
the
communion
rails
.
<EOS>
Hearing
a
cautious
step
behind
me
,
I
glanced
over
my
shoulder
:
one
of
the
strangers
 
a
gentleman
,
evidently
 
was
advancing
up
the
chancel
.
<EOS>
The
service
began
.
<EOS>
The
explanation
of
the
intent
of
matrimony
was
gone
through
;
and
then
the
clergyman
came
a
step
further
forward
,
and
,
bending
slightly
towards
Mr.
Rochester
,
went
on
.
  
<EOS>
"
I
require
and
charge
you
both
(
as
ye
will
answer
at
the
dreadful
day
of
judgment
,
when
the
secrets
of
all
hearts
shall
be
disclosed
)
,
that
if
either
of
you
know
any
impediment
why
ye
may
not
lawfully
be
joined
together
in
matrimony
,
ye
do
now
confess
it
;
for
be
<EOS>
ye
<EOS>
well
assured
that
so
many
as
are
coupled
together
otherwise
than
God
's
Word
doth
allow
,
are
not
joined
together
by
God
,
neither
is
their
matrimony
lawful
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
He
paused
,
as
the
custom
is
.
<EOS>
When
is
the
pause
after
that
sentence
ever
broken
by
reply
?
<EOS>
Not
,
perhaps
,
once
in
a
hundred
years
.
<EOS>
And
the
clergyman
,
who
had
not
lifted
his
eyes
from
his
book
,
and
had
held
his
breath
but
for
a
moment
,
was
proceeding
:
his
hand
was
already
stretched
towards
Mr.
Rochester
,
as
his
lips
unclosed
to
ask
,
"
Wilt
thou
have
this
woman
for
thy
wedded
wife
?
"
 
when
a
distinct
and
near
voice
said
    
"
The
marriage
can
not
go
on
:
I
declare
the
existence
of
an
impediment
.
"
  
<EOS>
The
clergyman
looked
up
at
the
speaker
and
stood
mute
;
the
clerk
did
the
same
;
Mr.
Rochester
moved
slightly
,
as
if
an
earthquake
had
rolled
under
his
feet
:
taking
a
firmer
footing
,
and
not
turning
his
head
or
eyes
,
he
said
,
"
Proceed
.
"
  
<EOS>
Profound
silence
fell
when
he
had
uttered
that
word
,
with
deep
but
low
intonation
.
<EOS>
Presently
Mr.
Wood
said
    
"
I
can
not
proceed
without
some
investigation
into
what
has
been
asserted
,
and
evidence
of
its
truth
or
falsehood
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
The
ceremony
is
quite
broken
off
,
"
subjoined
the
voice
behind
us
.
<EOS>
"
I
am
in
a
condition
to
prove
my
allegation
:
an
insuperable
impediment
to
this
marriage
exists
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
Mr.
Rochester
heard
,
but
heeded
not
:
he
stood
stubborn
and
rigid
,
making
no
movement
but
to
possess
himself
of
my
hand
.
<EOS>
What
a
hot
and
strong
grasp
he
had
!
<EOS>
and
how
like
quarried
marble
was
his
pale
,
firm
,
massive
front
at
this
moment
!
<EOS>
How
his
eye
shone
,
still
watchful
,
and
yet
wild
beneath
!
  
<EOS>
Mr.
Wood
seemed
at
a
loss
.
<EOS>
"
What
is
the
nature
of
the
impediment
?
"
he
asked
.
<EOS>
"
Perhaps
it
may
be
got
over
 
explained
away
?
<EOS>
"
  
"
Hardly
,
"
was
the
answer
.
<EOS>
"
I
have
called
it
insuperable
,
and
I
speak
advisedly
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
The
speaker
came
forward
and
leaned
on
the
rails
.
<EOS>
He
continued
,
uttering
each
word
distinctly
,
<EOS>
calmly
,
steadily
,
but
not
loudly
    
"
It
simply
consists
in
the
existence
of
a
previous
marriage
.
<EOS>
Mr.
Rochester
has
a
wife
now
living
.
"
  
<EOS>
My
nerves
vibrated
to
those
low
-
spoken
words
as
they
had
never
vibrated
to
thunder
 
<EOS>
my
blood
felt
their
subtle
violence
as
it
had
never
felt
frost
or
fire
;
but
I
was
collected
,
and
in
no

of
swooning
.
<EOS>
I
looked
at
Mr.
Rochester
:
I
made
him
look
at
me
.
<EOS>
His
whole
face
was
colourless
rock
:
his
eye
was
both
spark
and
flint
.
<EOS>
He
disavowed
nothing
:
he
seemed
as
if
he
would
defy
all
things
.
<EOS>
Without

,
without

,
without

a
human

,
he
only
twined
my

with
his

and
riveted
me
to

side
.
  
<EOS>
"
Who
are
you
?
"
<EOS>
he
asked
of
the

.
  
<EOS>
"
My
name
is
Briggs
,
a
solicitor
of
 
Street
,
London
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
And
you
would
thrust
on

a
wife
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
would
remind
you
of
your
lady
's
existence
,
sir
,
which
the
law

,

.
"
  
<EOS>
"
Favour

with
an
account
of
her
 
with
her
name
,

,

.
<EOS>
"
  
"
Certainly
.
"
<EOS>
Mr.
Briggs
calmly

,
and
read
out

:
    
"
"
I
affirm
and
can

that
on

(

)
,
Edward
Fairfax

,
of

,
in

,

,
Bertha

Mason

Jonas
Mason
,

,
and

Antoinetta
<EOS>
his

,
a

,
at
 
church
,

,

.
<EOS>
The

a

.
<EOS>
Signed

Richard

.
"
<EOS>
"
  
"
That
 
if

may

I

,
but

that
the
woman
mentioned
therein
as
my
wife
is
still

.
"
  
<EOS>
"
She
was
living
three
months
ago
,
"
returned
the

.
  
<EOS>
"
How
do

know
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
have
a
witness

,
whose

,

,

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Produce
him
 
or

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
will
produce
him
first
 
<EOS>
he
is
on
the

.
<EOS>
Mr.
Mason
,
have
the
goodness
to
step

.
"
  
<EOS>
Mr.
Rochester
,
on

,
set
his

;
he
experienced
,

,
a

near

I

,
I

.
<EOS>
The
second

,
who
had
hitherto

in
the

,
now
drew
near
;
a
pale
face
looked
over
the
solicitor
's

<EOS>
yes
,
it
was
Mason
himself
.
<EOS>
Mr.
Rochester
turned
and

at

.
<EOS>
His
eye
,
as
I
have
often
said
,
was
a
black

:
it
had
now
a
tawny
,
nay
,

;
and
his

flushed
 
olive
cheek
and
hueless

received
a

as
from

,

heart
-

:
and
he

,
lifted

strong
arm
 
he
could
have
struck
Mason
,
dashed
him
on
the
church
-

,
shocked
by
ruthless
blow
the
breath
from
his
body
 
<EOS>
but
Mason
shrank
away
,
and
cried

,
"
Good
God
!
"
<EOS>
Contempt
fell
cool
on

Rochester
 
his

died
as
if

had
shrivelled

up
:
he
only
asked
 
"
What
have
_
<EOS>
you
_
to

?
"
  
<EOS>
An

's

.
  
<EOS>
"
The
devil
is
in
it
if
you
can

.
<EOS>
I

,
what

to

?
"
  
<EOS>
"
Sir

,
"

,
"
do

.
"
<EOS>
Then

,

,
"
Are

,

,
whether

this

's
wife

?
<EOS>
"
  
"
Courage
,
"

,
 
"
speak

.
"
  
<EOS>
"
She
is
now

,
"

,

:
"
I

.
<EOS>
I

.
<EOS>
"
  
"
<EOS>
At

Hall
!
"

.
"
<EOS>
Impossible
!
<EOS>
I

,

,
and
I
never
heard

a
Mrs.
Rochester

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
I

grim

Mr.
Rochester
's

,
and
he

"
<EOS>
No
,
by
God
!
<EOS>
I
took
care
that
none
should
hear
of
it
 
or
of

under
that

.
"
<EOS>
He
mused
 
for
ten
minutes
he
held
counsel
with

:
he
formed
his
resolve
,
and
announced
it
    
"
Enough
!
<EOS>
all
shall

,

.
<EOS>
Wood
,

and

;
John
Green
(

)
,

:
there

be
no

.
<EOS>
"
The
man
obeyed
.
  
<EOS>
Mr.
Rochester
continued
,
hardily
and
recklessly
:
<EOS>
"
Bigamy
is
an
ugly
word
!
 
<EOS>
I
meant
,
however
,
to
be
a
bigamist
;
but
fate
has
out
-
manoeuvred
me
,
or
Providence
has
checked
me
,
 
perhaps
the
last
.
<EOS>
I
am
little
better
than
a
devil
at
this
moment
;
and
,
as
my
pastor
there
would
tell

,
deserve
no
doubt
the
sternest
judgments
of
God
,
even
to
the
quenchless
fire
and
deathless

.
<EOS>
Gentlemen
,
my
plan
is
broken
up
:
 
what
this
lawyer
and
his
client
say
is
true
:
I
have
been
married
,
and
the
woman
to
whom
I
was
married
lives
!
<EOS>
You
say
you
never
heard

a
Mrs.
Rochester
at
the
house

,
Wood
;
but
I
daresay
you
have
many
a
time
inclined
your
ear
to
gossip
about
the
mysterious
lunatic
kept
there
under
watch

.
<EOS>
Some
have

to
you
that
she
is
my
bastard
half
-

:
some
,
my
cast
-

.
<EOS>
I
now
inform
you
that
she
is
my
wife
,
whom
I
married
fifteen
years
ago
,
 
Bertha
Mason
by
name
;
sister
of
this
resolute

,
who
is
now
,
with
his

and
white

,
showing
you
what
a
stout
heart
men
may
bear
.
<EOS>
Cheer
up
,
Dick
!
 
<EOS>
never
fear
me
!
 
<EOS>
I
'd
almost
as
soon

a
woman
as
you
.
<EOS>
Bertha
Mason
is
mad
;
and
she
came
of
a
mad

;
idiots
and

through

!
<EOS>
Her

,
the
Creole
,
was
both
a

and

!
 
<EOS>
as

after

had
we

the
daughter
:
for

were
silent

before
.
<EOS>
Bertha
,

,

.
<EOS>
I

<EOS>
pure
,

,
modest
<EOS>
:
you
can
fancy
<EOS>
I

.
<EOS>
I
went

rich

!
<EOS>
Oh
!
<EOS>
my

,

!
<EOS>
But

.
<EOS>
Briggs

's

,

!
<EOS>
You

what

being
<EOS>
I

,

,

.
<EOS>

<EOS>

"
  
<EOS>
Still

,

:

.
<EOS>
At

.
  
<EOS>
"

,
"

;
"

.
"
  
<EOS>
At

,

,

,

,

,

.
  
<EOS>
"
To

-
about
 
every

!
"

;
"
away

!
<EOS>
Who

?
<EOS>
Not

!
 
<EOS>
they

!
"
  
<EOS>
He

,

,
and

.
<EOS>
We

,

,

:

,

,

.
  
<EOS>
"
You
know
this
place
,
Mason
,
"
said
our
guide
;
"
she
bit
and
stabbed
you
here
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
He
lifted
the
hangings
from

,
uncovering
the

:
this
,

,

opened
.
<EOS>
In
a

without
a
window
,

burnt

by

strong

,
and

suspended
from

ceiling
by
a
chain
.
<EOS>
Grace
Poole
bent
over
the
fire
,
apparently
cooking
something
in
a
saucepan
.
<EOS>
In
the
deep
shade
,
at
the
farther
end
of
the
room
,
a

ran
backwards
and

.
<EOS>
What
it
was
,
whether
beast
or

,
one
could
not
,
at
first

,
tell
:
it

,

,

;

and

like
some
strange

:
but
it
was
covered
with

,
and
a
quantity
of
dark
,

,
wild
as
a
mane
,
hid
its

and
face
.
  
<EOS>
"
Good
-
morrow
,
Mrs.
Poole
!
"
said
Mr.
Rochester
.
<EOS>
"
How
are
you
?
<EOS>
and
how
is
your
charge
to
-
day
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
We
're
tolerable
,
sir
,
I
thank
you
,
"
replied
Grace
,
lifting
the
boiling
mess
carefully
on
to
the
hob
:
"
rather
snappish
,
but
not
"
rageous
.
"
  
<EOS>
A
fierce
cry
seemed
to
give
the
lie
to
her
favourable
report
:
the
clothed
hyena
rose
up
,
and
stood
tall
on
its
hind
-
feet
.
  
<EOS>
"
Ah
!
<EOS>
sir
,
she
sees
you
!
"
<EOS>
exclaimed
Grace
:
"
you
'd
better
not
stay
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Only
a
few
moments
,
Grace
:
you
must
allow
me
a
few
moments
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Take
care
then
,
sir
!
 
for
God
's
sake
,
take
care
!
"
  
<EOS>
The
maniac
bellowed
:
she
parted
her
shaggy
locks
from
her
visage
,
and
gazed
wildly
at
her
visitors
.
<EOS>
I
recognised
well
that
purple
face
,
 
those
bloated
features
.
<EOS>
Mrs.
Poole
advanced
.
  
<EOS>
"
Keep
out
of
the
way
,
"
said
Mr.
Rochester
,
thrusting
her
aside
:
"
she
has
no
knife
now
,
I
suppose
,
and
I
'm
on
my
guard
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
One
never
knows
what
she
has
,
sir
:
she
is
so
cunning
:
<EOS>
it
is
not
in
mortal
discretion
to
fathom
her
craft
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
We
had
better
leave
her
,
"
whispered
Mason
.
  
<EOS>
"
Go
to
the
devil
!
"
<EOS>
was
his
brother
-
in
-
law
's
recommendation
.
  
<EOS>
"
"
Ware
!
"
cried
Grace
.
<EOS>
The
three
gentlemen
retreated
simultaneously
.
<EOS>
Mr.
Rochester
flung
me
behind
him
:
the
lunatic
sprang
and
grappled
his
throat
viciously
,
and
laid
her
teeth
to
his
cheek
:
they
struggled
.
<EOS>
She
was
a
big
woman
,
in
stature
almost
equalling
her
husband
,
and
corpulent
besides
:
she
showed
virile
force
in
the
contest
 
more
than
once
she
almost
throttled
him
,
athletic
as
he
was
.
<EOS>
He
could
have
settled
her
with
a
well
-
planted
blow
;
but
he
would
not
strike
:
he
would
only
wrestle
.
<EOS>
At
last
he
mastered
her
arms
;
Grace
Poole
gave
him
a
cord
,
and
he
pinioned
them
behind
her
:
with
more
rope
,
which
was
at
hand
,
he
bound
her
to
a
chair
.
<EOS>
The
operation
was
performed
amidst
the
fiercest
yells
and
the
most
convulsive
plunges
.
<EOS>
Mr.
Rochester
then
turned
to
the
spectators
:
he
looked
at
them
with
a
smile
both
acrid
and
desolate
.
  
<EOS>
"
That
is
_
<EOS>
my
wife
_
,
"
said
he
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Such
is
the
sole
conjugal
embrace
I
am
ever
to
know
 
<EOS>
such
are
the
endearments
which
are
to
solace
my
leisure
hours
!
<EOS>
And
_
this
_
is
what
I
wished
to
have
"
(
laying

on

)
:
"
this
young
girl
,
who
stands
so

at
the
mouth

,

at
the
gambols
of
a
demon
,
I
wanted

just
as
a
change
after
that

.
<EOS>
Wood
and
Briggs
,
look
at
the
difference
!
<EOS>
Compare
these
clear
eyes
with
the
red
balls
yonder
 
<EOS>
this
face
with
that
mask
 
<EOS>
this
form
with
that
bulk
;
then
judge
me
,
priest
of
the
gospel
and
man
of
the
law
,
and
remember

what
judgment
ye
judge
ye
shall
be

!
<EOS>
Off
with
you
now
.
<EOS>
I
must
shut
up
my
prize
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
We
all
withdrew
.
<EOS>
Mr.
Rochester
stayed
a
moment
behind
us
,
to
give
some
further
order
to
Grace
Poole
.
<EOS>
The

addressed
me
as
he

the

.
  
<EOS>
"
You
,
madam
,
"
said
he
,
"
are
cleared
from
all
blame
:
your
uncle
will
be
glad
to
hear
it
 
if
,
indeed
,
he
should
be
still
living
 
when
Mr.
Mason
returns
to
Madeira
.
"
  
<EOS>
"
My
uncle
!
<EOS>
What
of
him
?
<EOS>
Do
you
know
him
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Mr.
Mason
does
.
<EOS>
Mr.
Eyre
has
been
the
Funchal
correspondent
of
his
house
for
some
years
.
<EOS>
When
your
uncle
received
your
letter
intimating
the
contemplated
union
between

and
Mr.
Rochester
,
Mr.
Mason
,
who
was

at

to

health
,
on

back
to
Jamaica
,
happened
to

.
<EOS>
Mr.
Eyre
mentioned
the
intelligence
;
for
he
knew
that
my
client
here
was

with
a
gentleman
of
the
name
of
Rochester
.
<EOS>
Mr.
Mason
,
astonished
and
distressed
as
you
may

,
revealed
the
real
state
of

.
<EOS>
Your
uncle
,
I
am
sorry

,
is
now
on

sick

;
from

,

the

disease
 
decline
 
and

,

.
<EOS>
He

not

England

,
to

had

,
but

Mason
to

in

to

false

.
<EOS>
He

to
me
for

.
<EOS>
I
used
all
despatch
,
and
am
thankful
I
was
not
too
late
:
as
you
,

,
must
be

.
<EOS>
Were

that
your
uncle
will
be
dead
ere
<EOS>
you

,
I

Mason

;
but

,

Eyre
.
<EOS>
Have

anything
else

stay
for
?
"
<EOS>
he

of
Mr.
Mason
.
  
<EOS>
"
No
,
no
 
let
us
be
gone
,
"
was
the

reply
;
and
without

to
take

of
Mr.
Rochester
,
they
made

at

hall

.
<EOS>
The
clergyman
stayed
to
exchange
a
few
sentences
,
either
of

or
reproof
,
with
his
haughty
parishioner
;
this
duty

,
he
too

.
  
<EOS>
I
heard
him
go
as
I
stood
at
the
half

open
door
of
my
own
room
,
to
which
I
had
now
withdrawn
.
<EOS>
The
house
cleared
,
I
shut
myself
in
,
fastened
the
bolt
that
none
might
intrude
,
and
proceeded
 
not
to
weep
,
not
to

,
I
was
yet
too
calm
for
that
,
but
 
mechanically
to
take

the
wedding

,
and
replace
it
by
the
stuff
gown
I
had
worn
yesterday
,
as
I
thought
,
for
the
last
time
.
<EOS>
I
then
sat
down
:
I
felt
weak
and
tired
.
<EOS>
I
leaned
my
arms
on
a
table
,
and
my
head
dropped
on
them
.
<EOS>
And
now
I
thought
:
till
now
I
had
only
heard
,
seen
,
moved
 
followed
up
and
down
where
I
was
led
or
dragged
 
watched
event
rush
on
event
,
disclosure
open
beyond
disclosure
:
<EOS>
but
_
now
_
,
<EOS>
_
<EOS>
I
thought
_
.
  
<EOS>
The
morning
had
been
a
quiet
morning
enough
 
<EOS>
all
except
the
brief
scene
with
the
lunatic
:
the
transaction
in
the
church
had
not
been
noisy
;
there
was
no
explosion
of

,
no
loud

,
no
dispute
,
no
defiance
or
challenge
,
no
tears
,
no
sobs
:
a
few
words
had
been
spoken
,
a
calmly
pronounced
objection
to
the
marriage
made
;
some
stern
,
short
questions
put
by
Mr.
Rochester
;
answers
,
explanations
given
,
evidence

;
an
open

of
the
truth
had
been
uttered
by
my
master
;
then
the
living
proof
had
been
seen
;
the
intruders
were
gone
,
and
all
was
over
.
  
<EOS>
I
was
in
my
own
room
as
usual
 
just
myself
,
without
obvious
change
:
<EOS>
nothing
had
smitten
me
,
or
scathed
me
,
or
maimed
me
.
<EOS>
And
yet
where
was
the
Jane
Eyre
of
yesterday
?
 
<EOS>
where
was
her
life
?
 
<EOS>
where
were
her
prospects
?
  
<EOS>
Jane
Eyre
,
who
had
been
an
ardent
,
expectant
woman
 
almost
a
bride
,
was
a
cold
,
solitary
girl
again
:
her
life
was
pale
;
her
prospects
were
desolate
.
<EOS>
A
Christmas
frost
had
come
at
midsummer
;
a
white
December
storm
had
whirled
over
June
;
ice
glazed
the
ripe
apples
,
drifts
crushed
the
blowing
roses
;
on
hayfield
and
cornfield
lay
a
frozen
shroud
:
<EOS>
lanes
which
last
night
blushed
full
of
flowers
,
to
-
day
were
pathless
with
untrodden
snow
;
and
the
woods
,
which
twelve
hours
since
waved
leafy
and
flagrant
as
groves
between
the

,
now
spread
,
waste
,
wild
,
and

as

in

.
<EOS>
My
hopes
were
all
dead
 
struck
with
a
subtle
doom
,
such
as
,
in
one
night
,
fell
on
all
the
first
-
born
in
the
land
of
Egypt
.
<EOS>
I
looked
on
my
cherished
wishes
,
yesterday
so
blooming
and
glowing
;
they
lay
stark
,
chill
,
livid
corpses
that
could
never
revive
.
<EOS>
I
looked
at
my
love
:
<EOS>
that
feeling
which
was
my
master
's
 
which
he
had
created
;
it
shivered
in
my
heart
,
like
a
suffering
child
in
a
cold

;
sickness
and

had
seized
it
;
it
could
not
seek
Mr.
Rochester
's
arms
 
it
could
not
derive
warmth
from
his
breast
.
<EOS>
Oh
,
never
more
could
it
turn
to
him
;
for
faith
was
blighted
 
confidence
destroyed
!
<EOS>
Mr.
Rochester
was
not
to
me
what
he
had
been
;
for
he
was
not
what
I
had
thought
him
.
<EOS>
I
would
not
ascribe
vice
to
him
;
I
would
not
say
he
had
betrayed
me
;
but
the
attribute
of
stainless
truth
was
gone
from
his
idea
,
and
from
his
presence
I
must
go
:
<EOS>
_
that
_
I
perceived
well
.
<EOS>
When
 
how
 
whither
,
I
could
not
yet
discern
;
but
he
himself
,
I
doubted
not
,
would
hurry
me
from
Thornfield
.
<EOS>
Real
affection
,
it
seemed
,
he
could
not
have
for
me
;
it
had
been
only
fitful
passion
:
that
was
balked
;
he
would
want
me
no
more
.
<EOS>
I
should
fear
even
to
cross
his
path
now
:
my
view
must
be
hateful
to
him
.
<EOS>
Oh
,
how
blind
had
been
my
eyes
!
<EOS>
How
weak
my
conduct
!
  
<EOS>
My
eyes
were
covered
and
closed
:
eddying
darkness
seemed
to
swim
round
me
,
and
reflection
came
in
as
black
and
confused
a
flow
.
<EOS>
Self
-
abandoned
,
relaxed
,
and
effortless
,
I
seemed
to
have
laid
me
down
in
the
dried

up
bed
of
a
great
river
;
I
heard
a
flood
loosened
in
remote
mountains
,
and
felt
the
torrent
come
:
to
rise
I
had
no
will
,
to
flee
I
had
no
strength
.
<EOS>
I
lay
faint
,
longing
to
be
dead
.
<EOS>
One
idea
only
still
throbbed
life
-
like
within
me
 
a
remembrance
of
God
:
it
begot
an
unuttered

:
these
words
went
wandering
up

in
my

mind
,
as
something
that
should
be
whispered
,
but
no
energy
was
found
to
express
them
    
<EOS>
"
Be
not
far
from
me
,
for
trouble
is
near
:
there
is
none
to
help
.
"
  
<EOS>
It
was
near
:
and
as
I
had
lifted
no
petition
to
Heaven
to
avert
it
 
as
I
had
neither
joined
my
hands
,
nor
bent
my
knees
,
nor
moved
my
lips
 
<EOS>
it
came
:
in
full
heavy
swing
the
torrent
poured
over
me
.
<EOS>
The
whole
consciousness
of
my
life
lorn
,
my
love
lost
,
my
hope
quenched
,
my
faith
death
-
struck
,
swayed
full
and
mighty
above
me
in
one
sullen

.
<EOS>
That
bitter
hour
can
not
be
described
:
in
truth
,
"
the
waters
came
into
my
soul
;
I
sank
in
deep
mire
:
I
felt
no
standing
;
I
came
into
deep
waters
;
the
floods
overflowed
me
.
"
    
<EOS>
Some
time
in
the

I
raised
my
head
,
and
looking
round
and
seeing
the
western
sun
gilding
the
sign
of
its
decline
on
the
wall
,
I
asked
,
"
What
am
I
to
do
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
But
the
answer
my
mind
gave
 
"
Leave
Thornfield
at
once
"
 
<EOS>
was
so
prompt
,
so
dread
,
that
I
stopped
my
ears
.
<EOS>
I
said
I
could
not
bear
such
words
now
.
<EOS>
"
That
I
am
not
Edward
Rochester
's
bride
is
the
least
part
of
my
woe
,
"
I
alleged
:
"
that
I
have
wakened
out
of
most
glorious

,
and
found

all
void
and
vain
,
is
a
horror
I
could
bear
and
master
;
but
that
I
must
leave
him
decidedly
,
instantly
,
entirely
,
is
intolerable
.
<EOS>
I
can
not
do
it
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
But
,
then
,
a
voice
within
me
averred
that
I
could
do
it
and
foretold
that
I
should
do
it
.
<EOS>
I
wrestled
with
my
own
resolution
:
I
wanted
to
be
weak
that
I
might
avoid
the
awful
passage
of
further
suffering
I
saw
laid
out
for
me
;
and
Conscience
,
turned
tyrant
,
held
Passion
by
the
throat
,
told
her
tauntingly
<EOS>
,
she
had
yet
but
dipped
her
dainty
foot
in
the
slough
,
and
swore
that
with
that
arm
of
iron
he
would
thrust
her
down
to
unsounded
depths
of
agony
.
  
<EOS>
"
Let
me
be
torn
away
,
"
then
I
cried
.
<EOS>
"
Let
another
help
me
!
"
  
<EOS>
"
No
;
you
shall
tear
yourself
away
<EOS>
,
none
shall
help
you
:
you
shall
yourself
pluck
out
your
right
eye
;
yourself
cut
off
your
right
hand
:
your
heart
shall
be
the
victim
,
and
you
the
priest
to
transfix
it
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
I
rose
up
suddenly
,
terror
-
struck
at
the
solitude
which
so
ruthless
a
judge
haunted
,
 
at
the
silence
which
so
awful
a
voice
filled
.
<EOS>
My
head
swam
as
I
stood
erect
.
<EOS>
I
perceived
that
I
was
sickening
from
excitement
and
inanition
;
neither
meat
nor
drink
had
passed
my
lips
that
day
,
for
I
had
taken
no
breakfast
.
<EOS>
And
,
with
a
strange

,
I
now
reflected
that
,
long

I
had
been
shut
up
here
,
no

had
been
sent
to
ask

I
was
,
or
to
invite
me
to
come
down
:
not
even
little
Adele
had
tapped
at
the

;
not
even
Mrs.
Fairfax
had
sought
me
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Friends
always
forget
those
whom
fortune
forsakes
,
"
I
murmured
,
as
I
undrew
the
bolt
and
passed
out
.
<EOS>
I
stumbled
over
an
obstacle
:
my
head
was
still
dizzy
,
my
sight
was
dim
,
and
my
limbs
were
feeble
.
<EOS>
I
could
not
soon
recover
myself
.
<EOS>
I
fell
,
but
not
on
to
the
ground
:
an
outstretched
arm
caught
me
.
<EOS>
I
looked
up
 
<EOS>
I
was
supported
by
Mr.
Rochester
,
who
sat
in
a
chair
across
my
chamber
threshold
.
  
<EOS>
"
You
come
out
at
last
,
"
he
said
.
<EOS>
"
Well
,
I
have
been
waiting
for
you
long
,
and
listening
:
<EOS>
yet
not
one
movement
<EOS>
have
I
heard
,
nor
one
sob
:
five
minutes
more
of
that
death
-
like
hush
,
and
I
should
have
forced
the
lock
like
a
burglar
.
<EOS>
So
you
shun
me
?
 
<EOS>
you
shut
yourself
up
and
grieve
alone
!
<EOS>
I

<EOS>

<EOS>

,

.
<EOS>

soon
again
stopped
,
and
this
time
just
before
me
.
  
<EOS>
"
Jane
!
<EOS>
will
you
hear
reason
?
"
(
he
stooped
and
approached
his
lips
to
my

)
;
"
because
,
if
you
wo
n't
,
I
'll
try
violence
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
His

was
hoarse
;
his
look
that
of
a

.
<EOS>
I

,

should

.
<EOS>
The
present
 
<EOS>
the

second
of
time
 
was
all

had

which
to
control
and
restrain
him
 
a
movement
of
repulsion
,
flight
<EOS>
,
fear

have
sealed
my
doom
,
 
and
his
.
<EOS>
But
I
was
not

:

.
<EOS>
I

an

;
a

,

.
<EOS>
The

was
perilous
;
but
not
without
its
charm
:
such
as
the
Indian
,
perhaps
,
feels
when

.
<EOS>
I

,
loosened

contorted

,
and
said
to

,
soothingly
    
"
Sit
down
;
I
'll
talk
to

as
long

,
and
hear
all
you
have
to

,
whether
reasonable

.
"
  
<EOS>
He
sat
down
:
but
he
did
not

.
<EOS>
I
had

some

:
I

,
because
I

.
<EOS>
Now
,

,
I
considered

well
to

flow
as

.
<EOS>
If

annoyed
him
,
so
much
the
better
.
<EOS>
So
I
gave
way
and
cried
heartily
.
  
<EOS>
Soon
I
heard
him
earnestly

me
to
be

.
<EOS>
I
said
I
could
not
while
he
was
in
such

.
  
<EOS>
"
But
I
am
not

,
Jane
:
I

;
and
you
had
steeled

,
I
could
not

.
<EOS>
Hush
,
now
,
and

.
"
  
<EOS>
His

announced
that
he

;
so
I
,

.
<EOS>
Now

made

,
but
I
would
not

.
<EOS>
Then

would
draw
me
to
him
:
no
.
  
<EOS>
"
Jane
!
<EOS>
Jane
!
"
<EOS>
he

,

;
"
you

<EOS>

,

?
<EOS>

"
  
<EOS>
These

:

<EOS>

?
<EOS>
I

;

<EOS>
"

_

"

"

<EOS>

"
  
<EOS>
"

,

!
<EOS>
What

<EOS>

<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"

<EOS>
one

<EOS>
:

<EOS>
"

!
<EOS>
If

,

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Mr.
Rochester
,

.
<EOS>
"
  
"
For

,

?
<EOS>

,

"
  
"

<EOS>

:

<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Of

I

<EOS>
I
pass

.
<EOS>
You

.
<EOS>
As

:
<EOS>

:

.
<EOS>
You

Rochester

.
<EOS>
I

.
<EOS>
You

a

in

:

.
<EOS>
There

,

.
<EOS>
Never

.
<EOS>
Why

?
<EOS>
Jane
,

,

.
"
  
<EOS>
His

:
his
large

;

:
<EOS>
still

.
  
<EOS>
"
Sir
,
your
wife
is
living
:
that

a

.
<EOS>
If

,

:
to

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Jane
,
I
am

<EOS>
you

:
I

;

.
<EOS>

,

,

,
and
 
beware

"
  
<EOS>
He

,

:
the

was
forsaking
his

,

;

was

on

.
<EOS>
To

thus

,
by

,

:
to

out

.
<EOS>
I
did
what

do
instinctively
when

are
driven
to

looked
for
aid
to

higher
than
man
:
the

"
God

!
"
<EOS>
burst

.
  
<EOS>
"
I
am
a
fool
!
"
cried

Rochester
suddenly
.
<EOS>
"
I
keep
telling
her
I

,
and
do

.
<EOS>
I
forget
she
knows
nothing
of

,

.
<EOS>
Oh

<EOS>
Just

,

that

,

.

?
"
  
<EOS>
"
Yes

"
  
"
I

.
<EOS>
Jane
,

:

<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I

.
"
  
"
And

<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
have

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Well
,
Jane
,
being
so
,
it
was
his
resolution
to
keep

together
;

could
not

:
all

should

,
Rowland
.
<EOS>
Yet

.
<EOS>
I

.
<EOS>
He

a

.
<EOS>
Mr.
Mason
,
a
West
India

,

.
<EOS>
He
was
certain

were
real
and

:
he
made

.
<EOS>
Mr.
Mason
,
he
found
,
had
a
son
and
daughter
;
and
he
learned

that
he
could
and

:
that
sufficed
.
<EOS>
When

left

,
I
was

,
to
espouse
a
bride
already

.
<EOS>
My

said
nothing
about
her
money
;
but
he
told

Miss
Mason
was
the
boast
of
Spanish

for

:
and

.
<EOS>
I

a
fine

,

:

,

.
<EOS>
Her

wished

because

;
and

.
<EOS>
They

,

.
<EOS>
I
seldom
saw

alone
,
and
had
very

with

.
<EOS>
She
flattered
me
,
and
lavishly
displayed
for
my

her

and

.
<EOS>
All

her

.
<EOS>
I
was

,

:
<EOS>
my
senses
were
excited
;
and
being
ignorant
,
raw
,
and

,
I
thought
I
loved
her
.
<EOS>
There
is
no

so

that
the

,

,

,

of
youth
,

not

.
<EOS>
Her

encouraged
me
;
competitors

me
;
she
allured
me
:
<EOS>
a
marriage
was
achieved
almost
before
I
knew
where
I
was
.
<EOS>
Oh
,
I
have
no

for
myself
when
I
think
of
that

!
 
<EOS>
an
agony
of
inward
contempt
masters
me
.
<EOS>
I
never
loved
,
I
never

,
I
did

her
.
<EOS>
I
was
not

of

one

:
I
had
marked

,

,

,

or

<EOS>
and
,
I
married

:
 
<EOS>
gross
,

,

I

!
<EOS>
With
less
sin
I
might
have
 
But
let
me
remember

am

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
My
bride
's
mother
I

:
<EOS>
I

was

.
<EOS>
The

over
<EOS>
,
I
learned
my

;
she
was
only

,

.
<EOS>
There

,
too
 
a

.
<EOS>
The

,

seen
(

can

,

,

in

,

)
,

probably

one

.
<EOS>
My

my

Rowland
knew

;
but
they
thought
only
of
the
thirty
thousand
pounds
,
and
joined
in
the

against
me
.
"
  
<EOS>
"
These
were
vile

;
but
except
for
the
treachery
of

,
I
should
have
made

no
subject
of

to
my
wife
,
even
when
I
found
her

wholly

to

,
her

obnoxious
to
me
,
her
cast
of
mind
common
,
low
,
narrow
,
and
singularly
incapable
of
being
led
to
anything
higher
,
expanded
to
anything
larger
 
when
I
found
that
I
could
not
pass
a
single
evening
,
nor
even
a
single
hour
of
the
day
with
her
in
comfort
;
that

conversation
could
not
be
sustained
between
us
,
because
whatever
topic
I
started
,
immediately
received
from
her
a
turn
at
once
coarse
and
trite
,
perverse
and
imbecile
 
when
I
perceived
that
I
should
never
have
a
quiet
or
settled
household
,
because
no
servant
would
bear
the
continued
outbreaks
of
her
violent
and
unreasonable
temper
,
or
the
vexations
of
her
absurd
,
contradictory
,
exacting
orders
 
<EOS>
even
then
I
restrained
myself
:
<EOS>
I
eschewed
upbraiding
,
I
curtailed
remonstrance
;
I
tried
to
devour
my
repentance
and
disgust
in
secret
;
I
repressed
the
deep
antipathy
I
felt
.
  
<EOS>
"
Jane
,
I
will
not
trouble
you
with
abominable
details
:
some
strong
words
shall
express
what
I
have
to
say
.
<EOS>
I
lived
with
that
woman
upstairs
four
years
,
and
before
that
time
she
had
tried
me
indeed
:
her
character
ripened
and
developed
with
frightful
rapidity
;
her
vices
sprang
up
fast
and
rank
:
<EOS>
they
were
so
strong
,
only
cruelty
could
check
them
,
and
I
would
not
use
cruelty
.
<EOS>
What
a
pigmy
intellect
she
had
,
and
what
giant
propensities
!
<EOS>
How
fearful
were
the
curses
those
propensities
entailed
on
me
!
<EOS>
Bertha
Mason
,
the
true
daughter
of
an
infamous
mother
,
dragged

through

and

<EOS>
"

<EOS>

;
oftener
in
Paris
;
occasionally
in
Rome
,

,
and

.
<EOS>
Provided

and

of
an
old
name
,
I
could
choose

own

:
no

.
<EOS>

<EOS>
I

.
<EOS>
Sometimes

<EOS>

<EOS>
I

for

.
<EOS>
I

dissipation

.
<EOS>

"

Varens
 
another

.
<EOS>

<EOS>
Giacinta

<EOS>

have
for
the
first

found
what
I

truly

<EOS>
I

.
<EOS>
You

my

<EOS>
my
better
self
 
<EOS>
my
good

.
<EOS>
I

.
<EOS>
I

good
,

,
<EOS>
lovely
:
a
fervent
<EOS>
,

;
it

.
  
<EOS>
"

.
<EOS>

I

already

a

empty

:

but
<EOS>
a

.
<EOS>
I

;
but

a

that
exists

.
<EOS>
I
feared
early
instilled

:
I

.
<EOS>
This

:
