shown

,

_

,

.
<EOS>

.
<EOS>
Jane
 
give

.
"
  
<EOS>

.
  
<EOS>
"

,
Jane
?
"
  
<EOS>
I

:

.
<EOS>

<EOS>
Not

"

!
"

"

,

<EOS>

"

<EOS>
"
Jane
!
"
<EOS>

<EOS>

"
     
<EOS>

written
on
her
disk
.
<EOS>
She
broke
forth
as
never
moon
yet
burst
from
cloud
:
a
hand
first
penetrated
the
sable
folds
and
waved
them
away
;
then
,
not
a
moon
,
but
a
white
human
form
shone
in
the
azure
,
inclining
a
glorious
brow
earthward
.
<EOS>
It
gazed
and
gazed
on
me
.
<EOS>
It
spoke
to
my
spirit
:
<EOS>
immeasurably
distant
was
the
tone
,
yet
so
near
,
it
whispered
in
my
heart
    
"
My
daughter
,
flee
temptation
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Mother
,
I
will
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
So
I
answered
after
I
had
waked
from
the
trance
-
like
dream
.
<EOS>
It
was
yet
night
,
but
July
nights
are
short
:
soon
after
midnight
,
dawn
comes
.
<EOS>
"
It
can
not
be
too
early
to
commence
the
task
I
have
to
fulfil
,
"
thought
I.
I
rose
:
<EOS>
I
was
dressed
;
for
I
had
taken
off
nothing
but
my
shoes
.
<EOS>
I
knew
where
to
find
in
my
drawers
some
linen
,
a
locket
,
a
ring
.
<EOS>
In
seeking
these
articles
,
I
encountered
the
beads
of
a
pearl
necklace
Mr.
Rochester
had
forced
me
to
accept
a
few
days
ago
.
<EOS>
I
left
that
;
it
was
not
mine
:
<EOS>
it
was
the
visionary
bride
's
who
had
melted
in
air
.
<EOS>
The
other
articles
I
made
up
in
a
parcel
;
my
purse
,
containing
twenty
shillings
(
it
was
all
I
had
)
,
I
put
in
my
pocket
:
<EOS>
I
tied
on
my
straw
bonnet
,
pinned
my
shawl
,
took
the
parcel
and
my
slippers
,
which
I
would
not
put
on
yet
,
and
stole
from
my
room
.
  
<EOS>
"
Farewell
,
kind
Mrs.
Fairfax
!
<EOS>
"
I
whispered
,
as
I
glided
past
her
door
.
<EOS>
"
Farewell
,
my
darling
Adele
!
<EOS>
"
I
said
,
as
I
glanced
towards
the
nursery
.
<EOS>
No
thought
could
be
admitted
of
entering
to
embrace
her
.
<EOS>
I
had
to
deceive
a
fine
ear
:
<EOS>
for
aught
I
knew
it
might
now
be
listening
.
  
<EOS>
I
would
have
got
past
Mr.
Rochester
's
chamber
without
a
pause
;
but
my
heart
momentarily
stopping
its
beat
at
that
threshold
,
my
foot
was
forced
to
stop
also
.
<EOS>
No
sleep
was
there
:
the
inmate
was
walking
restlessly
from
wall
to
wall
;
and
again
and
again
he
sighed
while
I
listened
.
<EOS>
There
was
a
heaven
 
<EOS>
a
temporary
heaven
 
in
this
room
for
me
<EOS>
,
if
I
chose
:
I
had
but
to
go
in
and
to
say
    
"
Mr.
Rochester
,
I
will
love
you
and
live
with
you
through
life
till
death
,
"
and
a
fount
of
rapture
would
spring
to
my
lips
.
<EOS>
I
thought
of
this
.
  
<EOS>
That
kind
master
,
who
could
not
sleep
now
,
was
waiting
with
impatience
for
day
.
<EOS>
He
would
send
for
me
in
the
morning
;
I
should
be
gone
.
<EOS>
He
would
have
me
sought
for
:
vainly
.
<EOS>
He
would
feel
himself
forsaken
;
his
love
rejected
:
he
would
suffer
;
perhaps
grow
desperate
.
<EOS>
I
thought
of
this
too
.
<EOS>
My
hand
moved
towards
the
lock
:
I
caught
it
back
,
and
glided
on
.
  
<EOS>
Drearily
I
wound
my
way
downstairs
<EOS>
:
I
knew
what
I
had
to
do
,
and
I
did
it
mechanically
.
<EOS>
I
sought
the
key
of
the
side
-
door
in
the
kitchen
;
I
sought
,
too
,
a
phial
of
oil
and
a
feather
;
I
oiled
the
key
and
the
lock
.
<EOS>
I
got
some
water
<EOS>
,
I
got
some
bread
:
for
perhaps
I
should
have
to
walk
far
;
and
my
strength
,
sorely
shaken
of
late
,
must
not
break
down
.
<EOS>
All
this
I
did
without
one
sound
.
<EOS>
I
opened
the
door
,
passed
out
,
shut
it
softly
.
<EOS>
Dim
dawn
glimmered
in
the
yard
.
<EOS>
The
great
gates
were
closed
and
locked
;
but
a
wicket
in
one
of
them
was
only
latched
.
<EOS>
Through
that
I
departed
:
it
,
too
,
I
shut
;
and
now
I
was
out
of
Thornfield
.
  
<EOS>
A
mile
off
,
beyond
the
fields
,
lay
a
road
which
stretched
in
the
contrary
direction
to
Millcote
;
a
road
I
had
never
travelled
,
but
often
noticed
,
and
wondered
where
it
led
:
thither
I
bent
my
steps
.
<EOS>
No
reflection
was
to
be
allowed
now
:
not
one
glance
was
to
be
cast
back
;
not
even
one
forward
.
<EOS>
Not
one
thought
was
to
be
given
either
to
the
past
or
the
future
.
<EOS>
The
first
was
a
page
so
heavenly
sweet
 
<EOS>
so
deadly
sad
 
<EOS>
that
to
read
one
line
of
it
would
dissolve
my
courage
and
break
down
my
energy
.
<EOS>
The
last
was
an
awful
blank
:
something
like
the
world
when
the
deluge
was
gone
by
.
  
<EOS>
I
skirted
fields
,
and
hedges
,
and
lanes
till
after
sunrise
.
<EOS>
I
believe
it
was
a
lovely
summer
morning
:
<EOS>
I
know
my
shoes
,
which
I
had
put
on
when
I
left
the
house
,
were
soon
wet
with
dew
.
<EOS>
But
I
looked
neither
to
rising
sun
,
nor
smiling
sky
,
nor
wakening
nature
.
<EOS>
He
who
is
taken
out
to
pass
through
a
fair
scene
to
the
scaffold
,
thinks
not
of
the
flowers
that
smile
on
his
road
,
but
of
the
block
and
axe
-
edge
;
of
the
disseverment
of
bone
and
vein
;
of
the
grave
gaping
at
the
end
:
<EOS>
and
I
thought
of
drear
flight
and
homeless
wandering
 
<EOS>
and
oh
!
<EOS>
with
agony
I
thought
of
what
I
left
.
<EOS>
I
could
not
help
it
.
<EOS>
I
thought
of
him
now
 
in
his
room
 
watching
the
sunrise
;
hoping
I
should
soon
come
to
say
I
would
stay
with
him
and
be
his
.
<EOS>
I
longed
to
be
his
;
I
panted
to
return
:
it
was
not
too
late
;
I
could
yet
spare
him
the
bitter
pang
of
bereavement
.
<EOS>
As
yet
my
flight
,
I
was
sure
,
was
undiscovered
.
<EOS>
I
could
go
back
and
be
his
comforter
 
<EOS>
his
pride
;
his
redeemer
from
misery
,
perhaps
from
ruin
.
<EOS>
Oh
,
that
fear
of
his
self
-
abandonment
 
far
worse
than
my
abandonment
 
<EOS>
how
it
goaded
me
!
<EOS>
It
was
a
barbed
arrow
-
head
in
my
breast
;
it
tore
me
when
I
tried
to
extract
it
;
it
sickened
me
when
remembrance
thrust
it
farther
in
.
<EOS>
Birds
began
singing
in
brake
and
copse
:
birds
were
faithful
to
their
mates
;
birds
were
emblems
of
love
.
<EOS>
What
was
I
?
<EOS>
In
the
midst
of
my
pain
of
heart
and
frantic
effort
of
principle
,
I
abhorred
myself
.
<EOS>
I
had
no
solace
from
self
-
approbation
:
none
even
from
self
-
respect
.
<EOS>
I
had
injured
 
wounded
 
left
my
master
.
<EOS>
I
was
hateful
in
my
own
eyes
.
<EOS>
Still
I
could
not
turn
,
nor
retrace
one
step
.
<EOS>
God
must
have
led
me
on
.
<EOS>
As
to
my
own
will
or
conscience
,
impassioned
grief
had
trampled
one
and
stifled
the
other
.
<EOS>
I
was
weeping
wildly
as
I
walked
along
my
solitary
way
:
fast
,
fast
I
went
like
one
delirious
.
<EOS>
A
weakness
,
beginning
inwardly
,
extending
to
the
limbs
,
seized
me
,
and
I
fell
:
<EOS>
I
lay
on
the
ground
some
minutes
,
pressing
my
face
to
the
wet
turf
.
<EOS>
I
had
some
fear
 
or
hope
 
that
here
I
should
die
:
but
I
was
soon
up
;
crawling
forwards
on
my
hands
and
knees
,
and
then
again
raised
to
my
feet
 
as
eager
and
as
determined
as
ever
to
reach
the
road
.
  
<EOS>
When
I
got
there
,
I
was
forced
to
sit
to
rest
me
under
the
hedge
;
and
while
I
sat
,
I
heard
wheels
,
and
saw
a
coach
come
on
.
<EOS>
I
stood
up
and
lifted
my
hand
;
it
stopped
.
<EOS>
I
asked
where
it
was
going
:
the
driver
named
a
place
a
long
way
off
,
and
where
I
was
sure
Mr.
Rochester
had
no
connections
.
<EOS>
I
asked
for
what
sum
he
would
take
me
there
;
he
said
thirty
shillings
;
I
answered
I
had
but
twenty
;
well
,
he
would
try
to
make
it
do
.
<EOS>
He
further
gave
me
leave
to
get
into
the
inside
,
as
the
vehicle
was
empty
:
I
entered
,
was
shut
in
,
and
it
rolled
on
its
way
.
  
<EOS>
Gentle
reader
,
may
you
never
feel
what
I
then
felt
!
<EOS>
May
your
eyes
never
shed
such
stormy
,
scalding
,
heart
-
wrung
tears
as
poured
from
mine
.
<EOS>
May
you
never
appeal
to
Heaven
in
prayers
so
hopeless
and
so
agonised
as
in
that
hour
left
my
lips
;
for
never
may
you
,
like
me
,
dread
to
be
the
instrument
of
evil
to
what
you
wholly
love
.
    
<EOS>
Two
days
are
passed
.
<EOS>
It
is
a
summer
evening
;
the
coachman
has
set
me
down
at
a
place
called
Whitcross
;
he
could
take
me
no
farther
for
the
sum
I
had
given
,
and
I
was
not
possessed
of
another
shilling
in
the
world
.
<EOS>
The
coach
is
a
mile
off
by
this
time
;
I
am
alone
.
<EOS>
At
this
moment
I
discover
that
I
forgot
to
take
my
parcel
out
of
the
pocket
of
the
coach
,
where
I
had
placed
it
for
safety
;
there
it
remains
,
there
it
must
remain
;
and
now
,
I
am
absolutely
destitute
.
  
<EOS>
Whitcross
is
no
town
,
nor
even
a
hamlet
;
it
is
but
a
stone
pillar
set
up
where
four
roads
meet
:
whitewashed
,
I
suppose
,
to
be
more
obvious
at
a
distance
and
in
darkness
.
<EOS>
Four
arms
spring
from
its
summit
:
the
nearest
town
to
which
these
point
is
,
according
to
the
inscription
,
distant
ten
miles
;
the
farthest
,
above
twenty
.
<EOS>
From
the
well
-
known
names
of
these
towns
I
learn
in
what
county
I
have
lighted
;
a
north
-
midland
shire
,
dusk
with
moorland
,
ridged
with
mountain
:
this
I
see
.
<EOS>
There
are
great
moors
behind
and
on
each
hand
of
me
;
there
are
waves
of
mountains
far
beyond
that
deep
valley
at
my
feet
.
<EOS>
The
population
here
must
be
thin
,
and
I
see
no
passengers
on
these
roads
:
they
stretch
out
east
,
west
,
north
,
and
south
 
white
,
broad
,
lonely
;
they
are
all
cut
in
the
moor
,
and
the
heather
grows
deep
and
wild
to
their
very
verge
.
<EOS>
Yet
a
chance
traveller
might
pass
by
;
and
I
wish
no
eye
to
see
me
now
:
strangers
would
wonder
what
I
am
doing
,
lingering
here
at
the
sign
-
post
,
evidently
objectless
and
lost
.
<EOS>
I
might
be
questioned
:
I
could
give
no
answer
but
what
would
sound
incredible
and
excite
suspicion
.
<EOS>
Not
a
tie
holds
me
to
human
society
at
this
moment
 
not
a
charm
or
hope
calls
me
where
my
fellow
-
creatures
are
 
none
that
saw
me
would
have
a
kind
thought
or
a
good
wish
for
me
.
<EOS>
I
have
no
relative
but
the
universal
mother
,
Nature
:
<EOS>
I
will
seek
her
breast
and
ask
repose
.
  
<EOS>
I
struck
straight
into
the
heath
;
I
held
on
to
a
hollow
<EOS>
I
saw
deeply
furrowing
the
brown
moorside
;
I
waded
knee
-
deep
in
its
dark
growth
;
I
turned
with
its
turnings
,
and
finding
a
moss
-
blackened
granite
crag
in
a
hidden
angle
,
I
sat
down
under
it
.
<EOS>
High
banks
of
moor
were
about
me
;
the
crag
protected
my
head
:
the
sky
was
over
that
.
  
<EOS>
Some
time
passed
before
I
felt
tranquil
even
here
:
I
had
a
vague
dread
that
wild
cattle
might
be
near
,
or
that
some
sportsman
or
poacher
might
discover
me
.
<EOS>
If
a
gust
of
wind
swept
the
waste
,
I
looked
up
,
fearing
it
was
the
rush
of
a
bull
;
if
a
plover
whistled
,
I
imagined
it
a
man
.
<EOS>
Finding
my
apprehensions
unfounded
,
however
,
and
calmed
by
the
deep
silence
that
reigned
as
evening
declined
at
nightfall
,
I
took
confidence
.
<EOS>
As
yet
I
had
not
thought
;
I
had
only
listened
,
watched
,
dreaded
;
now
I
regained
the
faculty
of
reflection
.
  
<EOS>
What
was
I
to
do
?
<EOS>
Where
to
go
?
<EOS>
Oh
,
intolerable
questions
,
when
I
could
do
nothing
and
go
nowhere
!
 
<EOS>
when
a
long
way
must
yet
be
measured
by
my
weary
,
trembling
limbs
before
I
could
reach
human
habitation
 
when
cold
charity
must
be
entreated
before
I
could
get
a
lodging
:
reluctant
sympathy
importuned
,
<EOS>
almost
certain
repulse
incurred
,
before
my
tale
could
be
listened
to
,
or
one
of
my
wants
relieved
!
  
<EOS>
I
touched
the
heath
:
it
was
dry
,
and
yet
warm
with
the
heat
of
the
summer
day
.
<EOS>
I
looked
at
the
sky
;
it
was
pure
:
a
kindly
star
twinkled
just
above
the
chasm
ridge
.
<EOS>
The
dew
fell
,
but
with
propitious
softness
;
no
breeze
whispered
.
<EOS>
Nature
seemed
to
me
benign
and
good
;
I
thought
she
loved
me
,
outcast
as
I
was
;
and
I
,
who
from
man
could
anticipate
only
mistrust
,
rejection
,
insult
,
clung
to
her
with
filial
fondness
.
<EOS>
To
-
night
,
at
least
,
I
would
be
her
guest
,
as
I
was
her
child
:
my
mother
would
lodge
me
without
money
and
without
price
.
<EOS>
I
had
one
morsel
of
bread
yet
:
the
remnant
of
a
roll
I
had
bought
in
a
town
we
passed
through
at
noon
with
a
stray
penny
 
<EOS>
my
last
coin
.
<EOS>
I
saw
ripe
bilberries
gleaming
here
and
there
,
like
jet

in
the

:
I
gathered
a

and

with

.
<EOS>
My

,
sharp

,
was
,
if

,

's

.
<EOS>
I
said

at

,
and
then

.
  
<EOS>
{
I
said
my
evening
prayers
:
p311.jpg
}
  
<EOS>
Beside
the
crag
the

was
very

:
when
I
lay
down
my

were
buried
in

;
rising

,

.
<EOS>
I

,

spread

for

;

.
<EOS>
Thus

,

was
not
,
at
least

.
  
<EOS>
My

been
blissful
enough
,
only

.
<EOS>
It
plained
of
its
gaping

,

inward

,

riven

.
<EOS>
It
trembled
for
Mr.
Rochester
and
his
doom
;
it

;

;
and

,

still

in

.
  
<EOS>
Worn

this

,

to

.
<EOS>
Night
was
come
,
and
her

were
risen
:
a
safe
,
still

:
too
serene
for
the

.
<EOS>
We

everywhere
;
but

;

,

,
that

.
<EOS>
I

.
<EOS>
Looking

.
<EOS>

<EOS>
I

might

.
<EOS>
Sure

of

.
<EOS>
Mr.

;

,

<EOS>
I

ere

.
  
<EOS>
But

,

came

.
<EOS>
Long

,

<EOS>
What

!
<EOS>

!
<EOS>
Everywhere

.
<EOS>
I

.
<EOS>
I

;

.
<EOS>
I

,

,

.

:

.

;

<EOS>
Hopeless

future
<EOS>
,

Whitcross

,

,

.
<EOS>
By

I
will

.
<EOS>
I

,

,

,

.

.
<EOS>
Human

.
<EOS>
I
must

:

.
  
<EOS>
About

<EOS>

.
<EOS>
At

its
one

.
<EOS>
I

.
<EOS>
With

could

,

.
<EOS>
The

.
<EOS>
I

to

.
<EOS>
Had
I
nothing
about

I
could

?
<EOS>
I
considered
.
<EOS>
I
had

;
I

.
<EOS>
I

.
<EOS>
I

these
articles
would

:
probably

;
but

.
  
<EOS>
I

shop
:
a

.
<EOS>
Seeing

,

<EOS>
How

?
<EOS>
I
was

:

would

.
<EOS>
I
dared

the

,

:

,

.
<EOS>
I

.
<EOS>
Disappointed
in

expectation
of

,

.
<EOS>
She

;

.
<EOS>
I

;

.
<EOS>
Soon

"

?
<EOS>
"
  
"

.
<EOS>
Quite

.
<EOS>
"

.
<EOS>
I

.
<EOS>
I

.
<EOS>

.
<EOS>
I

.
<EOS>
What
?
<EOS>
I

.
<EOS>
Where
?
  
<EOS>
"
Did

?
<EOS>
"
  
"
Nay
;

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"

?
<EOS>

<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"

"
  
"

?
"
  
"
I

,
"

.
<EOS>
"

,

.
<EOS>
Poor

.

"

She

:
<EOS>

?

.

.
  
<EOS>

,

Much

<EOS>
Ere

,

,

something
 
<EOS>
a

,

.
<EOS>
A

,

,

.

I

.
<EOS>
What

to

?
<EOS>
In

?
<EOS>
Yet

.
<EOS>
A

.
<EOS>
In

<EOS>
I

?
  
<EOS>
"
No
,
"

;
"

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Can

?
<EOS>
"

.
<EOS>
"

,

.
<EOS>

:

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
But

:
<EOS>

,

"

,
"

;

.
  
<EOS>
I

,

,

.
<EOS>
I

I

,

a

.
<EOS>
Solitude
would

no
solitude
 
rest
no
rest
 
while
the

,

,
thus

and

in

.
  
<EOS>
I
drew
near

;

,

,
and

:

by
the

no

no

.
<EOS>
Meantime
,

,
while
I

.
<EOS>
In

,
I
saw

before

:
I

.
<EOS>
Near
the

,
and

,

,
which
I
had

<EOS>
was
the

.
<EOS>
I

that
strangers
who

where

,
and

,

.
<EOS>
It

's

help

.
<EOS>
I

.
<EOS>
Renewing

,
and

,

.
<EOS>
I

the

into
it
.
<EOS>
Young
woman
,
rise
,
and
pass
before

into

.
<EOS>
"
  
{
Hush
,
Hannah
;
I
have
a
word
to

to
the
woman
:
p323.jpg
}

.
<EOS>
Presently

stood

that
clean

on

;

<EOS>

,

,

.
  
<EOS>
"
St.
John
,
who

?
<EOS>
"

.
  
<EOS>
"
I
can
not

:
<EOS>
I

at
the

,
"

.
  
<EOS>
"
She

"

.
  
<EOS>
"
As

,
"

.
<EOS>
"
She

:

.
"
  
<EOS>
And

I

.
<EOS>
I
still

<EOS>
"

.
<EOS>

.
<EOS>

<EOS>
How

,

<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
A

!
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"

<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"

,

.
<EOS>
Hannah
,

?
<EOS>
Give

<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
Diana
(
I

"

"

"

<EOS>

"

"

"

<EOS>
"

I

"

.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>

.

<EOS>

"

,

<EOS>

<EOS>
Diana

<EOS>

<EOS>

"

my

.
<EOS>
"

.
<EOS>
Very

I

.
<EOS>
A

<EOS>

.
<EOS>
Ere

;

.
<EOS>
I

.
    
<EOS>
The

.
<EOS>
I

;

,

.
<EOS>
I

in

.
<EOS>
To

I
seemed

have

;

;
and

.
<EOS>
I

,

.
<EOS>
I
observed

:
I

;

;

.
<EOS>
Hannah
,

,

.
<EOS>
Her

.
<EOS>
I

:

;

.
<EOS>

.
<EOS>

<EOS>
"
It

<EOS>

.
<EOS>
"
  
"

.
<EOS>
I

?

"

<EOS>
,

poor

<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"

<EOS>

;

<EOS>

.

,

.
<EOS>

needless

:
nature
,

,

,

.
<EOS>
He
said

,

.
<EOS>

.
<EOS>
He

.
<EOS>
These

,

,

"
Rather

;

,

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Far

,
"

.
<EOS>
"
To

,
St.

,

to

poor

.
<EOS>
I
wish

may

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
That

,
"

.
<EOS>
"
You

.

.
"
<EOS>

;

"
She

,

.
"
  
<EOS>
"
She
is

,
St.

.
"
  
<EOS>
"
Ill

,

.
<EOS>
The

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
On

third

I
was
better
;
on
the
fourth
,
I
could

,

,

<EOS>
Hannah
had
brought

,
about
,

,
the

.
<EOS>
I
had

:

good
 
<EOS>
void
of

.
<EOS>
When

,
I

strong

:
ere

of

.
<EOS>
I
wished
to
rise
;
but
what

I
put

?
<EOS>
Only
my
damp
and

apparel
;
in

had

.
<EOS>
I
felt

to

.
<EOS>
I
was
spared
the
humiliation
.
  
<EOS>
On
a

were
all
my
own

,
clean
and
dry
.
<EOS>
My
black

hung
against

.
<EOS>
The

of
the
bog
were
removed
from

;

by

:
it
was
quite

.
<EOS>
My
very
shoes
and
stockings
were
purified
and
rendered
presentable
.
<EOS>
There
were
the
means
of
washing
in
the
room
,
and
a
comb
and
brush
to
smooth

.
<EOS>
After

,
and

every

,
I
succeeded
in

.
<EOS>
My

on

;
for
I
was
much

,
but
I
covered
deficiencies
with
a

,
and
once
more
,
clean
and
respectable
looking
 
no
speck
of
the
dirt
,
no
trace
of
the
disorder
I
so
hated
,
and
which
seemed
so
to
degrade
me
,
left
 
<EOS>
I
crept
down
a
stone

with
the
aid
of
the
banisters
,
to
a
narrow
low
passage
,
and
found
my
way
presently
to
the
kitchen
.
  
<EOS>
It
was
full
of
the
fragrance
of
new
bread
and
the
warmth
of
a
generous
fire
.
<EOS>
Hannah
was
baking
.
<EOS>
Prejudices
,
it
is
well
known
,
are
most
difficult
to
eradicate
from
the
heart
whose
soil
has
never
been
loosened
or
fertilised
by
education
:
they
grow
there
,
firm
as
weeds
among
stones
.
<EOS>
Hannah
had
been
cold
and
stiff
,
indeed
,
at
the
first
:
latterly
she
had
begun
to
relent
a
little
;
and
when
she
saw
me
come
in
tidy
and
well
-
dressed
,
she
even
smiled
.
  
<EOS>
"
What
,
you
have
got
up
!
"
<EOS>
she
said
.
<EOS>
"
You
are
better
,
then
.
<EOS>
You
may
sit
you
down
in
my
chair
on
the
hearthstone
,
if
you
will
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
She
pointed
to
the
rocking
-
chair
:
<EOS>
I
took
it
.
<EOS>
She
bustled
about
,
examining
me
every
now
<EOS>
and
then
with
the
corner
of
her
eye
.
<EOS>
Turning
to
me
,
as
she
took
some

from
the

,
she
asked
bluntly
    
"
Did
you
ever
go
a
-
begging
afore
<EOS>
you
came
here
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
I
was
indignant
for
a

;
but
remembering
that
anger
was
out
of
the
question
,
and
that
I
had
indeed
appeared
as
a

to

,
I
answered
quietly
,
but
still
not
without
a
certain

<EOS>
Mr.

John
 
sitting

was

<EOS>
He

<EOS>
It

.
<EOS>
He

,

.
<EOS>
His

,

<EOS>
This

,

,

?
<EOS>
Yet

whom
it
describes
scarcely
impressed
one
with
the
idea
of
a
gentle
,
a
yielding
,
an
impressible
,
or
even
of
a
placid
nature
.
<EOS>
Quiescent
as
he
now
sat
,
there
was
something
about
his
nostril
,
his
mouth
,
his
brow
,
which
,
to
my
perceptions
,
indicated
elements
within
either
restless
,
or
hard
,
or
eager
.
<EOS>
He
did
not
speak
to
me
one
word
,
nor
even
direct
to
me
one
glance
,
till
his
sisters
returned
.
<EOS>
Diana
,
as
she
passed
in
and
out
,
in
the
course
of
preparing
tea
,
brought
me
a
little
cake
,
baked
on
the
top
of
the
oven
.
  
<EOS>
"
Eat
that
<EOS>
now
,
"
she
said
:
"
you
must
be
hungry
.
<EOS>
Hannah
says
you
have
had
nothing
but
some
gruel
since
breakfast
.
<EOS>
"
  
I
did
not
refuse
it
,
for
my
appetite
was
awakened
and
keen
.
<EOS>
Mr.
Rivers
now
closed
his
book
,
approached
the
table
,
and
,
as
he
took
a
seat
,
fixed
his
blue
pictorial
-

full
on

.
<EOS>
There
was
an
unceremonious
directness
,
a

,
decided

in
his

now
,
which
told
that
intention
,
and
not
diffidence
,
had
hitherto
kept
it
averted
from
the

.
  
<EOS>
"
You
are
very
hungry
,
"
he
said
.
  
<EOS>
"
I
am
,
sir
.
<EOS>
"
It
is
my
way
 
it
always
was
my
way
,
by
instinct
 
ever
to
meet
the
brief
with
brevity
,
the
direct
with
plainness
.
  
<EOS>
"
It
is
well
for
you
that
a
low

has
forced

to

for
the
last
three
days
:
there
would
have
been
danger
in
yielding
to
the

of
your
appetite
at
first
.
<EOS>
Now
you
may
eat
,
though
still

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
trust
I
shall
not
eat
long
at
your
expense
,
sir
,
"
was
my
very
clumsily-
contrived
,
unpolished
answer
.
  
<EOS>
"
No
,
"
he
said
coolly
:
"

of
your
friends
,
we

,

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
That
,
I
must
plainly

,
is
out
of
my
power
to
do
;
being
absolutely
without
home
and
friends
.
"
  
<EOS>
The
three
looked
at

,
but

;
I
felt
there
was
no

in

:
there

more
of

.
<EOS>
I
speak
particularly
of

.
<EOS>
St.
John
's

,
though
clear

in

,

were

.
<EOS>
He

use

rather

to

:
the
which
combination
of

was

.
  
<EOS>
"
Do
you
mean

,
"

,
"

?
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
do
.
<EOS>
Not

to
any

:
not
a
claim
<EOS>
do

possess
to

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
A
most

at

age
!
"
  
<EOS>
Here

saw
his

to

,

.
<EOS>
I

he
sought

:
his

.
  
<EOS>
"
You
have
never

?
<EOS>
You

?
"
  
<EOS>
Diana

.
<EOS>
"
Why
,
she
ca

,

,
"

.
  
<EOS>
"
I

:
<EOS>
but

.
<EOS>
No
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
I

;
for

.
<EOS>
They
all
saw
the

.
<EOS>
Diana
and

relieved

by

elsewhere

;

.
  
<EOS>
"
Where

?
<EOS>
"

.
  
<EOS>
"
You

,

"

;

<EOS>
"
The

,

"

<EOS>
"

<EOS>
"

,
"

.
<EOS>
"

"
  
<EOS>
"
I

,

<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I

;

.
<EOS>
First

,

_

"
  
<EOS>
I

now

.
<EOS>
I

;

<EOS>
"
Mr.
Rivers
<EOS>
,
"

,

,

,
"

<EOS>
the

man
can
do

;
you

,

,

.
<EOS>
This

,

,

.
<EOS>
I

my

.
  
<EOS>
"
I

,

.
<EOS>
My

.
<EOS>
I

;

.
<EOS>
I

Lowood

Asylum
,
  
<EOS>
shire
:
<EOS>
you

,

Rivers
?
 
<EOS>
the

Robert
Brocklehurst

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
have
heard
of

,

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
left

.
<EOS>
I
obtained

,

.
<EOS>
This

.
<EOS>
The

I
can

:
it

<EOS>
No

.
<EOS>
Miserable
I

,

;

a

I

was

.
<EOS>
I
observed

,

:

,

<EOS>
To

<EOS>
I

<EOS>
I

<EOS>

"
  
"

"

<EOS>
I

but

:
<EOS>

.
<EOS>

<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
She

<EOS>
"

"

,

.
<EOS>
"

,

.
"
  
<EOS>
He

book

had

occupied
before
tea
.
<EOS>
I
soon
withdrew
,
for
I
had
talked
as
much
,
and
sat

long
,

my

.
    
<EOS>
The

knew
of
the

of
Moor
House
,
the
better
I

.
<EOS>
In

I
had
so
far

my
health
that
I
could
sit
up
all

,
and

sometimes
.
<EOS>
I
could
join
with
Diana
and
Mary
in
all
their
occupations
;
converse
with
them
as
much
as
they

,
and
aid

when
and
where

would
allow
me
.
<EOS>
There
was
a
reviving
pleasure
in
this
intercourse
,
of
a
kind
now
tasted
by
me
for
the
first
time
 
the
pleasure
arising
from
perfect
congeniality
of
tastes
,
sentiments
,
and
principles
.
  
<EOS>
I
liked
to
read
what
they
liked
to
read
:
what
they
enjoyed
,
delighted
me
;
what
they
approved
,
I
reverenced
.
<EOS>
They
loved
their
sequestered
home
.
<EOS>
I
,
too
,
in
the
grey
,
small
,
antique
structure
,
with
its
low
roof
,
its
latticed
casements
,
its
mouldering
walls
,
its
avenue
of
aged
firs
 
<EOS>
all
grown
aslant
under
the
stress
of
mountain
winds
;
its
garden
,
dark
with
yew
and
holly
 
and
where
no
flowers
but
of
the
hardiest
species
would
bloom
 
found
a
charm
both
potent
and
permanent
.
<EOS>
They
clung
to
the
purple
moors
behind
and
around
their
dwelling
 
to
the
hollow
vale
into
which
the
pebbly
bridle
-
path
leading
from
their
gate
descended
,
and
which
wound
between
fern
-
banks
first
,
and
then
amongst
a
few
of
the
wildest
little
pasture
-
fields
that
ever
bordered
a
wilderness
of
heath
,
or
gave
sustenance
to
a
flock
of
grey
moorland
sheep
,
with
their
little
mossy-
faced
lambs
:
 
<EOS>
they
clung
to
this
scene
,
I
say
,
with
a
perfect
enthusiasm
of
attachment
.
<EOS>
I
could
comprehend
the
feeling
,
and
share
both
its
strength
and
truth
.
<EOS>
I
saw
the
fascination
of
the
locality
.
<EOS>
I
felt
the
consecration
of
its
loneliness
:
my
eye
feasted
on
the
outline
of
swell
and
sweep
 
on
the
wild
colouring
communicated
to
ridge
and

by
moss
,
by
heath
-
bell
,
by
flower
-

turf
,
by
brilliant
bracken
,
and
mellow

.
<EOS>
These
details
were
just
to
me
<EOS>
what
they
were
to
them
 
so
many
pure
and
sweet
sources
of
pleasure
.
<EOS>
The
strong
blast
and
the
soft
breeze
;
the
rough
and
the
halcyon
day
;
the
hours
of
sunrise
and

;
the

and
the

,
developed
for

,
in
these
regions
,
the
same
attraction
as
for
them
 
<EOS>
wound
round
my
faculties
the
same

that
entranced
theirs
.
  
<EOS>
Indoors
we
agreed
equally
well
.
<EOS>
They
were
both
more
accomplished
and
better
read
than
I
was
;
but
with
eagerness
I
followed
in
the
path
of
knowledge
they
had
trodden
before
me
.
<EOS>
I
devoured
the
books
they
lent
me
:
then
it
was
full
satisfaction
to
discuss
with
them
in
the
evening
what
I
had
perused
during
the
day
.
<EOS>
Thought
fitted
thought
;
opinion
met
opinion
:
<EOS>
we
coincided
,
in
short
,
perfectly
.
  
<EOS>
If

our

there

a

and

,

Diana
.
<EOS>
Physically
,
she
far
excelled
me
:
<EOS>
she
was
handsome
;
she
was
vigorous
.
<EOS>
In
her
animal
spirits
there
was
an

of
life
and
certainty
of
flow
,
such
as
excited
my
wonder
,
while
it
baffled
my

.
<EOS>
I
could
talk
a
while
when
the
evening
commenced
,
but
the
first

of
vivacity
and

gone
,
I
was
fain

sit

at

,

and

to

and

,
while

sounded
thoroughly
the
topic
on
which
I
had
but

.
<EOS>
Diana
offered
to
teach
me
German
.
<EOS>
I
liked
to
learn
of
her
:
I
saw
the
part
of
instructress
pleased
and
suited
her
;
that
of
scholar
pleased
and
suited
me
no
less
.
<EOS>
Our
natures
dovetailed
:
mutual
affection
 
of
the
strongest
kind
 
was
the
result
.
<EOS>
They
discovered
I
could
draw
:
their
pencils
and
colour
-
boxes
were
immediately
at
my
service
.
<EOS>
My
skill
,
greater
in
this
one

than

,
surprised

.
<EOS>
Mary
would
sit
and
watch
me
by
the
hour

:
then
she
would
take
lessons
;
and
a
docile
,
intelligent
,
assiduous
pupil
she
made
.
<EOS>
Thus
occupied
,
and
mutually
entertained
,
days
passed
like
hours
,
and
weeks
like
days
.
  
<EOS>
As
to
Mr.
St
John
,
the
intimacy
which
had
arisen
so
naturally
and
rapidly
between
me
and
his
sisters
did
not
extend
to

.
<EOS>
One
reason
of
the
distance
yet
observed
between
us
was
,
that
he
was
comparatively
seldom
at
home
:
a
large

of
his
time
appeared
devoted
to
visiting
the
sick
and
poor
among
the
scattered

of
his

.
  
<EOS>
No
weather
seemed
to
hinder

in
these

:
rain
or
fair
,
he
would
,
when
his

of
morning

were

,
take
his
hat
,
and
,
followed
by
his
father
's
old
pointer
,
Carlo
,
go
out
on
his
mission
of
love
or
duty
 
<EOS>
I
scarcely
know
in
which
light
he
regarded
it
.
<EOS>
Sometimes
,
when
the
day
was
very

,
his
sisters
would
expostulate
.
<EOS>
He
would
then
say
,
with
a
peculiar

,
more
solemn
than

"
<EOS>
And
if
I
let

gust

wind
or
a

from
these
easy
tasks
,
what
preparation
would
such
sloth
be
for
the
future
I
propose
to

?
"
  
<EOS>
Diana
and
Mary
's
general
answer
to

was
a
sigh
,
and
some

of

.
  
<EOS>
But

frequent

,
there

another

with

:
he
seemed
of

reserved
,

,
and

.
<EOS>
Zealous
in
his

,
blameless

,
he
yet
did
not
appear
to

,
that
inward

,
which
should
be
the
reward
of
every
sincere

.
<EOS>
Often
,
of
an

,

,

,
he
would
cease

,
rest

,
and
deliver

up
to
<EOS>
I

not
what
course
of
thought
;
but
that

was
perturbed
and
exciting
might
be
seen
in

.
  
<EOS>
I
think
,
moreover
,
that
Nature
was
not

that

it
was
to

.
<EOS>
He
expressed
once
,
and
but
once
in
my
hearing
,
a
strong
sense
of
the
rugged
charm
of
the

,
and

for
the
dark

and

called
his

;
but
there

more
of

was

;
and
never

roam

for

their

never
seek

or

upon

thousand
peaceful

could

.
  
<EOS>
Incommunicative
<EOS>
as
he
was
,
some

elapsed
before

had
an

gauging

.
<EOS>
I
first
got
an
idea
of
its
calibre
when
I
heard

.
<EOS>
I
wish

could
describe
that

:
but
it
is
past

power
.
<EOS>
I
can
not

.
  
<EOS>
It
began
calm
 
and
indeed
,
as
far

and

,

was

to

:
an

,
yet
strictly

in

,
and

.
<EOS>
This
grew
to
force
 
compressed
,
condensed
,
controlled
.
<EOS>
The
heart
was
thrilled
,

,
by
the
power
of
the
preacher
:
neither
were

.
<EOS>
Throughout

was
a

;
an

of

;
stern

to
Calvinistic

election
,

,

were

;
and

.
<EOS>
When

,

;
for

me
 
<EOS>
I

that

where

.
<EOS>
I
was
sure
<EOS>
St.
John
Rivers
 
<EOS>
pure
-
lived
,
conscientious
,
zealous
as

was
 
had

yet

that
peace
of
God
which
passeth

:

,

.
  
<EOS>
Meantime

was
gone
.
<EOS>
Diana
and
Mary
were
soon
to
leave
Moor
House
,

,

-

,

,

,

.
<EOS>
Mr.
St.
John
had
said
nothing

;

.
<EOS>
One

,

<EOS>
and

,

<EOS>

for

.
  
<EOS>
Looking

drew
near
 
<EOS>
"
You
have
a
question
to
ask
of
me
?
"
<EOS>
he
said
.
  
<EOS>
"
Yes
;
I
wish
to

you
have
heard

I

?
"
  
<EOS>
"
I

three

;
but

useful

here
 
as
my

,

<EOS>
I

till

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
And

?
<EOS>
"

.
  
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Yes
;

,
I

:
<EOS>
Hannah

;
and

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
I

,

:

.
<EOS>
I

.
  
<EOS>
"
What

,

?
<EOS>
I

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Oh

;

,

.
"
  
<EOS>
He
again

:
there
seemed

.
<EOS>
I
grew
impatient
:
<EOS>
a

two
,
and
an
eager

exacting

fastened

,

,

.
  
<EOS>
"
You

,
"

:
"

,

.
<EOS>
Before

,

,

,
that

,

.
<EOS>
I

;
for
I

that
,

,

.
<EOS>
I

:
Rivers
is
an
old

;
but
of
the
three

of
the

,

earn

dependant
's

,
and
the

not

,

.
<EOS>
Yes
,
and
deems
,
and
is

deem
,
<EOS>
himself

the
lot
,
and

,

"
Rise
,

!
"
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
St.
John
said
these
words
as
he
pronounced
his

,
with
a

;

.
<EOS>
He
resumed
    
"
<EOS>
And
since
I
am
myself
poor
and

,
I
can
offer

but
a
service
of

and

.
<EOS>
_
<EOS>
You
_
may
even
think
it
degrading
 
for
I
see
now
<EOS>
your
habits
have
been
what
the
world
calls
refined
:
your
tastes
lean
to
the
ideal
,
and
your
society
has
at
least
been
amongst
the
educated
;
but
_
I
_
consider
that
no
service
degrades
which
can
better
our
race
.
<EOS>
I
hold
that
the
more
arid
and
unreclaimed
the
soil
where
the
Christian
labourer
's
task
of
tillage
is
appointed
him
 
the
scantier
the
meed
his
toil
brings
 
the
higher
the
honour
.
<EOS>
His
,
under
such
circumstances
,
is
the
destiny
of
the
pioneer
;
and
the
first

of
the
Gospel
were
the
Apostles
 
<EOS>
their
captain
was
Jesus
,
the
Redeemer
,
Himself
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Well
?
<EOS>
"
I
said
,
as
he
again
paused
 
"
proceed
.
"
  
<EOS>
He
looked
at
me
before
he
proceeded
:
indeed
,
he
seemed
leisurely
to
read
my
face
,
as
if
its
features
and

were

.
<EOS>
The

drawn
from
this

he
partially
expressed
in

.
  
<EOS>
"
I
believe
you
will
accept
the
post
I

you
,
"
said
he
,
"
and
hold

for
a

:
not

,

:
any
more
than
I
could
permanently
keep
the
narrow
and
narrowing
 
the
tranquil
,
hidden
office
of
English
country
incumbent
;
for
in
your
nature
is
an
alloy
as

as
that
in

,

.
<EOS>
"
  
"
Do

,
"
I

,
when
he

.
  
<EOS>
"
I
will
;
and
you
shall
hear
how
poor
the
proposal
is
,
 
how
trivial
 
<EOS>
how
cramping
.
<EOS>
I
shall
not
stay
long
at
Morton
,
now
that
my
father
is
dead
,
and
that
I
am
my
own
master
.
<EOS>
I
shall
leave
the
place
probably
in
the
course
of
a
twelve
-
month
;
but
while
I
do
stay
,
I
will
exert
myself
to
the
utmost
for
its
improvement
.
<EOS>
Morton
,
when
I
came
to
it
two
years
ago
,
had
no
school
:
the
children
of
the
poor
were
excluded
from
every
hope
of
progress
.
<EOS>
I
established
one
for
boys
:
I
mean
now
to
open
a
second
school
for
girls
.
<EOS>
I
have
hired
a
building
for
the
purpose
,
with
a
cottage
of
two
rooms
attached
to
it
for
the
mistress
's
house
.
<EOS>
Her
salary
will
be
thirty
pounds
a
year
:
<EOS>
her
house
is
already
furnished
,
very
simply
,
but
<EOS>
sufficiently
,
by
the
kindness
of
a
lady
,
Miss
Oliver
;
the
only
daughter
of
the
sole
rich
man
in
my
parish
 
Mr.
Oliver
,
the
proprietor
of
a
needle-
factory
and
iron
-
foundry
in
the
valley
.
<EOS>
The
same
lady
pays
for

an

from

,
on

and

as
her

of
teaching
will
prevent
her
having
time
to
discharge
in
person
.
<EOS>
Will
you
be
this
mistress
?
"
  
<EOS>
He
put
the
question
rather

;
he
seemed
half
to
expect
an
indignant
,

at

of

:
not

,
though

,
he
could
not

in
what
light
the
lot
would

.
<EOS>
In

it
was
humble
 
<EOS>
but

it
was

,
and
I
wanted
a
safe
asylum
<EOS>
:
it
was
plodding
 
but

,

of
a

in

,
it
was
independent
;
and
the
fear
of

with

like

:
it
was
not
ignoble
 
not
unworthy
 
not

,
I

.
  
<EOS>
"
I
thank
you
for
the
proposal
,
Mr.
Rivers
,
and

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
But
you
comprehend
me
?
"
<EOS>
he

.
<EOS>
"
It
is
a

:
your

only
poor

<EOS>
cottagers
'
children
 
at

best
,

.
<EOS>
Knitting

,

,

.
<EOS>

?
<EOS>
What
,

sentiments

?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Save

.
<EOS>
They

.
"
  
<EOS>
"
You

,

?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
do
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
He

:
and

.
  
<EOS>
"

<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I

,

,

,

<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Very

:

.
"
  
<EOS>
He

and

.
<EOS>
Standing

,
he
again

.
<EOS>
He

.
  
<EOS>
"
What

,

Rivers
?
<EOS>
"

.
  
<EOS>
"
You

:
<EOS>
no
,
no
!
"
  
<EOS>
"
Why
?
<EOS>
What

?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I

;

which

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I

.
"
  
<EOS>
He

"

.
"
<EOS>
He

,
"
No
.
<EOS>
What

?
<EOS>
Who
is

?
<EOS>
I
know

:
<EOS>
but
how

find

?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
was

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Well
,
if
you
are
not

,
you
are
 
"
<EOS>
He

.
  
<EOS>
"
What
?
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
was
going
to

,
impassioned
:
<EOS>
but

,

.
<EOS>
I
mean
,
that

and

have

.
<EOS>
I

:

,
"

,
with

,
"
to

here
buried

,
pent
in
with
mountains
 
my
nature
,
that
God
gave

,
contravened
;
my

,
heaven
-

,
paralysed
 
made

.
<EOS>
You

.
<EOS>
I
,
who
preached

with
a

,
and
justified

I
,

,

.
<EOS>
Well
,

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>

.
<EOS>
In

had

of

previous

:
<EOS>
yet

.
  
<EOS>
Diana
and
Mary
Rivers
became
more

and

as
the

approached
for
leaving
their
brother
and

.
<EOS>
They

appear

;
but

to

was

.
<EOS>
Diana
intimated
that
this

from
any

.
<EOS>
It
would
probably
,
as

St.
John
was
concerned
,
be

for

:
it
might

.
  
<EOS>
"
He
will
sacrifice
all
to
his
long

,
"
she

:
"
natural

and

more
potent

.
<EOS>
St.
John
looks
quiet
,
Jane
;
but
he
hides
a

in

.
<EOS>
You
would

gentle
,

he

as

;
and
the

,

from

:

,

.
<EOS>
It

,

,

:
yet

heart
!
"
<EOS>
And
the
tears
gushed
to
her
fine

.
<EOS>
Mary
bent
her

.
  
<EOS>
"
We
are
now
without
father
:
we
shall
soon

and

,
"
she

.
  
<EOS>
At

a

supervened
,
which
seemed

purposely

,
that
"
misfortunes
never

,
"
and
to

the

of
the

and

.
<EOS>
St.
John
passed
the
window
reading
a
letter
.
<EOS>
He
entered
.
  
<EOS>
"
Our
uncle
John
is
dead
,
"
said

.
  
<EOS>
Both

sisters
seemed

:
not

or

;
the
tidings
appeared
in

rather

than

.
  
<EOS>
"
Dead
?
"
repeated
Diana
.
  
<EOS>
"
Yes
.
"
  
<EOS>
She
riveted
a

on

brother
's

.
"
<EOS>
And
what
then
?
<EOS>
"
she

,
in

.
  
<EOS>
"
What

,
Die
?
"
<EOS>
he

,

immobility

.
<EOS>
"
What
then
?
<EOS>
Why
 
nothing
.
<EOS>
Read
.
"
  
<EOS>
He
threw
the
letter
into
her

.
<EOS>
She
glanced
over

,
and
handed
it
to
Mary
.
<EOS>
Mary

in

,
and

.
<EOS>
All

looked

,
and
all

smiled
 
a
dreary
,
pensive

enough
.
  
<EOS>
"
Amen
!
<EOS>
We
can
yet
live
,
"
said

.
  
<EOS>
"
At
any
rate
,

,
"

.
  
<EOS>
"
Only

the

,
"

,
"

_

_
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
He

,

,

.
  
<EOS>
For
some

no

spoke
.
<EOS>
Diana
then
turned
to
me
.
  
<EOS>
"
Jane
,
you
will
wonder
at
us
and
our
mysteries
,
"
she
said
,
"
and
think
us
hard
-
hearted
beings
not
to
be
more
moved
at
the
death
of
so
near
a
relation
as
an
uncle
;
but
we
have
never
seen

or
known

.
<EOS>
He
was
my
mother
's
brother
.
<EOS>
My
father
and
he
quarrelled
long
ago
.
<EOS>
It
was
by
his
advice
that
my
father
risked
most
of
his

in
the
speculation
that
ruined
him
.
<EOS>
Mutual
recrimination
passed
between
them
:
they
parted
in

,
and
were
never

.
<EOS>
My
uncle
engaged
afterwards
in
more
prosperous

:
it
appears
he
realised
a
fortune
of
twenty
thousand
pounds
.
<EOS>
He
was
never
married
,
and
had
no
near
kindred
but
ourselves
and
one
other
person
,
not
more
closely
related
than
we
.
<EOS>
My
father
always
cherished
the
idea
that
he
would
atone
for
his
error
by
leaving
his
possessions
to
us
;
that
letter
informs
us
that
he
has
bequeathed
every

to
the
other
relation
,
with
the
exception
of
thirty
guineas
,
to

between
St.
John
,
Diana
,
and
Mary

,
for

.
<EOS>
He
had
a
right
,
of
course
,
to
do
as
he
pleased
:
and
yet
a
momentary
damp
is
cast
on

by
the
receipt
of
such
news
.
<EOS>
Mary
and
I
would
have
esteemed
ourselves
rich
with
a
thousand

each
;
and
to
St.
John
such

would
have
been
valuable
,
for
the
good
it
would
have
enabled
him
to
do
.
"
  
<EOS>
This
explanation
given
,
the
subject
was
dropped
,
and
no

made
to

by
either

Rivers
or

.
<EOS>
The
next
day
I
left
Marsh
End
for
Morton
.
<EOS>
The
day
after
,
Diana
and
Mary
quitted
it
for
distant
B-
.
<EOS>
In
a
week
,
Mr.
Rivers
and
Hannah
repaired
to
the
parsonage
:
and
so
the
old
grange
was
abandoned
.
    
<EOS>
My
home
,
then
,
when
I
at
last
find
a
home
,
 
is
a
cottage
;
a
little
room
with
whitewashed
walls
and
a
sanded

,
containing
four
painted
chairs
and
a
table
,
a
clock
,
a

,
with
two
or
three
plates
and
dishes
,
and
a
set
of
tea
-
things
in
delf
.
<EOS>
Above
,
a
chamber
of
the
same
dimensions
as
the
kitchen
,
with
a
deal
bedstead
and
chest
of
drawers
;
small
,
yet
too
large
to
be
filled
with
my
scanty
wardrobe
:
though
the
kindness
of
my
gentle
and
generous
friends
has
increased
that
,
by
a
modest
stock
of
such
things
as
are
necessary
.
  
<EOS>
It
is
evening
.
<EOS>
I
have
dismissed
,
with
the
fee
of
an
orange
,
the
little
orphan
who
serves
me
as
a
handmaid
.
<EOS>
I
am
sitting
alone
on
the
hearth
.
<EOS>
This
morning
,
the
village
school
opened
.
<EOS>
I
had
twenty
scholars
.
<EOS>
But
three
of
the
number
can
read
:
none
write
or
cipher
.
<EOS>
Several
knit
,
and
a
few
sew
a
little
.
<EOS>
They
speak
with
the
broadest
accent
of
the
district
.
<EOS>
At
present
,
they
and
I
have
a
difficulty
in
understanding
each
other
's
language
.
<EOS>
Some
of
them
are
unmannered
,
rough
,
intractable
,
as
well
as
ignorant
;
but
others
are
docile
,
have
a
wish
to
learn
,
and
evince
a
disposition
that
pleases
me
.
<EOS>
I
must
not
forget
that
these
coarsely
-
clad
little
peasants
are
of
flesh
and
blood
as
good
as
the
scions
of
gentlest
genealogy
;
and
that
the
germs
of
native
excellence
,
refinement
,
intelligence
,
kind
feeling
,
are
as
likely
to
exist
in
their
hearts
as
in
those
of
the
best
-
born
.
<EOS>
My
duty
will
be
to
develop
these
germs
:
surely
I
shall
find
some
happiness
in
discharging
that
office
.
<EOS>
Much
enjoyment
I
do
not
expect
in
the
life
opening
before
me
:
yet
it
will
,
doubtless
,
<EOS>
if
I
regulate
my
mind
,
and
exert
my
powers
as
I
ought
,
yield
me
enough
to
live
on
from
day
to
day
.
  
<EOS>
Was
I
very
gleeful
,
settled
,
content
,
during
the
hours
I
passed
in
yonder
bare
,
humble

this

?
<EOS>
Not
to
deceive
myself
,
I
must
reply
 
<EOS>
No
:
<EOS>
I
felt
desolate
to
a
degree
.
<EOS>
I
felt
 
<EOS>
yes
,
idiot
that
I
am
 
<EOS>
I
felt
degraded
.
<EOS>
I
doubted
I
had
taken
a
step
which
sank
instead
of
raising
me
in
the
scale
of
social
existence
.
<EOS>
I
was
weakly
dismayed
at
the
ignorance
,
the
poverty
,
the
coarseness
of
all
I
heard
and
saw

.
<EOS>
But
let

not
hate
and
despise

too
much
for
these
feelings
;
I
know
them
to
be
wrong
 
<EOS>
that
is
a
great
step
gained
;
I
shall
strive
to
overcome
them
.
<EOS>
To
-
morrow
,
I
trust
,
I
shall
get
the
better
of
them
partially
;
and
in
a
few
weeks
,
perhaps
,
they
will
be
quite

.
<EOS>
In
a
few
months
,
it
is
possible
,
the
happiness
of
seeing
progress
,
and
a
change
for
the
better
in
my
scholars
may
substitute

for

.
  
<EOS>
Meantime
,
let
me
ask
myself
one
question
 
<EOS>
Which
is
better
?
 
<EOS>
To
have
surrendered
to
temptation
;
listened
to
passion
;
made
no
painful

<EOS>
no
struggle
;
 
but
to
have
sunk
down
in
the

;
fallen

;

:
to

now
living
in
France
,
Mr.
Rochester
's

;
delirious
with
his
love
half
my
time
 
for
he
would
 
<EOS>
oh
,
yes
,
he
would
have
loved
me
well
for
a
while
.
<EOS>
He
_
<EOS>
did
_
love
me
 
<EOS>
no
one
will
ever
love
me
so
again
.
<EOS>
I
shall
never

the
sweet

given
to
beauty
,
youth
,
and
grace
 
for
never
to

else
<EOS>
shall
I
seem
to

these

.
<EOS>
He
was
fond
and
proud
of
me
 
<EOS>
it
is
what
no
man
besides
will
ever
be
.
 
<EOS>
But
where

I
wandering
,
and
what

,
and

,

?
<EOS>
Whether

better
,
I

,
to
be
a
slave
in
a

fevered

,
free

,

?
  
<EOS>
Yes
;
I
feel
now
that
I

right
when

to
principle
and

,
and

and

of

.
<EOS>
God
directed
me
to
a
correct

:
I
thank
His
providence
for
the

!
  
<EOS>
Having

eventide

to

,
I

,
went
to

,
and

,

,
which
,
with

school
,
was
distant

.
<EOS>
The
birds
were
singing
their
last
strains
    
<EOS>
"
The
air
was
mild
,
the
dew
was
balm
.
"
  
<EOS>
While

,
I
thought

,
and
was

ere

weeping
 
and
why
?
<EOS>
For
the

had

from

to
my

:
for

no

,

.
<EOS>
At

,

eve

Morton
 
<EOS>
I

,

.
<EOS>

.
<EOS>
A

old

,

,

;

,

<EOS>
I

.
  
<EOS>
"
No

<EOS>
I

<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
I

:

.
<EOS>
He

,
I

,

:

.
  
<EOS>
"

"

.
  
<EOS>
"

,

!
<EOS>
On

<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
But

?
<EOS>
They

,

;
but
 
"
I

<EOS>
"
My

clean

;
my

sufficient

.
<EOS>
All

,

.
<EOS>
I

<EOS>

;

.
<EOS>
I

.
<EOS>
I

<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
But

?
<EOS>
The

<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I

<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"

<EOS>
St.
John
continued
    
<EOS>
"
It
is
hard

and
turn

;
but

,

.
<EOS>
God

,
in

,
the
power
to
make

;

when

after
a

<EOS>

<EOS>

,

stand

:

have
but
to
seek
another
nourishment

the

,
as
strong

it
longed
to
taste
 
and

;
and
to
hew

a

direct

the
one
Fortune
has
blocked

,
if

than

.
  
<EOS>
"
A

ago
I
was
myself
intensely

,
because

thought
I

a

in

the

:
its

.
<EOS>
I
burnt
for
the
more

of

for

for
the

,

;
anything

:
<EOS>
yes

,

,

.
<EOS>
I

;
my

,

,

.
<EOS>
After

:

<EOS>
my

,

,

<EOS>

;

,

,

<EOS>

_

<EOS>

<EOS>
We

;

,

"
Good

.
<EOS>

<EOS>
Your

,

<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
It

.
<EOS>
Though

<EOS>
A

<EOS>
There

;

.
<EOS>
Perfect

;

:
as
sweet

as

justified
,

,
the
term
.
<EOS>
No

was

,
no

was

;
the
young

had
regular

;

shaped

as

in

,
large
,

,

full
;
the

which

with

;
the

which
gives
such

;
the
white
smooth
forehead
,
which
adds
such
repose
to
the
livelier
beauties
of
tint
and
ray
;
the
cheek
oval
,
fresh
,
and
smooth
;
the
lips
,
fresh
too
,
ruddy
,
healthy
,
sweetly
formed
;
the
even
and
gleaming
teeth
without
flaw
;
the
small
dimpled
chin
;
the
ornament
of
rich
,
plenteous
tresses
 
<EOS>
all
advantages
,
in
short
,
which
,
combined
,
realise
the
ideal
of
beauty
,
were
fully
hers
.
<EOS>
I
wondered
,
as
I
looked
at
this
fair
creature
:
<EOS>
I
admired
her
with
my
whole
heart
.
<EOS>
Nature
had
surely
formed
her
in
a
partial
mood
;
and
,
forgetting
her
usual
stinted
step
-
mother
dole
of
gifts
,
had
endowed
this
,
her
darling
,
with
a
grand
-
dame
's
bounty
.
  
<EOS>
What
did
St.
John
Rivers
think
of
this
earthly
angel
?
<EOS>
I
naturally
asked
myself
that
question
as
I
saw
him
turn
to
her
and
look
at
her
;
and
,
as
naturally
,
I
sought
the
answer
to
the
inquiry
in
his
countenance
.
<EOS>
He
had
already
withdrawn
his
eye
from
the
Peri
,
and
was
looking
at
a
humble
tuft
of
daisies
which
grew
by
the
wicket
.
  
<EOS>
"
A
lovely
evening
,
but
<EOS>
late
for
you
to
be

alone
,
"
he
said
,
as
he
crushed
the

of
the
closed
flowers
with

.
  
<EOS>
"
Oh
,
I
only
came
home
from
S-
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
(
she
mentioned
the
name
of
a
large
town
some
twenty
miles
distant
)
"
this
afternoon
.
<EOS>
Papa
told
me
you
had
opened
your
school
,
and
that
the
new
mistress
was
come
;
and
so
I
put
on
my
bonnet
after
tea
,
and
ran
up
the
valley
to
see
her
<EOS>
:
this
is
she
?
"
<EOS>
pointing

me
.
  
<EOS>
"
It
is
,
"
said
St.
John
.
  
<EOS>
"
Do
you
think
you
shall
like
Morton
?
<EOS>
"
she
asked
of
me
,
with
a

,

,
if

<EOS>
"
I
hope
I
shall
.
<EOS>
I
have
many

to
do

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Did
you
find
your
scholars
as

as

expected
?
<EOS>
"
  
"
Quite
.
<EOS>
"
  
"
Do
you
like
your
house
?
"
  
"
Very
much
.
"
  
<EOS>
"
Have
I
furnished
it

?
"
  
"
Very

,
indeed
.
"
  
"
And
made
a
good

an

for
you
in
Alice
Wood
?
"
  
<EOS>
"
You
have
indeed
.
<EOS>
She
is
teachable
and
handy
.
"
<EOS>
(
This
then
,
I
thought
,
is
Miss
Oliver
,
the
heiress
;
<EOS>
favoured
,
it

,
in

,

!
<EOS>
What

the

?
)
  
<EOS>
"
I

come

,
"

.
<EOS>
"

will
be
a

to

;
and
I
like
a

.
<EOS>
Mr.
Rivers
,
I
have
been
_
<EOS>
so
_
gay
during
my
stay
at
S-
.
<EOS>
Last
night
,
or
rather
this
morning
,
I
was
dancing
till
two

.
<EOS>
The
th
regiment
are
stationed
there
since
the
riots
;
and
the
officers
are
the
most
agreeable

in
the
world
:
they
put
all
our
young
knife

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
It

that
Mr.
St.
John
's
under

,
and
his

.
<EOS>
His

,
and

.
<EOS>
He

.
<EOS>
An

<EOS>
She

,
and
laughter

,

,

.
  
<EOS>

caressing
Carlo
.
"
<EOS>
Poor

,
"

.
"
<EOS>
_
<EOS>
He
_

;
and
if

,

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
As

,

,

.
<EOS>
I

,

.
<EOS>
Flushed

,

.
<EOS>
His

,

,

,

,

.
<EOS>
But
he
curbed

,
I

,

.
<EOS>
He

.
  
<EOS>
"
Papa
says
you
never
come
to

now
,
"
continued
Miss
Oliver
,

.
<EOS>
"
You
are
quite

Vale
Hall
.
<EOS>
He
is
alone
this

,
and

?
"
  
<EOS>
"
It

,
"

.
  
<EOS>
"

!
<EOS>
But

.
<EOS>
It

papa

:

<EOS>
Now

.

"
<EOS>

his

.
  
<EOS>
"
I

!
"
<EOS>

,

.
<EOS>
"

<EOS>
_

.
<EOS>

.
<EOS>
Diana

,

.
<EOS>
I

.
<EOS>

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Not

,

,

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
Mr.

John
spoke

:
<EOS>
himself

.
  
<EOS>
"

,

;

:

.
<EOS>
Good

!
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
She

.
<EOS>
He

.
"
<EOS>
Good

!
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
he

,
in

.
<EOS>
She

,
but

.
  
<EOS>
"
Are

?
"
<EOS>
she

.
<EOS>
Well
might

:
his

was

.
  
<EOS>
"
Quite
well
,
"
he

;
and

.
<EOS>
She

one

;
he

.
<EOS>
She

;
he
,

.
  
<EOS>
This

's

and

from

.
<EOS>
Diana
Rivers
had
designated
her
brother
"
inexorable
as

.
<EOS>
"
She
had
not

.
    
<EOS>
I
continued

of
the
village

school
as

I

.
<EOS>
It
was

at

.
<EOS>
Some

before
,
with
all
my

,
I
could

.
<EOS>
Wholly

,
with

,
they

;
and
,

all

:
<EOS>
but
I
soon

I

.
<EOS>
There

;
and

,

me
,
this

rapidly

.
<EOS>
Their

at
me
,
my

,
my

,
and
ways
,
once

,
I
found
some

these
heavy

,

into
sharp

girls
enough
.
<EOS>
Many
showed

obliging
,
and

;

I

not
a

of
natural

,

self

,
as

,
that
won

and

.
<EOS>
These
soon
took
a
pleasure
in
doing
their
work
well
,
in
keeping
their
persons
neat
,
in
learning
their
tasks
regularly
,
in

and

.
<EOS>
The
rapidity
of
their
progress
,
in
some

,
was
even

;
and
an
honest
and

I
took

:
besides
,
I
began
personally
to
like
some
of
the
best
girls
;
and
they
liked
me
.
<EOS>
I
had
amongst
my
scholars
several
farmers
'
daughters
:
young
women
grown
,
almost
.
<EOS>
These
could
already
read
,
write
,
and
sew
;
and
to

I
taught
the
elements
of
grammar
,

,

,
and
the

.
<EOS>
I
found
estimable
characters
amongst
them
 
characters
desirous
of
information
and
disposed
for
improvement
 
with
whom
I
passed
many
a
pleasant
evening

in
their
own

.
<EOS>
Their
parents
then
(
the
farmer
and
his
wife
)
loaded
me
with

.
<EOS>
There
was
an
enjoyment
in
accepting
their
simple

,
and
in
repaying
it
by
a
consideration
 
a
scrupulous
regard
to
their
feelings
 
to
which
they
were
not
,
perhaps
,
at
all
times

,
and
which
both

;
because
,

elevated
them
in
their
own

,
it
made

to
merit
the
deferential

they

.
  
<EOS>
I
felt
I
became
a
favourite
in
the
neighbourhood
.
<EOS>
Whenever
I
went
out
,
I
heard

all
sides
cordial

,
and
was
welcomed
with
friendly

.
<EOS>
To
live
amidst
general
regard
,
though
it
be
<EOS>
but
the
regard
of
working

,
is
like
"
sitting
in
sunshine
,
calm
and

;
"
serene

bud
and
bloom
under

ray
.
<EOS>
At
this
period
of
my
life
,
my
heart
far
oftener

with
thankfulness
than
sank
with
dejection
:
and
yet
,
reader
,
to

all
,
in
the
midst

this

,
this
useful
existence
 
after
a
day
passed
in
honourable

amongst
my
scholars
,
an
evening
spent
in
drawing
or
reading
contentedly
alone
 
<EOS>
I
used
to
rush

at

:
dreams
many
-
coloured
,
agitated
,
full
of
the
ideal
,
the
stirring
,
the
stormy
 
dreams
where
,
amidst
unusual

,
charged
with

,
with
agitating
risk
and
romantic
chance
,
I
still
again
and
again
met
Mr.
Rochester
,
always
at
some
exciting
crisis
;
and
then
the
sense
of
being
in
his
arms
,
hearing
his
voice
,
meeting
his
eye
,
touching
his
hand
and

,
loving

,
being
loved
by
him
 
the
hope
of
passing
a
lifetime
at
his
side
,
would
be
renewed
,
with
all

first
force
and

.
<EOS>
Then
I
awoke
.
<EOS>
Then
I
recalled
where
I
was
,
and
how
situated
.
<EOS>
Then
I
rose
up
on
my
curtainless
bed
,
trembling
and

;
and
then
the
still
,
dark
night
witnessed
the
convulsion
of
despair
,
and
heard
the
burst
of
passion
.
<EOS>
By
nine
o'clock
the
next
morning
I
was
punctually
opening
the
school
;
tranquil
,
settled
,
prepared
for
the
steady
duties
of
the
day
.
  
<EOS>
Rosamond
Oliver
kept
her
word
in
coming
to
visit
me
.
<EOS>
Her
call
at
the
school
was
generally
made
in
the
course
of
her
morning
ride
.
<EOS>
She
would
canter
up
to
the
door
on
her
pony
,
followed
by
a
mounted
livery
servant
.
<EOS>
Anything
more
exquisite
than
her
appearance
,
in
her
purple

,
with
her
Amazon
's
cap
of
black

placed
gracefully
above
the
long
curls
that
kissed
her
cheek
and
floated
to
her
shoulders
,
can
scarcely
be
imagined
:
and
it
was
thus
she
would
enter
the
rustic
building
,
and
glide
through
the
dazzled
ranks
of
the
village
children
.
<EOS>
She
generally
came
at
the
hour
when
Mr.
Rivers
was
engaged
in
giving
his
daily
catechising
lesson
.
<EOS>
Keenly
,
I
fear
,
did
the
eye
of
the
visitress
pierce
the
young
pastor
's
heart
.
<EOS>
A
sort
of
instinct
seemed
to
warn
him
of
her
entrance
,
even
when
he
did
not
see

;
and
when
he
was
looking
quite
away
from
the
door
,
if
she
appeared

,
his
cheek
would
glow
,
and
his
marble

,
though

refused

,
changed
indescribably
,
and
in
their
very
quiescence
became
expressive
of
a
repressed
fervour
,
stronger
than
working
muscle
or
darting
glance
could
indicate
.
  
<EOS>
Of
course
,
she
knew
her
power
:
<EOS>
indeed
,
he
did
not
,
because
he
could
not
,
conceal
it
from
her
.
<EOS>
In
spite
of
his
Christian
stoicism
,
when
she
went
up
and
addressed
him
,
and
smiled
gaily
,
encouragingly
,
even
fondly
in
his
face
,
his
hand
would
tremble
and
his
eye
burn
.
<EOS>
He
seemed
to
say
,
with
his
sad
and
resolute
look
,
if
he
did
not
say
it
with
his
lips
,
"
I
love
you
,
and
I
know
you
prefer
me
.
<EOS>
It
is
not
despair
of
success
that
keeps
me
dumb
.
<EOS>
If
I
offered
my
heart
,
I
believe
you
would
accept
it
.
<EOS>
But
that
heart
is
already
laid
on
a
sacred
altar
:
the
fire
is
arranged
round
it
.
<EOS>
It
will
soon
be
no
more
than
a
sacrifice
consumed
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
And
then
she
would
pout
like
a
disappointed
child
;
a
pensive
cloud
would
soften
her
radiant
vivacity
;
she
would
withdraw
her
hand
hastily
from
his
,
and
turn
in
transient
petulance
from
his
aspect
,
at
once
so
heroic
and
so
martyr
-
like
.
<EOS>
St.
John
,
no
doubt
,
would
have
given
the
world
to
follow
,
recall
,
retain
her
,
when
she
thus
left
him
;
but
he
would
not
give
one
chance
of
heaven
,
nor
relinquish
,
for
the
elysium
of
her
love
,
one
hope
of
the
true
,
eternal
Paradise
.
<EOS>
Besides
,
he
could
not
bind
all
that
he
had
in
his
nature
 
<EOS>
the
rover
,
the
aspirant
,
the
poet
,
the
priest
 
in
the
limits
of
a
single
passion
.
<EOS>
He
could
not
 
he
would
not
 
renounce
his
wild
field
of
mission
warfare
for
the
parlours
and
the
peace
of
Vale
Hall
.
<EOS>
I
learnt
so
much
from
himself
in
an
inroad
I
once
,
despite
his
reserve
,
had
the
daring
to
make
on
his
confidence
.
  
<EOS>
Miss
Oliver
already
honoured
me
with
frequent
visits
to
my
cottage
.
<EOS>
I
had
learnt
her
whole
character
,
which
was
without
mystery
or
disguise
<EOS>
:
she
was
coquettish
but
not
heartless
;
exacting
,
but
not
worthlessly
selfish
.
<EOS>
She
had
been
indulged
from
her
birth
,
but
was
not
absolutely
spoilt
.
<EOS>
She
was
hasty
,
but
good
-
humoured
;
vain
<EOS>
(
she
could
not
help
it
,
when
every
glance
in
the
glass
showed
her
such
a
flush
of
loveliness
)
,
but
not
affected
;
liberal
-
handed
;
innocent
of
the
pride
of
wealth
;
ingenuous
;
sufficiently
intelligent
;
gay
,
lively
,
and
unthinking
:
she
was
very
charming
,
in
short
,
even
to
a
cool
observer
of
her
own
sex
like
me
;
but
she
was
not
profoundly
interesting
or
thoroughly
impressive
.
<EOS>
A
very
different
sort
of
mind
was
hers
from
that
,
for
instance
,
of
the
sisters
of
St.
John
.
<EOS>
Still
,
I
liked
her
almost
as
I
liked
my
pupil
Adele
;
except
that
,
for
a
child

over
and
taught
,
a
closer
affection
is
engendered
than
we
can
give
an
equally
attractive
adult
acquaintance
.
  
<EOS>
She
had
taken
an
amiable
caprice
to
me
.
<EOS>
She
said
I
was
like
Mr.
Rivers
,
only
,
certainly
,
she
allowed
,
"
not
one
-
tenth
<EOS>
so
handsome
,
though
I
was
a
nice
neat
little
soul
enough
,
but
he
was
an
angel
.
<EOS>
"
I
was
,
however
,
good
,
clever
,
composed
,
and
firm
,
like
him
.
<EOS>
I
was
a
_
lusus
naturae
_
<EOS>
,
she
affirmed
,
as
a
village
schoolmistress
:
she
was
sure
my
previous
history
,
if
known
,
would
make
a
delightful
romance
.
  
<EOS>
One
evening
,
while
,
with
her
usual
child

,

of

first
two

,

,

,

my

,
including
a

of
a

,
one

my

,
and
sundry

from

,

in

Morton

.
<EOS>
She
was
first
transfixed
with
surprise
,
and
then

.
  
<EOS>
"
Had
I
done
these

?
<EOS>
Did
I
know
French
and

?
<EOS>
What
a
love
 
<EOS>
what
a
miracle
<EOS>
I
was
!
<EOS>
I
drew
better
than
her
master
in
the
first
school
in
S-
.
<EOS>
Would
I
sketch
a
portrait
of
her
,
to

to

?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
With
pleasure
,
"
I
replied
;
and
I
felt
a
thrill
of
artist

at
the
idea
of
copying
from
so
perfect
and
radiant

model
.
<EOS>
She
had
then
on
a
dark
-
blue

;
her
arms
and
her

were
bare
;
her

her

,
which
waved

with
all

.
<EOS>
I
took
a
sheet
of
fine
card

board
,
and
drew
a
careful
outline
.
<EOS>
I
promised
myself
the
pleasure
of
colouring
it
;
and
,
as
it
was
getting
late
then
,
I
told

she
must
come
and
sit
another

.
  
<EOS>
She
made
such
a
report
of
me
to
her
father
,
that
Mr.
Oliver
himself
accompanied
her
next
evening
 
<EOS>
a
tall
,
massive
-

,
middle
-

,

,
at

his

daughter

.
<EOS>
He
appeared
a

,
and
perhaps

;
but
he
was
very

.
<EOS>
The

of
Rosamond
's

pleased

highly
:
he
said
I
must
make
a
finished

.
<EOS>
He
insisted
,
too
,
on
my
coming
the
next
day
to
spend
the
evening
at
Vale
Hall
.
  
<EOS>
I
went
.
<EOS>
I
found
it
a
large
,
handsome
residence
,
showing
abundant
evidences
of
wealth
in
the
proprietor
.
<EOS>
Rosamond
was
full
of
glee
and
pleasure
all
the
time
I
stayed
.
<EOS>
Her
father
was
affable
;
and
when
he
entered
into

,
he
expressed
in
strong
terms
his

of
what
I
had
done
in
Morton
school
,
and
said
he
only
feared
,
from
what
he
saw
and
heard
,
I
was
too
good
for
the
place
,
and
would
soon

it
for
one

.
  
<EOS>
"
Indeed
,
"
cried

,
"
she
is
clever
enough
to
be
a
governess
in
a
high

,
papa
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
I
thought
I
would
far

be
where
I
am
than

any
high
family

.
<EOS>
Mr.
Oliver
spoke
of
Mr.
Rivers
 
of
the
Rivers
family
 
with
great
respect
.
<EOS>
He
said
it
was
a
very
old
name
in
that
neighbourhood
;
that
the
ancestors
of
the
house
were
wealthy
;
that
all

;

the

that

might

.
<EOS>
He

so

;

.
<EOS>
It

,

.
<EOS>
Mr.

's

,

,

.
  
<EOS>
It

the
5th

,
and
a

.
<EOS>
My
little

,
after

,

,

.
<EOS>
All

was
spotless
and
bright
 
scoured
floor
,

,
and

.
<EOS>
I
had
also
made
myself
neat
,
and
had
now

before
me
to

as

.
  
<EOS>
The

;

,

<EOS>
The

:

;

,

a

.
<EOS>
I

nice

,
when
,

one

,
my

,

.
  
<EOS>
"
I

,
"

.
<EOS>
"
Not
,
I

,

?
<EOS>
No
,

:

draw

.
<EOS>
You

,
I
mistrust

,

borne

.
<EOS>
I
have

a
book

,
"
and
he
laid

table
a
new
publication
 
<EOS>
a

:
<EOS>
one
of
those
genuine
productions
so
often
vouchsafed
to
the
fortunate
public
of
those
days
 
the
golden
age
of
modern

.
<EOS>
Alas
!
<EOS>
the
readers
of
our
era
are
less
favoured
.
<EOS>
But
courage
!
<EOS>
I
will
not
pause

to

or

.
<EOS>
I
know

is
not
dead
,
nor

;
nor

Mammon
gained
power
over
either
,
to
bind

:
they
will
both
assert
their

,

,

.
<EOS>
Powerful

,
safe

!
<EOS>
they
smile
when

,
and
feeble

.
<EOS>
Poetry

?
<EOS>
Genius

?
<EOS>
No
!
<EOS>
Mediocrity
,
no
<EOS>
:
do
not
let

prompt
you
to
the
thought
.
<EOS>
No
;
they
not
only

,
but
reign
and

:
<EOS>
and
without
their
divine
influence
spread
everywhere
,
you
would
be
in
hell
 
the

your

.
  
<EOS>
While

"
Marmion
"
(
for

Marmion
"

<EOS>
His

<EOS>
:

.
<EOS>
I

:
he

.
<EOS>
I
knew
his

,
and

;

,

,

<EOS>
"
With

"

"

,

<EOS>
I

,

<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
I

"
Take

,

.
<EOS>
"
But

,

.
"
<EOS>
Very

,
"
I

,

"

;

<EOS>
,

:

.
<EOS>
I

,

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Is

?
"
<EOS>

<EOS>
"
Like
!
<EOS>
Like

?
<EOS>
I

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
You

,

Rivers
.
"
  
<EOS>
He

:

.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Oh
,

,
"

.
<EOS>
"
I

;

.
<EOS>
"

,
"
You

;

I

to

looking

again
,
"
and

.
  
<EOS>
"
A

-

,
"
he

"
very

;

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Yes

;

.
<EOS>
But

?
<EOS>
Who

?
"
  
<EOS>
Mastering

,
he

,
"
Miss
Oliver
,

.
"
  
"
Of
course
.
<EOS>
And

,

,

the

,
I

,

.
<EOS>
I
do
n't
wish

.
<EOS>
"

"

;
"
the

,

.
<EOS>

!
"

"

.
<EOS>

"

,

"

"

"

<EOS>
_

.

:

,

.

.
<EOS>

,

.
<EOS>

's

;

.
<EOS>
So

:

.
"
<EOS>
"

.

_

"
<EOS>
_

_
?
<EOS>
No
.

<EOS>
He

.
<EOS>
His

,

:
but

sentence
,
whatever
it
was
.
  
<EOS>
"
What
is
the
matter
?
<EOS>
"
I
asked
.
  
<EOS>
"
Nothing
in
the
world
,
"
was
the
reply
;
and
,
replacing
the
paper
,
I
saw
him
dexterously
tear
a
narrow
slip
from
the
margin
.
<EOS>
It
disappeared
in
his
glove
;
and
,
with
one
hasty
nod
and
"
good
-
afternoon
,
"
he
vanished
.
  
<EOS>
"
Well
!
<EOS>
"
I
exclaimed
,
using
an
expression
of
the
district
,
"
that
caps
the
globe
,
however
!
"
  
<EOS>
I
,
in
my
turn
,
scrutinised
the
paper
;
but
saw
nothing
on
it
save
a
few
dingy

of
paint
where
I
had
tried
the

in

.
<EOS>
I
pondered
the
mystery
a
minute
or
two
;
but
finding
it
insolvable
,
and
being
certain
it
could
not

of
much

,
I
dismissed
,
and
soon

.
    
<EOS>
When
Mr.
St.
John
went
,
it
was
beginning
to
snow
;
the
whirling
storm
continued
all
night
.
<EOS>
The
next
day
a
keen
wind
brought
fresh
and
blinding
falls
;
by
twilight
the
valley
was
drifted
up
and
almost
impassable
.
<EOS>
I
had
closed
my
shutter
,
laid
a
mat
to
the
door
to
prevent
the
snow
from
blowing
in
under

,
trimmed

,
and

,
I
lit

,
took
down
"
Marmion
,
"
and
beginning
    
"
Day
set
on
Norham
's
castled
steep
,
And
Tweed
's
fair
river
broad
and
deep
,
And
Cheviot

;
The

,
the
donjon

,
The

that
round

sweep
,
In
yellow

shone
"
    
<EOS>
I
soon
forgot
storm
in

.
  
<EOS>
I
heard
a
noise
:
<EOS>
the
wind
,
I
thought
,
shook
the
door
.
<EOS>
No
;
it
was
St.
John
Rivers
,
who
,
lifting

,
came
in
out
of
the
frozen
hurricane
 
the
howling

and
stood

:
the

that

all

.
<EOS>
I
was
almost

,
so
little
<EOS>
had

expected

from
the
blocked
-
up

.
  
<EOS>
"
Any

?
<EOS>
"
I
demanded
.
<EOS>
"
Has
anything
happened
?
"
  
<EOS>
"
No
.
<EOS>
How
very
easily

you
are
!
"
<EOS>
he

,

,

again

<EOS>
He
stamped

.
  
<EOS>
"
I
shall
sully
the

,
"
said

,
"
but

must

for

.
<EOS>
"
Then
he
approached

fire
.
<EOS>
"
I
have
had

to

here
,
I

,
"
he

,

.
"
<EOS>
One

took
me
up
to

;
happily
the
snow
is
quite

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
But

?
<EOS>
"
I
could

.
  
<EOS>
"
Rather

;
but

,
I

;
I

.
<EOS>
Besides
,
since
yesterday

have
experienced
the

of
a
person
to

a
tale
has
been
half

,
and
who
is

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
He
sat

.
<EOS>
I
recalled
his
singular
conduct
of
yesterday
,
and
really
I
began
to

his

were

.
<EOS>
If
he
were
insane
,
however
,
his

a

:
I
had

,

to

now

.
<EOS>
I

,

;
but
his

he

.
<EOS>
It

that

.
<EOS>
A

"
I

<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"

,
"

"
I

.
<EOS>
I

.
<EOS>
What

?
"
  
<EOS>

<EOS>

.

<EOS>
"
No

!
"
<EOS>

<EOS>
"

,
"

"

wo

;

,

"
Marmion
.
"
<EOS>
He

my

.
<EOS>
It

;

.
  
<EOS>
"

Diana

<EOS>
"

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

"

<EOS>
"
  
"
<EOS>
Yes

"
  
<EOS>
Again

:
the

.
<EOS>
It

;

<EOS>

<EOS>
"
Half

"

"

<EOS>
on

<EOS>
Before

<EOS>
For

<EOS>
"
Twenty

,
a

never

<EOS>

<EOS>
(

,

cold

of

<EOS>
I

.
<EOS>
Charity

;

,

(
I

)
<EOS>
Mrs.
Reed

.
<EOS>
You

<EOS>

<EOS>
I

<EOS>
:

and

,

.
 
<EOS>
To

.
<EOS>
Mrs.
Reed

:

<EOS>
you
know
 
being

,

.
<EOS>
It

:

<EOS>
"
  
"
Mr.
Rivers
!
<EOS>
"

.
  
<EOS>
"
I

,
"

"

:

<EOS>

<EOS>
no

<EOS>

;

:

?

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>
Oh

once

I
am
glad
!
 
<EOS>
I
am
glad
!
<EOS>
"
I
exclaimed
.
  
<EOS>
St.
John
smiled
.
<EOS>
"
Did
I
not
say
you
neglected
essential
points
to
pursue
trifles
?
<EOS>
"
he
asked
.
<EOS>
"
You
were
serious
when
I
told
you
you
had
got
a
fortune
;
and
now
,
for
a
matter
of
no
moment
,
you
are
excited
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
What
can
you
mean
?
<EOS>
It
may
be
of
no
moment
to
you
;
you
have
sisters
and
do
n't
care
for
a
cousin
;
but
I
had
nobody
;
and
now
three
relations
,
 
or
two
,
if
you
do
n't
choose
to
be
counted
,
 
are
born
into
my
world
full
-
grown
.
<EOS>
I
say
again
,
I
am
glad
!
"
  
<EOS>
I
walked
fast
through
the
room
:
I
stopped
,
half
suffocated
with
the
thoughts
that
rose
faster
than
I
could
receive
,
comprehend
,
settle
them
:
 
thoughts
of
what
might
,
could
,
would
,
and
should
be
,
and
that
ere
long
.
<EOS>
I
looked
at
the
blank
wall
:
it
seemed
a
sky
thick
with
ascending
stars
,
 
every
one
lit
me
to
a
purpose
or
delight
.
<EOS>
Those
who
had
saved
my
life
,
whom
,
till
this
hour
,
I
had
loved
barrenly
,
I
could
now
benefit
.
<EOS>
They
were
under
a
yoke
,
 
<EOS>
I
could
free
them
:
<EOS>
they
were
scattered
,
 
<EOS>
I
could
reunite
them
:
the
independence
,
the
affluence
which
was
mine
,
might
be
theirs
too
.
<EOS>
Were
we
not
four
?
<EOS>
Twenty
thousand
pounds
shared
equally
would
be
five
thousand
each
,
justice
 
enough
and
to
spare
:
justice
would
be
done
,
 
mutual
happiness
secured
.
<EOS>
Now
the
wealth
did
not
weigh
on
me
:
now
it
was
not
a
mere
bequest
of
coin
,
 
<EOS>
it
was
a
legacy
of
life
,
hope
,
enjoyment
.
  
<EOS>
How
I
looked
while
these
ideas
were
taking
my
spirit
by
storm
,
I
can
not
tell
;
but
I
perceived
soon
that
Mr.
Rivers
had
placed
a
chair
behind
me
,
and
was
gently
attempting
to
make
me
sit
down
on
it
.
<EOS>
He
also
advised
me
to
be
composed
;
I
scorned
the
insinuation
of
helplessness
and
distraction
,
shook
off
his
hand
,
and
began
to
walk
about
again
.
  
<EOS>
"
Write
to
Diana
and
Mary
to
-
morrow
,
"
I
said
,
"
and
tell
them
to
come
home
directly
.
<EOS>
Diana
said
they
would
both
consider
themselves
rich
with
a
thousand
pounds
,
so
with
five
thousand
they
will
do
very
well
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Tell
me
where
I
can
get
you
a
glass
of
water
,
"
said
St.
John
;
"
you
must
really
make
an
effort
to
tranquillise
your
feelings
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Nonsense
!
<EOS>
and
what
sort
of
an
effect
will
the
bequest
have
on
you
?
<EOS>
Will
it
keep
you
in
England
,
induce
you
to
marry
Miss
Oliver
,
and
settle
down
like
an
ordinary

?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
You
wander
:
your
head
becomes
confused
.
<EOS>
I
have
been
too
abrupt
in
communicating
the
news
;
it
has
excited
you
beyond
your
strength
.
"
  
"
<EOS>
Mr.
Rivers
!
<EOS>
you
quite
put
me
out
of
patience
:
I
am
rational
enough
;
it
is
you
who
misunderstand
,
or
rather
who
affect
to
misunderstand
.
"
  
<EOS>
"
Perhaps
,
if
you
explained
yourself
a
little
more
fully
,
I
should
comprehend
better
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Explain
!
<EOS>
What
is
there
to
explain
?
<EOS>
You
can
not
fail
to
see
that
twenty
thousand
pounds
,
the
sum
in
question
,
divided
equally
between
the
nephew
and
three
nieces
of
our
uncle
,
<EOS>
will
give
five
thousand
to
each
?
<EOS>
What
I
want
is
,
that
you
should
write
to
your
sisters
and
tell
them
of
the
fortune
that
has
accrued
to
them
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
To
you
,
you
mean
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
have
intimated
my
view
of
the
case
:
I
am
incapable
of
taking
any
other
.
<EOS>
I
am
not
brutally
selfish
,
blindly
unjust
,
or
fiendishly
ungrateful
.
<EOS>
Besides
,
I
am
resolved
I
will
have
a
home
and
connections
.
<EOS>
I
like
Moor
House
,
and
I
will
live
at
Moor
House
;
I
like
Diana
and
Mary
,
and
I
will
attach
myself
for
life
to
Diana
and
Mary
.
<EOS>
It
would
please
and
benefit
me
to
have
five
thousand
pounds
;
it
would
torment
and
oppress
me
to
have
twenty
thousand
;
which
,
moreover
,
could
never
be
mine
in
justice
,
though

might
in
law
.
<EOS>
I
abandon
to
you
,
then
,
what
is
absolutely
superfluous
to
me
.
<EOS>
Let
there
be
no
opposition
,
and
no
discussion
about
it
;
let
us
agree
amongst
each
other
,
and
decide
the

at

.
"
  
<EOS>
"
This
is
acting
on
first
impulses
;
you
must
take
days
to
consider
such

matter
,
ere
your
word
can
be
regarded
as
valid
.
<EOS>
"
  
"
<EOS>
Oh
!
<EOS>
if
all
you
doubt
is
my

,
I
am
easy
:
you
see
the
justice
of
the

?
<EOS>
"
  
"
I
_
do
_
see

certain

;
but
it
is
contrary
to
all

.
<EOS>
Besides
,
the
entire
fortune
is
your
right
<EOS>
:
my
uncle
gained
it
by
his
own

;
he
was
free
to
leave
it
<EOS>
to
whom
he
would
<EOS>
:
he
left
it
to
you
.
<EOS>
After
all
,
justice
permits
you
to
keep
it
:
you
may
,
with
a
clear
conscience
,
consider
it
absolutely
your
own
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
With
me
,
"
said
I
,
"
it
is
fully
as
much
a
matter
of
feeling
as
of
conscience
:
<EOS>
I
must
indulge
my
feelings
;
I
so
seldom
have
had
an
opportunity
of
doing
so
.
<EOS>
Were
you
to
argue
,
object
,
and
annoy
me
for
a
year
<EOS>
,
I
could
not
forego
the
delicious
pleasure
of
which
I
have
caught
a
glimpse
 
that
of
repaying
,
in

,
a
mighty

,
and
winning
to

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
You
think
so
now
,
"

John
,
"
because
you
do
not

what
it
is
to
possess
,
nor

to
enjoy
wealth
<EOS>
:
you
can
not
form
a
notion
of
the

twenty
thousand

would
give
you
;
of
the
place
it
would
enable
you
to
take
in
society
;
of
the

it
would

:
you
can
not
 
"
  
"
And
you
,
"
I
interrupted
,
"
can
not
at
all

the
craving
I
have
for
fraternal
and

love
.
<EOS>
I
never
had
a
home
,
I
never
had
brothers
or

;
I
must
and
will
have
them
now
:
you
are
not
reluctant
to
admit

and
own

,

you
?
"
  
<EOS>
"
Jane
,
I
will
be
your
brother
 
my
sisters
will
be
your
sisters
 
without
stipulating
for
this
sacrifice
of
your
just
rights
.
<EOS>
"
  
"
<EOS>
Brother
?
<EOS>
Yes
;
at
the
distance
of
a
thousand
leagues
!
<EOS>
Sisters
?
<EOS>
Yes
;
slaving
amongst
strangers
!
<EOS>
I
,
wealthy
 
gorged
with
gold
I
never
earned
and
do
not

!
<EOS>
You
,
penniless
!
<EOS>
Famous
equality
and
fraternisation
!
<EOS>
Close
union
!
<EOS>
Intimate

!
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
But
,
Jane
,
your

after
family

and

may
be
realised
otherwise
than
by
the
means

contemplate
:
you
may
marry
.
<EOS>
"
  
"
Nonsense
,
again
!
<EOS>
Marry
!
<EOS>
I
do
n't
want
to
marry
,
and
never
shall
marry
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
That
is
saying
too
much
:
such
hazardous
affirmations
are
a
proof
of
the
excitement
under
which
you
labour
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
It
is
not
saying
too
much
:
<EOS>
I
know
what
I
feel
,
and
how
averse
are
my
inclinations
to
the
bare
thought
of
marriage
.
<EOS>
No
one
would
take
me
for
love
;
and
I
will
not
be
regarded
in
the
light
of
a
mere
money
speculation
.
<EOS>
And
I
do
not
want
a
stranger
 
unsympathising
,
alien
,
different
from
me
;
I
want
my
kindred
:
those
with
whom
I
have
full
fellow-
feeling
.
<EOS>
Say
again
you
will
be
my
brother
:
when
you
uttered
the
words
I
was
satisfied
,
happy
;
repeat
them
,
if
you
can
,
repeat

sincerely
.
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
think
I
can
.
<EOS>
I
know
I
have
always
loved
my
own
sisters
;
and
I
know
on
what
my
affection
for
them
is
grounded
,
 
respect
for
their
worth
and
admiration
of
their
talents
.
<EOS>
You
too
have
principle
and
mind
:
<EOS>
your
tastes
and
habits
resemble
Diana
's
and
Mary
's
;
your
presence
is
always
agreeable
to
me
;
in
your

I
have
already
for
some

found
a
salutary

.
<EOS>
I
feel
I
can
easily
and
naturally
make
room
in
my
heart
for
you
,
as
my
third
and
youngest
sister
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Thank
you
:
that
contents
me
for
to
-
night
.
<EOS>
Now
you
had
better
go
;
for
if
you
stay
longer
,
you
will
perhaps
irritate
me
afresh
by
some

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
And
the
school
,
Miss
Eyre
?
<EOS>
It
must
now
be
shut
up
,
I

?
<EOS>
"
  
"
<EOS>
No
.
<EOS>
I
will
retain
my
post
of
mistress
till
you
get
a
substitute
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
He
smiled
approbation
:
we
shook
hands
,
and
he
took
leave
.
  
<EOS>
I
need
not
narrate
in
detail
the
further
struggles
I
had
,
and
arguments
I
used
,
to
get
matters
regarding
the
legacy
settled
as
I
wished
.
<EOS>
My
task
was
a
very
hard
one
;
but
,
as
I
was
absolutely
resolved
 
as
my
cousins
saw
at
length
that
my
mind
was
really
and
immutably
fixed
on
making
a
just
division
of
the
property
 
as
they
must
in
their
own
hearts
have
felt
the
equity
of
the
intention
;
and
must
,
besides
,
have
been
innately
conscious
that
in
my
place
they
would
have
done
precisely
what
I
wished
to
do
 
they
yielded
at
length
so
far
as
to
consent
to
put
the
affair
to
arbitration
.
<EOS>
The
judges
chosen
were
Mr.
Oliver
and
an
able
lawyer
:
both
coincided
in
my
opinion
:
I
carried
my
point
.
<EOS>
The
instruments
of
transfer
were
drawn
out
:
<EOS>
St.
John
,
Diana
,
Mary
,
and
I
,
each
became
possessed
of
a
competency
.
    
<EOS>
It
was
near
Christmas
by
the
time
all
was
settled
:
the
season
of
general
holiday
approached
.
<EOS>
I
now
closed
Morton
school
,
taking
care
that
the
parting
should
not
be
barren
on
my
side
.
<EOS>
Good
fortune
opens
the
hand
as
well
as
the
heart
wonderfully
;
and
to
give
somewhat
when
we
have
largely
received
,
is
but
to
afford
a
vent
to
the
unusual
ebullition
of
the
sensations
.
<EOS>
I
had
long
felt
with
pleasure
that
many
of
my
rustic
scholars
liked
me
,
and
when
we
parted
,
that
consciousness
was
confirmed
:
they
manifested
their
affection
plainly
and
strongly
.
<EOS>
Deep
was
my
gratification
to
find
I
had
really
a
place
in
their
unsophisticated
hearts
:
I
promised
them
that
never
a
week
should
pass
in
future
that
I
did
not
visit
them
,
and
give
them
an
hour
's
teaching
in
their
school
.
  
<EOS>
Mr.
Rivers
came
up
as
,
having
seen
the
classes
,
now
numbering
sixty
girls
,
file
out
before
me
,
and
locked
the
door
,
I
stood
with
the
key
in
my
hand
,
exchanging
a
few
words
of
special
farewell
with
some
half
-
dozen
of
my
best
scholars
:
as
decent
,
respectable
,
modest
,
and
well
-
informed
young
women
as
could
be
found
in
the
ranks
of
the
British
peasantry
.
<EOS>
And
that
is
saying
a
great
deal
;
for
after
all
,
the
British
peasantry
are
the
best
taught
,
best
mannered
,
most
self
-
respecting
of
any
in
Europe
:
since
those
days
I
have
seen
paysannes
and
Bauerinnen
;
and
the
best
of
them
seemed
to
me
ignorant
,
coarse
,
and
besotted
,
compared
with
my
Morton
girls
.
  
<EOS>
"
Do
you
consider
you
have
got
your
reward
for
a
season
of
exertion
?
"
asked
Mr.
Rivers
,
when
they
were
gone
.
"
<EOS>
Does
not
the
consciousness
of
having
done
some
real
good
in
your
day
and
generation
give
pleasure
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Doubtless
.
"
  
<EOS>
"
And
you
have
only
toiled
a
few
months
!
<EOS>
Would
not
a
life
devoted
to
the
task
of
regenerating
your
race
be
well
spent
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Yes
,
"
I
said
;
"
but
I
could
not
go
on
for
ever
so
<EOS>
:
I
want
to
enjoy
my
own
faculties
as
well
as
to
cultivate
those
of
other
people
.
<EOS>
I
must
enjoy
them
now
;
do
n't
recall
either
my
mind
or
body
to
the
school
;
I
am
out
of
it
and
disposed
for
full
holiday
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
He
looked
grave
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
What
now
?
<EOS>
What
sudden
eagerness
is
this
you
evince
?
<EOS>
What
are
you
going
to
do
?
<EOS>
"
  
"
To
be
active
:
as
active
as
I
can
.
<EOS>
And
first
I
must
beg
you
to
set
Hannah
at
liberty
,
and
get
somebody
else
to
wait
on
you
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"

?
"
  
<EOS>

<EOS>

"
  
<EOS>

<EOS>
"

<EOS>

_

<EOS>

<EOS>
to
_
<EOS>

"

"
  
<EOS>
"

"

<EOS>

<EOS>
"

two

'

<EOS>

"

<EOS>

,
"

"

.

<EOS>
To

<EOS>
"
  
"

Jane

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>
"
  
"

<EOS>

<EOS>
Happy
at
Moor
House
I
was
,
and

worked
;
and

Hannah
:
<EOS>
she

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>
I

:
my

_

to

<EOS>
The

room

<EOS>

<EOS>
Still

,

.
<EOS>
Dark

<EOS>
A

and

<EOS>

,

<EOS>
When

as

.
  
<EOS>
The

at

.
<EOS>
They
were
expected
about

,

ere

upstairs

;

<EOS>
St.
John

.
<EOS>
I

.
<EOS>
He

certain

,

.
<EOS>
Approaching

,

"

?

.
<EOS>

.
<EOS>
He

<EOS>
but

.
  
<EOS>
This

.
<EOS>
I

he

.
<EOS>
I

no

.
  
<EOS>
"

<EOS>
How

?
 
<EOS>
By

<EOS>
Now
,

did
not

this
,
reader
.
<EOS>
St.
John
was

;

.
<EOS>
The

<EOS>
its

no

.
<EOS>
Literally
,
he
lived

to
aspire
 
after
what
was
good
and

,

;
but
still

would

,

.
<EOS>
As

at
his
fine

<EOS>
I

all

:
that

.
<EOS>
I

,

,

Miss

;
I
agreed

that
it
was
but
a
love

.
<EOS>
I
comprehended
how
he
should
despise

for
the

;

;
how

mistrust

.
<EOS>
I
saw
he
was
of
the
material
from

hews
her
heroes
 
<EOS>
Christian
and
Pagan
 
<EOS>
her

,

,

:

;
but
,

,
too

a

,

.
  
<EOS>
"
This

is
not

,
"
<EOS>
I

:
"
the

,

.
<EOS>
Well

eschew

;

:
there
his

stagnate
 
they
can
not

or

.
<EOS>
It

<EOS>
where

,
and

,

that

.
<EOS>
A

.
<EOS>
He
is
right
to
choose
a

's
career
 
I
see

now
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
They
are

!
<EOS>
they
are

!
"
<EOS>

,

.
<EOS>
At

old
Carlo

.
<EOS>
Out

.
<EOS>
It

;
but

.
<EOS>
Hannah
soon
had
a

.
<EOS>
The

had

at

;
the
driver

:
first

well
-

,

,

.
<EOS>
In

had
my

under

,
in

first

Mary
's
soft

,
then

Diana
's

.
<EOS>
They

<EOS>
kissed
me
 
then
Hannah
:
<EOS>
patted
Carlo
,
who
was
half
wild

;

if
all

;
and
being

.
  
<EOS>
They
were

with

from
Whitcross
,
and

;
but

.
<EOS>
While

and

,

John
.
<EOS>
At
this
moment
he
advanced
from
the

.
<EOS>
They

threw
their
arms
round

.
<EOS>
He

one

,
said

a

of

,
stood

,

,

would
soon

,
withdrew

as

.
  
<EOS>
I
had
lit

to

,
but
Diana
had
first
to

orders
respecting
the
driver
;
this
done
,

me
.
<EOS>
They
were

with
the

and

of
their

;
with
the
new

,
and

,
and
rich

:
they

.
<EOS>
I
had
the
pleasure
of
feeling
that
my
arrangements
met
their
wishes
exactly
,
and
that
what
I
had
done
added
a

to
their
joyous

home
.
  
<EOS>
Sweet
was
that
evening
.
<EOS>
My
cousins
,
full
of

,
were
so
eloquent
in
narrative
and

,
that
their

covered
St.
John
's

:
he
was
sincerely

to
see
his
sisters
;
but
in
their

of
fervour
and

he

not

.
<EOS>
The
event
of
the
day
 
that
is
,
the
return
of
Diana
and
Mary
 
pleased
him
;
but
the
accompaniments
of
that
event
,
the
glad
tumult
,
the
garrulous
glee
of
reception
irked
him
:
I
saw
he
wished
the
calmer
morrow
was
come
.
<EOS>
In
the
very
meridian
of
the
night
's
enjoyment
,
about
an
hour
after
tea
,
a
rap
was
heard
at
the
door
.
<EOS>
Hannah
entered
with
the
intimation
that
"
a
poor
lad
was
come
,
at
that
unlikely
time
,
to
fetch
Mr.
Rivers
to
see
his
mother
,
who
was
drawing
away
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Where
does
she
live
,
Hannah
?
<EOS>
"
  
"
Clear
up
at
Whitcross
Brow
,
almost
four
miles
off
,
and
moor
and
moss
all
the
way
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Tell
him
I
will
go
.
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
'm
sure
,
sir
,
you
had
better
not
.
<EOS>
It
's
the
worst
road
to
travel
after
dark
that
can
be
:
there
's
no
track
at
all
over
the
bog
.
<EOS>
And
then
it
is
such
a
bitter
night
 
<EOS>
the
keenest
wind
you
ever
felt
.
<EOS>
You
had
better
send
word
,
sir
,
that
you
will
be
there
in
the
morning
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
But
he
was
already
in
the
passage
,
putting
on
his
cloak
;
and
without
one
objection
,
one

,
he
departed
.
<EOS>
It
was
then
nine
o'clock
:
he
did
not
return
till
midnight
.
<EOS>
Starved
and
tired
enough
<EOS>
he
was
:
<EOS>
but
he
looked
happier
than
when
he
set
out
.
<EOS>
He
had
performed
an
act
of
duty
;
made
an
exertion
;
felt
his
own
strength
to
do
and
deny
,
and
was
on
better
terms
with
himself
.
  
<EOS>
I
am
afraid
the
whole
of
the
ensuing
week
tried
his
patience
.
<EOS>
It
was
Christmas
week
:
we
took
to
no
settled
employment
,
but
spent
it
in
a
sort
of
merry
domestic
dissipation
.
<EOS>
The
air
of
the
moors
,
the
freedom
of
home
,
the
dawn
of
prosperity
,
acted
on
Diana
and
Mary
's
spirits
like
some
life
-
giving
elixir
<EOS>
:
they
were
gay
from
morning
till
noon
,
and
from
noon
till
night
.
<EOS>
They
could
always
talk
;
and
their
discourse
,
witty
,
pithy
,
original
,
had
such
charms
for
me
,
that
I
preferred
listening
to
,
and
sharing
in
it
,
to
doing
anything
else
.
<EOS>
St.
John
did
not
rebuke
our
vivacity
;
but
he
escaped
from
it
:
he
was
seldom
in
the
house
;
his
parish
was
large
,
the
population
scattered
,
and
he
found
daily
business
in
visiting
the
sick
and
poor
in
its
different
districts
.
  
<EOS>
One
morning
at
breakfast
,
Diana
,
after
looking
a
little
pensive
for
some
minutes
,
asked
him
,
"
If
his
plans
were
yet
unchanged
.
"
  
<EOS>
"
Unchanged
and
unchangeable
,
"
was
the
reply
.
<EOS>
And
he
proceeded
to
inform
us
that
his
departure
from
England
was
now
definitively
fixed
for
the
ensuing
year
.
  
<EOS>
"
And
Rosamond
Oliver
?
"
suggested
Mary
,
the
words
seeming
to
escape
her
lips
involuntarily
:
for
no
sooner
had
she
uttered

,
than
she
made
a
gesture
as
if
wishing
to
recall
them
.
<EOS>
St.
John
had
a
book
in
his
hand
 
<EOS>
it
was
his
unsocial
custom
to
read
at
meals
 
<EOS>
he
closed
it
,
and
looked
up
.
  
<EOS>
"
Rosamond
Oliver
,
"
said
he
,
"
is
about
to
be
married
to
Mr.
Granby
,
one
of
the
best
connected
and
most

in
S-
,
grandson
and
heir
to
Sir
Frederic
Granby
:
I
had
the
intelligence
from
her
father
yesterday
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
His
sisters
looked
at
each
other
and
at
me
;
we
all
three
looked
at
him
:
he
was
serene
as
glass
.
  
<EOS>
"
The
match
must
have
been
got
up

,
"
said
Diana
:
"
they
can
not

known
each
other

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
But
two
months
:
they
met
in
October
at
the
county
ball
at
S-
.
<EOS>
But
where
there
are
no
obstacles
to
a
union
,
as
in
the
present
case
,
where
the
connection
is
in
every

desirable
,
delays
are
unnecessary
:
they
will
be
married
as

as
S
Place
,
which
Sir
Frederic
gives
up
to
them
,
can
he
refitted
for
their

.
"
  
<EOS>
The
first

I
found
St.
John
alone
after
this
communication
,
I
felt
tempted
to
inquire
if
the
event
distressed
him
:
but
he
seemed
so
little
to
need
sympathy
,
that
,
so
far

venturing
to
offer
him
more
,
I
experienced
some

at
the
recollection
of
what
I
had
already

.
<EOS>
Besides
,
I
was
out
of
practice
in
talking
to

:
his
reserve
was
again
frozen
over
,
and
my

was
congealed
beneath

.
<EOS>
He
had
not
kept
his
promise
of
treating
me
like
his
sisters
;
he
continually
made
little

between

,

the

:
in

,
now
that
I
was
acknowledged
his
kinswoman
,
and
lived

,
I
felt
the

between

to
be
far
greater
than
when
he
had
known

only

the

.
<EOS>
When
I
remembered
how
far
I
had
once
been

to
his
confidence
,
I
could
hardly
comprehend
his
present
frigidity
.
  
<EOS>
Such
being
the
case
,
I
felt
not

when
he
raised
his

from
the

,
and
said
    
"
You
see
,
Jane
,
the
battle
is
fought
and
the
victory
won
.
"
  
<EOS>
Startled
at

thus

,
I
did
not
immediately

:
after
a
moment
's
hesitation
I
answered
    
"
<EOS>
But
are
you
sure
you
are
not
in
the
position
of
those
conquerors
whose
triumphs
have
cost
them
too
dear
?
<EOS>
Would
not
such
another
ruin
you
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
think
not
;
and
if
I
were
,
it
does
not
much
signify
;
I
shall
never
be
called
upon
to
contend
for
such
another
.
<EOS>
The
event
of
the
conflict
is
decisive
:
my
way
is
now
clear
;
I
thank
God
for
it
!
"
<EOS>
So
saying
,
he
returned
to
his
papers
and
his

.
  
<EOS>
As
our
mutual
happiness
(
_
i.e.
_
,
Diana
's
,
Mary
's
,
and
mine
)
settled
into
a
quieter
character
,
and
we
resumed
our
usual
habits
and
regular

,
St.
John
stayed
more
at
home
:
he
sat
with
us
in
the
same
room
,
sometimes
for
hours
together
.
<EOS>
While
Mary
drew
,
Diana
pursued
a
course
of
encyclopaedic
reading
she
had
(
to
my
awe
and

)
undertaken
,
and
I
fagged
away
at
German
,
he
pondered
a
mystic

of
his
own
:
that
of
some
Eastern

,
the
acquisition
of
which
he
thought
necessary
to
his
plans
.
  
<EOS>
Thus
engaged
,
he
appeared
,
sitting
in
his
own

,
quiet
and
absorbed
enough
;
but
that
blue
eye
of
his
had
a
habit
of
leaving
the
outlandish-
looking
grammar
,
and
wandering
over
,
and
sometimes

,
his
fellow

,
with

:
if
caught
,
it
would

;
yet
ever
and
anon
,
it
returned

to
our

.
<EOS>
I
wondered
what
it
meant
:
I
wondered
,
too
,
at
the
punctual
satisfaction
he
never
failed
to
exhibit
on
an
occasion
that
seemed
to
me
of
small

,
namely
,
my
weekly
visit
to
Morton
school
;
and
still
more
was
I
puzzled
when
,
if
the
day
was

,
if

was
snow
,

,
or
high

,
and
his
sisters

to

,
he
would
invariably
make
light
of
their

,
and
encourage
me
to
accomplish
the
task
without
regard
to
the
elements
.
  
<EOS>
"
Jane
is
not
such

as
you

,
"
he
would

:
"
she
can
bear

,

,

,
as

.
<EOS>
Her
constitution
is
both
sound
and
elastic
;
 
better
calculated
to
endure
variations
of
climate
than
many
more
robust
.
"
  
<EOS>
And
when
I
returned
,
sometimes
a
good

,
and
not

weather

,
I
never

,
because
I
saw
that
to
murmur
would
be

vex
him
:
on
all

fortitude
pleased
him
;
the
reverse
was
a
special

.
  
<EOS>
One
afternoon
,
however
,
I
got
leave
to
stay
at
home
,
because
I
really
had
a
cold
.
<EOS>
His
sisters
were
gone
to
Morton
in
my
stead
:
I
sat
reading
Schiller
;
he
,
deciphering
his
crabbed

.
<EOS>
As
I
exchanged
a
translation
for
an
exercise
,
I
happened
to
look
his
way
:
there
I
found
myself
under
the
influence
of
the
ever
-
watchful
blue
eye
.
<EOS>
How

it
had
been
searching
me
through
and
through
,
and
over
and
over
,
I
can
not

:
<EOS>
so
keen
was
it
,
and
yet
so
cold
<EOS>
,
I
felt
for
the
moment
superstitious
 
as
if
I
were
sitting
in
the
room
with
something

.
  
<EOS>
"
Jane
,
what
are
you
doing
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Learning
German
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
want
you
to
give
up
German
and
learn
Hindostanee
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
You
are
not
in

?
"
  
<EOS>
"
In
such
earnest
that
I
must
have
it
so
:
and
I
will
tell
you
why
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
He
then
went
on
to
explain
that
Hindostanee
was
the
language
he
was
himself
at
present
studying
;
that
,
as
he
advanced
,
he
was
apt
to
forget
the
commencement
;
that
it
would
assist
him
greatly
to
have
a

with

he
might
again
and
again
go
over
the
elements
,
and
so
fix
them
thoroughly
in

;
that
his
choice
had
hovered
for

between
me
and

;
but
that
he
had
fixed
on
me
because
he
saw
I
could
sit
at
a
task
the

of
the
three
.
<EOS>
Would
I
do

this

?
<EOS>
I
should
not
,
perhaps
,
have
to
make
the
sacrifice
long
,
as
it
wanted
now
barely
three
months
to
his
departure
.
  
<EOS>
St.
John
was
not
a
man
to
be
lightly
refused
:
you
felt
that
every
impression
made
on
him
,
either
for
pain
or
pleasure
,
was
deep
-

and
permanent
.
<EOS>
I
consented
.
<EOS>
When
Diana
and
Mary
returned
,
the
former
found
her
scholar
transferred
from
her
to
her
brother
:
she
laughed
,
and
both
she
and
Mary
agreed
that
St.
John
should
never
have
persuaded
them
to
such
