step
.
<EOS>
He
answered
quietly
    
"
I
know
it
.
"
  
<EOS>
I
found
him
a
very
patient
,
very
forbearing
,
and
yet
an
exacting
master
:
he
expected
me
to
do
a
great
deal
;
and
when
I
fulfilled
his
expectations
,
he
,
in
his
own
way
,
fully
testified
his
approbation
.
<EOS>
By
degrees
,
he
acquired
a
certain
influence
over
me
that
took
away
my
liberty
of
mind
:
his
praise
and
notice
were
more
restraining
than
his
indifference
.
<EOS>
I
could
no
longer
talk
or
laugh
freely
when
he
was
by
,
because
a
tiresomely
importunate
instinct
reminded
me
that
vivacity
(
at
least
in
me
)
was
distasteful
to
him
.
<EOS>
I
was
so
fully
aware
that
only
serious
moods
and
occupations
were
acceptable
,
that
in
his
presence
every
effort
to
sustain
or
follow
any
other
became
vain
<EOS>
:
I
fell
under
a
freezing
spell
.
<EOS>
When
he
said
"
go
,
"
I
went
;
"
come
,
"
I
came
;
"
<EOS>
do
this
,
"
I
did
it
.
<EOS>
But
I
did
not
love
my
servitude
:
I
wished
,
many
a
time
,
he
had
continued
to
neglect
me
.
  
<EOS>
One
evening
when
,
at
bedtime
,
his
sisters
and
I
stood
round
him
,
bidding
him
good

night
,
he
kissed
each
of
them
,
as
was
his
custom
;
and
,
as
was
equally
his
custom
,
he
gave
me
his
hand
.
<EOS>
Diana
,
who
chanced
to
be
in
a
frolicsome
humour
<EOS>
(
_
<EOS>
she
_
was
not
painfully
controlled
by
his
will
;
for
hers
,
in
another
way
,
was
as
strong
)
,
exclaimed
    
"
St.
John
!
<EOS>
you
used
to
call
Jane
your
third
sister
,
but
you
do
n't
treat
her
as
such
:
you
should
kiss
her
too
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
She
pushed
me
towards
him
.
<EOS>
I
thought
Diana
very
provoking
,
and
felt
uncomfortably
confused
;
and
while
I
was
thus
thinking
and
feeling
,
St.
John
bent
his
head
;
his
Greek
face
was
brought
to
a
level
with
mine
,
his
eyes
questioned
my
eyes
<EOS>
piercingly
 
he
kissed
me
.
<EOS>
There
are
no
such
things
as
marble
kisses
or
ice
kisses
,
or
I
should
say
my
ecclesiastical
cousin
's
salute
belonged
to
one
of
these
classes
;
but
there
may
be
experiment
kisses
,
and
his
was
an
experiment
kiss
.
<EOS>
When
given
,
he
viewed
me
to
learn
the
result
;
it
was
not
striking
:
I
am
sure
I
did
not
blush
;
perhaps
I
might
have
turned
a
little
pale
,
for
I
felt
as
if
this
kiss
were
a
seal
affixed
to
my
fetters
.
<EOS>
He
never
omitted
the
ceremony
afterwards
,
and
the
gravity
and
quiescence
with
which
I
underwent
it
,
seemed
to
invest
it
for
him
with
a
certain
charm
.
  
<EOS>
As
for
me
,
I
daily
wished
more
to
please
him
;
but
to
do
so
,
I
felt
daily
more
and
more
that
I
must
disown
half
my
nature
,
stifle
half
my
faculties
,
wrest
my
tastes
from
their
original
bent
,
force
myself
to
the
adoption
of
pursuits
for
which
I
had
no
natural
vocation
.
<EOS>
He
wanted
to
train
me
to
an
elevation
I
could
never
reach
;
it
racked
me
hourly
to
aspire
to
the
standard
he
uplifted
.
<EOS>
The
thing
was
as
impossible
as
to
mould
my
irregular
features
to
his
correct
and
classic
pattern
,
to
give
to
my
changeable
green
eyes
the
sea
-
blue
tint
and
solemn
lustre
of
his
own
.
  
<EOS>
Not
his
ascendancy
alone
,
however
,
held
me
in
thrall
at
present
.
<EOS>
Of
late
it
had
been
easy
enough
for
me
to
look
sad
:
a
cankering
evil
sat
at
my
heart
and
drained
my
happiness
at
its
source
 
the
evil
of
suspense
.
  
<EOS>
Perhaps
you
think
I
had
forgotten
Mr.
Rochester
,
reader
,
amidst
these
changes
of
place
and
fortune
.
<EOS>
Not
for
a
moment
.
<EOS>
His
idea
was
still
with
me
,
because
it
was
not
a
vapour
sunshine
could
disperse
,
nor
a
sand
-
traced
effigy
storms
could
wash
away
;
it
was
a
name
graven
on
a
tablet
,
fated
to
last
as
long
as
the
marble
it
inscribed
.
<EOS>
The
craving
to
know
what
had
become
of
him
followed
me
everywhere
;
when
I
was
at
Morton
,
I
re
-
entered
my
cottage
every
evening
to
think
of
that
;
and
now
at
Moor
House
,
I
sought
my
bedroom
each
night
to
brood
over
it
.
  
<EOS>
In
the
course
of
my
necessary
correspondence
with
Mr.
Briggs
about
the
will
,
I
had
inquired
if
he
knew
anything
of
Mr.
Rochester
's
present
residence
and
state
of
health
;
but
,
as
St.
John
had
conjectured
,
he
was
quite
ignorant
of
all
concerning
him
.
<EOS>
I
then
wrote
to
Mrs.
Fairfax
,
entreating
information
on
the
subject
.
<EOS>
I
had
calculated
with
certainty
on
this
step
answering
my
end
:
I
felt
sure
it
would
elicit
an
early
answer
.
<EOS>
I
was
astonished
when
a
fortnight
passed
without
reply
;
but
when
two
months
wore
away
,
and
day
after
day
the
post
arrived
and
brought
nothing
for
me
,
I
fell
a
prey
to
the
keenest
anxiety
.
  
<EOS>
I
wrote
again
:
there
was
a
chance
of
my
first
letter
having
missed
.
<EOS>
Renewed
hope
followed
renewed
effort
:
it
shone
like
the
former
for
some
weeks
,
then
,
like
it
<EOS>
,
it
faded
,
flickered
:
not
<EOS>
a
line
,
not
a
word
reached
me
.
<EOS>
When
half
a
year
wasted
in
vain
expectancy
,
my
hope
died
out
,
and
then
I
felt
dark
indeed
.
  
<EOS>
A
fine
spring
shone
round
me
,
which
I
could
not
enjoy
.
<EOS>
Summer
approached
;
Diana
tried
to
cheer
me
:
she
said
I
looked
ill
,
and
wished
to
accompany
me
to
the
sea
-
side
.
<EOS>
This
St.
John
opposed
;
he
said
I
did
not
want
dissipation
<EOS>
,
I
wanted
employment
;
my
present
life
was
too
purposeless
<EOS>
,
I
required
an
aim
;
and
,
I
suppose
,
by
way
of
supplying
deficiencies
,
he
prolonged
still
further
my
lessons
in
Hindostanee
,
and
grew
more
urgent
in
requiring
their
accomplishment
:
and
I
,
like
a
fool
,
never
thought
of
resisting
him
 
I
could
not
resist
him
.
  
<EOS>
One
day
I
had
come
to
my
studies
in
lower
spirits
than
usual
;
the
ebb
was
occasioned
by
a
poignantly
felt
disappointment
.
<EOS>
Hannah
had
told
me
in
the
morning
there
was
a
letter
for
me
,
and
when
I
went
down
to
take
it
,
almost
certain
that
the
long
-
looked
for
tidings
were
vouchsafed
me
at
last
,
I
found
only
an
unimportant
note
from
Mr.
Briggs
on
business
.
<EOS>
The
bitter
check
had
wrung
from
me
some
tears
;
and
now
,
as
I
sat
poring
over
the
crabbed
characters
and
flourishing
tropes
of
an
Indian
scribe
,
my
eyes
filled
again
.
  
<EOS>
St.
John
called
me
to
his
side
to
read
;
in
attempting
to
do
this
my
voice
failed
me
:
words
were
lost
in
sobs
.
<EOS>
He
and
I
were
the
only
occupants
of
the
parlour
:
<EOS>
Diana
was
practising
her
music
in
the
drawing
-
room
,
Mary
was
gardening
 
<EOS>
it
was
a
very
fine
May
day
,
clear
,
sunny
,
and
breezy
.
<EOS>
My
companion
expressed
no
surprise
at
this
emotion
,
nor
did
he
question
me
as
to
its
cause
;
he
only
said
    
"
We
will
wait
a
few
minutes
,
Jane
,
till
you
are
more
composed
.
"
<EOS>
And
while
I
smothered
the
paroxysm
with
all
haste
,
he
sat
calm
and
patient
,
leaning
on
his
desk
,
and
looking
like
a
physician
watching
with
the
eye
of
science
an
expected
and
fully
understood
crisis
in
a
patient
's
malady
.
<EOS>
Having
stifled
my
sobs
,
wiped
my
eyes
,
and
muttered
something
about
not
being
very
well
that
morning
,
I
resumed
my
task
,
and
succeeded
in
completing
it
.
<EOS>
St.
John
put
away
my
books
and
his
,
locked
his
desk
,
and
said
    
"
Now
,
Jane
,
you
shall
take
a
walk
;
and
with
me
.
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
will
call
Diana
and
Mary
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
No
;
I
want
only
one
companion
this
morning
,
and
that
must
be
you
.
<EOS>
Put
on
your
things
;
go
out
by
the
kitchen
-
door
:
take
the
road
towards
the
head
of
Marsh
Glen
<EOS>
:
I
will
join
you
in
a
moment
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
I
know
no
medium
:
I
never
in
my
life
have
known
any
medium
in
my
dealings
with
positive
,
hard
characters
,
antagonistic
to
my
own
,
between
absolute
submission
and
determined
revolt
.
<EOS>
I
have
always
faithfully
observed
the
one
,
up
to
the
very
moment
of
bursting
,
sometimes
with
volcanic
vehemence
,
into
the
other
;
and
as
neither
present
circumstances
warranted
,
nor
my
present
mood
inclined
me
to
mutiny
,
I
observed
careful
obedience
to
St.
John
's
directions
;
and
in
ten
minutes
I
was
treading
the
wild
track
of
the
glen
,
side
by
side
with
him
.
  
<EOS>
The
breeze
was
from
the
west
:
it
came
over
the
hills
,
sweet
with
scents
of
heath
and
rush
;
the
sky
was
of
stainless
blue
;
the
stream
descending
the
ravine
,
swelled
with
past
spring
rains
,
poured
along
plentiful
and
clear
,
catching
golden
gleams
from
the
sun
,
and
sapphire
tints
from
the
firmament
.
<EOS>
As
we
advanced
and
left
the
track
,
we
trod
a
soft
turf
,
mossy
fine
and
emerald
green
,
minutely
enamelled
with
a
tiny
white
flower
,
and
spangled
with
a
star
-
like
yellow
blossom
:
the
hills
,
meantime
,
shut
us
quite
in
;
for
the
glen
,
towards
its
head
,
wound
to
their
very
core
.
  
<EOS>
"
Let
us
rest
here
,
"
said
St.
John
,
as
we
reached
the
first
stragglers
of
a
battalion
of
rocks
,
guarding
a
sort
of
pass
,
beyond
which
the
beck
rushed
down
a
waterfall
;
and
where
,
still
a
little
farther
,
the
mountain
shook
off
turf
and
flower
,
had
only
heath
for
raiment
and
crag
for
gem
 
where
it
exaggerated
the
wild
to
the
savage
,
and
exchanged
the
fresh
for
the
frowning
 
where
it
guarded
the
forlorn
hope
of
solitude
,
and
a
last
refuge
for
silence
.
  
<EOS>
I
took
a
seat
:
St.
John
stood
near
me
.
<EOS>
He
looked
up
the
pass
and
down
the
hollow
;
his
glance
wandered
away
with
the
stream
,
and
returned
to
traverse
the
unclouded
heaven
which
coloured
it
<EOS>
:
he
removed
his
hat
,
let
the
breeze
stir
his
hair
and
kiss
his
brow
.
<EOS>
He
seemed
in
communion
with
the
genius
of
the
haunt
:
with
his
eye
he
bade
farewell
to
something
.
  
<EOS>
"
And
I
shall
see
it
again
,
"
he
said
aloud
,
"
in
dreams
when
I
sleep
by
the
Ganges
:
and
again
in
a
more
remote
hour
 
when
another
slumber
overcomes
me
 
on
the
shore
of
a
darker
stream
!
"
  
<EOS>
Strange
words
of
a
strange
love
!
<EOS>
An
austere
patriot
's
passion
for
his
fatherland
!
<EOS>
He
sat
down
;
for
half
-
an
-
hour
we
never
spoke
;
neither
he
to
me
nor
I
to
him
:
that
interval
past
,
he
recommenced
    
"
Jane
,
I
go
in
six
weeks
;
I
have
taken
my
berth
in
an
East
Indiaman
which
sails
on
the
20th
of
June
.
<EOS>
"
  
"
God
will
protect
you
;
for
you
have
undertaken
His
work
,
"
I
answered
.
  
<EOS>
"
Yes
,
"
said
he
,
"
there
is
my
glory
and
joy
.
<EOS>
I
am
the
servant
of
an
infallible
Master
.
<EOS>
I
am
not
going
out
under
human
guidance
,
subject
to
the
defective
laws
and
erring
control
of
my
feeble
fellow
-
worms
:
my
king
,
my
lawgiver
,
my
captain
,
is
the
All
-
perfect
.
<EOS>
It
seems
strange
to
me
that
all
round
me
do
not
burn
to
enlist
under
the
same
banner
,
 
to
join
in
the
same
enterprise
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
All
have
not
your
powers
,
and
it
would
be
folly
for
the
feeble
to
wish
to
march
with
the
strong
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
do
not
speak
to
the
feeble
,
or
think

them
:
I
address
only
such
as
are
worthy
of
the
work
,
and
competent
to

it
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Those
are
few
in
number
,
and
difficult

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
You
say
truly
;
but
when
found
,
it
is
right
to
stir
them
up
 
to
urge
and
exhort

to
the
effort
 
to
show

what
their
gifts
are
,
and
why
they
were
given
 
to
speak
Heaven
's
message
in

,
 
to
offer
them
,
direct

God
,
a
place
in

ranks

His

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
If
they
are
really
qualified
for
the
task
,
will
not
their
own
hearts
be
the
first
to
inform

of
it
?
"
  
<EOS>
I
felt
as
if
an
awful
charm
was
framing
round
and
gathering
over
me
:
<EOS>
I
trembled
to
hear
some
fatal
word
spoken
which
would
at
once
declare
and
rivet
the
spell
.
  
<EOS>
"
And
what
does
_
your
_
heart
say
?
"

John
.
  
<EOS>
"
My
heart
is
mute
,
 
<EOS>
my
heart
is
mute
,
"
I
answered
,
struck
and

.
  
<EOS>
"
Then
I
must
speak
for
it
,
"
continued
the
deep
,

.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Jane
,
come
with
me
to
India
:
come
as
my
helpmeet
and
fellow
-
labourer
.
"
  
<EOS>
The
glen

sky
spun
round
:
the
hills
heaved
!
<EOS>
It
was
as
if
I
had
heard
a

from
Heaven
 
as
if
a

,
like

,

enounced
,
"
Come

!
"
<EOS>
But
I
was
no

,
 
<EOS>
I
could
not
behold
the
herald
,
 
<EOS>
I
could
not
receive
his
call
.
  
<EOS>
"
Oh
,
St.
John
!
<EOS>
"
I
cried
,
"
have
some
mercy
!
"
  
<EOS>
I
appealed
to
one
who
,
in
the
discharge
of
what
he
believed
his
duty
,
knew
neither
mercy
nor

.
<EOS>
He
continued
    
"
God
and
nature
intended
you
for
a
missionary
's
wife
.
<EOS>
It
is
not
personal
,
but
mental
endowments
they
have
given
you
:
<EOS>
you
are
formed
for
labour
,
not

.
<EOS>
A
missionary
's
wife
you
must
 
shall
be
.
<EOS>
You
shall
be
mine
<EOS>
:
I
claim
you
 
not
for
my
pleasure
,
but
for
my
Sovereign
's
service
.
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
am
not
fit
for
it
:
I
have
no
vocation
,
"
I
said
.
  
<EOS>
He
had
calculated
on
these
first
objections
:
he
was
not
irritated
by
them
.
<EOS>
Indeed
,
as
he
leaned
back
against
the
crag
behind
him
,
folded
his
arms
on
his
chest
,
and
fixed
his
countenance
,
I
saw
he
was
prepared
for
a
long
and
trying
opposition
,
and
had
taken
in
a
stock
of
patience
to
last
him
to
its
close
 
resolved
,
however
,
that
that
close
should
be
conquest
for
him
.
  
<EOS>
"
Humility
,
Jane
,
"
said
he
,
"
is
the
groundwork
of
Christian
virtues
:
you
say
right
that
you
are
not
fit
for
the
work
.
<EOS>
Who
is
fit
for
it
?
<EOS>
Or
who
,
that
ever
was
truly
called
,
believed
himself
worthy
of
the
summons
?
<EOS>
I
,
for
instance
,
am
but
dust
and
ashes
.
<EOS>
With
St.
Paul
,
I
acknowledge
myself
the
chiefest
of
sinners
;
but
I
do
not
suffer
this
sense
of
my
personal
vileness
to
daunt
me
.
<EOS>
I
know
my
Leader
:
that
He
is
just
as
well
as
mighty
;
and
while
He
has
chosen
a
feeble
instrument
to
perform
a
great
task
,
He
will
,
from
the
boundless
stores
of
His
providence
,
supply
the
inadequacy
of
the
means
to
the
end
.
<EOS>
Think
like
me
,
Jane
 
trust
like
me
.
<EOS>
It
is
the
Rock
of
Ages
<EOS>
I
ask
you
to
lean
on
:
<EOS>
do
not
doubt
<EOS>
but
it
will
bear
the
weight
of
your
human
weakness
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
do
not
understand
a
missionary
life
:
I
have
never
studied
missionary
labours
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
There
I
,
humble
<EOS>
as
I
am
,
can
give
you
the
aid
you
want
:
I
can
set
you
your
task
from
hour
to
hour
;
stand
by
you
always
;
help
you
from
moment
to

.
<EOS>
This
I
could
do
in
the
beginning
:
soon
(

mere
personal
inclination
 
you
will
hasten
to
enter
into
that
union
at
once
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Shall
I
?
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
I
said
briefly
;
and
I
looked
at
his
features
,
beautiful
in
their
harmony
,
but
strangely
formidable
in
their
still

;
at
his

,
commanding

;

,

;
at
his
tall

;
and
fancied
myself
in
idea
_
his
wife
_
.
<EOS>
Oh
!
<EOS>
it
would
never
do
!
<EOS>
As
his
curate
,
his
comrade
,
all

:
I
would

;
toil

,
in

;

;

;

;
discriminate

from

:
profoundly

,

other
.
<EOS>
I
should
suffer
often
,
no

,
attached
to
him
only
in
this

:
my
body
would
be
under
rather

stringent

,
but
my
heart
and
mind
would
be
free
.
<EOS>
I
should
still
have
my
unblighted
self
to
turn
to
:
my
natural
unenslaved
feelings
with
which
to

in

.
<EOS>
There
would

which

,
to

he
never
came
,
and

growing

which

,

:
but
as
his
wife
 
at
his
side
always
,
and
always
restrained
,
and
always
checked
 
forced
to
keep
the
fire
of
my
nature
continually
low
,
to

to
burn
inwardly
and
never

,
though
the
imprisoned
flame
consumed
vital
after

_
<EOS>
this
_
would
be
unendurable
.
  
<EOS>
"
St.
John
!
<EOS>
"
I
exclaimed
,
when
I
had

so

.
  
<EOS>
"
Well
?
"
he

.
  
<EOS>
"
I
repeat

freely

to

as

fellow

,
but
not

wife
;
I
can

and

.
"
  
<EOS>
"
A

of
me
you
must

,
"
he

;
"
otherwise
the
whole
bargain
is
void
.
<EOS>
How

,

India

,
unless

?
<EOS>
How

be
for

sometimes

,

and

?
"
  
<EOS>
"
Very

,
"
I

;
"
under

.
"
  
<EOS>
"

:

<EOS>
And

a
woman

it

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
It

,
"
I

"
perfectly

.
<EOS>
I

a

,

;

nothing

do

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
It
is

I
want
,
"
he

,
speaking

;
"
it
is
just
what
I

.
<EOS>
And

.
<EOS>
Jane
,

<EOS>

;

_
<EOS>

.
<EOS>

:

;

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I

,
"

<EOS>
"
I

you

:
yes
,
St.
John
,
and
I

.
"
  
<EOS>
He

,

well

.
<EOS>
Whether

:
he

.
  
<EOS>
"
I

"

"
I

<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
I

.
  
<EOS>
"
Forgive

;

<EOS>
You

<EOS>
a

<EOS>
:

.
<EOS>
If

?
<EOS>

?
<EOS>

forget

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
No
,
"

;
"

a
long

,

:
<EOS>

<EOS>
To

:

<EOS>
I

<EOS>

<EOS>

.
<EOS>

"
  
<EOS>
He

<EOS>

,
he
once

"

,

<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
But

I

.
<EOS>

:

,

<EOS>
the

:

he

,

.
  
<EOS>
That

,

<EOS>
I
 
<EOS>
who
,

,

was

:

.
  
<EOS>
"
I

"

,
"

<EOS>

;

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
I

:
I

;
and
I
ran

he

.
  
<EOS>
"
Good

,
St.

,
"

"

"

.
  
<EOS>
"
Then

,
"
I

.
  
<EOS>
What

cold
,

touch
,
he
impressed
on
my

!
<EOS>
He
was
deeply
displeased
by
what
had
occurred
that
day
;
cordiality
would
not
warm
,
nor

.
<EOS>
No
happy
reconciliation
was
to

had
with

no
cheering

or

:
but
still
the
Christian
was
patient
and
placid
;
and
when
I
asked

,
he
answered
that
he
was
not
in

cherishing
the

of

;
that
he
had
nothing
to
forgive
,
not
having
been

.
  
<EOS>
And
with
that
answer
he
left
me
.
<EOS>
I
would
much
rather
he
had
knocked
me
down
.
    
<EOS>
He
did
not
leave
for
Cambridge
the
next

,
as
he
had

would
.
<EOS>
He
deferred
his
departure
a
whole
week
,
and
during
that
time
he
made
me
feel
what
severe
punishment
a
good
yet
stern
,
<EOS>
a
conscientious
yet
implacable
man
can
inflict
on
one
who
has
offended
him
.
<EOS>
Without
one
overt
act
of
hostility
,
one

,
he
contrived
to
impress
me
momently
with
the
conviction
that
I
was
put
beyond
the
pale
of
his
favour
.
  
<EOS>
Not
that
St.
John
harboured
a
spirit
of
unchristian
vindictiveness
 
not
that
he
would
have
injured
a
hair
of
my

,
if

had
been

in

to

.
<EOS>
Both
by
nature
and
principle
,
he
was
superior
to

mean

of
vengeance
:
he
had
forgiven

for
saying
I
scorned
him
and
his
love
,
but
he
had
not
forgotten
the
words
;
and
as
long

he
and

he
never
would

them
.
<EOS>
I
saw
by
his

,
when
he

,
that

were
always
written
on
the
air
between

;
whenever
I

,
they
sounded
in
my
voice
to

,
and
their

toned
every
answer
he
gave

.
  
<EOS>
He
did
not
abstain
from
conversing
with
me
:
he
even
called
me
as
usual
each

;
and
I
fear
the
corrupt
man
within
him
had
a
pleasure
unimparted
to
,
and
unshared

,
the
pure
Christian
,
in

with
what

he
could
,
while
acting
and

apparently

usual
,
extract
from
every

and

the
spirit
of
interest
and
approval
which
had
formerly
communicated
a
certain
austere

to
his
language
and

.
<EOS>
To
me
,
he
was
in
reality
become
no
longer

,
but
marble
;
his
eye
was
a
cold
,
bright
,
blue

;
his
tongue
a
speaking

nothing
more
.
  
<EOS>
All
this
was
torture
to
me
 
refined
,
lingering
torture
.
<EOS>
It
kept
up
a
slow
fire
of
indignation
and
a
trembling
trouble
of

,
which
harassed

.
<EOS>
I
felt
how
 
if
I
were
his
wife
,
this
good
man
,
pure
as
the
deep
sunless
source
,
could
soon
kill
me
,
without
drawing

my

a
single

of

,
or
receiving
on
his
own
crystal

the

of
crime
.
<EOS>
Especially
I
felt
this
when
I
made
any
attempt
to
propitiate
him
.
<EOS>
No
ruth
met
my
ruth
.
<EOS>
_
<EOS>
He
_
experienced
no
suffering
from
estrangement
 
<EOS>
no
yearning
after
reconciliation
;
and
though
,
more
than
once
,
my
fast
falling

blistered
the
page
over
which
we
both
bent
,

produced
no
more
effect
on
him
than
if
his
heart
had
been
really

or

.
<EOS>
To
his
sisters
,
meantime
,
he
was
somewhat
kinder
than
usual
:
as
if
afraid
that
mere

would
not
sufficiently

me
how

I
was

and

,
he
added
the
force
of
contrast
;
and
this
I
am
sure
he
did
not
by

,
but
on

.
  
<EOS>
The
night
before
he
left
home
,
happening
to

him
walking
in
the
garden
about

,
and
remembering
,
as
I
looked
at
him
,
that
this
man
,
alienated
as
he
now
was
,
had
once
saved
my

,
and
that
we
were
near

,
I
was
moved
to
make
a
last
attempt
to

his

.
<EOS>
I
went
out
and
approached
him
as
he
stood
leaning
over
the
little
gate
;
I
spoke
to
the
point
at
once
.
  
<EOS>
"
St.
John
,
I
am
unhappy
because
you
are
still
angry
with
me
.
<EOS>
Let
us
be
friends
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
hope
we
are
friends
,
"
was
the
unmoved
reply
;
while
he
still
watched
the
rising
of
the
moon
,
which
he
had
been

as
I
approached
.
  
<EOS>
"
No
,
St.
John
,
we
are
not
friends
as
we
were
.
<EOS>
You
know
that
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Are
we
not
?
<EOS>
That
is
wrong
.
<EOS>
For
my
part
,
I
wish
you
no
ill
and
all
good
.
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
believe
you
,
St.
John
;
for
I
am
sure
you
are
incapable
of
wishing
any
one
ill
;
but
,
as
I
am
your
kinswoman
,
I
should
desire
somewhat
more
of
affection
than
that
sort
of
general
philanthropy
you
extend
to
mere
strangers
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Of
course
,
"
he
said
.
<EOS>
"
Your
wish
is
reasonable
,
and
I
am
far
from
regarding
you
as
a
stranger
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
This
,
spoken
in
a
cool
,
tranquil
tone
,
was
mortifying
and
baffling
enough
.
<EOS>
Had
I
attended
to
the
suggestions
of
pride
and
ire
,
I
should
immediately
have
left
him
;
but
something
worked
within
me
more
strongly
than
those
feelings
could
.
<EOS>
I
deeply
venerated
my
cousin
's
talent
and
principle
.
<EOS>
His
friendship
was
of
value
to
me
:
to
lose
it
tried
me
severely
.
<EOS>
I
would
not
so
soon
relinquish
the
attempt
to
reconquer
it
.
  
<EOS>
"
Must
we
part
in
this
way
,
St.
John
?
<EOS>
And
when
you
go
to
India
,
will
you
leave
me
so
,
without
a
kinder
word
than
you
have
yet
spoken
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
He
now
turned
quite
from
the
moon
and
faced
me
.
  
<EOS>
"
When
I
go
to
India
,
Jane
,
will
I
leave
you
!
<EOS>
What
!
<EOS>
do
you
not
go
to
India
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
You
said
I
could
not
unless
I
married
you
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
And
you
will
not
marry
me
!
<EOS>
You
adhere
to
that
resolution
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
Reader
,
do
you
know
,
as
I
do
,
what
terror
those
cold
people
can
put
into
the
ice
of
their
questions
?
<EOS>
How
much
of
the
fall
of
the
avalanche
is
in
their
anger
?
<EOS>
of
the
breaking
up
of
the
frozen
sea
in
their

?
  
<EOS>
"
No
.
St.
John
,
I
will
not
marry
you
.
<EOS>
I
adhere
to
my
resolution
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
The
avalanche
had
shaken
and
slid
a
little
forward
,
but
it
did
not
yet
crash
down
.
  
<EOS>
"
Once
more
,
why
this
refusal
?
"
<EOS>
he

.
  
<EOS>
"
Formerly
,
"
I
answered
,
"
because
you
did
not
love
me
;
now
,
I
reply
,
because
you
almost
hate
me
.
<EOS>
If
I
were
to
marry
you
,
you
would
kill
me
.
<EOS>
You
are
killing
me
now
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
His
lips
and
cheeks
turned
white
 
quite
white
.
  
<EOS>
"
_
I
should
kill
you
_
 
<EOS>
_
I
am
killing
you
_
?
<EOS>
Your
words
are
such
as
ought
not
to
be
used
:
violent
,
unfeminine
,
and
untrue
.
<EOS>
They
betray
an
unfortunate
state
of
mind
:
they
merit
severe
reproof
:
they
would
seem
inexcusable
,
but
that
it
is
the
duty
of
man
to
forgive
his
fellow
even
until
seventy
-
and
-
seven
times
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
I
had
finished
the
business
now
.
<EOS>
While

wishing
to
erase
from
his
mind
the
trace
of
my
former

,
I
had
stamped
on
that

another
and
far

impression
,
I
had
burnt
it
in
.
  
<EOS>
"
Now
you
will
indeed
hate

,
"
I
said
.
<EOS>
"
It
is
useless
to
attempt
to
conciliate
you
:
<EOS>
I
see
I
have
made
an

of

.
"
  
<EOS>
A
fresh
wrong
did
these
words
inflict
:
<EOS>
the
worse
,
because
they
touched
on
the
truth
.
<EOS>
That
bloodless
lip
quivered
to
a
temporary

.
<EOS>
I
knew
the
steely
ire
I
had
whetted
.
<EOS>
I
was
heart
-

.
  
<EOS>
"
You
utterly
misinterpret
my
words
,
"
I
said
,
at
once

his
hand
:
"
I
have
no
intention
to
grieve
or
pain
you
 
indeed
,
I
have
not
.
"
  
<EOS>
Most

he
smiled
 
most
decidedly
<EOS>
he
withdrew
his
hand
from
mine
.
<EOS>
"
And
now
you
recall
your
promise
,
and
will

,
I

?
"
<EOS>
said

,

.
  
<EOS>
"
Yes
,
I
will
,
as
your

,
"
I
answered
.
  
<EOS>
A

succeeded
.
<EOS>
What

there
was
in
him
between
Nature
and
Grace
in
this

,
I
can
not

:
only
singular

in

,

passed

.
<EOS>
He
spoke
at
last
.
  
<EOS>
"
I
before
proved
to
you
the
absurdity
of
a
single
woman
of
your

proposing
to

a

.
<EOS>
I

to

in
such

as
,
I
should

thought
,
would
have
prevented
your
ever
again

.
<EOS>
That
you
have
done
so
<EOS>
,
I
regret
 
for
your

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
I
interrupted
him
.
<EOS>
Anything
like
a
tangible
reproach
gave
me

at

.
<EOS>
"
Keep
to
common

,
St.
John
:
you
are
verging

.
<EOS>
You
pretend
to
be
shocked
by
what
I
have
said
.
<EOS>
You
are

shocked
:
for
,

,

can
not

as

.
<EOS>
I
say
again
,
I
will

your

,

,
but
never
your
wife
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
Again
he
turned
lividly
pale
;
but
,
as

,
controlled
his
passion
perfectly
.
<EOS>
He
answered
emphatically
but
calmly
    
"
A
female
curate
,
who
is
not
my
wife
,
would
never
suit
me
.
<EOS>
With
me
,
then
,
it
seems
,
you
can
not

:
<EOS>
but
if
you
are
sincere
in

,
I
will
,
while
in

,
speak
to
a
married

,
whose
wife
needs
a

.
<EOS>
Your
own

will
make
you
independent
of
the
Society
's

;
and
thus
you
may
still
be
spared
the

of
breaking
your

and

you

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
Now
I
never
had
,
as
the
reader
knows
,
either

or
entered
into
any

;
and
this

was
all
much

.
<EOS>
I
replied
    
"
There
is
no

,
no

,
no

in
the

.
<EOS>
I
am
not
under

to

to
India
,

.
<EOS>
With
you
I
would
have
ventured
much
,
because
I

,

,
and
,
as

;

I

that
,
go
when

,
I

not

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Ah
!
<EOS>
you
are
afraid
of

,
"
he
said
,

.
  
<EOS>
"
I
am
.
<EOS>
God
did
not
give
me
my
life
to

;
and

do

you
wish

,
I

,

.
<EOS>
Moreover
,

England
,
I
will

whether
I
can

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
What

you
mean
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
It
would
be
fruitless
to
attempt
to

;
but
there
is
a

on

I
have
long
endured
painful
doubt
,
and
I
can
go
nowhere
till

some

that
doubt
is
removed
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
know
where
your
heart
turns
and
to

.
<EOS>
The
interest
you
cherish
is
lawless
and

.
<EOS>
Long
since
you
ought
to
have
crushed
it
:
now
you
should
blush

.
<EOS>
You
think

Mr.
Rochester
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
It
was
true
.
<EOS>
I

.
  
<EOS>
"
Are

Rochester
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I

.
"
  
<EOS>
"
It

"

.
<EOS>
I

recognised

one
of

.
<EOS>
But
God
sees
not
as
man

:
<EOS>
_
<EOS>
His
_
will
be
done
 
"
  
<EOS>
He

,
passed

,
and

.
<EOS>
He

.
  
<EOS>
On

-

the

,
I

,

.
<EOS>
Diana

:
she

,

,

.
  
<EOS>
"
Jane
,
"
she

,
"
you
are
always

.
<EOS>
I

something
the

.
<EOS>

St.

.
<EOS>
I

this

;

,
but

.
<EOS>
St.
John

<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
She

<EOS>
I

:
soon

resumed
    
"
That
brother
of
mine
cherishes
peculiar

of
some

respecting

,

:
he
has

distinguished

by

never

to

?
<EOS>
I

he
loved

<EOS>
does

,

?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
I

her
cool

hot

;
"
No
,
Die
,
not

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Then

<EOS>
Mary

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
He
does
 
<EOS>
he

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>

.
<EOS>
"

<EOS>

,

,

<EOS>

.
<EOS>
"

;

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"

?
<EOS>
"
  
"
<EOS>
Yes
.
"
  
"
Madness
!
"
<EOS>

.
<EOS>
"

,

.
<EOS>
You

:

?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
have

"
  
"
And

?
"

.
  
<EOS>
"
Deeply
:
he
will

,

:
<EOS>

<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
It

,

.
<EOS>
Think

you

one

,

,

.
<EOS>
St.
John
 
you

him

:

;

.
<EOS>
I

.
<EOS>

<EOS>
"

<EOS>

"

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
And

,

.
<EOS>
We

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Plain
!
<EOS>
You
?
<EOS>
Not

.
<EOS>
You

,

,

in
Calcutta
.
"
<EOS>
And

.
  
<EOS>
"
I

,
"
I

;
"

,

expressed

.
<EOS>
He

unmarried
:

,

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
What

,

?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
You
should

himself

.
<EOS>
He

again

,

.
<EOS>
He

I

:

,

.
<EOS>
But
,

,

,

I

.
<EOS>
Would

,
Die
,

a
man
who
regarded
one
but

?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Insupportable
 
unnatural
 
out
of
the

!
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
And

,
"
I

,
"

,

,

,

kind

love
for
him
,
because

so

;
and

<EOS>
In

,

.
<EOS>
He

;

,

,

.
<EOS>
I

.
<EOS>
"
  
"
<EOS>
And

"

.
  
<EOS>
"

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

He

For

"

<EOS>

The

"

He

<EOS>
He

<EOS>
All

<EOS>

"

?

!
<EOS>
Jane
!
<EOS>
Jane
!
"

?
"

!

?

back
 
<EOS>
"
Where

?
<EOS>
"

The

<EOS>
"

<EOS>
"

<EOS>

,

no

.

"

,

<EOS>

_

.
<EOS>
_

_

.
<EOS>
I

<EOS>
He

.
<EOS>
Where

.
<EOS>
I

.
<EOS>
I

;

His
feet
.
<EOS>
I
rose
from
the
thanksgiving
 
<EOS>
took
a
resolve
 
and
lay
down
,
unscared
,
enlightened
 
<EOS>
eager
but
for
the
daylight
.
    
<EOS>
The
daylight
came
.
<EOS>
I
rose
at
dawn
.
<EOS>
I
busied
myself
for
an
hour

two
with

in
my

,
drawers

and

in
the

wherein

should
wish

during
a
brief

.
<EOS>
Meantime
,
I
heard
St.
John
quit
his
room
.
<EOS>
He
stopped
at
my
door
:
I
feared
he
would
knock
 
<EOS>
no
,
but
a
slip
of
paper
was
passed
under

.
<EOS>
I
took
it
up
.
<EOS>
It
bore
these
words
    
<EOS>
"
You
left
me
too
suddenly
last
night
.
<EOS>
Had

but

,
you
would

's

and

.
<EOS>
I

when

return
this

fortnight
.
<EOS>
Meantime
,
watch
and
pray
that
you
enter
not
into

:
the

,
I

,

,
but

,
I

,

.
<EOS>
I
shall

hourly
.
 
<EOS>
Yours
,
ST
.
JOHN
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
My
spirit
,
"
I
answered
mentally
,
"
is
willing
to
do
what
is
right
;
and
my
flesh
<EOS>
,
I
hope
,
is
strong
enough
to

,

.
<EOS>
At

,

shall

search
 
inquire

an

this

of

,
and

open

of

.
"
  
<EOS>
It
was
the
first
of

;
yet

was

and

<EOS>
:

.
<EOS>
I

.
<EOS>

.
<EOS>
He

Whitcross
 
there

.
  
<EOS>
"
In

"

"

.
<EOS>

<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
It
wanted
yet

.
<EOS>
I

in

,

which
had

.
<EOS>
I

:
for

,

.
<EOS>

.
<EOS>

<EOS>

?
<EOS>
I

.
<EOS>

;

,

;

"

"

.
<EOS>

no

personal

.
"
  
<EOS>

<EOS>
"

"

<EOS>
"

news
of

<EOS>

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
They

,

,

<EOS>
I

,

.
<EOS>
I

,
that

.
  
<EOS>
It

;

.
<EOS>

<EOS>

,

<EOS>

whence

,

<EOS>
how

,

<EOS>

<EOS>
I
entered
 
not

.
<EOS>
Once

<EOS>
It

.
<EOS>
I

,

(

!
)
<EOS>
met

.
<EOS>
Yes
,

:

.
  
<EOS>
"

?

"

.
  
<EOS>

,

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"

,

.
<EOS>
"

.
<EOS>
It

:

:
    
<EOS>
"

,

<EOS>

<EOS>

.
<EOS>

Hall

.
<EOS>
There

<EOS>

!

<EOS>

<EOS>

;

;

.
<EOS>
Strange

:

.
<EOS>
Another

crossed
 
a

<EOS>
and

<EOS>

:
<EOS>
the

,

.
<EOS>
"

"

"

,

:

:

<EOS>

<EOS>
but

<EOS>

.
<EOS>
And

?
<EOS>

!
<EOS>

?
<EOS>

<EOS>
I

:

,

<EOS>
"

:

,

<EOS>

:

.
  
<EOS>
The

.
<EOS>
I
wonder

they
thought
.
<EOS>
They
must
have
considered
I
was
very

,

.
<EOS>
A

.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
What

was

?
<EOS>
"
they
might

demanded
;
"
what
stupid

now
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
Hear
an

,
reader
.
  
<EOS>
A
lover
finds

;

to

fair

.
<EOS>
He
steals

over

,
careful
to

no

;
he
pauses
 
fancying
she
has
stirred
:
he
withdraws
:
not
for
worlds
would
he
be
seen
.
<EOS>
All
is
still
:
he
again

:

;
a

on

features
<EOS>
:

,

;

of

warm
,
and

,
and
lovely
,
in

.
<EOS>
How
hurried
was
their
first

!
<EOS>
But

they
fix
!
<EOS>
How
he
starts
!
<EOS>
How

suddenly

the

dared
not
,
a

since
,
touch

!
<EOS>
How

calls
aloud

,
and
drops

,
and

!
<EOS>
He
thus

and

,
and

,
because
he
no

to
waken

any

he
can
utter

any

can

.
<EOS>
He
thought

love
slept
sweetly
:
he
finds

is
stone
dead
.
  
<EOS>
I
looked
with
timorous
joy
towards
a

house
:
I
saw
a

.
  
<EOS>
No

,

!
 
<EOS>
to

,
fearing

was
astir
behind

!
<EOS>
No
need
to
listen
for
doors
opening
 
to

steps
on
the

or

-

!
<EOS>
The
lawn
,

were
trodden
and

:

.
<EOS>
The
front
was
,
as

,
but

,

?
<EOS>
"
I

.
<EOS>
"

?
"
  
<EOS>
"
Ay
 
<EOS>
ay
 
<EOS>
he

;
he
ca

England
<EOS>
,

fancy
 
<EOS>

<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
What

!
<EOS>

.
  
<EOS>
"

<EOS>
"

,

<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>
I

.
  
<EOS>
"

<EOS>

<EOS>
He

"
  
<EOS>
"

?

<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"

"

<EOS>
"

:

.
<EOS>
He

<EOS>
"

<EOS>
"

"

<EOS>
The

was

,

,

.
<EOS>
I

heard
of

.
<EOS>
Mr.
Rochester
often

,
and
sometimes

.
<EOS>
His

.
<EOS>
He

,
but

.
<EOS>
Ferndean
then

<EOS>
To

just
ere
dark

small

.
<EOS>
The

<EOS>
Even

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>
The

<EOS>

<EOS>
I

<EOS>

,

<EOS>

<EOS>
The

"

"

<EOS>

.
<EOS>

<EOS>

.
  
<EOS>
And
,

,

?
 
<EOS>
if

little

.
<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

"
  
<EOS>

"

<EOS>
John

.
<EOS>
Mr.

:
vainly
,
 
all

.
<EOS>
He

,

,

.
  
<EOS>
I

:
<EOS>

.
"
<EOS>
Mary
,
"

,

?
"
  
<EOS>

<EOS>
To

<EOS>
"

<EOS>
"

,
"

This

!
"

<EOS>

<EOS>

?
<EOS>

?
"
<EOS>

_

"

"

<EOS>
"
Will

?
<EOS>
I

,
"

<EOS>
"
_
<EOS>
Who
_

?
<EOS>
_

<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Pilot

,

.

.
  
<EOS>
"
Great

!
 
<EOS>
what

?
<EOS>

?
"
  
<EOS>
"
No

<EOS>

:

your

<EOS>
"

"

?
<EOS>

<EOS>
Oh

<EOS>
I
_

_

,

.
<EOS>
Whatever
 
whoever
you
are
 
be

touch

I
can

!
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
He

.
  
<EOS>
"
Her
very
fingers
!
"
<EOS>

"
her

!
<EOS>
If

neck

"

?

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Because
I
had
come
in
,
in
Mary
's
stead
,
with
the
tray
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
And
there
is
enchantment
in
the
very
hour
I
am
now
spending
with
you
.
<EOS>
Who
can
tell
what
a
dark
,
dreary
,
hopeless
life
I
have
dragged
on
for
months
past
?
<EOS>
Doing
nothing
,
expecting
nothing
;
merging
night
in
day
;
feeling
but
the
sensation
of
cold
when
I
let
the
fire
go
out
,
of
hunger
when
I
forgot
to
eat
:
and
then
a
ceaseless
sorrow
,
and
,
at
times
,
a
very
delirium
of
desire
to
behold
my
Jane
again
.
<EOS>
Yes
:
for
her
restoration
I
longed
,
far
more
than
for
that
of
my
lost
sight
.
<EOS>
How
can
it
be
that
Jane
is
with
me
,
and
says
she
loves
me
?
<EOS>
Will
she
not
depart
as
suddenly
as
she
came
?
<EOS>
To
-
morrow
,
I
fear
I
shall
find
her
no
more
.
"
  
<EOS>
A
commonplace
,
practical
reply
,
out
of
the
train
of
his
own
disturbed
ideas
,
was
,
I
was
sure
,
the
best
and
most
reassuring
for
him
in
this
frame
of
mind
.
<EOS>
I
passed
my
finger
over
his
eyebrows
,
and
remarked
that
they
were
scorched
,
and
that
I
would
apply
something
which
would
make
them
grow
as
broad
and
black
as
ever
.
  
<EOS>
"
Where
is
the
use
of
doing
me
good
in
any
way
,
beneficent
spirit
,
when
,
at
some
fatal
moment
,
you
will
again
desert
me
 
passing
like
a
shadow
,
whither
and
how
to
me
unknown
,
and
for
me
remaining
afterwards
undiscoverable
?
  
<EOS>
"
Have
you
a
pocket
-
comb
about
you
,
sir
?
"
  
<EOS>
"
What
for
,
Jane
?
"
  
<EOS>
"
Just
to
comb
out
this
shaggy
black
mane
.
<EOS>
I
find
you
rather
alarming
,
when
I
examine
you
close
at
hand
:
you
talk
of
my
being
a
fairy
,
but
I
am
sure
,
you
are
more
like
a
brownie
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Am
I
hideous
,
Jane
?
"
  
<EOS>
"
Very
,
sir
:
you
always
were
,
you
know
.
"
  
<EOS>
"
Humph
!
<EOS>
The
wickedness
has
not
been
taken
out
of
you
,
wherever
you
have
sojourned
.
"
  
<EOS>
"
Yet
I
have
been
with
good
people
;
far
better
than
you
:
a
hundred
times
better
people
;
possessed
of
ideas
and
views
<EOS>
you
never
entertained
in
your
life
:
quite
more
refined
and
exalted
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Who
the
deuce
have
you
been
with
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
If
you
twist
in
that
way
you
will
make
me
pull
the
hair
out
of
your
head
;
and
then
I
think
you
will
cease
to
entertain
doubts
of
my
substantiality
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Who
have
you
been
with
,
Jane
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
You
shall
not
get
it
out
of
me
to
-
night
,
sir
;
you
must
wait
till
to
-
morrow
;
to
leave
my
tale
half
told
,
will
,
you
know
,
be
a
sort
of
security
that
I
shall
appear
at
your
breakfast
table
to
finish
it
.
<EOS>
By
the
bye
,
I
must
mind
not
to
rise
on
your
hearth
with
only
a
glass
of
water
then
:
I
must
bring
an
egg
at
the
least
,
to
say
nothing
of
fried
ham
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
You
mocking
changeling
 
fairy
-
born
and
human
-
bred
!
<EOS>
You
make
me
feel
as
I
have
not
felt
these
twelve
months
.
<EOS>
If
Saul
could
have
had
you
for
his
David
,
the
evil
spirit
would
have
been
exorcised
without
the
aid
of
the
harp
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
There
,
sir
,
you
are
redd
up
and
made
decent
.
<EOS>
Now
I
'll
leave
you
:
I
have
been
travelling
these
last
three
days
,
and
I
believe
I
am
tired
.
<EOS>
Good
night
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Just
one
word
,
Jane
:
were
there
only
ladies
in
the
house
where
you
have
been
?
"
  
<EOS>
I
laughed
and
made
my
escape
,
still
laughing
as
I
ran
upstairs
.
<EOS>
"
A
good
idea
!
<EOS>
"
I
thought
with
glee
.
<EOS>
"
I
see
I
have
the
means
of
fretting
him
out
of
his
melancholy
for
some
time
to
come
.
"
  
<EOS>
Very
early
the
next
morning
I
heard
him
up
and
astir
,
wandering
from
one
room
to
another
.
<EOS>
As
soon
as
Mary
came
down
I
heard
the
question
:
"
Is
Miss
Eyre
here
?
"
<EOS>
Then
:
"
Which
room
did
you
put
her
into
?
<EOS>
Was
it
dry
?
<EOS>
Is
she
up
?
<EOS>
Go
and
ask
if
she
wants
anything
;
and
when
she
will
come
down
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
I
came
down
as
soon
as
I
thought
there
was
a
prospect
of
breakfast
.
<EOS>
Entering
the
room
very
softly
,
I
had
a
view
of
him
before
he
discovered
my
presence
.
<EOS>
It
was
mournful
,
indeed
,
to
witness
the
subjugation
of
that
vigorous
spirit
to
a
corporeal
infirmity
.
<EOS>
He
sat
in
his
chair
 
still
,
but
not
at
rest
:
expectant
evidently
;
the
lines
of
now
habitual
sadness
marking
his
strong
features
.
<EOS>
His
countenance
reminded
one
of
a
lamp
quenched
,
waiting
to
be
re
-
lit
 
and
alas
!
<EOS>
it
was
not
himself
that
could
now
kindle
the
lustre
of
animated
expression
:
he
was
dependent
on
another
for
that
office
!
<EOS>
I
had
meant
to
be
gay
and
careless
,
but
the
powerlessness
of
the
strong
man
touched
my
heart
to
the
quick
:
still
I
accosted
him
with
what
vivacity
I
could
.
  
<EOS>
"
It
is
a
bright
,
sunny
morning
,
sir
,
"
I
said
.
<EOS>
"
The
rain
is
over
and
gone
,
and
there
is
a
tender
shining
after
it
:
you
shall
have
a
walk
soon
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
I
had
wakened
the
glow
:
his
features
beamed
.
  
<EOS>
"
Oh
,
you
are
indeed
there
,
my
skylark
!
<EOS>
Come
to
me
.
<EOS>
You
are
not
gone
:
not
vanished
?
<EOS>
I
heard
one
of
your
kind
an
hour
ago
,
singing
high
over
the
wood
:
but
its
song
had
no
music
for
me
,
any
more
than
the
rising
sun
had
rays
.
<EOS>
All
the
melody
on
earth
is
concentrated
in
my
Jane
's
tongue
to
my
ear
<EOS>
(
I
am
glad
it
is
not
naturally
a
silent
one
)
:
<EOS>
all
the
sunshine
I
can
feel
is
in
her
presence
.
"
  
<EOS>
The
water
stood
in
my
eyes
to
hear
this
avowal
of
his
dependence
;
just
as
if
a
royal
eagle
,
chained
to
a
perch
,
should
be
forced
to
entreat
a
sparrow
to
become
its
purveyor
.
<EOS>
But
I
would
not
be
lachrymose
:
I
dashed
off
the
salt
drops
,
and
busied
myself
with
preparing
breakfast
.
  
<EOS>
Most
of
the
morning
was
spent
in
the
open
air
.
<EOS>
I
led
him
out
of
the
wet
and
wild
wood
into
some
cheerful
fields
:
I
described
to
him
how
brilliantly
green
they
were
;
how
the
flowers
and
hedges
looked
refreshed
;
how
sparklingly
blue
was
the
sky
.
<EOS>
I
sought
a
seat
for
him
in
a
hidden
and
lovely
spot
,
a
dry
stump
of
a
tree
;
nor
did
I
refuse
to
let
him
,
when
seated
,
place
me
on
his
knee
.
<EOS>
Why
should
I
,
when
both
he
and
I
were
happier
near
than
apart
?
<EOS>
Pilot
lay
beside
us
:
all
was
quiet
.
<EOS>
He
broke
out
suddenly
while
clasping
me
in
his
arms
    
"
Cruel
,
cruel
deserter
!
<EOS>
Oh
,
Jane
,
what
did
I
feel
when
I
discovered
you
had
fled
from
Thornfield
,
and
when
I
could
nowhere
find
you
;
and
,
after
examining
your
apartment
,
ascertained
that
you
had
taken
no
money
,
nor
anything
which
could
serve
as
an
equivalent
!
<EOS>
A
pearl
necklace
I
had
given
you
lay
untouched
in
its
little
casket
;
your
trunks
were
left
corded
and
locked
as
they
had
been
prepared
for
the
bridal
tour
.
<EOS>
What
could
my
darling
do
,
I
asked
,
left
destitute
and
penniless
?
<EOS>
And
what
did
she
do
?
<EOS>
Let
me
hear
now
.
"
  
<EOS>
Thus
urged
,
I
began
the
narrative
of
my
experience
for
the
last
year
.
<EOS>
I
softened
considerably
what
related
to
the
three
days
of
wandering
and
starvation
,
because
to
have
told
him
all
would
have
been
to
inflict
unnecessary
pain
:
the
little
I
did
say
lacerated
his
faithful
heart
deeper
than
I
wished
.
  
<EOS>
I
should
not
have
left
him
thus
,
he
said
,
without
any
means
of
making
my
way
:
I
should
have
told
him
my
intention
.
<EOS>
I
should
have
confided
in
him
:
he
would
never
have
forced
me
to
be
his
mistress
.
<EOS>
Violent
as
he
had
seemed
in
his
despair
,
he
,
in
truth
,
loved
me
far
too
well
and
too
tenderly
to
constitute
himself
my
tyrant
:
he
would
have
given
me
half
his
fortune
,
without
demanding
so
much
as
a
kiss
in
return
,
rather
than
I
should
have
flung
myself
friendless
on
the
wide
world
.
<EOS>
I
had
endured
,
he
was
certain
,
more
than
I
had
confessed
to
him
.
  
<EOS>
"
Well
,
whatever
my
sufferings
had
been
,
they
were
very
short
,
"
I
answered
:
and
then
I
proceeded
to
tell
him
how
I
had
been
received
at
Moor
House
;
how
I
had
obtained
the
office
of
schoolmistress
,
&
<EOS>
c.
The
accession
of
fortune
,
the
discovery
of
my
relations
,
followed
in
due
order
.
<EOS>
Of
course
,
St.
John
Rivers
'
name
came
in
frequently
in
the
progress
of
my
tale
.
<EOS>
When
I
had
done
,
that
name
was
immediately
taken
up
.
  
<EOS>
"
This
St.
John
,
then
,
is
your
cousin
?
<EOS>
"
  
"
<EOS>
Yes
.
"
  
<EOS>
"
You
have
spoken
of
him
often
:
do
you
like
him
?
"
  
<EOS>
"
He
was
a
very
good
man
,
sir
;
I
could
not
help
liking
him
.
"
  
"
<EOS>
A
good
man
.
<EOS>
Does
that
mean
a
respectable
well
-
conducted
man
of
fifty
?
<EOS>
Or
what
does
it
mean
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
St
John
was
only
twenty
-
nine
,
sir
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
"
_
Jeune
encore
_
,
"
as
the
French
say
.
<EOS>
Is
he
a
person
of
low
stature
,
phlegmatic
,
and
plain
.
<EOS>
A
person
whose
goodness
consists
rather
in
his
guiltlessness
of
vice
,
than
in
his
prowess
in
virtue
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
He
is
untiringly
active
.
<EOS>
Great
and
exalted
deeds
are
what
he
lives
to
perform
.
<EOS>
"
  
"
<EOS>
But
his
brain
?
<EOS>
That
is
probably
rather
soft
?
<EOS>
He
means
well
:
but
you
shrug
your
shoulders
to
hear
him
talk
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
He
talks
little
,
sir
:
what
he
does
say
is
ever
to
the
point
.
<EOS>
His
brain
is
first
-
rate
,
I
should
think
not
impressible
,
but
vigorous
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Is
he
an
able
man
,
then
?
"
  
<EOS>
"
Truly
able
.
"
  
<EOS>
"
A
thoroughly
educated
man
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
St.
John
is
an
accomplished
and
profound
scholar
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
His
manners
,
I
think
,
you
said
are
not
to
your
taste
?
 
<EOS>
priggish
and
parsonic
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
never
mentioned
his
manners
;
but
,
unless
I
had
a
very
bad
taste
,
they
must
suit
it
;
they
are
polished
,
calm
,
and
gentlemanlike
.
"
  
<EOS>
"
His
appearance
,
 
I
forget
what
description
you
gave
of
his
appearance
;
 
a
sort
of
raw
curate
,
half
strangled
with
his
white
neckcloth
,
and
stilted
up
on
his
thick
-
soled
high
-
lows
,
eh
?
"
  
<EOS>
"
St.
John
dresses
well
.
<EOS>
He
is
a
handsome
man
:
tall
,
fair
,
with
blue
eyes
,
and
a
Grecian
profile
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
(
Aside
.
)
<EOS>
"
Damn
him
!
"
 
<EOS>
(
To
me
.
)
<EOS>
"
Did
you
like
him
,
Jane
?
"
  
<EOS>
"
Yes
,
Mr.
Rochester
,
I
liked
him
:
but
you
asked
me
that
before
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
I
perceived
,
of
course
,
the
drift
of
my
interlocutor
.
<EOS>
Jealousy
had
got
hold
of
him
:
she
stung
him
;
but
the
sting
was
salutary
:
it
gave
him
respite
from
the
gnawing
fang
of
melancholy
.
<EOS>
I
would
not
,
therefore
,
immediately
charm
the
snake
.
  
<EOS>
"
Perhaps
you
would
rather
not
sit
any
longer
on
my
knee
,
Miss
Eyre
?
<EOS>
"
was
the
next
somewhat
unexpected
observation
.
  
<EOS>
"
Why
not
,
Mr.
Rochester
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
The
picture
you
have
just
drawn
is
suggestive
of
a
rather
too
overwhelming
contrast
.
<EOS>
Your
words
have
delineated
very
prettily
a
graceful
Apollo
:
he
is
present
to
your
imagination
,
 
tall
,
fair
,
blue-
eyed
,
and
with
a
Grecian
profile
.
<EOS>
Your
eyes
dwell
on
a
Vulcan
,
 
a
real
blacksmith
,
brown
,
broad
-
shouldered
:
and
blind
and
lame
into
the
bargain
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
never
thought
of
it
,
before
;
but
you
certainly
are
rather
like
Vulcan
,
sir
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Well
,
you
can
leave
me
,
ma'am
:
<EOS>
but
before
you
go
"
(
and
he
retained
me
by
a
firmer
grasp
than
ever
)
,
"
you
will
be
pleased
just
to
answer
me
a
question
or
two
.
"
<EOS>
He
paused
.
  
<EOS>
"
What
questions
,
Mr.
Rochester
?
"
  
Then
followed
this
cross
-
examination
.
  
<EOS>
"
St.
John
made
you
schoolmistress
of
Morton
before
he
knew
you
were
his
cousin
?
<EOS>
"
  
"
<EOS>
Yes
.
"
  
<EOS>
"
You
would
often
see
him
?
<EOS>
He
would
visit
the
school
sometimes
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Daily
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
He
would
approve
of
your
plans
,
Jane
?
<EOS>
I
know
they
would
be
clever
,
for
you
are
a
talented
creature
!
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
He
approved
of
them
 
yes
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
He
would
discover
many
things
in
you
<EOS>
he
could
not
have
expected
to
find
?
<EOS>
Some
of

are
not
ordinary
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
do
n't
know
about
that
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
You
had
a
little
cottage
near
the
school
,
you
say
:
did
he
ever
come
there
to
see
you
?
<EOS>
"
  
"
<EOS>
Now
and
then
?
"
  
"
Of
an
evening
?
"
  
<EOS>
"
Once
or
twice
.
"
  
<EOS>
A
pause
.
  
<EOS>
"
How
long
did
you
reside
with
him
and
his
sisters
after
the
cousinship
was
discovered
?
"
  
"
Five
months
.
<EOS>
"
  
"
Did
Rivers
spend
much

with
the
ladies
of
his
family
?
"
  
"
Yes
;
the
back
parlour
was
both
his
study
and
ours
:
he
sat
near
the
window
,
and
we
by
the
table
.
"
  
<EOS>
"
Did
he
study
much
?
"
  
<EOS>
"
A
good
deal
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
What
?
"
  
"
Hindostanee
.
"
  
<EOS>
"
And
what
did
you
do
meantime
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
learnt
German
,
at

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Did
he
teach
you
?
"
  
<EOS>
"
He
did
not

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Did
he

nothing
?
"
  
"
<EOS>
A
little
Hindostanee
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Rivers

Hindostanee
?
"
  
<EOS>
"
Yes
,

.
"
  
<EOS>
"
And

?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
No
.
"
  
<EOS>
"
Only
you
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Only
me
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Did
you
ask
to
learn
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
No
.
"
  
<EOS>
"
He
wished
to

?
"
  
<EOS>
"
Yes
.
"
  
<EOS>
A
second
pause
.
  
<EOS>
"
Why
did
he
wish
it
?
<EOS>
Of
what
use
could
Hindostanee
be
to
you
?
"
  
<EOS>
"
He
intended
me
to
go
with
him
to

.
<EOS>
"
  
"
<EOS>
Ah
!
<EOS>
here

reach
the

of

matter
.
<EOS>
He
wanted
you
to
marry
him
?
"
  
<EOS>
"
He
asked
me
to
marry
him
.
"
  
<EOS>
"
That
is
a
fiction
 
an
impudent
invention
to
vex
me
.
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
beg
your
pardon
,
it
is
the
literal
truth
:
he
asked
me
more
than
once
,
and
was
as
stiff
about
urging
his
point
as
ever
<EOS>
you
could
be
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Miss
Eyre
,
I
repeat
it
,
you
can
leave
me
.
<EOS>
How
often
am
I
to
say
the
same
thing
?
<EOS>
Why
do
you
remain
pertinaciously
perched
on
my

,
when
I
have
given
you

to
quit
?
"
  
<EOS>
"
Because
I
am
comfortable
there
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
No
,
Jane
,
you
are
not
comfortable
there
,
because
your
heart
is
not
with
me
:
it
is
with
this
cousin
 
<EOS>
this
St.
John
.
<EOS>
Oh
,
till
this

,
I
thought
my
little
Jane
was
all

!
<EOS>
I
had
a
belief
she
loved
me
even
when
she
left
me
:
that
was
an
atom
of
sweet
in
much
bitter
.
<EOS>
Long
as
we
have
been
parted
,
hot

as
I
have
wept
over
our
separation
<EOS>
,
I
never
thought
that
while
I
was

her
,
she
was
loving
another
!
<EOS>
But
it
is
useless
grieving
.
<EOS>
Jane
,
leave
me
:
go
and
marry
Rivers
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Shake

,
then
,

,
 
push

,
for

'll

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Jane
,
I
ever
like
your
tone
of
voice
:
it
still
renews
hope
<EOS>
,
it

so

.
<EOS>
When

,

carries

.
<EOS>
I
forget
that
you
have
formed

new

.
<EOS>
But
I
am
not
a
fool
 
<EOS>
go
 
"
  
<EOS>
"
Where
must

,

?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Your
own
way
 
with
the
husband

have
chosen
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Who
is
that
?
"
  
<EOS>
"
You
know
 
this
St.
John
Rivers
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
He
is
not
my
husband
,
nor
ever
will

.
<EOS>
He
does
not
love
me
:
I
do
not

.
<EOS>
He
loves
(
as
he
_
can
_
love
,
and
that
is
not
as
you
love
)
a
beautiful
young

called
Rosamond
.
<EOS>
He
wanted
to

me
only
because
he
thought
I
should
make
a
suitable
missionary
's
wife
,
which
she
would
not

done
.
<EOS>
He
is
good
and
great
,
but
severe
;
and
,
for
me
,
cold
as
an
iceberg
.
<EOS>
He
is
not
like
you
,
sir
:
I
am
not
happy
at
his
side
,
nor
near
him
,
nor
with
him
.
<EOS>
He
has
no
indulgence
for
me
 
no
fondness
.
<EOS>
He
sees
nothing
attractive
in
me
;
not
even
youth
 
only
a
few
useful
mental
points
.
 
<EOS>
Then
I
must
leave
you
,
sir
,
to
go
to
him
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
I
shuddered
involuntarily
,
and
clung
instinctively
closer
to
my
blind
but
beloved
master
.
<EOS>
He
smiled
.
  
<EOS>
"
What
,
Jane
!
<EOS>
Is
this
true
?
<EOS>
Is
such
really
the
state
of
matters
between
you
and
Rivers
?
<EOS>
"
  
"
<EOS>
Absolutely
,
sir
!
<EOS>
Oh
,
you
need
not
be
jealous
!
<EOS>
I
wanted
to
tease
you
a
little
to
make
you
less
sad
:
I
thought
anger
would
be
better
than
grief
.
<EOS>
But
if
you
wish
me
to
love
you
,
could
you
but
see
how
much
I
_
do
<EOS>
_
love
you
<EOS>
,
you
would
be
proud
and

.
<EOS>
All
my
heart
is
yours
,
sir
<EOS>
:
it
belongs
to
you
;
and
with
you
it
would
remain
,
were
fate
to
exile
the
rest
of
me
from
your
presence
for
ever
.
"
  
<EOS>
Again
,
as
he
kissed
me
,
painful
thoughts
darkened
his
aspect
.
  
<EOS>
"
My
seared
vision
!
<EOS>
My
crippled
strength
!
"
<EOS>
he
murmured
regretfully
.
  
<EOS>
I
caressed
,
in
order
to
soothe
him
.
<EOS>
I
knew
of
what
he
was
thinking
,
and
wanted
to
speak
for
him
,
but
dared
not
.
<EOS>
As
he
turned
aside
his
face
a
minute
,
I
saw
a
tear
slide
from
under
the
sealed
eyelid
,
and
trickle
down
the
manly
cheek
.
<EOS>
My
heart
swelled
.
  
<EOS>
"
I
am
no
better
than
the
old
lightning
-
struck
chestnut
-
tree
in
Thornfield
orchard
,
"
he
remarked
ere
long
.
"
<EOS>
And
what
right
would
that
ruin
have
to
bid
a
budding
woodbine
cover
its
decay
with
freshness
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
You
are
no
ruin
,
sir
 
<EOS>
no
lightning
-
struck
tree
<EOS>
:
you
are
green
and
vigorous
.
<EOS>
Plants
will
grow
about
your
roots
,
whether
you
ask
them
or
not
,
because
they
take
delight
in
your
bountiful
shadow
;
and
as
they
grow
they
will
lean
towards
you
,
and
wind
round
you
,
because
your
strength
offers
them
so
safe
a
prop
.
"
  
<EOS>
Again
he
smiled
:
I
gave
him
comfort
.
  
<EOS>
"
You
speak
of
friends
,
Jane
?
"
<EOS>
he
asked
.
  
<EOS>
"
Yes
,
of
friends
,
"
I
answered
rather
hesitatingly
:
for
I
knew
I
meant
more
than

,
but
could
not
tell
what
other
word
to

.
<EOS>
He
helped
me
.
  
<EOS>
"
Ah
!
Jane
.
<EOS>
But
I
want
a
wife
.
<EOS>
"
  
"
Do

,

?
"
  
<EOS>
"
Yes
:

?
"
  
<EOS>
"
Of

:

<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Is

?
"
  
"
<EOS>
That

,

on

.
<EOS>
"
  
"
<EOS>
Which
you

,

.
<EOS>

<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Choose

,

<EOS>
_
her

_
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I

_
<EOS>
her
<EOS>
I
love

_
.
<EOS>
Jane
,

?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Yes
,

.
"
  
<EOS>
"
A

,

<EOS>
"
  
"
<EOS>
Yes
,

.
"
  
<EOS>
"
A

"
  
<EOS>
"

.
"
  
<EOS>
"
Truly

<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Most

,

.
<EOS>
"
  
"
<EOS>
Oh
!
<EOS>
my

!
<EOS>
God

!
"
  
"
<EOS>
Mr.
Rochester
,
if

I
did
a

if

if

,
 
I

.
<EOS>
To

your
wife
is
,

,

.
"
  
<EOS>
"
Because

delight

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Sacrifice
!
<EOS>
What
do
I
sacrifice
?
<EOS>
Famine
for
food
,
expectation
for
content
.
<EOS>
To
be
privileged
to
put
my
arms
round
what
I
value
 
to

my

to
what
I
love
 
to
repose
on
what
I
trust
:
is
that
to
make
a
sacrifice
?
<EOS>
If
so
,
then
certainly
I
delight
in
sacrifice
.
<EOS>
"
  
"
And
to
bear
with
my
infirmities
,
Jane
:
to
overlook
my

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Which
are
none
,
sir
,
to
me
.
<EOS>
I
love
you
better
now
,
when
I
can
really
be
useful

you
,
than
I
did
in
your
state
of
proud

,
when
you
disdained
every
part
but
that
of
the
giver
and
protector
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Hitherto
I
have
hated
to
be
helped
 
to
be
led
:
henceforth
,
I
feel
I
shall
hate
it
no
more
.
<EOS>
I
did
not
like
to
put
my
hand
into
a
hireling
's
,
but
it
is
pleasant
to
feel
it
circled
by
Jane
's
little
fingers
.
<EOS>
I
preferred
utter
loneliness
to
the
constant
attendance
of
servants
;
but
Jane
's
soft
ministry
will
be
a
perpetual
joy
.
<EOS>
Jane
suits
me
:
do
I
suit
her
?
<EOS>
"
  
"
<EOS>
To
the
finest
fibre
of
my
nature
,
sir
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
The
case
being
so
,
we
have
nothing
in
the
world
to
wait
for
:
we
must
be
married
instantly
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
He
looked
and
spoke
with
eagerness
:
his
old
impetuosity
was
rising
.
  
<EOS>
"
We
must
become
one
flesh
without
any
delay
,
Jane
:
there
is
but
the
licence
to
get
 
<EOS>
then
we
marry
.
<EOS>
"
  
"
Mr.
Rochester
,
I
have
just
discovered
the
sun
is
far
declined
from
its
meridian
,
and
Pilot
is
actually
gone
home
to
his
dinner
.
<EOS>
Let
me
look
at
your
watch
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Fasten
it
into
your

,
Janet
,
and
keep

henceforward
:
I
have
no
use
for

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
It
is
nearly
four
o'clock
in
the
afternoon
,
sir
.
<EOS>
Do
n't
you
feel
hungry
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
The
third
day
from
this
must
be
our
wedding
-
day
,
Jane
.
<EOS>
Never
mind
fine
clothes
and
jewels
,
now
:
all
that
is
not
worth
a
fillip
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
The
sun
has
dried
up
all
the
rain
-
drops
,
sir
.
<EOS>
The
breeze
is
still
:
it
is
quite
hot
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Do
you
know
,
Jane
,
I
have
your
little
pearl
necklace
at
this
moment
fastened
round
my
bronze
scrag
under
my
cravat
?
<EOS>
I
have
worn
it
since
the
day
I
lost
my
only
treasure
,
as
a
memento
of
her
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
We
will
go
home
through
the
wood
:
that
will
be
the
shadiest
way
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
He
pursued
his
own
thoughts
without
heeding
me
.
  
<EOS>
"

.
<EOS>
We
talk
,
I
believe
,
all
day
long
:
to
talk
to
each
other
is
but
a
more
animated
and
an
audible
thinking
.
<EOS>
All
my
confidence
is
bestowed
on
him
,
all
his
confidence
is
devoted
to
me
;
we
are
precisely
suited
in
character
 
perfect
concord
is
the
result
.
  
<EOS>
Mr.
Rochester
continued
blind
the
first
two
years
of
our
union
;
perhaps
it
was
that
circumstance
that
drew
us
so
very
near
 
that
knit
us
so
very
close
:
for
I
was
then
his
vision
,
as
I
am
still
his
right
hand
.
<EOS>
Literally
,
I
was
(
what
he
often
called
me
)
<EOS>
the
apple
of
his
eye
.
<EOS>
He
saw
nature
 
<EOS>
he
saw
books
through
me
;
and
never
did
I
weary
of
gazing
for
his
behalf
,
and
of
putting
into
words
the
effect
of
field
,
tree
,
town
,
river
,
cloud
,
sunbeam
 
of
the
landscape
before
us
;
of
the
weather
round
us
 
and
impressing
by
sound
on
his
ear
<EOS>
what
light
could
no
longer
stamp
on
his
eye
.
<EOS>
Never
did
I
weary
of
reading
to
him
;
never
did
I
weary
of
conducting
him
where
he
wished
to
go
:
of
doing
for
him
what
he
wished
to
be
done
.
<EOS>
And
there
was
a
pleasure
in
my
services
,
<EOS>
most
full
,
most
exquisite
,
even
though
sad
 
because
he
claimed
these
services
without
painful
shame
or
damping
humiliation
.
<EOS>
He
loved
me
so
truly
,
that
he
knew
no
reluctance
in
profiting
by
my
attendance
<EOS>
:
he
felt
I
loved
him
so
fondly
,
that
to
yield
that
attendance
was
to
indulge
my
sweetest
wishes
.
  
<EOS>
One
morning
at
the
end
of
the
two
years
,
as
I
was
writing
a
letter
to
his
dictation
,
he
came
and
bent
over
me
,
and
said
 
"
Jane
,
have
you
a
glittering
ornament
round
your
neck
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
I
had
a
gold
watch
-
chain
:
I
answered
"
Yes
.
"
  
"
And
have
you
a
pale
blue
dress
on
?
"

have

a

<EOS>
I
had
.
<EOS>
He
informed
me
then
,
that
for
some
time
he
had
fancied
the
obscurity
clouding
one
eye
was
becoming
less
dense
;
and
that
now
he
was
sure
of
it
.
  
<EOS>
He
and
I
went
up
to
London
.
<EOS>
He
had
the
advice
of
an
eminent
oculist
;
and
he
eventually
recovered
the
sight
of
that
one
eye
.
<EOS>
He
can
not
now
see
very
distinctly
:
he
can
not
read
or
write
much
;
but
he
can
find
his
way
without
being
led
by
the
hand
:
the
sky
is
no
longer
a
blank
to
him
 
the
earth
no
longer
a
void
.
<EOS>
When
his
first
-
born
was
put
into
his
arms
,
he
could
see
that
the
boy
had
inherited
his
own
eyes
,
as
they
once
were
 
large
,
brilliant
,
and
black
.
<EOS>
On
that
occasion
,
he
again
,
with
a
full
heart
,
acknowledged
that
God
had
tempered
judgment
with
mercy
.
  
<EOS>
My
Edward
and
I
,
then
,
are
happy
:
and
the
more
so
,
because
those
we
most
love
are
happy
likewise
.
<EOS>
Diana
and
Mary
Rivers
are
both
married
:
alternately
,
once
every
year
,
they
come
to
see
us
,
and
we
go
to
see
them
.
<EOS>
Diana
's
husband
is
a
captain
in
the
navy
,
a
gallant
officer
and
a
good
man
.
<EOS>
Mary
's
is
a
clergyman
,
a
college
friend
of
her
brother
's
,
and
,
from
his
attainments
and
principles
,
worthy
of
the
connection
.
<EOS>
Both
Captain
Fitzjames
and
Mr.
Wharton
love
their
wives
,
and
are
loved
by
them
.
  
<EOS>
As
to
St.
John
Rivers
,
he
left
England
:
he
went
to
India
.
<EOS>
He
entered
on
the
path
he
had
marked
for
himself
;
he
pursues
it
still
.
<EOS>
A
more
resolute
,
indefatigable
pioneer
never
wrought
amidst
rocks
and
dangers
.
<EOS>
Firm
,
faithful
,
and
devoted
,
full
of
energy
,
and
zeal
,
and
truth
<EOS>
,
he
labours
for
his
race
;
he
clears
their
painful
way
to
improvement
;
he
hews
down
like
a
giant
the
prejudices
of
creed
and
caste
that
encumber
it
.
<EOS>
He
may
be
stern
;
he
may
be
exacting
;
he
may
be
ambitious
yet
;
but
his
is
the
sternness
of
the
warrior
Greatheart
,
who
guards
his
pilgrim
convoy
from
the
onslaught
of
Apollyon
.
<EOS>
His
is
the
exaction
of
the
apostle
,
who
speaks
but
for
Christ
,
when
he
says
 
"
Whosoever
will
come
after
me
,
let
him
deny
himself
,
and
take
up
his
cross
and
follow
me
.
"
<EOS>
His
is
the
ambition
of
the
high
master
-
spirit
,
which
aims
to
fill
a
place
in
the
first
rank
of
those
who
are
redeemed
from
the
earth
 
who
stand
without
fault
before
the
throne
of
God
,
who
share
the
last
mighty
victories
of
the
Lamb
,
who
are
called
,
and
chosen
,
and
faithful
.
  
<EOS>
St.
John
is
unmarried
:
he
never
will
marry
now
.
<EOS>
Himself
has
hitherto
sufficed
to
the
toil
,
and
the
toil
draws
near
its
close
:
<EOS>
his
glorious
sun
hastens
to
its
setting
.
<EOS>
The
last
letter
I
received
from
him
drew
from
my
eyes
human
tears
,
and
yet
filled
my
heart
with
divine
joy
:
he
anticipated
his
sure
reward
,
his
incorruptible
crown
.
<EOS>
I
know
that
a
stranger
's
hand
will
write
to
me
next
,
to
say
that
the
good
and
faithful
servant
has
been
called
at
length
into
the
joy
of
his
Lord
.
<EOS>
And
why
weep
for
this
?
<EOS>
No
fear
of
death
will
darken
St.
John
's
last
hour
:
his
mind
will
be
unclouded
,
his
heart
will
be
undaunted
,
his
hope
will
be
sure
,
his
faith
steadfast
.
<EOS>
His
own
words
are
a
pledge
of
this
    
"
My
Master
,
"
he
says
,
"
has
forewarned
me
.
<EOS>
Daily
He
announces
more
distinctly
,
 
"
Surely
I
come
quickly
!
"
<EOS>
and
hourly
I
more
eagerly
respond
,
 
<EOS>
"
Amen
;
even
so
come
,
Lord
Jesus
!
"
<EOS>
"
